An alternative is entering the park on the East side via Route 64. There are 3 overlooks to stop at along Route 64 before getting to the Visitor Center.

Travel on Route 7 from the East is NOT RECOMMENDED since the road is unpaved and unmaintained between Sawmill and the Spider Rock turnoff.
weatherInfo: Canyon de Chelly is located at 5,500 feet.  Spring is cool and windy; highs from 50 to 70; lows of 35 degrees.  Expect dust storms and canyon flooding. Summer is hot and dry; highs from 85 to 100; lows of 51 degrees.  Drink plenty of water outdoors. Fall is warm and often wet; highs from 60 to 80; lows of 40 degrees.  Expect lightning, thunderstorms, and flash floods. Winter is cold and breezy; highs from 40 to 60; lows of 18 degrees. Expect 1-4 inches of snow and freezing nighttime temperatures.
name: Canyon de Chelly
description: For nearly 5,000 years, people have lived in these canyons - longer than anyone has lived uninterrupted anywhere on the Colorado Plateau.  In the place called Tsegi, their homes and images tell us their stories. Today, Navajo families make their homes, raise livestock, and farm the lands in the canyons. A place like no other, the park and Navajo Nation work together to manage the land's resources.

images.altText: Farm in the canyon
images.title: Canyon Farm
images.caption: Navajo families continue to live and farm in the canyon they call Tsegi

images.altText: Hiking in the canyon
images.title: Canyon Hike
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy a free ranger led hike into the canyon

images.altText: View of Spider Rock from the overlook
images.title: Spider Rock
images.caption: Her home on top of Spider Rock, Spider Woman taught the Navajo people how to weave

images.altText: View of the canyon from the White House Trail
images.title: Canyon View
images.caption: The Navajo people call the canyon Tsegi meaning "within the rocks"

images.altText: View of White House Ruin
images.title: White House
images.caption: Ancient Puebloans built villages like White House that offered opportunities for trade, ceremony, and social gatherings.

directionsInfo: Transportation is by private vehicle. The park is in Coolidge, Arizona, about an hour-long drive from either Phoenix or Tucson. From Interstate 10 take the Coolidge exits and follow the signs to the park entrance.
weatherInfo: Summer daytime temperatures frequently exceed 100 degrees F. Winter temperatures range from the 60's to the 80's F. Spring and fall are warm and dry, with highs in the 80's and 90's F. During summer months, be prepared for hot temperatures. Protective clothing, hats, sunscreen and personal water containers are highly recommended. BE AWARE: Walls of dirt and debris, usually miles wide and thousands of feet high, are pushed across dry desert terrain by high winds, causing dust to engulf highways.
name: Casa Grande Ruins
description: Explore the mystery and complexity of an extended network of communities and irrigation canals. An Ancestral Sonoran Desert People's farming community and "Great House" are preserved at Casa Grande Ruins. Whether the Casa Grande was a gathering place for the Desert People or simply a waypoint marker in an extensive system of canals and trading partners is but part of the mystique of the Ruins

images.altText: eathern building under modern roof structure
images.title: Great House
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande Ruins has existed for over 600 years.

images.altText: earthern ruins including the Great House and other parts
images.title: Great House from the South
images.caption: A highlight of Compound A is the Great House but it is not the only earthern building to intrigue visitors.

images.altText: earthern Great House with its roof among desert plants
images.title: Great House in the Sonoran Desert
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande Ruins is a sentinel of the desert.

images.altText: earthern Great House standing out in the Sonoran Desert plants
images.title: Morning from the Northeast
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande may have been an orientation point for travelers and traders.

images.altText: historic copper sign with Great House and saguaro flanking
images.title: Historic Sign
images.caption: The park's historic copper sign was relocated with roadway changes, and now sits near the visitor center.

images.altText: child, adult female, adult male American Indian actors in costume making jewelry in movie shoot
images.title: Actors Recreating Jewelry
images.caption: In this scene from the park movie, actors demonstrate jewelry making as done in ancestral times.

directionsInfo: Chiricahua National Monument is located 120 miles southeast of Tucson. Take I-10 east from Tucson to the first exit for Willcox. Travel 3 miles into town to the stoplight and turn right. You will follow Arizona State Highway 186 for 32 miles to the junction of Arizona State Highway 181. Turn left and 4 miles later you will be at the Chiricahua entrance station. Maximum vehicle length is 29 feet to drive beyond the visitor center. A hiking shuttle is available daily at 9 am from the visitor center.
weatherInfo:
Chiricahua National Monument ranges from 5,124 feet / 1,562 meters in elevation at the entrance station to 7,310 feet / 2,228 meters at the summit of Sugarloaf Mountain. You can enjoy the differences of four seasons.
http://www.nps.gov/chir/planyourvisit/weather.htm
name: Chiricahua
description: A "Wonderland of Rocks" is waiting for you to explore at Chiricahua National Monument. The 8-mile paved scenic drive and 17-miles of day-use hiking trails provide opportunities to discover the beauty, natural sounds, and inhabitants of this 11,985 acre site. Visit the Faraway Ranch Historic District to discover more about the people who have called this area home.

images.altText: Hikers make their way through a rock canyon
images.title: Hiking through Echo Canyon
images.caption: A network of easily navigable trails lead hikers into the heart of Chiricahua's standing rocks

images.altText: Children climb through rock archways
images.title: Echo Canyon Grotto
images.caption: The standing rocks at Chiricahua create natural nooks and crannies ready to be explored

images.altText: A hiker stands among rock formations
images.title: View from Massai Point
images.caption: Massai Point offers excellent views of the standing rocks at Chiricahua

images.altText: A ranch house in a green field surrounds by low mountains
images.title: Faraway Ranch
images.caption: Faraway Ranch preserves the heritage of early European settlers in the Chiricahua Mountains

images.altText: A narrow road winds between tall oaks and rock cliffs
images.title: Bonita Canyon
images.caption: Bonita Canyon Scenic Drive winds through standing rocks and rhyolite cliffs, climbing to Massai Point at 6900 ft / 2100 m.

directionsInfo: From the city of Sierra Vista continue south on Hwy 92 about 20 miles and turn right onto S. Coronado Memorial Drive. Follow Coronado Memorial Drive (it will turn into E Montezuma Canyon Rd) 5 miles to the Visitor Center.
weatherInfo:
Though the park shares a border with our southern neighbors, the elevation and the mountain ecosystem keep Coronado National Memorial relatively cool in the summer, and winter can bring snow. 
Summers are warm, with daytime temps in the 90s F (32-37 C) and low humidity in May, June, and July. The summer rainy season (monsoon) is between late June and early September. Monsoon thunderstorms can cause flash floods. Winter temps can fall below freezing at night, with highs 40-60 F (4-15 C).
name: Coronado
description: It was a journey of conquest filled with exploration, wonder - and cruelty. Inspired by tales of vast cities of gold, 339 European soldiers and hundreds of Aztec allies embarked on an epic journey through arid deserts and rugged mountains. They encountered rich traditions and brought new technologies. The resulting collision and combination of cultures reverberates today.

images.altText: Pink morning glories with mountain and grasslands
images.title: Pink-throated morning glories in the grasslands
images.caption: Each year the pink-throated morning glories bloom during monsoon season in the grasslands

images.altText: Agave stalks and wildflowers with mountains in the distance
images.title: Wildflowers and Montezuma Peak
images.caption: A field of wildflowers blooms in the grasslands, one of the many life zones in the park

images.altText: Cactus and mountain range in sunset light
images.title: View from Montezuma Pass at sunset
images.caption: Views stretch along mountain ridges and beyond the US/Mexico border from Montezuma Pass,

images.altText: Two cavers inspect a series of calcite cave formations
images.title: Cave formations of Coronado Cave
images.caption: Coronado Cave is a large limestone cavern with cave formations such as stalactites and stalagmites

images.altText: A brilliant red bird in a tree
images.title: Vermillion Flycatcher
images.caption: A great diversity of birds are found in and near Coronado National Memorial

directionsInfo: From Willcox, AZ / points west on I-10: drive 23 miles east of Willcox on Interstate 10 to the the town of Bowie. Exit at the first Bowie exit and drive through the town. Follow the signs for Fort Bowie National Historic Site and turn south on Apache Pass Road. Drive 13 miles to the Fort Bowie Trailhead (the last mile of the road is unpaved). Be prepared to walk the three miles round trip to the ruins and back to your car.
weatherInfo: Please check the Fort Bowie weather page for up to date weather conditions: http://www.wunderground.com/personal-weather-station/dashboard?ID=MAU921
name: Fort Bowie
description: Fort Bowie witnessed almost 25 years of conflict between the Chiricahua Apache and the US Army, and remains a tangible connection to the turbulent era of the late 1800s. Explore the history of Fort Bowie and Apache Pass as you hike the 1.5 mile trail to the visitor center and old fort ruins. Today, this peaceful landscape stands in stark contrast to the violence that once gripped this land.

images.altText: Ruined walls of the old buildings and mountains in the background
images.title: Fort Bowie landscape and ruins
images.caption: Fort Bowie was once a bustling frontier military fort. Today, the ruins offer a place of reflection.

images.altText: Close up of a canon barrel
images.title: Mountain howitzer
images.caption: The mountain howitzer is a symbolic relic from the active days of Fort Bowie

images.altText: Black and white photo of white tombstones in a cemetery, mountains in the background
images.title: Fort Bowie Cemetery
images.caption: Fort Bowie cemetery is accessed via the Fort Bowie Trail, and in addition to many US troops buried here, some Apache/Indeh are buried here as well.

images.altText: A group gathers as a ranger displays the heliograph equipment
images.title: Heliograph demonstration
images.caption: The heliograph was an important communications tool in the late 1880s. Stationed on top of high desert peaks, sunlight was reflected off mirrors in coded patterns to send a message miles away.

images.altText: Weathered remains of an adobe building at Fort Bowie
images.title: Fort Bowie Ruins
images.caption: After the fort's abandonment in the late 1800s the unmaintained buildings slowly weathered until the 1950s when the park service acquired the site.

directionsInfo: There are multiple districts in Glen Canyon very far away from each other. Make sure you know which district you are going to before you begin travelling here.
weatherInfo: The weather in Glen Canyon National Recreation Area is usually typical for the high deserts. Summers are extremely hot with little, if any, shade. Winters are moderately cold with night time lows often below freezing. Spring weather is highly variable and unpredictable with extended periods of winds. Fall weather is usually nice and mild, a great time to beat the heat (and the crowds!).
name: Glen Canyon
description: Encompassing over 1.25 million acres, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area offers unparalleled opportunities for water-based & backcountry recreation. The recreation area stretches for hundreds of miles from Lees Ferry in Arizona to the Orange Cliffs of southern Utah, encompassing scenic vistas, geologic wonders, and a vast panorama of human history.

images.altText: Woman raises her arms while standing in front of a sandstone butte
images.title: Enjoy Lake Powell
images.caption: Spending time on Lake Powell near Tower Butte can make anyone excited.

images.altText: Green river winds through high cliffs.
images.title: Horseshoe Bend
images.caption: The Colorado River makes a 270 degree turn at Horseshoe Bend. Watch your step at the 1000 foot drop!

images.altText: A concrete dam plugs high canyon walls. Buildings and wires on the sides.
images.title: Glen Canyon Dam
images.caption: Glen Canyon Dam is the country's second largest gravity arch dam. Take a tour from the Carl Hayden Visitor Center.

images.altText: Three kayaks on the lake.
images.title: So Many Ways to Find Your Park
images.caption: If motorized recreation isn't your thing, take a kayak and paddle through the high side canyons of Lake Powell.

images.altText: Log cabin and fences with a wooden wagon.
images.title: Lonely Dell Ranch at Lees Ferry Historic District
images.caption: Glen Canyon isn't just houseboats and wakeboards. Come down to Lees Ferry Historic District to relive pioneer times when crossing the river was a major undertaking.

directionsInfo:
South Rim: Open all year, is located 60 miles north of Williams, Arizona (via route 64 from Interstate 40) and 80 miles northwest of Flagstaff (via route 180). Grand Canyon lies entirely within the state of Arizona.

 North Rim: located 30 miles south of Jacob Lake on Highway 67; the actual rim of the canyon is an additional 14 miles south. Jacob Lake, AZ is located in northern Arizona on Highway 89A, not far from the Utah border.
weatherInfo: This weather varies with cold winters and mild pleasant summers, moderate humidity, and considerable diurnal temperature changes at the higher elevations, with hot and drier summers at the bottom of the Grand Canyon along with cool damp winters. Summer thunderstorms and winter snowfall adds to the weather variety in this region.
name: Grand Canyon
description:
Unique combinations of geologic color and erosional forms decorate a canyon that is 277 river miles (446km) long, up to 18 miles (29km) wide, and a mile (1.6km) deep. Grand Canyon overwhelms our senses through its immense size.

The South Rim is open all year.  The North Rim is open for the season.

On February 26, 1919, Grand Canyon became a National Park. This is our Centennial Year!

images.altText: The canyon glows orange as people visit Mather Point, a rock outcropping that juts into Grand Canyon
images.title: Grand Canyon Mather Point Sunset on the South Rim
images.caption: People come from all over the world to view Grand Canyon's sunset

images.altText: The Cape Royal viewpoint curves into the distance and closer rock formations jut into the canyon.
images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: View from Cape Royal on the North Rim
images.caption: A popular outdoor site for weddings and receptions, Cape Royal Amphitheater is located 23 miles (37 km) from the North Rim developed area.

images.altText: The Desert View Watchtower looms 70 feet into the air over a vast and dramatic view of the canyon.
images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: Desert View Watchtower (South Rim)
images.caption: The Watchtower is located at Desert View, the eastern-most developed area on the South Rim of Grand Canyon National Park.

images.altText: Tall canyon walls frame the wide Colorado river weaving back and forth.
images.title: Looking down the Colorado River from Nankoweap at river mile 53
images.caption: A view down the Colorado river from Nankoweap in Marble canyon.

directionsInfo: Please do not attempt to visit this area. The park was not established beyond an administrative action. There is nothing to see and it is trespassing to wander Gila River Indian Community lands.
weatherInfo: Park is not open to the public. Desert landscape, with all its usual inhabitants, is not friendly to trespassers.
name: Hohokam Pima
description: The "Monument" is located on the Gila River Indian Reservation and is under tribal ownership. The Gila River Indian Community has decided not to open the extremely sensitive area to the public. There is no park brochure, passport stamp, picture stamp or other free literature available.

images.altText: two rangers in the distance in desert nothingness
images.title: Pima 1
images.caption: No features, no services, no markers, no signs, NO PUBLIC ACCESS

images.altText: dirt and desert scrub plants in featureless area
images.title: PIMA 2
images.caption: Backfilled old archeological dig, NOT OPEN TO PUBLIC, nothing to see

images.altText: tiny pottery sherds on desert floor
images.title: Pima 3
images.caption: Illegal to collect any artifact, plant, rock. TRESPASSING to atempt a visit.

images.altText: telephone pole, female ranger, dip in rather featureless desert
images.title: PIMA 4
images.caption: Park is NOT open to the public. No special features to view, no signs, no tours, no roads.

images.altText: desert scrub brush and a lumpy hill of tan dirt
images.title: Pima 5
images.caption: It is too easy to get lost, and is trespassing besides. Please do NOT attempt to visit the site.

directionsInfo: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site is located at mile post 446.3 on AZ state route 264. Visitors traveling on I-40 can take U.S. Highway 191 North to Ganado and drive west on Hwy. 264. If you are traveling from Gallup, New Mexico, you may take U.S. Highway 491 North to U.S. Highway 264 west toward Ganado, through Window Rock,Arizona. When you are driving south from Chinle, Arizona on Hwy. 191 you will drive east when you reach Hwy. 264.
weatherInfo:
Spring is normally windy.
Summer can reach into high 90s with thunderstorms beginning in July into August.
Fall is cooling off.
Last couple of Winters have been dry and with a couple of inches of snow.
name: Hubbell Trading Post
description:
The squeaky wooden floor greets your entry into the oldest operating trading post on the Navajo Nation.  When your eyes adjust to the dim light in the "bullpen" you find you’ve just entered a mercantile.  Hubbell Trading Post has been serving Ganado selling goods and Native American Art since 1878.

Discover Hubbell Trading Post NHS, where history is made every day!

images.altText: Spring lambs with their Navajo-Churro ewe.
images.title: Navajo-Churro ewe with lambs
images.caption: Each spring Navajo-Churro ewes give birth to their lambs at Hubbell Trading Post.

images.altText: Steer skull greets visitors.
images.title: Front of Trading Post
images.caption: Above the entry way into the trading post, there is a sun-bleached steer skull.

images.altText: Inside the Hubbell Family home, looking south.
images.title: Hubbell Family Home
images.caption: Thousands of visitors have visited the Hubbell Family home in the past 50 years.

images.altText: Bullpen inside the trading post.
images.title: Hubbell Trading Post bullpen
images.caption: Thousands of visitors and community members walk through the bullpen of the trading post.

images.altText: Interpretive exhibit has Mr. JL Hubbell holding his grand daughter LaCharles.
images.title: Interpretive exhibits inside the Visitor Center
images.caption: New interpretive exhibits on the family, trading post, and weaving.

fullName: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site

directionsInfo: Details listed are for the San Francisco administrative office of the Anza Trail. The 1,200-mile Anza Trail connects historic, cultural, and recreation sites from Nogales, AZ, to the San Francisco Bay Area that reveal the legacy of our Spanish colonial heritage. To learn more, visit http://www.nps.gov/juba. Each site along the Anza Trail is managed independently. Contact individual sites for hours, directions, and other details.
weatherInfo: The 1,200-mile Anza Trail connects historic, cultural, and recreation sites from Nogales, AZ, to the San Francisco Bay Area that reveal the legacy of our Spanish colonial heritage. To learn more, visit http://www.nps.gov/juba. Each site along the Anza Trail is managed independently. Contact individual sites for hours, directions, and other details.
name: Juan Bautista de Anza
description: "¡Vayan Subiendo!"("Everyone mount up!") was the rousing call from Juan Bautista de Anza. In 1775-76, he led some 240 men, women, and children on an epic journey to establish the first non-Native settlement at San Francisco Bay. Today, the 1,200-mile Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail connects history, culture, and outdoor recreation from Nogales, Arizona, to the San Francisco Bay Area.

images.altText: Anza Trail Logo
images.title: Anza Trail Logo
images.caption: The Anza Trail is one of 30 National Scenic and Historic Trails

images.altText: Anza Trail at the Presidio
images.title: Anza Trail at Presidio of San Francisco
images.caption: Annual events bring together descendants of the Anza Expedition of 1776.

images.altText: heritage event
images.title: Remembering His Ancestors
images.caption: Annual events bring together descendants of the Anza Expedition of 1776.

images.altText: trails & rails
images.title: Trails & Rails
images.caption: Anza Trail volunteers ride the Amtrak Coast Starlight to share about California's landscape and history.

images.altText: reenactors in costume
images.title: Campfire Program
images.caption: Annual events bring together descendants of the Anza Expedition of 1776.

fullName: Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail

directionsInfo: By car you can drive to one of the park's many entrances. The four main entrances to Lake Mead are the north entrance near the town of Overton, Lake Mead Boulevard entrance, Lake Mead Parkway entrance and  Boulder Harbor entrance. For the southern sections of the park, near Lake Mohave, there is the Willow Beach entrance, Katherine Landing entrance and Cottonwood Cove entrance station.
weatherInfo:
Spring (April, May and June): Daytime highs 80 F. to 98 F. Nightime lows 50 F. to 66 F.
Summer* (July, August and September): Daytime highs  89 F. to 103 (It can get up to 117 F.)
Fall (October, November and December): Daytime highs 59 F. to 83 F. Nightime lows 32 F. to 50 F.
Winter (January, February and March) Daytime highs 57 F. to 69 F. Nighttime lows 30 F. to 40 F.

*Summer can be a dangerous time due to excessive heat. Some trails are closed for public safety.
name: Lake Mead
description: Boat, hike, cycle, camp and fish at America’s most diverse national recreation area. With striking landscapes and brilliant blue waters, this year-round playground spreads across 1.5 million acres of mountains, canyons, valleys and two vast lakes. See the Hoover Dam from the waters of Lake Mead or Lake Mohave, or find solitude in one of the park's nine wilderness areas.

images.altText: sun rising on Black Canyon
images.title: Black Canyon at Lake Mead NRA
images.caption: Visit Black Canyon Water Trail for rafting or kayaking

images.altText: picnic area at Redstone
images.title: Redstone Picnic Area Lake Mead NRA
images.caption: There are many picnic areas at Lake Mead NRA

images.altText: power boaters on Lake Mead
images.title: Boating at lakes Mead and Mohave
images.caption: Boating is a popular activity at lakes Mead and Mohave

images.altText: people on a tour operated craft exploring the lake.
images.title: Tour Operators Guide You through the Park
images.caption: There are many tour operators to provide you with an excellent visit to Lake Mead NRA.

images.altText: A group of bighorn sheep overlooking Lake Mead.
images.title: Bighorn Sheep Enjoying the View at Lake Mead NRA
images.caption: With wilderness comes wildlife. Bighorn sheep can be spotted at most areas of the park.

directionsInfo:
Montezuma Castle: Follow I-17 to exit 289 (90 minutes north of Phoenix, 45 minutes south of Flagstaff).  Drive east (through two traffic circles) for approximately 1/2 mile to the blinking red light. Turn left onto Montezuma Castle Road.

Montezuma Well: Follow I-17 to exit 293 (north of the exit for Montezuma Castle). Continue through the towns of McGuireville and Rimrock, following the signs for 4 miles to the entrance to the Well.
weatherInfo:
Summer: Hot. Temperatures range from 95°F (35°C) beyond 110°F (42°C). Nighttime temperatures can be much cooler, around 70°F (21°C). From late June through early August, heavy rains called monsoons are common in the afternoons.  

Winter: Cool. Highs average around 55°F (13°C); lows may be in the teens (-10°C). Snow is rare, but possible.

For detailed information, visit the National Weather Service: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=34.61151944900047&lon=-111.8389592099997#.Vi_FZX6rSUk
name: Montezuma Castle
description:
Today we gaze through the windows of the past into one of the best preserved cliff dwellings in North America. This 20 room high-rise apartment, nestled into a towering limestone cliff, tells a story of ingenuity, survival and ultimately, prosperity in an unforgiving desert landscape.

Come marvel at this enduring legacy of the Sinagua culture and reveal a people surprisingly similar to ourselves.

images.altText: Two masonry walls with a dark doorway in a short cliff ledge.
images.title: Storage Room at Montezuma Castle
images.caption: The Sinagua used space efficiently - here a storage room sits in a short cliff space below the main Castle.

images.altText: Sun shines on the window sill in a masonry wall; trees in fall color are seen outside the window.
images.title: Window in Montezuma Castle
images.caption: Visitors to Montezuma Castle usually only get to see the dwelling from the outside.  This view shows what the Sinagua might have seen.

images.altText: A 5-story masonry dwelling sits in a cliff alcove.
images.title: Montezuma Castle in the Cliff
images.caption: Montezuma Castle was built in an alcove about 90 feet up a cliff. This protects the dwelling from flooding.

images.altText: Low masonry walls without roofs against the base of a cliff.
images.title: Castle A at Montezuma Castle National Monument
images.caption: The remains of the dwelling called Castle A show what 600 years of weather can do to a building.

images.altText: Two cliff dwellings and a tree with yellow leaves above a pond.
images.title: Montezuma Well
images.caption: Montezuma Well provided a stable source of water to the Sinagua.

directionsInfo: Drive 9 Miles at the end of AZ Highway 564, off US Highway 160.
weatherInfo: Check weather updates at NOAA.gov and enter city Betatakin, and State, Arizona.
name: Navajo
description: The Puebloan Ancestors built Tsegi Phase villages within the natural sandstone alcoves of our canyons. Betatakin, Keet Seel, and Inscription House are the three cliff dwelling sites that are tucked away in the alcoves. These villages, which date from AD 1250 to 1300, thrill all who visit with original architectural elements such as masonry walls, roof beams, and pictographs.

images.altText: view from inside the Betatakin Cliff Dwelling looking out.
images.title: Betatakin Cliff dwelling and Alcove
images.caption: Betatakin Cliff Dwelling was home to the Ancestral Puebloans over 700 years ago.

directionsInfo: Old Spanish Trail includes a wide variety of sites and organizations across Arizona, California, Colorado, New Mexico, Nevada, or Utah.
weatherInfo:
Due to the length of Old Spanish National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Here's a link to the South Central US:

www.accuweather.com/en/us/south-central/weather-radar
name: Old Spanish
description: Follow the routes of mule pack trains across the Southwest on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail between Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Los Angeles, California. New Mexican traders moved locally produced merchandise across what are now six states to exchange for mules and horses.

images.altText: crumbling adobe structure with blue sky
images.title: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.caption: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú provided a way station for travelers along the Old Spanish Trail in the 1800s. It is privately owned by the Archdiocese of Santa Fe.

images.altText: hikers walk beside a river with cottonwoods alongside the river
images.title: Rio Chama River, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.caption: This section of the Rio Chama River, tributary of the Rio Grande, is located about six miles north of Abiquiú, New Mexico and flows through the Carson National Forest.

images.altText: desert scrub in foreground, spiky mountains in background, clouds
images.title: Sierra Blanca, San Luis Valley, Colorado
images.caption: Sierra Blanca is a prominent mountain in the Sangre de Cristo Range along San Luis Valley on Highway 17. Locating landmarks were essential to traveling the Old Spanish Trail.

images.altText: desert scenery, dead tree, blue sky with puffy coulds
images.title: San Rafael Swell, Utah
images.caption: The San Rafael Swell is a huge craggy geologic feature (an anticline), about 75 miles by 40 miles, located in south-central Utah approximately 30 miles west of Green River.

images.altText: a river carves through the landscape, greenery in the foreground, mountains and redrock backdrop
images.title: Virgin River Canyon, Arizona
images.caption: This section of the Virgin River Canyon Recreation Area is off Interstate 15 about 20 miles southwest of St. George, Utah and about 20 miles northeast of Mesquite, Nevada

images.altText: rocky trail through desert with yucca, mountain in the background
images.title: Old Spanish Trail segment, Nevada
images.caption: This trail segment is 5.25 miles, and is part of the Old Spanish Trail/Mormon Road Historic District, outside Blue Diamond, Clark County, Nevada.

images.altText: trail through desert scrub with Joshua trees, mountains in the distance, puffy clouds
images.title: Mojave Road, California
images.caption: Old Spanish Trail travelers used this section of the historic Mojave Road is within Mojave National Preserve.

directionsInfo: The Kris Eggle Visitor Center is located on Highway 85, approximately 25 miles south of Why, AZ.
weatherInfo: Summer months are hot, with temperatures exceeding 100F.  Winter months are milder, with temperatures in the 70s, with overnight lows in the 40s.
name: Organ Pipe Cactus
description: Look closely. Look again. The sights and sounds of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, an International Biosphere Reserve, reveal a thriving community of plants and animals. Human stories echo throughout this desert preserve, chronicling thousands of years of desert living. A scenic drive, wilderness hike or a night of camping will expose you to a living desert that thrives.

images.altText: sun setting on a green organ pipe cactus
images.title: Organ Pipe Cactus
images.caption: Experience the only place in the US where the Organ Pipe Cactus naturally grows

images.altText: View through the valley, flanked by Ajo Mountains
images.title: Scenic view through the Ajo Mountains
images.caption: Capture amazing views from the scenic drives

images.altText: a green desert environment with cholla cactus glowing in the light
images.title: Cholla Cactus in the Light
images.caption: Experience the rich assemblage of cacti at Organ Pipe Cactus.

images.altText: Jagged Bates Mountains with shadows and clouds
images.title: View of the Bates Mountains
images.caption: Watch sun and shadow interplay across the jagged mountains

images.altText: Yellow poppies on the green desert floor with cacti in the background
images.title: Desert Wildflowers
images.caption: The desert awakens in the Spring with vibrant wildflowers

directionsInfo: The monument is located in the northwest corner of Arizona, bordering Nevada to the west and near the southern border of Utah. There are no paved roads or visitor services within the monument's million-plus acres. Visitors should be prepared for travel on rugged dirt roads. Traveling with an appropriate high clearance vehicle equipped with all-terrain tires. The spare tire should also be all-terrain rated. The monument has entry roads from Nevada, Utah and Arizona.
weatherInfo: Parashant is split between low elevation Mojave Desert on the west side and high elevation pinyon/juniper/ponderosa highlands on the east side. Expect sun on average 310 days per year. The summer months of June through September are very hot on the west side with highs above 100°F daily (80°F+ at night) below 2,500 feet. The high elevation east side is ~15°F cooler. Expect heavy afternoon monsoon storms June - September. Roads often stay muddy/icy above 5,500 feet December - February.
name: Parashant
description: Take a lonely and rocky two-track road in a 4x4 to the edge of the Grand Wash Cliffs. Find a stunning solitary vista deep into the Grand Canyon. Relax in the shade of ponderosas at Mt. Trumbull. Touch ancient waters at Pakoon Springs in one of the driest places in the world. Parashant is remote. There are no crowds here. Be equipped to leave pavement, cell service, and the 21st century behind.

images.altText: Red rock formations
images.title: Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument
images.caption: Red rock formations jut up from the canyon floor.

directionsInfo: Petrified Forest stretches north and south between I-40 and Highway 180. Westbound I-40 travelers should take Exit 311, drive the 28 miles through the park and connect with Hwy 180 at the south end. Travel 19 miles on Hwy 180 North to return to Interstate 40 via Holbrook. Eastbound I-40 travelers should take Exit 285 into Holbrook then travel 19 miles on Hwy 180 South to the park's south entrance. Drive the 28 miles north through the park to return to I-40.
weatherInfo: Petrified Forest National Park is a semi-arid grassland. Temperatures range from above 100° F (38° C) to well below freezing. About 10 inches (25.4 cm) of moisture comes during infrequent snow in the winter and often dramatic summer thunder-storms. Animals and plants are adapted to extremes in temperature and moisture. You should be ready too. Check out the forecast before you arrive and plan accordingly.
name: Petrified Forest
description: Did you know that Petrified Forest is more spectacular than ever? While the park has all the wonders known for a century, there are many new adventures and discoveries to share. There are backcountry hikes into areas never open before such as Red Basin and little known areas like the Martha's Butte. There are new exhibits that bring the stories to life. Come rediscover Petrified Forest!

images.title: Petrified Forest National Wilderness Area
images.caption: Sunrise and sunset are favorite times to view the colorful Painted Desert of the Petrified Forest National Wilderness Area

images.altText: A large petrified log stretches across a gully

images.caption: Many Hopi symbols are featured in this Fred Kabotie mural at the Painted Desert Inn National Historic Landmark

images.altText: a long petrified log stretches across a wash
images.title: Onyx Bridge, Petrified Forest National Wilderness Area
images.caption: Onyx Bridge is a popular destination for hikers in the Petrified Forest National Wilderness Area's north unit.

images.altText: many petrified logs lay on the ground and on eroded pedestals of clay

images.caption: This ancient petroglyph of a mountain lion has become an icon of the park.

images.altText: striped badlands glow red in the sunset light at the Tepees
images.title: Sunset on the Tepees
