images.altText: Kids excavating in the field with Park Paleontologist Bill Parker
images.title: Kids Day Camp Field Trip with Park Paleontologist Bill Parker
images.caption: Kids excavating in the field with Park Paleontologist Bill Parker

images.altText: Dark blue sky filled with stars over banded badland.
images.title: Milky Way Over Blue Mesa
images.caption: Petrified Forest is now an International Dark Sky Park!

directionsInfo:
Pipe Spring National Monument is located 15 miles west of Fredonia, AZ and 45 miles east of Hurricane, UT. 

From Interstate 15, turn onto Utah State Route 9 in Hurricane, Utah. Take Utah State Route 59 east out of Hurricane. This road turns into Arizona State Route 389 at the state line. Pipe Spring is 45 miles east of Hurricane. 

From Utah Highway 89 and 89A, turn onto Arizona State Route 389 in Fredonia, Arizona. Pipe Spring is 15 miles west of Fredonia.
weatherInfo: Weather is hot in summer and cold in winter. Expect summer highs to be 80-100 degrees Fahrenheit and winter highs to be 30-50 degrees. Early morning and late afternoon can be considerably cooler; dress in layers and bring plenty of sunscreen. Arizona climate is very dry -- bring at least 1 liter of water per person per visit to Pipe Spring.
name: Pipe Spring
description: Beneath vermilion cliffs, American Indians, Mormon ranchers, plants, animals, and many others have depended on the life-giving water found at the desert oasis at Pipe Spring. Learn about settler and Kaibab Paiute life by exploring the museum, historic fort and cabins, garden, and Ridge Trail. Visit with rangers and ranch animals, and attend living history demonstrations and talks.

images.altText: A glittering sky of stars glows above a historic covered wagon.
images.title: Milky Way over the Chuckwagon
images.caption: The Milky Way glitters above the chuckwagon at Pipe Spring National Monument. The monument has great night sky clarity because it is located inside the first Dark Sky Nation: The Kaibab Indian Reservation.

images.altText: A sandstone fort rests between desert scrub in the foreground and a mountain in the distance.
images.title: Winsor Castle
images.caption: Winsor Castle, constructed in 1870-72, is surrounded by the harsh beauty of Utah and Arizona's canyon country.

images.altText: A lush garden filled with settler and native crops grows in front of a sandstone fort
images.title: Historic Garden at Pipe Spring
images.caption: Pipe Spring maintains a living history garden that grows settler and native crops as they would have grown in the 1870s. In the fall, visitors may harvest free fruit and veggies.

images.altText: A red-orange sandstone cabin surrounded by white snow.
images.title: West Cabin in Snow
images.caption: Wintertime showcases a stark peace and stillness at the historic buildings. Pictured here, West Cabin sticks out after a snowstorm.

images.altText: A large longhorn cattle steer shows off his 6-foot span horns inside a corral.
images.title: Longhorn Cattle
images.caption: Whitmore and Tess, two Texas Longhorns, greet visitors. Longhorns were brought to Pipe Spring in the 1860s.

directionsInfo: Saguaro National Park has two districts separated by the city of Tucson.  We do not recommend using mobile mapping applications to search for either district.  Instead, please click the link to the directions page, determine which district you plan to visit, and enter that physical address into the mobile application.
weatherInfo:
Winter Season
With daytime temperature from the low 50's to the high 70's

Summer Season 
As we get deeper into the summer season, temperatures will range from mid-90's to low 110's. This is a great time to experience the desert as the day breaks or in the late of the day as the sun disappears behind the surrounding mountain ranges. During the late spring and summer months Saguaro National Park only offers interpretive programs on an intermittent basis.
name: Saguaro
description: Tucson, Arizona is home to the nation's largest cacti. The giant saguaro is the universal symbol of the American west. These majestic plants, found only in a small portion of the United States, are protected by Saguaro National Park, to the east and west of the modern city of Tucson. Here you have a chance to see these enormous cacti, silhouetted by the beauty of a magnificent desert sunset.

images.altText: A flowering fishhook pincushion cactus
images.title: Flowering Fishhook Pincushion Cactus
images.caption: Wildflower season at Saguaro National Park is at it's peak in the month of MArch. The Pincushion cactus, however, blooms April through August.

images.altText: Two coyote pups captured on a wilderness camera
images.title: Coyote Pups
images.caption: Saguaro National Park has a vast variety of wildlife, and with the help of wilderness cameras, can be photographed to help with studies and for visitors to learn about animals only seen by chance.

images.altText: Lightning strike captured on camera with saguaros in the background
images.title: Saguaro National Park Lighting Storm
images.caption: Saguaro deaths are usually attributed to natural weather conditions and other natural phenomena. Specifically, lightning strikes have been known to strike saguaros due to the large amount of water stored within their fleshy tissue.

images.altText: Rare Sight of snow in Saguaro National Park East Visitor Center (Rincon Mountain District)
images.title: Weather at Saguaro National Park
images.caption: Saguaro National Park summers can be extremely hot with temperatures exceeding 105 degrees F, lows averaging 72 degrees F.  Winters are mild warm days averaging 65 degrees F and cool nights averaging 40 degrees F. Snowfall is extremely rare in the area.

images.altText: A group of Phrynosoma solare, or regal horned lizards.
images.title: Group of Regal Horned Lizards
images.caption: Regal horned lizards are one of many reptiles in the park, who have adapted to living in the harsh desert environment. Information on how different species survive can be found on the park's website, visitor center, or through our many programs offered.

directionsInfo: Sunset Crater Volcano and Wupatki National Monuments are connected by loop road FR-545. Visitors can enter the loop road near mile markers 430 (Sunset Crater Volcano) and 444 (Wupatki) on U.S. Highway 89.
weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 95ºF (35ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and snow from fall to spring. Dress in layers, as weather at Sunset Crater Volcano can change quickly at any time of year.
name: Sunset Crater Volcano
description: The cinder cone volcano's rim is the dusky red of sunset, but the crater is only part of the story. Around 1085 the ground began to shake, and lava spewed high into the air. When the eruption finished, it had changed both the landscape and the people who lived here. Today, it teaches how nature and humankind affect each other—and how rebirth and renewal happen in the wake of disaster.

images.altText: a cinder cone volcano and ponderosa pine trees
images.title: Sunset Crater Volcano
images.caption: Sunset Crater Volcano is named for the color of the rusty red cinders near its peak.

images.altText: a jagged field of lava beneath a cinder cone volcano
images.title: Sunset Crater and Bonito Lava Flow
images.caption: Three trails allow visitors to explore the Bonito Lava Flow.

images.altText: a massive volcano rising behind a smaller, tree-covered volcano in the foreground
images.title: Lenox Crater and the San Francisco Peaks
images.caption: Sunset Crater Volcano is the most recent eruption in the San Francisco volcanic field. Visitors can climb Lenox Crater, foreground, for excellent views of the field, including the San Francisco Peaks.

images.altText: a small ponderosa pine tree in a field of rolling cinder hills
images.title: Lone Ponderosa
images.caption: Geologists and biologists study the area surrounding Sunset Crater Volcano to better understand how landscapes recover after an eruption.

images.altText: tall pine trees grow beneath the Sunset Crater Volcano cinder cone
images.title: Ponderosas Reaching Skyward
images.caption: On warm days, the bark of ponderosa pine trees smells like vanilla or butterscotch.

directionsInfo: The cliff dwellings at Tonto National Monument are roughly two hours from the Phoenix metro area, located in the Tonto Basin. The monument is off AZ Highway 188 near Roosevelt Lake. The nearest major towns are Globe (30 miles) and Payson (50 miles). See our Directions page for recommendations on the best way to drive here from the larger metro areas of Arizona.
weatherInfo: Weather during the summer can be extremely hot. It is typically 10 degrees Fahrenheit cooler than Phoenix. Winter weather may create hazardous conditions on the roads to Tonto National Monument. Severe thunderstorms may lead to a closer of the hiking trails.
name: Tonto
description: The Salado Phenomena, 700 years ago, blended ideas of neighboring Native American cultures to emerge a unique and vibrant society. Tonto National Monument showcases two Salado-style cliff dwellings. Colorful pottery, woven cotton cloth, and other artifacts tell a story of people living and using resources from the northern Sonoran Desert from 1250 to 1450 CE.

images.altText: cliff cwelling in the desert with wildflowers
images.title: Lower Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The Lower Cliff Dwelling in Spring

images.altText: 700 year old walls of the cliff dwelling
images.title: Lower Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: Inside the Lower Cliff Dwelling

images.altText: Visitor Center with cliff dwelling and a rainbow in the background
images.title: Visitor Center Dwelling
images.caption: The Visitor Center sits below the Lower Cliff Dwelling

images.altText: the walls still standing for over 700 years
images.title: Upper Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The of the front view of the Upper Cliff Dwelling

images.altText: the view looking out from the cliff dwelling over Roosevelt Lake
images.title: Upper Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The view from the back of the Upper Cliff Dwelling

directionsInfo: Tumacácori National Historical Park is located off of Exit 29 of Interstate 19, forty-five miles (80 kilometers) south of Tucson, Arizona, and eighteen miles (26 kilometers) north of Nogales, Arizona.
weatherInfo: Located above the heat of the low desert, Tumacácori National Historical Park is in the mesquite highlands, close to 3,300 feet in elevation, where temperatures are five to ten degrees cooler than Tucson or Phoenix. Visiting the park in this moderate climate is pleasurable during any season of the year but remember to prepare accordingly. Bring layered clothing and drink plenty of water.
name: Tumacácori
description: Tumacácori sits at a cultural crossroads in the Santa Cruz River valley. Here O’odham, Yaqui, and Apache people met and mingled with European Jesuit and Franciscan missionaries, settlers, and soldiers, sometimes in conflict and sometimes in cooperation. Follow the timeworn paths and discover stories that connect us to enduring relationships, vibrant cultures, and traditions of long ago.

images.altText: panorama of mission church with green grass and clouds
images.title: Tumacácori on a Summer Day
images.caption: A summer day yields beautiful colors and a striking scene on the mission grounds.

images.altText: folklorico dancers in front of church
images.title: La Fiesta de Tumacácori
images.caption: The Fiesta de Tumacácori, held annually in December, has over 40 years of history and hundreds of years of heritage.

images.altText: long paved sidewalk leads to adobe mission church
images.title: Visiting Tumacácori
images.caption: Modern facilities like paved sidewalks and restrooms complement a visit to this site's rich history.

images.altText: milky way in sky over dimly lit bell tower
images.title: Milky Way over the Bell Tower
images.caption: Several times each year, the park opens late to invite visitors to experience dark night skies and the legacy of astronomy priest Padre Eusebio Francisco Kino.

images.altText: ranger and visitors looking at church facade
images.title: Visitors on a Mission Tour
images.caption: Guided mission tours explore the hidden treasures and untold stories of Tumacácori's past.

directionsInfo: From Phoenix or Flagstaff take I-17 to exit 287, and then travel west on Hwy 260 to Cottonwood. Once in Cottonwood travel north through the town on Main Street. Just before Clarkdale you will see signs directing visitors onto Tuzigoot Rd.
weatherInfo:
Summer: Hot. Temperatures range from 95°F (35°C) beyond 110°F (42°C). Nighttime temperatures can be much cooler, around 70°F (21°C). From late June through early August, heavy rains called monsoons are common in the afternoons.  

Winter: Cool. Highs average around 55°F (13°C); lows may be in the teens (-10°C). Snow is rare, but possible.

For detailed information, visit the National Weather Service: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-112.02729309051725&lat=34.7698307603777#.VmWtK3arSUk
name: Tuzigoot
description: Crowning a desert hilltop is an ancient pueblo. A child scans the desert landscape for the arrival of traders. What riches will they bring? What stories will they tell? From the rooftop of the Tuzigoot pueblo it is easy to imagine such a moment. The pueblo shows us this ancient village built by the Sinagua people. They were farmers and artists with trade connections that spanned hundreds of miles.

images.altText: 4 foot masonry walls covered in snow
images.title: Tuzigoot with Snow!
images.caption: Even central Arizona can get a lot of snow!  Check out the dwellings at Tuzigoot covered in a winter storm.

images.altText: 4 foot masonry walls with mountains and clouds behind them.
images.title: Tuzigoot with Black Hills
images.caption: Tuzigoot was built on a low hilltop in the Verde Valley. The Verde River and Black Hills provided a variety of resource areas for the Sinagua.

images.altText: A marsh with open water, cattails, and a masonry dwelling beyond.
images.title: Tuzigoot with Tavasci Marsh
images.caption: Tuzigoot Pueblo sits on a hilltop above an area perfect for farming. Tavasci Marsh provides water and other resources.

images.altText: The inside of a masonry room with wood posts supporting the roof.
images.title: Inside Tuzigoot
images.caption: Rebuilt in the 1930s, this room at Tuzigoot would not originally have had a roof. Today, you can climb through the room to experience the landscape that surrounds this enduring Pueblo.

images.altText: Two women stand with 8 large ceramic pots
images.title: Tuzigoot Ollas
images.caption: During the 1930s, when Tuzigoot was excavated, the procedure was to rebuild artifacts. These women were employed as part of the CCC to glue back together these large olla pots. Today we know that gluing them back together can actually damage the pots.

directionsInfo: Walnut Canyon National Monument is located approximately 7.5 miles (12 km) east of Flagstaff. From Interstate 40, take Exit 204, and turn south. The Walnut Canyon Visitor Center is located at the end of this 3-mile (5 km) road.
weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 95ºF (35ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and heavy snow from fall to spring. Dress in layers, as weather at Walnut Canyon can change quickly at any time of year.
name: Walnut Canyon
description: Come gaze across curved canyon walls! Among the remarkable geological formations of the canyon itself, the former homes of ancient inhabitants are easily evident. Along the trails you can imagine life within Walnut Canyon, while visiting actual pueblos and walking in the steps of those who came before.

images.altText: sunlight illuminates stone walls in a canyon cliff dwelling
images.title: Cliff Dwellings
images.caption: Walnut Canyon National Monument protects a series of ancient cliff dwellings built between 1125 and 1250 CE.

images.altText: a circular overlook at the edge of the canyon rim
images.title: Walnut Canyon Rim Overlook
images.caption: The 0.7-mile (1.1 km) Rim Trail reveals expansive views of Walnut Canyon and its cliff dwellings.

images.altText: warm sunlight illuminates a cliff dwelling wall beside a snowy trail
images.title: Walnut Canyon Snow
images.caption: The 0.9-mile (1.4 km) Island Trail leads visitors down 240 stairs to explore 25 cliff dwelling rooms.

images.altText: a common raven landing on a barren juniper branch
images.title: Walnut Canyon Raven
images.caption: At the rim of Walnut Canyon, visitors stand at eye level with soaring ravens, eagles, and other birds

images.altText: a visitor looks out over Walnut Canyon from the trail
images.title: A Visitor at Walnut Canyon
images.caption: More than 125,000 people visit Walnut Canyon each year.

directionsInfo: Wupatki and Sunset Crater Volcano National Monuments are connected by loop road FR-545. Visitors can enter the loop road near mile markers 430 (Sunset Crater Volcano) and 444 (Wupatki) on U.S. Highway 89.
weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 100ºF (38ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and occasional snow in winter and early spring. Dress in layers, as Wupatki weather can change quickly at any time of year.
name: Wupatki
description: Nestled between the Painted Desert and ponderosa highlands of northern Arizona, Wupatki is a landscape of legacies. Ancient pueblos dot red-rock outcroppings across miles of prairie. Where food and water seem impossible to find, people built pueblos, raised families, farmed, traded, and thrived. Today, if you linger and listen, earth and artifacts whisper their stories to us still.

images.altText: a large stone pueblo in a desert beneath partly cloudy skies
images.title: Wupatki Pueblo
images.caption: Wupatki, the monument's namesake pueblo, is made up of more than 100 rooms. The trail also features an ancient ball court and natural blowhole.

images.altText: a man and woman walking toward a three-story sandstone tower
images.title: Wukoki Pueblo
images.caption: Wukoki Pueblo is located three miles from the Wupatki Visitor Center.

images.altText: a stone pueblo beneath a dark blue sky
images.title: Lomaki Pueblo
images.caption: Lomaki means "beautiful house" in the Hopi language. The pueblo is located ten miles from the visitor center and is reachable via a short, 0.25-mile trail.

images.altText: stars and the Milky Way galaxy over a desert juniper tree
images.title: Dark Skies over the Desert
images.caption: Wupatki National Monument features exceptionally dark night skies and hosts numerous star parties each year.

images.altText: T-shaped doorways in adjoining pueblo walls beneath a clear sky
images.title: Crack-In-Rock Pueblo
images.caption: Each April and October, park rangers guide visitors into the Wupatki back country on overnight hikes to Crack-In-Rock Pueblo.

directionsInfo: The Alcatraz Ferry Terminal is located on The Embarcadero near the intersection of Bay Street at Pier 33.
weatherInfo: The climate on Alcatraz is unpredictable and can change suddenly. Cold, foggy mornings may give way to sunny afternoons, which in turn can shift quickly back to more fog and blustery winds. The most pleasant weather usually occurs in spring and fall. Summers tend to be cool and foggy, winter is our rainy season. Temperatures on Alcatraz seldom rise above 75°F (24°C) or fall below 38°
name: Alcatraz Island
description: Alcatraz Island offers a close-up look at the site of the first lighthouse and US built fort on the West Coast, the infamous federal penitentiary long off-limits to the public, and the history making 18 month occupation by Indians of All Tribes. Rich in history, there is also a natural side to the Rock—gardens, tide pools, bird colonies, and bay views beyond compare.

images.altText: Mugshot camera
images.title: Mug Shot Camera
images.caption: Mugshot camera used to record new inmates.

images.altText: Alcatraz Rangers and Firetruck
images.title: Alcatraz Rangers and Firetruck
images.caption: Alcatraz Rangers and 1934 Diamond T Firetruck

images.altText: Inmate Fake Head Used in 1962 Escape
images.title: Inmate Fake Head Used in 1962 Escape
images.caption: Inmate Fake Head Used in 1962 Escape

images.credit: NPS Photo - Golden Gate National Recreation Area, GOGA 2316a
images.altText: Army Prisoners in the Stockade, 1902
images.title: Army Prisoners in the Stockade, 1902
images.caption: Army Prisoners in the Stockade, 1902

images.altText: Cook serving Christmas dinner with menu posted above.
images.title: Serving the Christmas Meal, c 1951
images.caption: An inmate worker distributes trays near the steam table. Bars separate the kitchen from the mess hall.  The day’s menu, the Christmas meal, appears on a sign over his head. The menu includes consomme, stuffed celery, green olives and mixed sweet pickles,

directionsInfo:
FROM DOWNTOWN SAN DIEGO

Take Harbor Drive past the airport
Turn left onto Rosecrans Street
Turn right onto Canon Street
Turn left onto Catalina Blvd. (also known as Cabrillo Memorial Drive)
Follow Catalina Blvd. all the way to the end
weatherInfo:
Near Perfection
Almost three million county residents can't be wrong: it's the weather. While many areas of the country are hibernating under blankets of snow or sweltering in muggy mid-summer humidity, San Diego's climate is generally sunny and mild year-round.
name: Cabrillo
description: Climbing out of his boat and onto shore in 1542, Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo stepped into history as the first European to set foot on what is now the West Coast of the United States. In addition to telling the story of 16th century exploration, the park is home to a wealth of cultural and natural resources. Join us and embark on your own Voyage of Discovery.

images.altText: Tidepools at Cabrillo
images.title: Rocky Intertidal Zone
images.caption: Low Tide at the Tidepools

images.altText: Sun setting over the Pacific
images.title: Sunset at Cabrillo
images.caption: Sunset at Cabrillo

images.altText: Dusk at the Old Point Loma Lighthouse
images.title: Dusk at the Old Point Loma Lighthouse
images.caption: Dusk over the Old Point Loma Lighthouse

images.altText: Spring flowers in front of Old Point Loma Lighthouse
images.title: Old Point Loma Lighthouse
images.caption: Spring flowers in front of Old Point Loma Lighthouse

images.altText: Looking out on San Diego from Cabrillo
images.title: View from Cabrillo
images.caption: View looking over to Coronado from Cabrillo

images.altText: View of Pelican Point at Cabrillo
images.title: Pelican Point
images.caption: Pelican Point at Cabrillo National Monument

directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.
weatherInfo: Due to the length of the California National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. The trail passes through 10 states.
name: California
description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.

images.altText: A white canvas wagon sits in front of a large rock buttress with mountains in the distance.
images.title: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve
images.caption: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve

images.altText: A woman in gray with a green purse reads a wayside exhibit in front of a river with trees.
images.title: A visitor reads a wayside exhibit at New Fork River Crossing Historical Park in Wyoming
images.caption: A visitor reads a wayside exhibit at New Fork River Crossing Historical Park in Wyoming

images.altText: A still creek winds through brown rolling hills.
images.title: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail
images.caption: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail

images.altText: A dirt road passes through sagebrush and a white post with a mountain in the background.
images.title: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada
images.caption: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada

images.altText: A rock buttress with a notch in it surrounded by sagebrush flats.
images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

directionsInfo: You can approach Castle Mountains from Walking Box Ranch Road off of Nevada State Rd 164 (Nipton Road) or from several unnamed dirt roads off of Lanfair Road in Mojave National Preserve.
weatherInfo: Weather at Castle Mountains changes with the seasons. Freezing temperatures are expected in winter, with occasional snow. Spring brings mild warm days and cooler nights. With enough rain, wildflowers can carpet the area, making for spectacular displays. Summer months are much hotter, with temperatures nearing 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Strong monsoonal storms in late summer may cause flash-flooding in low-lying areas and can create hazardous road conditions. Fall is a cooler respite after the heat of summer.
name: Castle Mountains
description: Castle Mountains represents some of the most unique elements of the Mojave Desert. Nestled between the Nevada state line and Mojave National Preserve, the nearly 21,000 acres of Castle Mountains boasts Joshua tree forests, unbroken natural landscapes, rare desert grasslands, and rich human history. This intriguing area provides serenity and solitude from nearby metropolitan areas.

images.altText: Red rocks frame a stand of Joshua trees and sage brush.
images.title: Red Rocks Outcropping
images.caption: Red rocks frame a stand of Joshua trees and sage brush in the desert floor..

directionsInfo: The monument is located near the small town of Keene, California on Highway 58. From Highway 58, take exit 138 toward Keene, then turn right on Woodford-Tehachapi Road. César E. Chávez National Monument will be on your left.
weatherInfo: The climate in this area is mild, with warm, dry summers and cool winters. Average temperatures in July, the warmest month, are in the mid-80s and hot days often reach into the 90s. In winter, frosty mornings are common and roads may be icy.
name: César E. Chávez
description:
Yes, we can!

Widely recognized as the most important Latino leader in the United States during the twentieth century, César E. Chávez led farm workers and supporters in the establishment of the country's first permanent agricultural union. His leadership brought sustained international attention to the plight of U.S. farm workers, and secured for them higher wages and safer working conditions

images.altText: A walkway with a fountain
images.title: Courtyard at Visitor Center Entrance
images.caption: A walkway separates the entrances to the visitor center and the memorial garden.

images.altText: Red roses bloom near a fountain and grave marker
images.title: Memorial Garden & Gravesite
images.caption: Roses grow in the memorial garden near the gravesite of César Chávez.

images.altText: A chair and desk near bookshelves
images.title: César Chávez's Office
images.caption: César Chávez's office was carefully preserved and can be seen in the exhibit hall.

images.altText: Desert plants grow from rocky soil
images.title: Desert Garden
images.caption: A desert garden features plants found in Yuma, Arizona, where César E. Chávez was born.

images.altText: A black and white photo showing a farmworker demonstration
images.title: Photo Collection
images.caption: In the exhibit hall, explore the history of the farmworker movement through photos taken during marches and strikes.

directionsInfo: While the mainland visitor center in Ventura is readily accessible by car or public transportation, the islands are only accessible by park concessionaire boats and planes or private boat. Advanced planning is highly recommended.
weatherInfo: In general, the islands have a Mediterranean climate year-round. Temperatures are relatively stable, with highs averaging in the mid-60s (°F) and lows in the low-50s. However, there are seasonal differences that visitors should take into consideration when visiting the park. In addition, visitors also should be aware that ocean and weather conditions vary considerably from day-to-day and island-to-island. For more information visit: http://www.nps.gov/chis/planyourvisit/weather.htm
name: Channel Islands
description: Channel Islands National Park encompasses five remarkable islands and their ocean environment, preserving and protecting a wealth of natural and cultural resources. Isolation over thousands of years has created unique animals, plants, and archeological resources found nowhere else on Earth and helped preserve a place where visitors can experience coastal southern California as it once was.

images.altText: Steep, rugged ocean cliffs extending in an island chain.
images.title: Inspiration Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Inspiration Point, Anacapa Island: One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Looking to the west, one may see Middle and West Anacapa, with Santa Cruz Island in the distance.

images.altText: Yellow flowers in foreground extending out along a rocky coastline to a natural arch.
images.title: Arch Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Arch Point, Santa Barbara Island: With winter rains, the coreopsis emerges from summer's dormancy with light green foliage and bright yellow daisy-like flowers

images.altText: Pine tree high on a ridge overlooking a bay with blue water and white sand beach.
images.title: Torrey Pines by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Torrey Pines, Santa Rosa Island: Torrey pines occur naturally in only two locations throughout the world--on the cool, fog drenched northeastern slopes of Bechers Bay and just north of San Diego.

images.altText: Brown seals and sea lions on white sand beach with blue water and partly cloudy sky.
images.title: Point Bennet by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Point Bennet, San Miguel Island: One of the greatest concentrations of wildlife in the world occurs on San Miguel with over 100,000 pinnipeds gathering to breed, pup, and rest.

images.altText: Rust and grey colored fox in green grass.
images.title: Island Fox by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Island Fox, Santa Cruz Island: Thousands of years of isolation in a unique island environment has resulted in the development of the endemic island fox, a dwarf form of the mainland gray fox.

directionsInfo:
The main road transecting Death Valley National Park from east to west is California Highway 190.
On the east in Nevada, U.S. Route 95 parallels the park from north to south with connecting highways at Scotty's Junction (State Route 267), Beatty (State Route 374), and Lathrop Wells (State Route 373).
weatherInfo:
AUTUMN arrives in late October, with warm but pleasant temperatures and generally clear skies.
WINTER has cool days, chilly nights and rarely, rainstorms. With snow capping the high peaks and low angled winter light, this season is especially beautiful for exploring the valley.
SPRINGTIME is the most popular time to visit Death Valley. Besides warm and sunny days, the possibility of spring wildflowers is a big attraction.
SUMMER starts early in Death Valley. By May the valley is too hot for most visitors
name: Death Valley
description: In this below-sea-level basin, steady drought and record summer heat make Death Valley a land of extremes. Yet, each extreme has a striking contrast. Towering peaks are frosted with winter snow. Rare rainstorms bring vast fields of wildflowers. Lush oases harbor tiny fish and refuge for wildlife and humans. Despite its morbid name, a great diversity of life survives in Death Valley.

images.altText: Morning light on the badlands below Zabriskie Point.
images.title: Zabriskie Point
images.caption: Zabriskie Point is a popular place to view sunrise over the badlands.

directionsInfo:
Shuttle Bus: Most visitors must park at the Mammoth Mountain Ski Area and use the mandatory shuttle. The shuttle bus operates from mid-June through the Wednesday after Labor Day.

By car: From U.S. Highway 395, drive 10 miles west on S.R. 203 to Minaret Vista and then another 8 miles on a paved, steep mountain road. Please note that this road is single lane for approximately 3 miles.

By plane: The closest commercial airport is the Mammoth Lakes/Yosemite Airport (MMH), located on U.S. Highway 395.
weatherInfo:
Devils Postpile National Monument is located at 7,560 feet above sea level just west of the Sierra Nevada crest. As such, it experiences typical summer weather in the Sierras.

Afternoon thunderstorms are possible in July and August. Daytime temperatures can range from the mid-70s to to mid-80s (degrees Fahrenheit). Evening temperatures can drop into the low 40s (and even the low 30s in the months of September and October).
name: Devils Postpile
description: Established in 1911 by presidential proclamation, Devils Postpile National Monument protects and preserves the Devils Postpile formation, the 101-foot high Rainbow Falls, and pristine mountain scenery.  The formation is a rare sight in the geologic world and ranks as one of the world's finest examples of columnar basalt. Its columns tower 60 feet high and display an unusual symmetry.

images.altText: The Devils Postpile basalt formation resembles tall columns.
images.title: Devils  Postpile Formation
images.caption: Devils Postpile formation is one of many features to see at Devils Postpile National Monument.

directionsInfo: Due to the nature of the The Eugene O'Neill NHS, visitors are not able to drive directly to the park site. Instead, reservations are required and we offer a free shuttle that will pick up the visitor in downtown Danville, CA. The shuttle meets at 205 Railroad Avenue in downtown Danville, just outside the Museum of the San Ramon Valley. Parking is available next to the museum. More information will be given once you call and make a reservation with the park staff. Danville, CA, is approximately 31 miles east
weatherInfo: The Mediterranean climate of Danville features hot, dry summers with lower temperatures near 60º F and upper temperatures near 100º F. The heat gives way to cool, rainy winters with lows near 45º F and highs near 75º F. Fall and spring can bring rain and temperatures from 55-80º F.
name: Eugene O'Neill
description: America's only Nobel Prize winning playwright, Eugene O'Neill, chose to live in Northern California at the height of his writing career. Isolated from the world and within the walls of his home, O'Neill wrote his final and most memorable plays; The Iceman Cometh, Long Day's Journey Into Night, and A Moon for the Misbegotten.

images.altText: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California
images.title: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California
images.caption: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California

directionsInfo:
Fort Point is located at the south anchorage of the Golden Gate Bridge at the end of Marine Drive on the Presidio of San Francisco.

By car take Highway 101 N or S, exit at the Golden Gate Bridge toll plaza at south end of bridge. From S turn right at end of exit ramp, or from N go straight on Merchant Drive. Turn left onto Lincoln Boulevard. Take a left onto Long Avenue and follow onto Marine Drive.
weatherInfo: Fort Point is typically cold and windy throughout the year. Fog is especially common in the summer months.  Come prepared with layers and windbreakers for maximum comfort.
name: Fort Point
description: From its vantage point overlooking the spectacular Golden Gate, Fort Point defended the San Francisco Bay following California's Gold Rush through World War II. Its beautifully arched casemates display the art of 3rd system brick masonry and interacts gracefully with the Golden Gate Bridge.

images.altText: Fort Point with visitors approaching on road in front and Golden Gate Bridge above.
images.title: Fort Point from Marine Drive
images.caption: Fort Point offers stunning views from under the south end of the Golden Gate Bridge.

images.altText: Golden sunset light on the roof of Fort Point with Golden Gate Bridge and bay behind.
images.title: Fort Point Sunset View
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy winter sunsets from the top of Fort Point.

images.altText: Arched red brick casemates extend into the distance at Fort Point.
images.title: Brick Casemates
images.caption: Fort Point is known for its masterful masonry work.

images.altText: A cannon stands in front of Civil War re-enactors talking to the public.
images.title: Civil War Days at Fort Point
images.caption: Visitors can interact with Civil War re-enactors twice in January and August at the Fort.

images.altText: View of Fort Point lighthouse through red brick arches
images.title: Fort Point Lighthouse
images.caption: Fort Point has a historic lighthouse mounted on its top.

directionsInfo:
Golden Gate National Recreation Area has many sites that span over 60 miles of mostly coastal areas north and south of San Francisco. Park areas can be reached by Highways 1, 101 and 280 from the north and south San Francisco Bay Area, and by Highway 80 from the East Bay. 

To access park headquarters at Fort Mason, please use the entrance at Franklin and Bay Streets in San Francisco.
weatherInfo: Winter is characterized by sporadic rain and cool weather punctuated by brilliant sunshine. In winter the grass greens. Trees and flowers dormant through winter start blooming in late February or early March and last until May or June. By July, summer fog predominates in most coastal areas of the park. Grasses and plants have now turned to the golden brown and muted grays characteristic of California summer and fall.  September and October skies are clear and sunshine is abundant everywhere in the park.
name: Golden Gate
description: Experience a park so rich it supports 19 distinct ecosystems with over 2,000 plant and animal species. Go for a hike, enjoy a vista, have a picnic or learn about the centuries of overlapping history from California’s indigenous cultures, Spanish colonialism, the Mexican Republic, US military expansion and the growth of San Francisco. All of this and more awaits you, so get out and find your park.

images.altText: Mori Point view north with yellow an blue flowers, the blue-green Pacific Ocean and Mt. Tamalpais.
images.title: Spring Flowers at Mori Point
images.caption: View north from Mori Point showing abundant spring flowers and Mt. Tamalpais in the background.

images.altText: View over the Pacific from Bolinas Ridge; Stinson Beach, Bolinas Lagoon and head in mid-ground.
images.title: Stinson Beach from Bolinas Ridge
images.caption: Bolinas Ridge offers outstanding panaramas of the Pacific Coast, here including Stinson Beach and Lagoon.

images.altText: Orange Golden Gate Bridge with waves crashing in foreground and storm clouds behind.
images.title: Storm over the Golden Gate
images.caption: The Golden Gate Bridge is an iconic attraction year-round.

images.altText: View south with family on road in foreground and Rodeo Beach and cove in front of Point Bonita.
images.title: Marin Headlands and Rodeo Beach
images.caption: Trails in the Marin Headlands offer a fun and spectacular hiking experience for all.

images.altText: Row of red brick barracks with white-columned porches where infantry soldiers lived.
images.title: Montgomery Street Barracks, Presidio of San Francisco
images.caption: The Presidio offers an outdoor museum of military architecture over the centuries.

images.altText: White buildings with red roofs at Crissy Field with blue bay and Golden Gate Bridge and fog behind.
images.title: Morning Fog at Crissy Field
images.caption: Visiting Crissy Field is an ever changing experience as the fog comes in and dissipates.

images.altText: Closeup shot of Alcatraz Island showing lighthouse and prison with yellow flowers on slope in front.
images.title: Alcatraz Island from Crissy Field
images.caption: Visitors can learn about the complex layered history of Alcatraz Island.

directionsInfo: Please visit our main website for specific directions to our park. You may call the John Muir Visitor Center for additional information.
weatherInfo:
The Mediterranean climate of Martinez features hot, dry summers with lower temperatures near 60º F and upper temperatures near 100º F. The heat gives way to cool, rainy winters with lows near 45º F and highs near 75º F. Fall and spring can bring rain and temperatures from 55-80º F.

March to April: wet/dry, 60-80º F
May to September: very dry, 60-100º+ F
October to November: dry/wet, 55-80º F
December to February: wet, 45-75º F
name: John Muir
description: John Muir played many roles in his life, all of which helped him succeed in his role as an advocate for Nature. As America’s most famous naturalist and conservationist, Muir fought to protect the wild places he loved, places we can still visit today. Muir’s writings convinced the U.S. government to protect Yosemite, Sequoia, Grand Canyon and Mt. Rainier as national parks.

images.altText: John Muir Home at the John Muir National Historic Site
images.title: John Muir Home at the John Muir National Historic Site
images.caption: John Muir Home at the John Muir National Historic Site

directionsInfo:
From I-10, take exit 117 for CA Hwy 62 toward 29 Palms/Yucca Valley. This will allow you to access the West Entrance, the North Entrance, Black Rock, and Indian Cove.

Take exit 168 off I-10 to come in at the park's South Entrance.
weatherInfo: Days are typically clear with less than 25% humidity. Temperatures are most comfortable in the spring and fall, with an average highs around 85°F (29°C) and average lows around 50°F (10°C) respectively. Winter brings cooler days, around 60°F (15°C), and freezing nights. It occasionally snows at higher elevations. Summers are hot, over 100°F (38°C) during the day and not cooling much below 75°F (24°C) at night.
name: Joshua Tree
description: Two distinct desert ecosystems, the Mojave and the Colorado, come together in Joshua Tree National Park. A fascinating variety of plants and animals make their homes in a land sculpted by strong winds and occasional torrents of rain. Dark night skies, a rich cultural history, and surreal geologic features add to the wonder of this vast wilderness in southern California. Come explore for yourself.

images.altText: hiker looks over Hidden Valley
images.title: Hidden Valley Hiker
images.caption: Scrambling to the top of boulders in Joshua Tree can get you a great view.

images.altText: a fiery sky behind the silhouette of a Joshua tree
images.title: Joshua Tree Sunset
images.caption: The wide-open desert of Joshua Tree National Park makes for stunning sunsets.

images.altText: an historic wood house seen through the missing windshield of an old, rusty vehicle
images.title: Historic Keys Ranch
images.caption: The historic Keys Ranch can be visited only on a ranger-guided tour.

images.altText: night scene showing stars of the Milky Way over a sign saying "Entering Joshua Tree National Park"
images.title: Stars Over the Park Entrance
images.caption: Enjoy some of the darkest night skies in Southern California.

images.altText: a little girl smiles while wearing a Jr. Ranger hat and badge
images.title: Joshua Tree Junior Ranger
images.caption: Kids of all ages can take part in Joshua Tree National Park's Junior Ranger program.

images.altText: people climbing on boulders are silhouetted against a colorful sunset sky
images.title: Jumbo Rocks at Sunset
images.caption: Jumbo Rocks Campground is a fun place to explore the park's bouldered landscape.

images.altText: Joshua trees grow on a flat plain with boulder outcrops and mountains in the distance
images.title: Lost Horse Valley
images.caption: Take in views of the park's iconic Joshua trees and rock outcrops in Lost Horse Valley.

directionsInfo: From Interstate 5 (Redding), take Hwy 44 - 48 miles east to the junction of Hwy 89. Follow Hwy 89 south 1 mile to the north entrance of the park. From Interstate 5 (Red Bluff) take Hwy 36 E - 51 miles east to the junction of Hwy 89. Follow Hwy 89 north 6 miles to south entrance of the park.
weatherInfo:
Weather at Lassen can vary dramatically throughout the year.

Average January temperatures are a high of 40.4 °F (4.7 °C) and a low of 20.8 °F (-6.2 °C). Average July temperatures are a high of 88.4 °F and a low of 49.8 °F. Temperatures reach 90 °F or higher on an average of 36.9 days, and drop to 32 ° or lower on an average of 164 days days annually.
name: Lassen Volcanic
description: Lassen Volcanic National Park is home to steaming fumaroles, meadows freckled with wildflowers, clear mountain lakes, and numerous volcanoes. Jagged peaks tell the story of its eruptive past while hot water continues to shape the land. Lassen Volcanic offers opportunities to discover the wonder and mysteries of volcanoes and hot water for visitors willing to explore the undiscovered.

images.altText: A frozen lake below snow-covered trees and peak
images.title: Winter at Manzanita Lake
images.caption: With over 30 feet of snowfall annually, Lassen provides numerous opportunities for winter recreation.

images.altText: Golden grasses edge a pond reflecting a snow-dusted peak
images.title: Hat Creek
images.caption: Lassen Volcanic's rugged volcanic landscape is softened by numerous meadows, lakes, and creeks.

images.altText: A boardwalk passes through a colorful, steaming hydrothermal basin.
images.title: Bumpass Hell
images.caption: A 3-mile round-trip trail leads to Bumpass Hell, the largest of the park's hydrothermal areas.

images.altText: Two hikers sit on a mountain top with a view of multiple peaks, dotted with patches of snow
images.title: Brokeoff Panorama
images.caption: Over 150 miles of trails let you choose your adventure.

images.altText: A volcanic peak rises above a tree-lined, deep blue lake.
images.title: Deep Blue
images.caption: Lassen Peak stands out boldly between the bright blue sky and the sapphire hue of Lake Helen.

images.altText: A fisherman casts a line from a boat below a snow-dotted volcanic peak.
images.title: A Fisherman's Paradise
images.caption: Manzanita Lake offers spectacular catch-and-release fishing in the shadow of volcanoes.

images.altText: An ash cloud rises above a volcano with an early 19th century vehicle at the forefront.
images.title: Lassen Peak Eruption
images.caption: A large, explosive eruption of Lassen Peak brought national attention and set the stage for the establishment of Lassen Peak.

directionsInfo: Lava Beds is a truly remote park, in a corner of California most people never visit. Most roads into this area wind through mountains, and along rivers, and travel may take longer than expected. Services are few and far between and winter driving conditions can be encountered anytime between fall and spring.
weatherInfo: Park elevations range from 4,000 to 5,700 feet. Cold weather is possible any time of year, and snow has been recorded in all months. Winter day­time highs average 40°F; lows average 20°F. Morning fog is frequent from autumn through spring. Summer daytime highs average 75° to 80°F; lows average 50°F. Occasional thunderstorms occur in summer.
name: Lava Beds
description: Lava Beds National Monument is a land of turmoil, both geological and historical. Over the last half-million years, volcanic eruptions on the Medicine Lake shield volcano have created a rugged landscape dotted with diverse volcanic features. More than 700 caves, Native American rock art sites, historic battlefields and campsites, and a high desert wilderness experience await you!

images.title: Paintbrush along park trail
images.caption: Paintbrush along park trail

images.title: Sunset at Lava Beds
images.caption: Sunset at Lava Beds

images.title: Sunrise at Lava Beds

images.title: Schonchin Butte & Skull Cave
images.caption: Schonchin Butte & Skull Cave

images.caption: Snowy sunrise at Hopkins Chocolate Cave

directionsInfo: Manzanar is located on the west side of U.S. Highway 395, 9 miles north of Lone Pine, California and 6 miles south of Independence, CA.
weatherInfo: Manzanar is located in the Owens Valley at 4,000' elevation, at the eastern base of the Sierra Nevada. We get little precipitation but we do have four distinct seasons. Summer temperatures can soar over 100 degrees. Winter highs are usually in the 40's. Nighttime temperatures year round are 30 to 40 degrees less than daytime highs. High winds are common in any season.
name: Manzanar
description: In 1942, the United States government ordered more than 110,000 men, women, and children to leave their homes and detained them in remote, military-style camps. Manzanar War Relocation Center was one of ten camps where Japanese American citizens and resident Japanese aliens were incarcerated during World War II.

images.altText: People walk to barracks framed by mountain peaks.
images.title: Historic Barracks
images.caption: People walk to long rows of barracks.

directionsInfo: Park headquarters in Barstow, California is 60 miles from the Preserve, and offers maps, a bookstore and information. Our main visitor center, Kelso Depot, is located inside the Preserve, 95 miles north of Barstow, and 90 miles south of Las Vegas,  at the intersection of Kelso-Cima and Kelbaker Roads.
weatherInfo: Mojave Desert experiences change with the seasons. In winter, freezing temperatures and strong winds can be expected, with rain and snow in the mountains. With enough moisture, spring wildflowers may carpet the desert floor with vivid colors. Summers are hot, and temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit are typical. In summer, adventurers head for the higher elevations such as Mid-Hills and the New York Mountains. The cooler temperatures of fall mark hunting season.
name: Mojave
description: Singing sand dunes, cinder cone volcanoes, Joshua tree forest, and carpets of wildflowers are all found at this 1.6-million-acre park. A visit to its canyons, mountains, and mesas will reveal long-abandoned mines, homesteads, and rock-walled military outposts. Located between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, Mojave provides serenity and solitude from major metropolitan areas.

images.altText: Spring wildflowers carpeting the desert floor
images.title: A desert road surrounded by spring wildflowers
images.caption: Many people visit Mojave in the spring season to view stunning wildflower displays.

images.altText: A lonely desert trail leads to tall sand dunes
images.title: Hiking Opportunities Abound
images.caption: Mojave has endless options for hikers. Kelso Sand Dunes are a popular trail in cooler months.

images.altText: A desert tortoise rest in the shade of a bush near some hikers
images.title: Desert Wildlife
images.caption: Mojave has a great diversity of wildlife. In spring and fall, the elusive desert tortoise can be seen foraging food.

images.altText: A man standing on a mountain peak in front of a wide desert landscape
images.title: Stunning Vistas
images.caption: Mojave is a hiker's paradise. With no less than 9 named mountain ranges int he park, there's no shortage of amazing views to be had.

images.altText: A Joshua tree seen though the window of an old miner's cabin
images.title: Rich Human History
images.caption: Visitors can still hear the echos of history here. Evidence of days long past still persist in Mojave. Native American petroglyphs, long-abandoned mines, and cattle ranches still dot the landscape.

directionsInfo:
From San Francisco

Muir Woods is located 11 miles north of the Golden Gate Bridge
Take Hwy 101 North 
Then the Mill Valley/Highway 1/ Stinson Beach Exit
Follow the signs to Hwy 1
Follow the signs to Muir Woods

From the East Bay

Take Hwy 580/Richmond/San Rafael Bridge West
Then Hwy 101 South
Take the Stinson Beach/Mill Valley Exit
Follow the signs to Highway 1
Follow the signs to Muir Woods

Vehicles over 35 feet long are prohibited. There are no RV parking facilities.
weatherInfo: The coast redwood forest is cool most times of the year with temperatures ranging from 40 - 70 degrees F or 4 - 21 degrees C. From late October to early May expect rain. Summer months (June-August) can be warmer but it is generally cool and dry. Expect heavy fog in the morning, burning off in the afternoon. Some say fall (August-October) is the best weather of the year. But, don't let the weather stop you from having fun. If you're dressed for the elements and wearing sturdy shoes, you will enjoy your walk.
name: Muir Woods
description: Walk among old growth coast redwoods, cooling their roots in the fresh water of Redwood Creek and lifting their crowns to reach the sun and fog. Federally protected as a National Monument since 1908, this primeval forest is both refuge and laboratory, revealing our relationship with the living landscape. What will you discover in Muir Woods?

images.altText: A wooden bridge crosses Redwood Creek in the redwood forest
images.title: Bridge through Muir Woods
images.caption: Summer is a busy time at Muir Woods. Visit early in the morning for the most pleasant experience.

images.altText: Black fire scars are visible on trunks of large redwood trees
images.title: Redwood trees
images.caption: Many fires over the centuries have encouraged new growth and opened up the under story of the redwood forest. Black scars are present among the oldest of redwoods in Muir Woods.

images.altText: Sun rays shine down on a visitor among very tall redwood trees
images.title: Bohemian Grove
images.caption: Later afternoon is a gorgeous time of day to visit Bohemian Grove, inside Muir Woods.

images.altText: A Lady Fern grows over Redwood Creek
images.title: Lady Fern
images.caption: At least ten species of ferns grow in Muir Woods - fern seem to grow larger in redwood forests than other forests - possibly competing for attention from the redwoods?

images.altText: soft, spindly horsetail fern
images.title: Horestail Fern
images.caption: Horsetail fern, an Equisetum, is common along Redwood Creek. Horsetail fern is one of the oldest plant species in the world.

images.altText: trillium, a white flower with large green leaves in bloom on the forest floor
images.title: Trillium ovatum
images.caption: Trillium ovatum blooms in late winter and early spring along the forest floor.

images.altText: A yellow banana slug creeping along a twig
images.title: Banana Slug
images.caption: Banana slugs creep along the forest floor in Muir Woods and are likely to be abundant in the warmer days of winter.

images.altText: two scientists hanging from branches in a redwood tree
images.title: Tree Climbing
images.caption: Scientists Marie Antoine and Steve Sillett climbing a redwood tree in Muir Woods for the 2014 BioBlitz.

images.altText: A bench along the boardwalk with the sun shining through the redwoods
images.title: Bench along main trail
images.caption: Relax in the sunshine on this quiet bench along Muir Woods main trail.

images.altText: A hiker appears very small among the redwood trees
images.title: Redwood trees
images.caption: Meander along the main trail and consider your size compared to these giants.

directionsInfo: Pinnacles National Park is accessible through highway 101 for the West entrance, and highway 25 for the East entrance. From highway 101 you must pass through the City of Soledad to find highway 146 which will lead to West side of Pinnacles. To enter East Pinnacles you must find highway 25 through the City of Hollister coming from the North, and King City through Bitter Water Road (G-13) when coming from the South.
weatherInfo: Pinnacles National Park has a Mediterranean climate with hot and dry summers, and mild winters with moderate precipitation. The park is several miles inland from the Pacific Ocean. A wider variation in seasonal temperatures can be expected in the local area. On July or August day, daytime temperatures over 100° F are not uncommon, but a bright sunny day can turn into a very cold night.
name: Pinnacles
description: Some 23 million years ago multiple volcanoes erupted, flowed, and slid to form what would become Pinnacles National Park. What remains is a unique landscape. Travelers journey through chaparral, oak woodlands, and canyon bottoms. Hikers enter rare talus caves and emerge to towering rock spires teeming with life: prairie and peregrine falcons, golden eagles, and the inspiring California condor.

images.altText: Boulders in the Balconies Cave.
images.title: Balconies Caves
images.caption: Balconies Cliffs as seen from the inside of the Balconies Caves

images.altText: Light falling on tree
images.title: Tree
images.caption: Light illuminates a tree on a rainy day, seen from the Resurrection Wall.

images.altText: A Tarantula walking
images.title: Tarantula
images.caption: A Tarantula crawls in the wild.

directionsInfo: Point Reyes is located along the west coast of California approximately 30 miles (50 km) north of San Francisco. Travelers may approach the park from the winding scenic Highway 1, either from the north or the south. Visitors can also reach the park via Sir Francis Drake Boulevard or the Point Reyes/Petaluma Road.
weatherInfo: The moderating influence of the Pacific Ocean creates a climate with no great extremes of heat or cold. Any season can bring interesting weather during your visit to Point Reyes National Seashore. Come prepared!
name: Point Reyes
description: From its thunderous ocean breakers crashing against rocky headlands and expansive sand beaches to its open grasslands, brushy hillsides, and forested ridges, Point Reyes offers visitors over 1500 species of plants and animals to discover. Home to several cultures over thousands of years, the Seashore preserves a tapestry of stories and interactions of people. Point Reyes awaits your exploration.

images.altText: Point Reyes Lighthouse
images.title: Point Reyes Lighthouse
images.caption: Point Reyes Lighthouse

directionsInfo: The Pony Express National Historic Trail crosses eight states.
weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Pony Express National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. The trail passes through seven states.
name: Pony Express
description: It is hard to believe that young men once rode horses to carry mail from Missouri to California in the unprecedented time of only 10 days. This relay system along the Pony Express National Historic Trail in eight states was the most direct and practical means of east-west communications before the telegraph.

images.altText: A tall rock buttress with a cleft in the center sits behind a sagebrush covered valley.
images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important landmark on the trail in Wyoming.

images.altText: A tall obelisk monument with bronze plaques sits on a paved pathway in front of a building.
images.title: Fort Laramie NHS monument, Wyoming
images.caption: A monument and plaque about the Pony Express can be found at Fort Laramie in Wyoming.

images.altText: A footbridge leads to a dark steel silhouette of a Pony Express rider.
images.title: Schelbourne Station, Nevada
images.caption: A Pony Express rider silhouette can be found at the Schelbourne Station site in Nevada.

images.altText: A rider in a red vest on a horse in a grassy patch surrounded by sagebrush with clouds in the sky.
images.title: Simpson Spring NPEA rider, Utah
images.caption: A National Pony Express Association rider poses at Simpson Springs in Utah.

images.altText: A covered wagon with fiberglass oxen sits in front of a tall rock buttress surrounded by grass.
images.title: Scotts Bluff National Monument, Nebraska
images.caption: The Pony Express traveled through Scotts Bluff National Monument in Nebraska.

directionsInfo: The Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial is on an active military base, so it is only accessible by reservation. The shuttle picks up visitors with reservations at the John Muir National Historic Site. Please know that all visitors for the memorial must have a reservation. Please visit our website for information on how to obtain reservations.
weatherInfo: The Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial is on a base and sits on the waterfront. There is no shelter at the memorial, aside from the shuttle. It can be windy and cold during any season. Many people prefer to at least bring a light jacket during the summer, or coat during the other seasons.
name: Port Chicago Naval Magazine
description: On the evening of July 17, 1944, residents in the San Francisco east bay area were jolted awake by a massive explosion that cracked windows and lit up the night sky. At Port Chicago Naval Magazine, 320 men were instantly killed when two ships being loaded with ammunition for the Pacific theater troops blew up. It was WWII's worst home front disaster.

images.altText: Port Chicago Memorial
images.title: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial
images.caption: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial

fullName: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial

directionsInfo: The Presidio lies at the north end of San Francisco at the south end of the Golden Gate Bridge. It can be reached from the north by crossing the Golden Gate Bridge and taking the first exit from Highways 1 and 101; from the east by way of Lombard Street (Highway 101); and from the south via Highway 1 and exiting just before the bridge.
weatherInfo: The weather at the Presidio is typically cool and quite variable from location to location. The summer is often foggy and cool, so a light coat or sweater is appropriate year-round.
name: Presidio of San Francisco
description: For 218 years, the Presidio served as an army post for three nations. World and local events, from military campaigns to World Fairs and earthquakes, left their mark. Come enjoy the history and the natural beauty of the Presidio. Explore centuries of architecture. Reflect in a national cemetery. Walk along an historic airfield, through forests or to beaches, and admire spectacular vistas.

images.altText: Rows of grave markers in the green grass of the cemetery as light shafts through misty trees.
images.title: San Francisco National Cemetery
images.caption: San Francisco National Cemetery in the Presidio offers a place to contemplate service to your country.

images.altText: Rocky bluffs above the blue ocean covered with yellow flowers in the foreground and and trees.
images.title: Coastal Bluffs
images.caption: The coastal bluffs of the Presidio still retain a wild feeling within the city.

images.altText: A long row of red brick barracks with green lawns in front extends into the distance.
images.title: Montgomery Street Barracks
images.caption: The brick barracks on Montgomery Street showcase military architecture from the late 1800s.

images.altText: Scattered Monterey Cypress trunks with green grass and fern cover at their bases.
images.title: Historic Forest
images.caption: The planted historic forests offer tranquil places to walk.

images.altText: A kite boarder with yellow kite on beach with wind surfers behind on the blue bay.
images.title: Wind Surfers at Crissy Field
images.caption: On windy days, Crissy Field is a popular wind surfing and Kite boarding location.

images.altText: White building with red roofs on Crissy Field with blue bay and orange bridge with fog behind.
images.title: Crissy Field
images.caption: Crissy Field is a popular spot to wak and run while viewing the bay and changing fog conditions.l

directionsInfo:
Redwood National and State Parks is located in northernmost coastal California - almost on the Oregon border. The parks are about 60-miles long, with four visitor centers from north to south.

We are a six to seven-hour drive (325 miles) north of San Francisco, a six-hour drive (330 miles) south of Portland, OR and a four-hour drive (170 miles) west of Redding, CA.
weatherInfo:
Visitors should be prepared for cooler and damp weather. Dress in layers and expect to get wet.
Year-round temperatures along California's redwood coast: mid-40s°F (7°C) to mid-60s°F (18°C). 

Summer can be foggy, with highs occasionally reaching low 70s°F (20°C). 
Winters are cooler with considerable rain. October through April averages 60-80 inches of rain over the region.
name: Redwood
description: Most people know Redwood as home to the tallest trees on Earth. The parks also protect vast prairies, oak woodlands, wild river-ways, and nearly 40-miles of rugged coastline.  For thousands of years people have lived in this verdant landscape.  Together, the National Park Service and California State Parks are managing and restoring these lands for the inspiration, enjoyment, and education of all.

images.altText: Visitors chatting with a ranger above a river mouth.

directionsInfo: Please visit the "Directions and Transportation" link on the main website at http://www.nps.gov/rori/planyourvisit/directions.htm
weatherInfo: Weather typical for San Francisco Bay Area.  Can be cold and windy year round.  Fog in the summer.
name: Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front
description: Explore and honor the efforts and sacrifices of American civilians on the World War II home front.  Find out how they lived, worked and got along. Many faces, many stories, many truths weave a complex tapestry of myths and realities from this time of opportunity and loss.

images.altText: Rosie the Riveter Visitor Education Center
images.title: Rosie the Riveter Visitor Education Center
images.caption: Rosie the Riveter Visitor Education Center

fullName: Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front National Historical Park

directionsInfo: The park is located within the city limits of San Francisco, in the Fisherman's Wharf neighborhood, on the shoreline of San Francisco Bay.
weatherInfo: San Francisco is located in a Mediterranean climate. The rainy season usually lasts from November to March. The warmest months are usually September and October. The famous San Francisco fog begins rolling in through the Golden Gate in the spring and can persist throughout the summer months. That said, the city can be foggy and windy any time of the year, so if your visit to “sunny California” includes a stop in San Francisco, bring some warm clothing. The average annual temperature is 62.5°F (16.9°C).
name: San Francisco Maritime
description: Located in the Fisherman's Wharf neighborhood, San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park offers visitors the sights, sounds, smells and stories of Pacific Coast maritime history. The Park includes a magnificent fleet of historic ships, a Visitor Center, Maritime Museum, Maritime Research Center, and Aquatic Park Historic District.

directionsInfo:
There are multiple trailheads around the park, so there is not one main entrance.
You can begin your visit at the visitor center, located off Mulholland Highway in Calabasas.
The Santa Monica Mountains are traversed by the 405 Freeway on the east side; crowned by the 101 Freeway on the north and west side; and Highway 1, the Pacific Coast Highway (PCH), on the southern ocean border.
weatherInfo: Summers are hot and dry while winters are cool and wet.
name: Santa Monica Mountains
description: Hidden in plain sight from Los Angeles, the Santa Monica Mountains offer easy access to surprisingly wild places. Experience the famous beaches of Malibu or explore more than 500 miles of trails. The park abounds with historical and cultural sites, from old movie ranches to Native American centers. What will you and your family discover?

images.altText: Clouds between the mountains
images.title: Mountains
images.caption: Clouds between the mountains

images.altText: A large balanced rock with mountain ridges fading into the horizon.
images.title: Balanced Roack
images.caption: Hike to Balanced Rock along the Mishe Mokwa Trail, located near Circle X

fullName: Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area

directionsInfo:
Two highways enter the parks. Hwy 180 from Fresno leads east to Kings Canyon National Park, then continues 30 miles east to Cedar Grove. Hwy 198 from Visalia leads east to Sequoia National Park via Three Rivers. Inside the parks, Highway 198 becomes the Generals Highway, which connects 198 to 180. 

Vehicles over 22-feet long should enter the parks via Highway 180.

In winter, the Generals Highway between the parks often closes. Chains may be required on park roads.

No roads cross these parks east to west.
weatherInfo:
Because of the extreme elevation range in these parks, weather conditions vary widely between areas. 

In summer, the sequoia groves have comfortable temperatures and the foothills are hot and dry. Snow lingers on high-mountain passes well into summer.

In fall, some areas close or reduce their hours. Winter brings snow to sequoia groves and rain to the foothills. Be prepared for tire chain requirements. 

Spring is a great time to hike in the foothills and snow begins to melt at higher elevations.
name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon
description: This dramatic landscape testifies to nature's size, beauty, and diversity--huge mountains, rugged foothills, deep canyons, vast caverns, and the world's largest trees. These two parks lie side by side in the southern Sierra Nevada east of the San Joaquin Valley. Weather varies a lot by season and elevation, which ranges from 1,370' to 14,494'.

images.title: Kings Canyon
images.caption: The Glaciers carved the Kings Canyon's steep granite cliffs, leaving a wide U-shaped valley.

directionsInfo: The visitor center is located at the Tulelake - Butte Valley Fairgrounds at 800 Main St. Tulelake, CA 96134
weatherInfo: Summer daytime highs average 75° to 80°F; lows average 50°F. Occasional thunderstorms occur in summer. Winter daytime highs average 40°F; lows average 20°F. Morning fog is frequent from autumn through spring.
name: Tule Lake
description: The Tule Lake National Monument includes both the the Tule Lake Segregation Center, the largest and most controversial of the sites where Japanese Americans were incarcerated during World War II, and Camp Tulelake, which was first a Civilian Conservation Corps camp, then an additional facility to detain Japanese Americans, and finally a prisoner of war camp.

directionsInfo:
Car
From Interstate 5, take the Highway 44 West exit toward Downtown Redding and Eureka. From Downtown Redding, follow Highway 299 west toward Eureka for approximately 8 miles to reach the Visitor Center.
 
Plane
Commercial air service is available to Redding California located approximately 16 miles from Whiskeytown. Rental vehicles are available.
weatherInfo: Whiskeytown NRA is in a Mediterranean climate, which means hot, dry summers followed by cool, wet winters. Summer temperatures often reach the upper 90's to lower 100 degrees Fahrenheit, as well as the occasional thunderstorm. Winter brings snow to the upper elevations (only occasionally down to the lake level of 1,200'), and rain and ice.
name: Whiskeytown
description: Whiskeytown Lake’s beautiful crystal-clear waters, surrounded by mountain peaks, are perhaps the most prominent feature of the park.  However, water-based recreation is only a small part of what the park has to offer. The 39,000 acres surrounding the lake hold four waterfalls, pristine mountain creeks, 70 miles of trails, and opportunities to explore the history of the California Gold Rush.

directionsInfo:
You can drive to Yosemite all year and enter via Highways 41, 140, and 120 from the west. Tioga Pass Entrance (via Highway 120 from the east) is closed from around November through late May or June. Hetch Hetchy is open all year but may close intermittently due to snow.

Please note that GPS units do not always provide accurate directions to or within Yosemite.
weatherInfo: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)
name: Yosemite
description:
Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra.

First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.altText: Mountains reflecting in water
images.title: Glen Aulin
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.altText: Mountains surrounding a lake.
images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.

images.altText: Glaciated valley with vertical cliffs.
images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.altText: Granite dome with trace amounts of snow.
images.title: Half Dome
images.caption: Half Dome is one of the most recognizable granitic formations in the world.

images.altText: Massive cliff of El Capitan reflected in the Merced River
images.title: El Capitan
images.caption: El Capitan rises over 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley.

images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.altText: Very tall sequoia trees in a sequoia grove.
images.title: Giant Sequoia Tree
images.caption: Giant Sequoia trees are the largest living things (by volume) on the planet. Though not the tallest trees, one feels miniature in their presence..

directionsInfo: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 109 north 1 mile to Colorado Highway 194, then east on Colorado Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.
weatherInfo: Summer temperatures are are often in the high 90s and low 100s. Weather is generally fair in the fall and spring. Winter temperatures can be below freezing. Most of the fort is unheated and does not have modern cooling systems, so dress accordingly.
name: Bent's Old Fort
description: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed 1840s adobe fur trading post on the mountain branch of the Santa Fe Trail where traders, trappers, travelers, and the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes came together in peaceful terms for trade.  Today, living historians recreate the sights, sounds, and smells of the past with guided tours, demonstrations and special events.

images.altText: Bent's Fort
images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.caption: Bent's Old Fort was the only permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and Santa Fe.

images.altText: Fur trapper in camp
images.title: Fur trapper explains the work of the 1830s.
images.caption: Special events bring the past alive with encampments, fort trade and Plains Indian life.

images.altText: Plains Indian trade in plaza
images.title: A Lakota warrior barters with the traders in the fort plaza
images.caption: Trade with a Lakota warrior for trade goods from around the world.

images.altText: HIkers follow behind the fort's wagon on the Santa Fe Trail
images.title: Hiking the Santa Fe Trail
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail Encampment features a hike with the fort's wagon down the original Santa Fe Trail.

images.altText: Cooking in fort kitchen
images.title: Open hearth cooking in the fort kitchen
images.caption: Buffalo meat is broil in the reflector oven for the fort employees as was done in the 1840s.

images.altText: Swivel cannon firing
images.title: Swivel cannon is fired using 18th century drill
images.caption: The fort's security depended on its ability to resist attack.

fullName: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site

directionsInfo: 7 miles north on CO Highway 347 from the intersection with U.S. Highway 50 east of Montrose
weatherInfo:
Today's Weather: http://www.weather.com/weather/today/l/NPBLCA:13:US

CLIMATE
Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 55 to 90F (13 to 32C), nights 45 to 60F (7 to 16C). Winter daytime temperatures range between 15 to 40F (-9 to 4C), nights 10 to 20F (-12 to -6C).

Afternoon thunderstorms are common during the summer. Snow accumulation varies greatly year to year. Layered clothing appropriate for the season is recommended.
name: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison
description: Big enough to be overwhelming, still intimate enough to feel the pulse of time, Black Canyon of the Gunnison exposes you to some of the steepest cliffs, oldest rock, and craggiest spires in North America. With two million years to work, the Gunnison River, along with the forces of weathering, has sculpted this vertical wilderness of rock, water, and sky.
