directionsInfo: Dry Tortugas National Park is one of the most remote parks in the National Park System. Located approximately 70 miles west of Key West it is accessible only by a daily concession ferry, private boats, charter boats, or seaplane.
weatherInfo: The climate in the Dry Tortugas is subtropical, which basically means that it has warm and tropical weather in the range of 60°F to 90°F. The two main seasons are the winter stormy season from December through March which is windier and sees rougher seas, and the summertime tropical storm season from June through November where there is a higher chance of isolated storms. During the summers it is hot and humid. During the winter the temperature is milder and drier.
name: Dry Tortugas
description: Almost 70 miles (113 km) west of Key West lies the remote Dry Tortugas National Park. This 100-square mile park is mostly open water with seven small islands.  Accessible only by boat or seaplane, the park is known the world over as the home of magnificent Fort Jefferson, picturesque blue waters, superlative coral reefs and marine life, and the vast assortment of bird life that frequents the area.

images.altText: Park visitors enjoy a sunset on the moat wall.
images.title: Sunset at Fort Jefferson
images.caption: Sunsets at the Dry Tortugas are breathtaking. Visitors who choose to camp over night can view the sun set at Fort Jefferson.

images.altText: A view of Fort Jefferson from the moat all.
images.title: Fort Jefferson
images.caption: ort Jefferson is a massive but unfinished coastal fortress. It is the largest masonry structure in the Americas, and is composed of over 16 million bricks.

images.altText: A boat passes in front of Loggerhead Key during sunset.
images.title: Loggerhead Key
images.caption: The largest island in the Dry Tortugas, Loggerhead Key is a site of shipwrecks, a significant lighthouse installation, and where the historic Carnegie Laboratory for Marine Ecology once stood. Named for its abundance of loggerhead sea turtles, Loggerhead

images.altText: A view inside Fort Jefferson.
images.title: Inside Fort Jefferson
images.caption: Garden Key is the second largest island in the Dry Tortugas, about 14 acres in size, and has had the most human impact. Located on Garden Key is historic Fort Jefferson, one of the nation’s largest 19th century forts and a central cultural feature of Dry

images.altText: A few of the stars at night with a view of Fort Jefferson.
images.title: Night sky at the Dry Tortugas
images.caption: The Dry Tortugas is so remote that night sky viewing is possible.

images.altText: Two divers dive the Windjammer Wreck
images.title: Diving at the Dry Tortugas
images.caption: The Dry Tortugas has over 300 sunken ships. One of the most accessible is the Winjammer Wreck which can be dove or snorkeled.

images.altText: An aerial view of the Dry Tortugas
images.title: Aerial view of the Dry Tortugas
images.caption: The Dry Tortugas is made up of seven islands.

directionsInfo:
Directions to Ernest Coe Visitor Center
40001 State Road 9336, Homestead, FL 33034

Visitors coming from the Miami area and points north should take the Florida Turnpike (Route 821) south until it ends merging with U.S. 1 at Florida City. Turn right at the first traffic light onto Palm Drive (State Road 9336/SW 344th St.) and follow the signs to the park.

Visitors driving north from the Florida Keys should turn left on Palm Drive in Florida City and follow the signs to the park.
weatherInfo: The climate in Florida is known to be mild and sunny.The average annual temperatures for South Florida and the Keys range from 74° to 77°F (23° to 25°C). There are two seasons at the Everglades National Park: the wet season and the dry season. The wet season runs from Mid-May to November and the dry season runs from December to mid-May.
name: Everglades
description:
Everglades National Park protects an unparalleled landscape that provides important habitat for numerous rare and endangered species like the manatee,  American crocodile, and the elusive Florida panther.

An international treasure as well -  a World Heritage Site, International Biosphere Reserve, a Wetland of International Importance, and a specially protected area under the Cartagena Treaty.

images.altText: Two canoes at Nine Mile Pond during sunset.
images.title: Nine Mile Pond
images.caption: A meeting ground of marsh and mangrove environments. You may see alligators, wading birds, turtles, and fish.

images.altText: An American Alligator high walks the Anhinga Trail.
images.title: American Alligator
images.caption: An American Alligator high walks the Anhinga Trail.

images.altText: Two visitors bike along the road in Shark Valley.
images.title: Shark Valley Tram and Bicycle Road
images.caption: Biking is a great way to experience the quiet beauty of the Everglades.

images.altText: An aerial view of the landscape transition from Sawgrass to Florida Bay.
images.title: Transition from Sawgrass to Florida Bay
images.caption: An aerial view of the landscape transition from Sawgrass to Florida Bay.

images.altText: Three tents are put up along the Long Pine Key campsite.
images.title: Camping at Long Pine Key
images.caption: Long Pine Key Campground is open seasonally from November through May. It is located seven miles (11 km) from the main entrance, just off the main road.

directionsInfo: Fort Matanzas is 14 miles south of Saint Augustine on State Route A1A.
weatherInfo:
Summers are hot and humid with afternoon thundershowers. Sunscreen, a hat, UV protective sunglasses, and are recommended. Drink plenty of water.
 
Winters are cool to mild with some cold spells, especially with wind from the north or off the water. Fall and spring are temperate with temperatures around 70F-80F (21C-26C).
 
During danger of lightning, the fort will be closed and ferry service will be suspended.

June-November is hurricane season so check for tropical storms before visiting.
name: Fort Matanzas
description: Coastal Florida was a major field of conflict as European nations fought for control in the New World. As part of this struggle, Fort Matanzas guarded St. Augustine’s southern river approach. The colonial wars are over, but the monument is still protecting—not just the historic fort, but also the wild barrier island and the plants and animals who survive there amidst a sea of modern development

images.altText: A nature trail boardwalk with seating area.
images.title: Nature Trail
images.caption: Follow an elevated boardwalk through some pristine Florida barrier island habitat.

images.altText: Fort Matanzas, a fortified watch tower made form coquina.
images.title: Fort Matanzas
images.caption: Fort Matanzas sits on Rattlesnake Island in the middle of the Matanzas River.

images.altText: Wooden bunks and uniform items in the soldier's quarters.
images.title: Soldier's Quarters
images.caption: The few enlisted soldiers at Fort Matanzas shared a small, sparse room as living space.

images.altText: The cannon of Fort Matanzas point toward the river's inlet.
images.title: Protecting the riverway
images.caption: Fort Matanzas protected the southern river approach to Saint Augustine.

images.altText: People wading in the river and relaxing on the beach.
images.title: Recreational Opportunities
images.caption: More the half-a-million people visit Fort Matanzas each year to enjoy both the river and ocean beaches.

directionsInfo: Gulf Islands National Seashore is a place of myriad riches - blue-green, sparkling waters, magnificent white beaches, and fertile coastal marshes.  Its 13 areas include historic forts, shaded picnic areas, trails, and campgrounds.  From Cat Island, Mississippi, it stretches eastward 160 miles tot he Okaloosa Area east of For Walton Beach, Florida.
weatherInfo: Weather along the northern coast of the Gulf of Mexico can change quickly. During the winter temperatures range from 40-70 degrees fahrenheit, rain is less common than other seasons. Snow and freezing temperatures are not common. During the summer temperatures range from 70-100+ degrees fahrenheit. Rain is common during the summer with many thunderstorms. Hurricanes impact the area during the tropical storm season between June and November. Tornadoes can impact the area during the Spring and Fall.
name: Gulf Islands
description: What is it that entices people to the sea?  Poet John Masefield wrote, “I must go down to the seas again, for the call of the running tide is a wild call and a clear call that may not be denied.”  Millions of visitors are drawn to the islands in the northern Gulf of Mexico for the white sandy beaches, the aquamarine waters, a boat ride, a camping spot, a tour of an old fort, or a place to fish.

images.altText: A beach umbrella shades a chair as blue-green waves crash against a white sand beach.
images.title: Beach Scene
images.caption: A beach umbrella shades a chair as blue-green waves crash against a white sand beach.

images.altText: A room full of exhibits and displays about natural and cultural resources.
images.title: Fort Pickens Museum
images.caption: Visit the Fort Pickens Museum and learn more about the national seashore's awesome stories and resources.

images.altText: Two kayakers paddle toward the camera.
images.title: Kayaking at Gulf Islands National Seashore
images.caption: Experience the park from the water and see what makes Gulf Islands National Seashore so special.

images.altText: A brick fort stands on the edge of a white sand beach.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts is one of the four forts built in 1800s preserved by Gulf Islands National Seashore.

images.altText: A recently hatched turtle makes its way to the water from the beach.
images.title: Sea Turtles
images.caption: Gulf Islands National Seashore biologist study sea turtle to protect them and their habitats.

directionsInfo: The corridor encompasses a cultural and linguistic area along the southeastern coast of the United States from the northern border of Pender County, North Carolina to the southern border of St. Johns County, Florida and 30 miles inland.  The Commission operates a small business office on Johns Island, SC., but there are many sites to explore within the Corridor.
weatherInfo: The weather varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov for forecast information.
name: Gullah/Geechee
description: Designated by Congress in 2006, the Gullah Geechee Cultural Heritage Corridor extends from Wilmington, North Carolina in the north to Jacksonville, Florida in the south. It is home to one of America's most unique cultures, a tradition first shaped by captive Africans brought to the southern United States from West Africa and continued in later generations by their descendents.

images.altText: Vera Manigault demonstrates the art of sewing sweetgrass baskets.
images.title: Sweetgrass Basket
images.caption: Vera Manigault demonstrates the art of sewing sweetgrass baskets.

directionsInfo: The beautiful expanse of the Timucuan Preserve is located within the city limits of Jacksonville, Florida.  The Preserve can be accessed from major roads and highways in and around Jacksonville. Directions to individual park sites such as Kingsley Plantation, American Beach and the Ribault Column can be found on our website.  Our main visitor center is located at Fort Caroline, about 14 miles northeast of downtown.
weatherInfo: We have mild winters and hot summers.  In the winter average highs are in the 60's, lows in the 40's.  The summer temperatures reach up into the 90's.
name: Timucuan
description:
Visit one of the last unspoiled coastal wetlands on the Atlantic Coast. Discover 6,000 years of human history and experience the beauty of salt marshes, coastal dunes, and hardwood hammocks.

The Timucuan Preserve includes Fort Caroline and Kingsley Plantation.

images.altText: slave cabins made of tabby with wooden roofs
images.title: Kingsley Plantation Slave Quarters
images.caption: The tabby cabins at Kingsley Plantation were the homes of many enslaved people.

images.altText: sand dune and blue sky
images.title: Nana dune at American Beach
images.caption: The sand dune at American Beach is a protected part of the Timucuan Preserve.

images.altText: fort gate
images.title: Fort Caroline
images.caption: The fort exhibit at Fort Caroline teaches visitors of the failed French colony in Florida.

images.altText: park bench alongside a trail
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Area
images.caption: The Theodore Roosevelt Area trails provide a getaway from the urban hustle within the city of Jacksonville.

images.altText: A baby fox pops it's head from a burrow
images.title: Baby Fox
images.caption: The Timucuan Preserve hosts wondrous biodiversity.

directionsInfo: Andersonville National Historic Site is located in southwest Georgia. The park is approximately 12 miles north of Americus and 11 miles south of Montezuma on GA-49.
weatherInfo: Summer temperatures reach highs in the 80s-90s and high humidity. Winter temperatures tend to be in the 40s and below. Snow can occur but is rare. Average annual precipitation is 46.24 inches and is fairly evenly distributed throughout the year. The National Prisoner of War Museum is maintained at a cool temperature to help preserve artifacts; dressing in layers is recommended.
name: Andersonville
description: The Camp Sumter military prison at Andersonville was one of the largest Confederate military prisons during the Civil War. During the 14 months the prison existed, more than 45,000 Union soldiers were confined here. Of these, almost 13,000 died here. Today, Andersonville National Historic Site is a memorial to all American prisoners of war throughout the nation's history.

images.altText: A cannon sits out in front of a replica of part of the wooden stockade walls once at Andersonville
images.title: Historic Site of Camp Sumter Civil War Military Prison at Andersonville
images.caption: Camp Sumter Military Prison, known as Andersonville, was the deadliest ground of the Civil War. Nearly 13,000 American soldiers died here.

images.altText: A historic photo of thousands of emaciated Union soldiers held prisoner in 1865
images.title: Summer of 1865 at Andersonville Photo by A.J. Riddle
images.caption: Over 32,000 Union soldiers languished at Andersonville in August 1865 when this photo was taken by A.J. Riddle.

images.altText: Fog rests on a stone monument of a Civil War soldier standing among hundreds of graves.
images.title: Andersonville National Cemetery
images.caption: The site where the nearly 13,000 Union soldiers who died at Andersonville, designated as a National Cemetery in 1865, is still an active cemetery. Nearly 21,000 American military veterans rest here in honor.

images.altText: A large stone monument with 2 Civil War soldiers, a female figure, and 2 children.
images.title: The Illinois Monument at Andersonville National Historic Site
images.caption: Many states honored their fallen sons with monuments placed at Andersonville National Historic Site.

images.altText: A military garrison cap with a small U.S. flag and silver bar in an exhibit case
images.title: National Prisoner of War Museum
images.caption: Andersonville is the only National Park Service site with the mission of preserving the stories of all American Prisoners of War throughout history.

directionsInfo: The Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area lies just east of Atlanta along I-20.  It is a partnership area 40,000 large where visitors will find large, granite outcroppings, historic communities and spiritual spaces.
weatherInfo: https://www.wunderground.com/q/zmw:30087.1.99999?sp=KGASTONE4
name: Arabia Mountain
description: For millions of years, granite monadnocks have stood watch over the rivers and forests of Georgia. These breathtaking landscapes are the cornerstones of the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area, which serves to protect & promote these outcrops and the surrounding region as a recreational wonder and national treasure.

directionsInfo:
To Augusta Canal Discovery Center (1450 Greene Street, Augusta, GA  30901):
From I-20 Exit 200, turn left onto GA-104/Riverwatch Parkway (signs for Downtown Augusta). In approximately 4.5 miles, use the right lane to take the ramp to Downtown Augusta/Medical District. Continue straight onto Greene Street. Continue for approximately 0.4 miles. Enterprise Mill and the Discovery Center will be on your right.
weatherInfo: The weather varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov for forecast information.
name: Augusta Canal
description: The Augusta Canal helped usher the Industrial Revolution into the American South. Built in 1845 as a source of power, water, and transportation, the canal today is the only fully intact American industrial canal in continuous operation. By 1847 the first mills opened, followed by the massive Civil War era Confederate Powder Works and many more industries in the later decades of the 19th century.

images.altText: Petersburg Boat passes Sibley Mill and the chimney of Confederate States Powder Works along the Augu
images.title: Petersburg Boat
images.caption: Petersburg Boat passes Sibley Mill and the chimney of Confederate States Powder Works along the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area

directionsInfo: To find the Island Ford Visitor Center enter the physical address, 8800 Roberts Drive, Sandy Springs, GA 30350, into your GPS unit or your favorite map software. Once you have arrived at the park entrance turn onto Island Ford Parkway and follow the signs to the park headquarters.
weatherInfo:
Summers typically consist of long spells of warm, humid weather. Average highs are in the lower 90's and overnight lows range from the upper 60's to lower 70's. 

Winters are more variable with highs averaging from the mid 50's to lower 60's while the lows average in the mid 30's. Oftentimes, stretches of mild weather will alternate with cold spells.

Spring and Autumn seasons are characterized by much variability from day to day and from year to year.
name: Chattahoochee River
description: Today the river valley attracts us for so many reasons. Take a solitary walk to enjoy nature’s display, raft leisurely through the rocky shoals with friends, fish the misty waters as the sun comes up, or have a picnic on a Sunday afternoon. Get Outdoors and experience your Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area as you have never done before.

images.altText: Two adult Great Blue Herons stand watch over their 3 young chicks in the nest.
images.title: Family Time
images.caption: Great Blue Herons are plentyful along the river. Look towards the tree tops along the river to spot their nest. If you're lucky the whole will be home.

images.altText: Park ranger showing a group of school children the critter on his arm.
images.title: Look Closely
images.caption: School children from the city enjoy visiting the park on a ranger-led hike.

images.altText: Stone ruins of the Marietta Paper Mill surrounded by lush green vegatation.
images.title: Marietta Paper Mill
images.caption: All that is left of the Marietta Paper Mill is a few stone walls in the woods. Hike to the ruins and you'll get a closeup of Sope Creek that was harnessed by the mills.

images.altText: Angler in waders landing a fish using a landing net.
images.title: Landing A Rainbow
images.caption: Fishing the Chattahoochee River can be a great way to spend an afternoon out of the office or as a diversion from rush hour traffic.

images.altText: Trail heading off under a canopy of trees.
images.title: Inviting Trail
images.caption: Trails along the Chattahoochee River are calling you to visit.

directionsInfo:
From I-75, take exit 350 onto Battlefield Parkway (GA HWY 2) and continue to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway and LaFayette Road. Turn left onto LaFayette Road and continue for approximately 1 mile. The visitor center will be on the right. 

From I-24, take exit 180 onto Rossville Boulevard (US HWY 27). Continue south to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway. Drive through the intersection, continuing on the LaFayette Road. The visitor center will be on the right.
weatherInfo: The climate in northern Georgia is generally temperate. Short, cool winters give relief from hot summers. Most visitors enjoy this area during long, mild fall and spring seasons.
name: Chickamauga & Chattanooga
description: In 1863, Union and Confederate forces fought for control of Chattanooga, known as the "Gateway to the Deep South." The Confederates were victorious at nearby Chickamauga in September. However, renewed fighting in Chattanooga that November provided Union troops victory and control of the city. After the fighting, a Confederate soldier ominously wrote, "This...is the death-knell of the Confederacy."

images.altText: Kelley Cabin
images.title: Kelley Cabin on Chickamauga Battlefield
images.caption: Living Historians are seen in Kelley Field and in the distance at the Kelley Cabin during the 150th anniversary

images.altText: Illinois Monument
images.title: Illinois Monument at Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge
images.caption: Silent sentinels stand on the Illinois Monument at the Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge Battlefield

images.altText: Cannon on Lookout Mountain
images.title: Cannon on Lookout Mountain
images.caption: As the sun sets on Lookout Mountain, a lone cannon guards the valley below.

images.altText: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.title: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.caption: The graves of fallen soldiers from Chickamauga to present dot the landscape in Chattanooga as Lookout Mountain looms in the background

images.altText: Living Historians on Orchard Knob
images.title: Living Historians on Orchard Knob in Chattanooga
images.caption: Confederate soldiers stand watch from Orchard Knob during the 150th anniversary of the Battles for Chattanooga in 2013.

directionsInfo:
Driving Directions
To reach the visitor center from Interstate 95:
•	Take Exit 3 for US 40
•	Take US 40 East toward “Historic Downtown St. Marys”
•	US 40 becomes Osborne Rd. Continue on until you reach the waterfront
•	Turn right on St. Marys Rd 
•	The visitor center will be two blocks down on your left (113 St. Marys St W, St Marys GA 31558)
weatherInfo:
Cumberland Island’s climate is hot and humid during summer when temperatures tend to be in the 80's (>26 C) and mild during winter when temperatures tend to be in the 60's (<20 C). The warmest month of the year is July with an average high of 90 degrees F (32 C), while the coldest is January with an average low of 45 degrees F (44 C). Visit the Current Conditions page for an up-to-date local forecast:
https://www.nps.gov/cuis/planyourvisit/conditions.htm#weather
name: Cumberland Island
description: St Marys is the gateway to Cumberland Island, Georgia's largest and southernmost barrier island. Here pristine maritime forests, undeveloped beaches and wide marshes whisper the stories of both man and nature. Natives, missionaries, enslaved African Americans and Wealthy Industrialists all walked here.  Cumberland Island is also home to over 9,800 acres of Congressionally designated Wilderness.

images.altText: Sand dunes covered with shrubs and grasses
images.title: Vegetated Dunes
images.caption: Vegetation holds dunes in place providing a barrier to erosion forces and creating essential interdune meadows to support island life.

images.altText: Alligator resting on a log in pond
images.title: Home To Wildlife
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses a variety of forest, marsh, and coastal landscapes providing a home for numerous species including American Alligators.

images.altText: Ocean beach at sunrise
images.title: Undeveloped Coast
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses nearly 18 miles of undeveloped beach offering recreation for visitors and essential nesting area for birds and sea turtles.

images.altText: large, white mansion behind oak trees draped with Spanish Moss
images.title: Plum Orchard Mansion
images.caption: Visitors can take a guided tour of the Plum Orchard Mansion and experience the luxuries of Victorian high society as well as the effort and ingenuity it took to make it possible.

images.altText: rippled sands of a beach in front of pine tree covered bluffs
images.title: Island Bluffs Shaped By Tides
images.caption: Tidal forces continue to shape the land today as they have for thousands of years forming high bluffs used for fortifications and ship docking throughout the island’s history.

images.altText: huge oak trees and palm shrubs line a sand road
images.title: Historic Main Road
images.caption: While visitors to the island cannot bring vehicles, they can travel the historic main park road by foot and bicycle. Some remaining island residents will still drive vehicles on the road to reach their residences as they have for generations.

images.altText: brick and stone ruins of a large mansion at sunset under colorful clouds
images.title: Dungeness Ruins
images.caption: Dugeness was the largest mansion built on the island as part of the Carnegie Estate. Though lost to fire in 1959, the ruins of the mansion and several of its support structures are a reminder of the island’s rich history.

images.altText: small white one room church, old red house in the background, under cloudy skies
images.title: The Settlement
images.caption: The remote north end of the island is home to the First African Baptist Church and The Settlement, where African American residents were able to purchase their first deeded property on the island at the end of the 1800s.

images.altText: tidal creek at low tide surrounded by palm and oak trees
images.title: Tidal Creek
images.caption: Rising tides bring valuable nutrients into tidal creeks, while receding tides remove waste. This makes the tide cycle the beating heart of the island’s tidal creeks, salt marshes, and estuaries.

directionsInfo:
South on I 95 to U.S. 17:
Exit 38 and Left onto Spur 25. Follow Spur 25 until U.S. 17. Take a right on U.S. 17 (south).

North on I 95 to U.S. 17:
Exit 29 and Right onto U.S. 17.

From US 17:
Take Causeway to St. Simons Island. Take first left onto Sea Island Rd. Go 1.5 miles to third traffic light, and Left onto Frederica Road. Follow Frederica Road for two miles (take second right off roundabout). The park entrance 300 yards past Christ Church.
weatherInfo: The site enjoys mild climate from fall through early summer, followed by hot, humid summers.
name: Fort Frederica
description: Georgia's fate was decided in 1742 when Spanish and British forces clashed on St. Simons Island. Fort Frederica's troops defeated the Spanish, ensuring Georgia's future as a British colony. Today, the archeological remnants of Frederica are protected by the National Park Service.

images.altText: Ruin of Soldier Barracks at Fort Frederica NM
images.title: Ruin of Soldier Barracks at Fort Frederica NM
images.caption: The Barracks ruin is one of the few above ground structures at Fort Frederica

images.altText: Artist rendering of Downtown Frederica Town
images.title: Artist rendering of Downtown Frederica Town
images.caption: Artist rendering of Downtown Frederica Town

images.altText: Artist rendering of Downtown Frederica Town
images.title: Artist rendering of Downtown Frederica Town
images.caption: Artist rendering of Downtown Frederica Town

images.altText: Artifacts found at Frederica
images.title: Artifacts found at Frederica
images.caption: Artifacts found at Frederica

images.altText: Reenactors performing as the original redcoats who served at Frederica
images.title: Soldiers of the 42nd Regiment of Foote
images.caption: Soldiers of the 42nd Regiment of Foote

images.altText: A large grapevine draped among the Live Oaks
images.title: 100 year old grapevine at Frederica
images.caption: 100 year old grapevine at Frederica which still produces "Summer Grapes"

images.altText: The shadow of the ruin of Fort Frederica highlighted by a sunset along the Frederica River.
images.title: Fort Frederica at Sunset
images.caption: Nature and History combine in a beautiful setting at Fort Frederica

images.altText: Brick building of the Visitor Center with Azaleas blossoming in front
images.title: Fort Frederica's Visitor Center during Azalea Season
images.caption: Fort Frederica's Visitor Center during Azalea Season

directionsInfo:
From Interstate I-95, take Exit 99 onto Interstate I-16 East (James L Gillis Memorial Hwy) for 7 miles.
Take Exit 164A onto Interstate I-516 East toward US-80 East.
Take Exit 3 (US-17 S/US-80 E) toward US-80 East. 
Turn left onto Ocean Highway, Ogeechee Rd (US-17 N, US-80 East). 
Bear right onto West Victory Drive (US-80 East).
Continue on US-80 East for 13 miles.

GPS Coordinates for Fort Pulaski National Monument:

N32° 01.680 W080° 53.525
weatherInfo: Savannah has a humid sub tropical climate with over two hundred days of sunshine each year. Summers are typically hot, bright and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures often range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F. Spring and autumn can be quite pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F. The winter months are usually dry. Temperatures can be cooler than one would expect, ranging from the upper 30s through the 60s F generally, though sudden cold snaps can occur.
name: Fort Pulaski
description: For much of the 19th century, masonry fortifications were the United States’ main defense against overseas enemies. However, during the Civil War, new technology proved its superiority to these forts. The Union army used rifled cannon and compelled the Confederate garrison inside Fort Pulaski to surrender. The siege was a landmark experiment in the history of military science and invention.

images.altText: The white masonry Cockspur Island lighthouse sits in the Savannah River.
images.title: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse
images.caption: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse still stands guard over the south channel of the Savannah River and Fort Pulaski.

images.altText: The red masonry walls of Fort Pulaski still show battle damage over 150 years later.
images.title: The Battered Walls of Fort Pulaski
images.caption: A walk along the outside of Fort Pulaski reveals damaged walls over 150 years after the Civil War.

images.altText: The brick of the fort glow in the late afternoon light. The arches inside the fort reveal a cannon i
images.title: The Casemates of a Fort
images.caption: Fort Pulaski shows off its classic arched architecture and cannon.

images.altText: A great blue heron stands watch on top of the fort's brick walls.
images.title: The Sentinel
images.caption: A great blue heron stands on the top of Fort Pulaski like a lonely sentinel.

images.altText: Two women dressed in mid nineteenth century civilian attire watch through looking glasses
images.title: The Ladies of a Fort
images.caption: Volunteer living historians play an important role for the National Park Service and Fort Pulaski National Monument.

images.altText: The night sky is illuminated as a cannon fires at Fort Pulaski
images.title: Night Cannon Firing at Fort Pulaski
images.caption: Artillery demonstrations are an important part of the interpretation program at Fort Pulaski.

directionsInfo: The Jimmy Carter National Historic Site, Plains High School Museum and Visitor Center is located in Plains, Georgia. The address is 300 North Bond Street. The zip code is 31780
weatherInfo: Weather in Southwest Georgia can change in the blink of an eye during the summer months. Thunderstorms and high temperatures can make it unpleasant for visitors. Check the local forecast and dress appropriately.
name: Jimmy Carter
description: Few U.S. Presidents have had such close ties with where they were born and raised. The rural southern culture of Plains, Georgia, that revolves around farming, church and school, had a large influence in molding the character and in shaping the political policies of the 39th President of the United States.

images.altText: A picture of the front of the home Jimmy Carter lived in as a young boy.
images.title: Jimmy Carter's Boyhood Home
images.caption: Front view of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home in Archery, Georgia.

images.altText: Front view of Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum
images.title: Plains High School Museum and Visitors Center
images.caption: Almost one hundred thousand visitors visit Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum yearly.

images.altText: The Plains train depot that President Carter used as the 1976 campaign headquarters.
images.title: Plains Depot, 1976 Campaign Headquarters
images.caption: The oldest building in Plains, the train depot, was used as the 1976 campaign headquarters for President Carter.

images.altText: Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd; Presidents' Day 2016
images.title: Jimmy Carter Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: President Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd at Plains High School for Presidents' Day 2016

images.altText: Rosalynn Carter signing a book, Presidents' Day 2016
images.title: Rosalynn Carter, Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: Rosalynn Carter signing a book she authored during Presidents' Day 2016

directionsInfo:
Take exit 269 (Barrett Parkway). At the stoplight head west onto Barrett Parkway.
Follow Barrett Parkway for approximately 3 miles, turn left at the light, onto Old Hwy 41.
Turn right at your next light, Stilesboro Rd.
The visitor center will be immediately on your left (brown and white signs located along the roads will guide you as well).
weatherInfo: Before you start your trip to the mountain, check the local weather forecast to be sure that you will have a dry time. Though we are located north of Atlanta, we're still have the same hot summers and mild winters as our neighbors. The mountain top generally ranges 8-10 degrees cooler than at the base. In fall and winter, be prepared with a light weight jacket on hand. After planning your activities, check back to see what the weather will have in store for your day.
name: Kennesaw Mountain
description: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park is a 2,965 acre National Battlefield that preserves a Civil War battleground of the Atlanta Campaign. Opposing forces maneuvered and fought here from June 19, 1864 until July 2, 1864. Although most famous as a Civil War battlefield, Kennesaw Mountain has a much richer story.

images.altText: Casson with Cannon Fire
images.title: Casson with Cannon Fire
images.caption: Casson with Cannon Fire Demonstration.

images.altText: Cannon with front field and Visitor Center in background.
images.title: Fall at Kennesaw Mountain
images.caption: Cannon with front field and Visitor Center in background.

images.altText: Illinois Monument at Kennesaw Mountain.
images.title: Illinois Monument at Kennesaw Mountain
images.caption: Illinois Monument at Kennesaw Mountain.

images.altText: Infantry Demonstration at Kennesaw Mountain.
images.title: Infantry Demonstration at Kennesaw Mountain
images.caption: Infantry Demonstration at Kennesaw Mountain.

images.altText: Kolb Farmhouse at Kennesaw Mountain.
images.title: Kolb Farmhouse at Kennesaw Mountain
images.caption: Kolb Farmhouse at Kennesaw Mountain.

directionsInfo: The park is accessible via public transportation and by car.
weatherInfo: Summers typically are warm and humid with average afternoon high temperatures are in the lower 90s.  During winter the high temperatures average from the mid-50s to  the lower 60s.  Lows average in the mid-30s.   Spring and Autumn seasons are characterized by much variability from day to day and from year to year.  The average date of first freeze is in mid-November and the date of the last freeze is mid to late March.
name: Martin Luther King, Jr.
description: A young boy grows up in a time of segregation…A dreamer is moved by destiny into leadership of the modern civil rights movement…This was Martin Luther King, Jr.  Come hear his story, visit the home of his birth, and where he played as a child.  Walk in his footsteps, and hear his voice in the church where he moved hearts and minds.  Marvel at how he was an instrument for social change.

images.altText: The Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.title: Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.caption: The Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.

images.altText: Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church
images.title: Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church
images.caption: The spiritual home of the King Family.

images.altText: Visitor center and the "I Have a Dream" Internrational World Peace Rose
images.title: The Visitor Center at Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park
images.caption: The visitor center features an exhibit entitled "Courage To Lead".

images.altText: Fire Station No. 6
images.title: Fire Station No. 6
images.caption: The second Fire Station integrated in the City of Atlanta.

images.altText: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.title: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.caption: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.  rests on a brick island within a reflecting pool.

fullName: Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park

directionsInfo: Drive on I-75 to Macon. Exit I-75 onto I-16 east (exit on left) . Get off I-16 at exit 2 (Coliseum Drive), take a left under the highway and proceed to where Coliseum Dr. ends at Emery Highway. Turn right on Emery Highway and proceed to the third light. Our entrance is on the right side of the road.
weatherInfo:
Macon has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa). The normal monthly mean temperature ranges from 46.3 °F (7.9 °C) in January to 81.8 °F (27.7 °C) in July. On average, there are 4.8 days with 100 °F (38 °C


Winter's are mild. Temps ranging from 30 degrees to 50 degrees. Spring is mild but wet. Temps ranging from 50 degrees to low 70 degrees. Summers are hot and very humid. Temp ranging from upper 80 degrees to 100 degrees. Fall is pleasant. Temps ranging from 60 to 80 degrees.
name: Ocmulgee Mounds
description: Welcome to Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. This park is a prehistoric American Indian site.  American Indians first came here during the Paleo-Indian period hunting Ice Age mammals. Many different American Indian cultures occupied this land for thousands of years.  Around 900 CE, the Mississippian Period began. They constructed mounds for their elite, which remain today.

images.altText: mounds
images.title: Great Temple and Lesser Temple Mound
images.caption: The Great Temple Mound is the largest mound at the park, it stands at 55 feet tall.

images.altText: earth lodge
images.title: Earth Lodge
images.caption: The Earth Lodge was used as a council chamber for the Mississippian Culture (900-1600)

images.altText: earth lodge floor
images.title: Earth Lodge Floor
images.caption: The earth Lodge floor is original it was carbon dated to 1015.

images.altText: funeral mound
images.title: The Funeral Mound
images.caption: The Funeral Mound was by prehistoric cultures to bury their dead. Today there are still remains instead the mound

images.altText: spear point
images.title: Clovis Point

directionsInfo: From the airport or Tumon, where most hotels are located, make your way to Route 1, Marine Corps Drive. Head south until the road ends and you arrive at the Naval Station Guam front gate. To the right, adjacent to the large 2-man Type-C Japanese midget submarine, is the T. Stell Newman Visitor Center.
weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=13.47190933300044&lon=144.74977715100056
name: War In The Pacific
description: War in the Pacific National Historical Park was established to commemorate the bravery, courage, and sacrifice of those participating in the campaigns of the Pacific Theater of World War II.  At War in the Pacific National Historical Park, the former battlefields, gun emplacements, trenches, and historic structures all serve as silent reminders of the bloody World War II battles.

images.altText: Mountain view down toward beach.
images.title: Asan Beach Overlook
images.caption: Overlooking the invasion Asan Beach, this overlook honors the men and women killed on Guam in World War II.

images.altText: Night view of light up US flags.
images.title: Memorial Day Flag Honors at Asan Beach
images.caption: Honoring the Chamorro citizens and US service personnel killed during World War II.

images.altText: Calm water beach at sunset.
images.title: Apaca point
images.caption: This serene scene of Apaca Point does not reveal the intensity felt on the July 21, 1944 invasion.

fullName: War In The Pacific National Historical Park

directionsInfo: The trail can be unofficially accessed through sections within the four National Parks on the Island of Hawai'i including Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Pu'uhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park, Kaloko-Honokohau National Historical Park and Pu'ukohola National Historic Site. Otherwise, the section of the Ala Kahakai Trail under Hawaii State Na Ala Hele jurisdiction is open for public use.
weatherInfo: Island weather is unpredictable. Visitors should be prepared for rain and wear layers of clothing to ensure their comfort while exploring the park.
name: Ala Kahakai
description: Established in 2000 for the preservation, protection and interpretation of traditional Native Hawaiian culture and natural resources, Ala Kahakai National Historic Trail is a 175 mile corridor and trail network of cultural and historical significance. It traverses through hundreds of ancient Hawaiian settlement sites and over 200 ahupua'a (traditional land divisions). Connect now!

images.altText: sandy beach
images.title: Waiulaula Bay
images.caption: Sandy beach after a storm

directionsInfo:
Located on the island of Maui, Haleakalā National Park extends from the 10,023 foot (3055m) summit of Haleakalā down the southeast flank of the mountain to the Kīpahulu coast near Hana. These two sections of the park are not directly connected by road, but both can be reached from Kahului.
There are no gas stations within the park. The last place to get gas in route to the Summit Area is in the town of Pukalani, and along the Hana Highway before Hana is in the town of is in the town of Paia.
weatherInfo:
On any given day, the temperatures in the park can range from a high of 80°F (27°C) in Kīpahulu to a low of 30°F (-1°C) at the summit. In either area clouds and rain can quickly replace warm sunshine.
Weather in the high-elevation summit and wilderness areas of the park is highly unpredictable and changes often. Cool temperatures, intense solar radiation, and rapidly moving clouds are characteristic. On average, the temperature drops about 3°F for every 1,000 foot rise in elevation.
name: Haleakalā
description: This special place vibrates with stories of ancient and modern Hawaiian culture and protects the bond between the land and its people. The park also cares for endangered species, some of which exist nowhere else. Come visit this special place - renew your spirit amid stark volcanic landscapes and sub-tropical rain forest with an unforgettable hike through the backcountry.

directionsInfo: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park is located on the island of Hawai‘i. From Hilo: 30 miles southwest on Highway 11 (a 45 minute drive); from Kailua-Kona: 96 miles southeast on Highway 11 (2 to 2 1/2 hour drive), or 125 miles through Waimea and Hilo via highways 19 and 11 (2 1/2 to 3 hours).
weatherInfo: The weather at Kīlauea's summit (4000' elevation) varies daily and may be rainy and chilly any time of the year. Temperature varies by elevation. At the summit of the volcano, temperatures may be 12 to 15 degrees cooler than at sea level. The coastal plain at the end of Chain of Craters Road, where lava crossed the road in 2003, is often hot, dry, and windy with the possibility of passing showers.
name: Hawai'i Volcanoes
description: Hawai‘i Volcanoes National Park protects some of the most unique geological, biological, and cultural landscapes in the world. Extending from sea level to the summit of Mauna Loa at 13,677 feet, the park encompasses the summits of two of the world's most active volcanoes - Kīlauea and Mauna Loa. Learn more about this special place and traditional Hawaiian culture connected to these landscapes.

directionsInfo: There are currently no directions to the Honouliuli National Monument as the monument remains closed to the public due to accessibility issues in the process of being resolved.
weatherInfo: The temperature ranges from 70°F/22°C to 85°F/29°C year round with light tropical showers common.
name: Honouliuli
description: Although not yet open to the public, Honouliuli National Monument (NM) will tell the history of internment, martial law, and the experience of prisoners of war in Hawai‘i during World War II. Honouliuli NM will be a place to reflect on wartime experiences and recommit ourselves to the pursuit of freedom and justice.

directionsInfo: Kalaupapa is an extremely isolated place, surrounded on three sides by ocean and two-thousand foot cliffs on the fourth. Consequently, there is no road access into the peninsula. Kalaupapa cannot be reached by automobile. To get to the park, visitors must travel by air, mule, or on foot. See the park's Direction and Transportation webpage for additional information.
weatherInfo: Hawaii enjoys warm temperatures year-round, although site conditions at the park can vary depending on weather and time of year.  The rainy season is in the winter with the more hot and humid days in the summer. Trade winds are fairly constant and typically blow from the northeast. Daytime temperatures range from 65–75° F in the winter to 80-90°F in the summer. Nighttime temperatures are often in the 60-70°F range.
name: Kalaupapa
description:
When Hansen's disease (leprosy) was introduced to the Hawaiian Islands, King Kamehameha V banished all afflicted to the isolated Kalaupapa peninsula on the north shore of Molokai.  

Since 1866, more than 8000 people, mostly Hawaiians, have died at Kalaupapa. Once a prison, Kalaupapa is now refuge for the few remaining residents who are now cured, but were forced to live their lives in isolation.

images.altText: View of Kalaupapa Peninsula from Overlook
images.title: Overview of Kalaupapa Peninsula
images.caption: The Kalaupapa peninsula was once a prison for those inflicted with Hansen's disease.  Approximately 8000 people were forced to live their lives in isolation here.

images.altText: View of pali (sea cliffs) on the north shore of Molokai
images.title: Pali (Sea cliffs) at Kalaupapa
images.caption: Kalaupapa National Historical Park contains some of the world's tallest sea cliffs, which formed a natural barrier to the Hansen's disease settlement.

images.altText: View of residences along Damien Road
images.title: Kalaupapa Settlement
images.caption: Patients lived in a combination of group homes and single family residences at Kalaupapa.

images.altText: View of the sunrise over the north shore of Molokai
images.title: Kalawao at Sunrise
images.caption: Kalawao with its rocky shoreline was the landing spot for the first Hansen's disease patients sent to Kalaupapa.

images.altText: View of Black Sand Beach and Awahua Bay
images.title: Black Sand Beach
images.caption: Black Sand Beach is one of several sandy beaches at Kalaupapa, most known for its sea turtle nesting habitat.

images.altText: View of rock walls and native Hawaiian archeological sites at Kalaupapa.
images.title: Archeological Sites at Kalaupapa
images.caption: Kalaupapa is also home to one of the most well-preserved archeological complexes in all of Hawaii.

images.altText: Siloama Church at Kalawao settlement
images.title: Siloama Church at Kalawao
images.caption: Siloama Church was the first church established at Kalawao in 1866.  It is one of two remaining buildings at Kalawao today.

images.altText: View of St. Damien's Grave at Kalawao with ocean in background.
images.title: St. Damien's Grave
images.caption: Saint Damien is one of two Catholic saints at Kalaupapa who came to serve the Hansen's disease patients in the late 19th century.

images.altText: View of Paschoal Hall also known as the Kalaupapa Social Hall
images.title: Paschoal Hall
images.caption: Paschoal Hall, also known as the Kalaupapa Social Hall, served as the community's recreational center with movies, entertainers, and dances.

images.altText: View of grave markers at Papaloa Cemetery in Kalaupapa
images.title: Papaloa Cemetery
images.caption: Kalaupapa is the final resting place for approximately 8000 people. Papaloa Cemetery is the largest cemetery located along the west shoreline of the peninsula.

images.altText: View of Kana'ana Hou Church through gates
images.title: Kana'ana Hou Church
images.caption: Religion was a prominent part of patients' lives at Kalaupapa. Protestant, Catholic, and Mormon churches were established at both Kalawao and Kalaupapa settlements.

images.altText: View of warehouse and store at the Kalaupapa Pier
images.title: Kalaupapa Pier
images.caption: The Kalaupapa Pier, warehouse, and store were the lifeline of the settlement during the 20th century. Historically, shipments of goods and supplies were sent to Kalaupapa weekly.

directionsInfo:
Kaloko-Honokohau National Historical Park is located on the west coast of the island of Hawai'i, approximately 3 miles south of the Keahole International Airport and 3 miles north of the town of Kailua-Kona, on the ocean side of Highway 19.

The visitor center, Hale Ho'okipa, is located half a mile north of the entrance to Honokohau Harbor. The Kaloko road gate is located across the highway from the Kaloko New Industrial Park (across from the big yellow "Kona Trade Center" building).
weatherInfo: The weather in the park is typically hot and sunny, with temperatures in the upper 80's.
name: Kaloko-Honokōhau
description: To survive in a hot and arid environment the native Hawaiians (kanaka maoli) used ancient fishing skills, including the building of fishponds, and the knowledge of the location of precious fresh water (wai) that flows into the many brackish pools throughout the park. The spirit of the people (poe) and the knowledge of the elders (kupuna) created a tradition of respect and reverence for this area.

images.altText: The rehabilitation of Kaloko fishpond started in 1998 and still continues today....
images.title: Kaloko Fishpond
images.caption: Kaloko Fishpond is the largest walled fishpond in the state (800 ft. long)

images.altText: Honu (sea turtles) are common on the beach in this area of the park
images.title: Ai'opio fishtrap
images.caption: Ai'opio fishtrap is on the south boundary of the park and is used frequently by visitors and for special events (annual children's cultural festival shown).

directionsInfo: Please input our address rather than just "Pearl Harbor," as this will take you to the active military base, not the Pearl Harbor Visitor Center.
weatherInfo: Hawaii has two seasons – winter (ho'oilo) and summer (kau wela) – and temperatures don't change drastically the way they do in the mainland United States. During the day, expect temperatures in the mid-70s to the mid-80s all year around. Expect lows in the winter months (November to March) to be around 60 degrees. The Hawaiian winter is also considered the rainy season, and flash floods are not uncommon. You can expect to see lots of rainbows as the rain clears.
name: Pearl Harbor
description: At the Pearl Harbor National Memorial, learn about one of the most pivotal moments in US history: the attack on Pearl Harbor, and the subsequent entry of the United States into World War II.

images.altText: The USS Arizona Memorial in front of the USS Missouri.
images.title: USS Arizona Memorial
images.caption: About 1.4 million people from all over the world visit the USS Arizona Memorial every year.

images.altText: The USS Arizona Memorial
images.title: The USS Arizona and Memorial
images.caption: The USS Arizona is the final resting place for many of the ship's 1,177 crewmen who lost their lives on December 7, 1941. The memorial

images.altText: The USS Utah off the coast of Ford Island
images.title: The USS Utah
images.caption: The USS Utah lays where she fell on the north side of Ford Island. This decision was made in 1944 after several attempts at raising the ship failed. The quiet decision was made to leave the bodies of 58 crewmen onboard, considering them buried at sea.

images.altText: USS Arizona Memorial
images.title: USS Arizona Memorial
images.caption: USS Arizona Memorial and turret

images.altText: Visitors at the USS Arizona Memorial
images.title: USS Arizona Memorial
images.caption: Daily visitation to the USS Arizona Memorial is often more than 4,000 visitors.

images.altText: The USS Oklahoma Memorial
images.title: The USS Oklahoma Memorial
images.caption: After receiving seven to nine torpedo hits on the port (left) side, the USS Oklahoma capsized in roughly 20 minutes after the attack began. Over 400 men were trapped inside, of which only 32 were rescued.

directionsInfo: From Kailua-Kona: Take Highway 11 south, approximately 20 miles. Between mileposts 103 and 104, at the Honaunau Post Office, turn right towards the ocean onto Hwy 160. Travel 3.5 miles and turn left at the Pu'uhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park sign. Travel times will vary due to ongoing construction in North Kona.
weatherInfo: The weather in the park is typically hot and sunny with daytime temperatures in the upper 80's. An excellent time to experience the park is in the morning and in the late afternoon when the temperatures are a bit cooler. The park is open daily from 7 a.m. until sunset. However the park does occasionally close because of high winds or dangerous storm conditions. Please check with the visitor center or your hotel for any weather advisories or hazardous conditions on the day of your visit.
name: Pu`uhonua O Hōnaunau
description: Imagine you had just broken the sacred laws, the kapu, and the only punishment was death. Your only chance of survival is to elude your pursuers and reach the Pu'uhonua, a place of refuge. The Pu'uhonua protected the kapu breaker, defeated warriors, as well as civilians during the time of battle. No physical harm could come to those who reached the boundaries of the Pu'uhonua.

images.altText: Hula dancers
images.title: Hula
images.caption: Hula dancers

fullName: Pu`uhonua O Hōnaunau National Historical Park

directionsInfo:
From Keahole (Kona) International Airport:
Head east on HI-19 toward HI-19 26.0 mi
Turn left onto HI-270 0.4 mi
Turn left  0.3 mi
(Approximately 34 minute drive)
weatherInfo: The weather in the park is typically hot and sunny with daytime temperatures in the upper 80's. An excellent time to experience the park is in the morning and in the late afternoon when the temperatures are a bit cooler. The park is open daily from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m. However the park does occasionally close because of high winds or dangerous storm conditions. Please check with the visitor center or your hotel for any weather advisories or hazardous conditions on the day of your visit.
name: Pu`ukoholā Heiau
description: How many places in America can you walk in the footsteps of a king? Where else has a stranded sailor risen up to become a great chief over an entire island? Where else can you experience the culminating event of a people, foretold from centuries past? Where else can you stand on a beach and watch as sharks pass over a submerged temple? Experience all this and much more – only at Pu'ukoholā Heiau!

images.altText: Sun set at Pu'ukohol$#257; Heiau NHS
images.title: Pu'ukohol$#257; Heiau National Historic Site Banner
images.caption: Pelekane Bay sits below the majestic Pu'ukohol$#257; Heiau and Mailekini Heiau

directionsInfo:
From Boise: take I-84 East to exit 216 (Declo); go south on Highway 77 to Conner Creek Junction; turn right (west) on Highway 77 Spur to Almo. The visitor center and the park entrance are south of the post office and businesses.
From Pocatello: take I-86 West to I-84 West to exit 216 and proceed as above.
From Salt Lake City: take I-84 west to exit 245 (Sublette), turn left and go west to Malta. From Malta take Highway 77. Take Highway 77 Spur to Almo.
weatherInfo: City of Rocks is located in south-central Idaho within the northern edge of the Basin and Range geologic province. Outdoor recreation can be pleasant from April through October. Summers are generally dry with 10 to 15 inches of precipitation in winter and spring. Summer temperatures range widely with night time lows occasionally approaching freezing and midday highs nearing 100° F; however, the typical range of low and high temperature is 45-85. Thunderstorms are common in the summer months (June - August)
name: City Of Rocks
description: Emigrants of the California Trail describe the rocks here in vivid detail as "a city of tall spires,” “steeple rocks," and "the silent city." Today, this backcountry byway attracts rock climbers, campers, hikers, hunters, and those with the spirit of adventure. There's inspirational scenery, exceptional opportunities for geologic study, and remnants of the Old West awaiting your discovery.

images.altText: Granite monoliths stand silently, reaching toward a summer sky

images.caption: Campsites are nestled here in the Elephant Rock Basin

images.altText: A climber ascend a granite spire with snowy mountains in the distance

images.altText: Golden aspens mixed with pinyon and juniper blanket this sweeping view of City of Rocks

directionsInfo: Visitor Center and Loop Drive are located 18 miles southwest of Arco, Idaho on U.S. Highway 20/26/93, 24 miles northeast of Carey, Idaho on U.S. Highway 20/26/93, 84 miles from Idaho Falls, and 90 miles from Twin Falls. Physical address is 1266 Craters Loop Road(Lat/Long: 43° 27.711'N/113° 33.7) Access to the main visitor use area is via a paved highway. Unpaved roads provide additional access to the BLM monument and NPS Preserve but should only be utilized by four wheel drive and high clearance vehicles.
weatherInfo: Weather at Craters of the Moon is characterized by hot summers and cold winters. In February, average snow depth ranges from 26 inches at the north end of the monument to just 2 inches at the south end. Intense summer sun bakes the black lava, generating surface temperatures of 170 degrees Fahrenheit and air temperatures in the 90s. Drying winds are a daily occurence, especially in the afternoon, and may reach 15 to 30 miles per hour.
name: Craters Of The Moon
description: Craters of the Moon is a vast ocean of lava flows with scattered islands of cinder cones and sagebrush. We invite you to explore this "weird and scenic landscape" where yesterday's volcanic events are likely to continue tomorrow...

images.altText: moon behind volcanic cones
images.title: Volcanic Cones and Moon
images.caption: Craters of the Moon is out of this world!

images.altText: visitor exploring lava tube cave
images.title: Indian Tunnel
images.caption: The lava tube caves are fun to explore.

images.altText: hikers climbing a volcanic cone
images.title: Spatter Cone
images.caption: Craters of the Moon is famous for its well preserved spatter cones.

images.altText: Students follow a Ranger on a snowshoe walk.
images.title: Snowshoe Walk
images.caption: Craters of the Moon is a winter wonderland that is great for cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.

images.altText: Park Ranger in cave with visitors
images.title: Ranger Guided Walk
images.caption: A wide variety of Ranger guided activities are offered through out the year.

images.altText: Snowhoeing and crosscountry skiers
images.title: Winter Wonderland
images.caption: Snowhoeing and crosscountry skiers enjoy a winter wonderland.

fullName: Craters Of The Moon National Monument & Preserve

directionsInfo:
When visiting Hagerman Fossil Beds NM we recommend you stop at the Visitor Center, located at 221 N State St, to begin your visit. There you get the latest information, see an introductory DVD, view fossils up close, and obtain helpful information about the amenities available in the area.
Hagerman Fossil Beds NM Visitor Center, 221 North State Street, is located along Highway 30 in the town of Hagerman across from the high school.
weatherInfo: Hagerman, Idaho, gets 10 inches of rain per year. On average, there are 213 sunny days per year in Hagerman, Idaho. The July high is around 94 degrees. The January low is 22. Our comfort index, which is based on humidity during the hot months, is a 78 out of 100, where higher is more comfortable. The US average on the comfort index is 44.
name: Hagerman Fossil Beds
description: Do you know horses evolved in North America? The Hagerman Horse, Equus simplicidens, is the first true one toed horse. It's the park's most famous fossil but we have fossil evidence of over two hundred different species. From saber-toothed cat, mastodon, bear, camel, and ground sloth, to much smaller animals like rodents and frogs, the scientific study of Pliocene fossils is the key to Hagerman.

images.caption: Rangers and the Paleo crew excavate an articulated snake.

weatherInfo: The National Geologic Trail is a collection of sites stretched across a four state area, the weather will vary from site to site. Please check the weather for your local region, or the region you'll be visiting, through their respective sites.
name: Ice Age Floods
description:
"At the end of the last Ice Age, some 12,000 to 17,000 years ago, a series of cataclysmic floods occurred in what is now the northwest region of the United States, leaving a lasting mark of dramatic and distinguishing features on the landscape of parts of the States of Montana, Idaho, Washington and Oregon." 

Public Law 111-11, March 30, 2009

images.caption: Dry Lake lake bed and falls in winter

images.altText: A overhead shot of the Dry Falls area
images.title: Dry Falls
images.caption: A beautiful shot from the ledge near the visitor's center in the Dry Falls area.

fullName: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail

directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located inside the National Park Service Mid-West Regional Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.
weatherInfo:
In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks.
 
In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days.

Keep in mind the Trail covers 11 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
name: Lewis & Clark
description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail is approximately 4,900 miles long, extending from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to the mouth of the Columbia River, near present day Astoria, Oregon.  It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition as well as the preparatory section from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to Wood River, Illinois.

images.altText: MWRO office building with arrowhead logo.
images.title: MWRO building
images.caption: Mid-West Regional Office Building and Visitor Center for Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail.

images.altText: Arrowhead logo with bison, tree and mountain.
images.title: Arrowhead
images.caption: National Park Service logo.

images.altText: Logo with silhouette of Lewis and Clark.
images.title: L&C Triangle
images.caption: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Logo.

directionsInfo: Minidoka National Historic Site is located between the towns of Twin Falls and Jerome, Idaho in south central Idaho. There are minimal facilities and services at the site. Many buildings and features that were part of the center are located on private property surrounding the Historic Site. Please do not enter any private property.
weatherInfo: Jerome and Twin Falls, Idaho, gets 10 inches of rain per year. On average, there are 213 sunny days per year here. The July high is around 94 degrees. The January low is 22. Our comfort index, which is based on humidity during the hot months, is a 78 out of 100, where higher is more comfortable. The US average on the comfort index is 44.
name: Minidoka
description: The Pearl Harbor attack intensified existing hostility towards Japanese Americans. As wartime hysteria mounted, President Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066 forcing over 120,000 West Coast persons of Japanese ancestry (Nikkei) to leave their homes, jobs, and lives behind and move to one of ten prison camps spread across the nation all because of their ethnicity.  This is Minidoka's story.

images.altText: Origami cranes twirl on carousel
images.title: Origami Go Around
images.caption: Origami cranes twirl on a colorful carousel.

images.altText: The replicated Minidoka Honor Roll is part of the history at Minidoka NHS.
images.title: The Replicated Minidoka Honor Roll
images.caption: The replicated Minidoka Honor Roll is part of the history at Minidoka NHS.

images.altText: A view from Minidoka through the barbed wire fence.
images.title: View Across the Barbed Wire
images.caption: A view from Minidoka through the barbed wire fence.

images.altText: A view of the Northside Canal and reconstructed barbed wire fence.
images.title: Looking at the northside Canal
images.caption: Looking northeast from the entrance area to the Northside Canal and reconstructed barbed wire fence.

images.altText: An original barrack was retuned to Minidoka and placed on site.
images.title: An Original Barrack Returns to the Site
images.caption: An original barrack was retuned to Minidoka and placed on site.

directionsInfo:
Driving south bound on  U.S. Highway 95 you will find the Visitor Center 10 miles from Lewiston, ID.  Roughly one mile after crossing the Clearwater River you will find the park entrance on your left.

When driving north on U.S. Highway 95 the Visitor Center will be 3 miles north of Lapwai, ID.  The park entrance will be on your right.
weatherInfo:
Elevations in the Park range from 700 feet above sea level to over 8,000, providing a wide range of climatic conditions, that follow the four seasons.
Be prepared for very warm weather in the summer months, in particular in the river valleys. The spring and fall are moderate and comfortable. Winter conditions can be severe in the higher elevations, with snow and ice making travel difficult and dangerous.
Please visit the National Weather Service for comprehensive weather information.
name: Nez Perce
description: For thousands of years the valleys, prairies, mountains, and plateaus of the inland northwest have been home to the nimí·pu· (Nez Perce) people. Extremely resilient, they have adapted and survived the settling of the United States. Explore these places. Learn their stories.

images.altText: Birds in flight across a grassy field.
images.title: Take Flight
images.caption: Birds take flight across a grassy field.

images.altText: Petroglyph carvings on the bank of the Snake River.
images.title: Buffalo Eddy
images.caption: Buffalo Eddy contains many petroglyphs and is considered a ancient crossing place.

images.altText: Colorful painted tipi on green lawn
images.title: Painted Tipi
images.caption: Every morning in the summer Rangers put a tipi on the front lawn of the visitor center. Visitors are always welcome to help.

images.altText: Elder (Mylie Lawyer) sitting in front of Old Buffalo hide tipi.
images.title: Buffalo Hide Tipi
images.caption: The only known remaining complete buffalo hide tipi belonging to a Nez Perce.

images.altText: Horses and riders dressed in native regalia.
images.title: Appaloosa Horse Parade
images.caption: This horse parade was held in the Spalding picnic area during the parks 50th anniversary in 2015.

images.altText: Blue Camas flowers in a prairie field.
images.title: Weippe Camas
images.caption: Camas has been a food staple of the Nez Perce for thousands of years.

directionsInfo: More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states-reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.
weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Oregon National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. The trail passes through seven states.
name: Oregon
description: Imagine yourself an emigrant headed for Oregon: would promises of lush farmlands and a new beginning lure you to leave home and walk for weeks? More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states and serve as reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.

images.altText: A rock buttress with a notch in it surrounded by sagebrush flats.
images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

images.altText: An exhibit with an illustration in front of green trees and a rock ledge.
images.title: Alcove Spring Park Wayside
images.caption: Alcove Spring Park is located in Kansas near Blue Rapids and Marysville.

images.altText: A wagon swale is cut deep into limestone rock with trees in background.
images.title: Guernsey Ruts, Wyoming
images.caption: The Guernsey Ruts in Wyoming feature deeply eroded rock from wagon traffic.

images.altText: A large yellow flowering desert shrub in front of sagebrush and a large rock buttress.
images.title: Split Rock, Wyoming
images.caption: Split Rock was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

images.altText: Two people walk on a green lawn in front of historic fort buildings.
images.title: Fort Laramie, Wyoming
images.caption: Fort Laramie National Historic Site features a replica fort with exhibits, located in eastern Wyoming.

directionsInfo: Yellowstone National Park covers nearly 3,500 square miles in the northwest corner of Wyoming (3% of the park is in Montana and 1% is in Idaho). Yellowstone has five entrance stations, and several are closed to regular vehicles during winter. It takes many hours to drive between these entrances, so be sure to check the status of roads at the entrance you intend to use while planning your trip and before you arrive.
weatherInfo: Yellowstone's weather can vary quite a bit, even in a single day. In the summer, daytime highs can exceed 70F (25C), only to drop 20 or more degrees when a thunderstorm rolls through. It can snow during any month of the year, and winter lows frequently drop below zero, especially at night. Bring a range of clothing options, including a warm jacket and rain gear, even in the summer.
name: Yellowstone
description: On March 1, 1872, Yellowstone became the first national park for all to enjoy the unique hydrothermal wonders. Yellowstone’s abundant and diverse wildlife are as famous as its geysers, with nearly 300 species of birds, 16 species of fish, five species of amphibians, six species of reptiles, and 67 species of mammals roaming the park.

images.altText: Crowd watching Aurum Geyser erupt
images.title: Aurum Geyser
images.caption: Aurum Geyser Erupting

images.altText: People on boardwalk watching Beehive Geyser erupt
images.title: Beehive Geyser
images.caption: Visitors to the Lower Geyser Basin watch Beehive Geyser Erupt.

images.altText: Photo of bison in Lamar Valley
images.title: Bison in Lamar Valley
images.caption: Bison in Lamar Valley

images.altText: Photo of black bear sow with cub
images.title: Black bear sow with cub
images.caption: A sow black bear walks with her cub.

images.altText: A visitor stands on a boardwalk near a hot spring and a lake
images.title: Black Pool
images.caption: Black Pool at the West Thumb Geyser Basin

images.altText: A bull elk bugles
images.title: Bull Elk bugling
images.caption: Bull elk bugling in the fall season at Mammoth Hot Springs.

images.altText: Photo of a wolf howling
images.title: Wolf howling
images.caption: The alpha male of the Canyon wolf pack.

images.altText: People walking down wooden steps in a canyon with waterfall at the bottom
images.title: Red Rock Point of the Grand Canyon
images.caption: Climbing the steps to Red Rock Point in the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone.

images.altText: Photo of cottonwoods and bison along the Lamar River
images.title: Cottonwoods and bison along the Lamar River
images.caption: Fall colors the cottonwoods and bison in the Lamar River Valley

images.altText: People hike along a trail next to a waterfall.
images.title: Exploring the South Rim Trail at Canyon
images.caption: If you are willing to walk a little ways, you can find some extraordinary views of the Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone, like this trail on the South Rim.

images.altText: Visitors walk into rustic building
images.title: Fishing Bridge Museum
images.caption: The Fishing Bridge Museum with it's stone-and-log architecture became a prototype for park buildings all around the country.

images.altText: Brilliant colors of a hot spring
images.title: Grand  Prismatic
images.caption: The bright colors found in Grand Prismatic Spring come from "thermophiles" —microorganisms that thrive in hot temperatures.

images.altText: Geyser erupting

images.caption: Great Fountain Geyser erupts against a blue summer sky.

images.caption: A male grizzly can weigh between 200–700 pounds!

images.altText: Yellowstone Lake Hotel
images.title: Lake Yellowstone Hotel -
images.caption: Lake Hotel opened in 1891 and is the oldest hotel operating in the park!

images.altText: Entrance building with vehicle line.
images.title: North Entrance
images.caption: The North Entrance to Yellowstone is open year-round.

images.altText: A crowd in front of a geyser
images.title: People enjoying a winter eruption of Old Faithful
images.caption: Did you know that you can visit Old Faithful in the winter? You need to take a snowcoach or snowmobile!

images.altText: Visitors walk in front of brightly colored landscape.
images.title: Palette Spring
images.caption: The vibrant colors of Palette Springs are formed by "thermophiles" -- heat-loving organisms.

images.title: Bighorn Sheep
images.caption: Two bighorn rams chew their cud.

directionsInfo:
By car:
The Visitor Center is located at 426 South Seventh Street. Use this address when seeking GPS or on-line directions. The 4-block Lincoln Home Neighborhood is open to pedestrians and closed to vehicles. 
For specific directions go to http://www.nps.gov/liho/planyourvisit/directions.htm
weatherInfo: Temperatures can range from 0 degrees Fahrenheit in the winter to 95+ degrees in the summer. High humidity is common during the summer months.
name: Lincoln Home
description: Abraham Lincoln believed in the ideal that everyone in America should have the opportunity to improve his/her economic and social condition.  Lincoln’s life was the embodiment of that idea.  We know him as the sixteenth president but he was also a spouse, parent, and neighbor who experienced the same hopes, dreams, and challenges of life that are still experienced by many people.

images.altText: Lincoln Home with snow
images.title: Lincoln Home in winter
images.caption: Lincoln Home during a snowstorm

images.altText: Lincoln Home surrounded by trees in autumn

images.title: Lincoln Home at night
images.caption: Lincoln Home at night
