images.title: Lincoln Home
images.caption: Thousands of visitors tour Lincoln Home every year

directionsInfo: The Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail crosses five states following the route the Pioneer Company of 1846-1847 established from Nauvoo, Illinois, to Salt Lake City, Utah, covering about 1,300 miles.
weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Oregon National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. The trail passes through seven states.
name: Mormon Pioneer
description: Explore the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail across five states to see the 1,300-mile route traveled by Mormons who fled Nauvoo, Illinois, to the Great Salt Lake Valley in 1846-1847.

images.altText: A yellow flowering desert shrub sits in front of sagebrush and a rock buttress.
images.title: Split Rock, Wyoming
images.caption: Split Rock in Wyoming was an important landmark for pioneers.

images.altText: A red rock face with words carved into the face and a green tree on the left.
images.title: Echo Canyon Billboard Rocks, Utah
images.caption: Mormons wrote advertisements in the rock faces in Echo Canyon on the route into Salt Lake City, Utah.

images.altText: People approach a tan rock outcrop surrounded by grass and stormy clouds.
images.title: Porters Rock, Wyoming
images.caption: Visitors approach Porters Rock in Wyoming.

images.altText: A bronze plaque with description on a metal fence surrounding Brigham Young's grave.
images.title: Brigham Young grave, Utah
images.caption: Brigham Young's grave lies in the heart of downtown Salt Lake City, Utah

images.altText: Red cliffs line a highway as seen from a high point with grass in the foreground.
images.title: Echo Canyon, Utah
images.caption: Echo Canyon on the way from Wyoming to Salt Lake City, Utah is both beautiful and historic.

directionsInfo: For detailed directions please visit the park's website.
weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Chicago winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 26 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 72 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is about 36". Snowfall in the winter is moderate with an average total snowfall of about 38".
name: Pullman
description: In a growing Chicago neighborhood, diverse people and stories intertwine. All were seeking opportunity. Some succeeded. Others were limited—by race, gender, or economic status. Their stories came together in Pullman, a planned community famed for its urban design and architecture.

images.altText: Historic Administration Building
images.title: Historic Administration Building
images.caption: Administration Building

images.altText: Clock Tower and Administration Building
images.title: Clock Tower and Administration Building
images.caption: Built in 1880 for the rail car construction factory and executive offices of Pullman's Palace Car Company, this building complex was one of the most beautiful industrial landscapes in America.

images.altText: Hotel Florence Building in Fall.
images.title: Hotel Florence Building
images.caption: The Hotel Florence opened on November 1, 1881 as the hospitality showcase for visitors to George Pullman's "perfect town" of Pullman. The hotel was named for George's favorite daughter, Florence.

images.altText: American flag flying on front porch.
images.title: American Flag
images.caption: The Pullman district also benefits from a diverse and proud residential community.

images.altText: Clock Tower and Administration Building and open field
images.title: Clock Tower and Administration Building
images.caption: Built in 1880 for the rail car construction factory and executive offices of Pullman's Palace Car Company

directionsInfo: The George Rogers Clark National Historical Park is located within the city of Vincennes, Indiana. Evansville is approximately 50 miles to the south and Terre Haute is approximately 50 miles to the north. Highway 41 provides good roads from the north or south. Highway 50 provides access from the east and west. From Hwy 50 east and west or from Hwy 41 from the north use the 6th Street exit. On Hwy 41 from the South use the Willow Street exit. From there follow the blue directional signs for the park.
weatherInfo: The weather in the area is quite typical for the Midwest.  The average temperature for the winter months is the mid-30s, but the summers can often be hot and humid with temperatures reaching into the 90s.
name: George Rogers Clark
description: The British flag would not be raised above Fort Sackville Feb. 25, 1779. At 10 a.m., the garrison surrendered to American Colonel George Rogers Clark. His American army, aided by French residents of the Illinois country, had marched through freezing floodwaters to gain this victory. The fort’s capture assured United States claims to the frontier, an area nearly as large as the original 13 states.

images.altText: George Rogers Clark Memorial entrance
images.title: George Rogers Clark Memorial
images.caption: Thousands of visitors ascend the steps of the Clark Memorial and gain a glimpse of the heroic eagle above the entrance doors.

images.altText: Sun setting behind the Francis Vigo Statue
images.title: Francis Vigo Statue
images.caption: At the end of each day, visitors gather in the shadow of Vigo to watch the sun set over the Wabash River

images.altText: Sun setting behind the Clark Memorial
images.title: Clark Memorial at Sunset
images.caption: Many people enjoy watching the sun set behind the George Rogers Clark Memorial on the banks of the Wabash River

fullName: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park

directionsInfo: Visitors can access the national park via Interstate 94, the Indiana Toll Road (Interstate 80/90), U.S. Highway 12, U.S. Highway 20, Indiana State Road 49, and various other local roads. The Indiana Dunes Visitor Center is located on Indiana State Road 49, between U.S. Highway 20 and Interstate 94 (1215 North State Road 49, Porter, IN 46304). For a driving map to the Indiana Dunes Visitor Center or other locations, check out our maps page.
weatherInfo: On average, the warmest month is July and the highest recorded temperature was 105F in 1934. The coolest month is January, with the lowest recorded temperature of -25F in 1985. June sees the most precipitation with an average rainfall of 4.66 Inches.
name: Indiana Dunes
description: Indiana Dunes National Park hugs 15 miles of the southern shore of Lake Michigan and has much to offer. Whether you enjoy scouting for rare species of birds or flying kites on the sandy beach, the national park's 15,000 acres will continually enchant you.  Hikers will enjoy 50 miles of trails over rugged dunes, mysterious wetlands, sunny prairies, meandering rivers and peaceful forests.

images.title: Mnoké Prairie in Bloom
images.caption: Mnoké Prairie

directionsInfo:
From the east or west - From Interstate 64, exit onto US 231, (exit 57A). Travel south on US 231 to Indiana Highway 162. Take the Santa Claus/Gentryville exit. Turn west (right) on Indiana Highway 162; go 1-1/2 miles to the park entrance on the right.

From the north or south - From US 231 take the Santa Claus/Gentryville exit. Turn west on Indiana Highway 162; go 1-1/2 miles to the park entrance on the right.
weatherInfo: Southern Indiana has a moderate climate, characterized by warm, yet moist conditions. Summers are usually warm, and winters cool. Much of the area's average 46 inches of precipitation falls in spring, the rainiest season.
name: Lincoln Boyhood
description: Abraham Lincoln grew from youth to manhood on this southern Indiana soil.  Many character and moral traits of one of the world's most respected leaders was formed and nurtured here.  Explore Lincoln's boyhood and learn about the boy who would one day become the leader of our nation.

images.altText: Park ranger is period dress standing near fireplace cooking in the cabin.
images.title: Cabin at Living Historical Farm
images.caption: Park rangers depict pioneer life in the 1820s.

images.altText: Bronze casting on the ground covering bottom logs of a cabin and fireplace.
images.title: Cabin Site Memorial
images.caption: The site of what is believed Memorial at the site of the third Lincoln cabin.

images.altText: Cabin and smokehouse in the fall
images.title: Lincoln Living Historical Farm
images.caption: Replica cabin at re-created 1820s homestead which is on four of the original 160 acres owned by Thomas LIncoln.

images.altText: White marble headstone of Nancy Hanks Lincoln
images.title: Gravesite of Nancy Hanks Lincoln
images.caption: The headstone, erected in 1879, marks the burial spot of Abraham Lincoln's mother, who died of milk sickness in 1818.

images.altText: Memorial Building
images.title: Memorial Visitor Center
images.caption: Memorial Building contains memorial halls to remember Abraham Lincoln and his family.

directionsInfo: Located 3 miles north of Marquette, Iowa on Hwy 76.
weatherInfo: All four seasons are represented in this area with summer temperature in the upper 80’s with higher heat indexes due to humidity and winter daytime highs in the 20's. Temperatures are in °Fahrenheit.
name: Effigy Mounds
description: The mounds preserved here are considered sacred by many Americans, especially the Monument's 20 culturally associated American Indian tribes. A visit offers opportunities to contemplate the meanings of the mounds and the people who built them. The 200 plus American Indian mounds are located in one of the most picturesque sections of the Upper Mississippi River Valley.

images.altText: Bear Effigy Mounds with visitor walking nearby.
images.title: Marching Bear in Spring
images.caption: Marching Bear Mound Group in summer.

images.altText: Scenic view of the steep bluffs adjacent to the Mississippi River as trees start to change color.
images.title: Scenic Overlook at Fire Point
images.caption: Scenic overlook from the popular Fire Point Trail overlooking the Mississippi River and Driftless area bluffs.

images.altText: Three conical mounds in a foggy morning setting.
images.title: Mounds on a Foggy Morning
images.caption: Three Conical mounds along the Fire Point Trail during a foggy morning.

images.altText: Circular mounds in a single line.
images.title: Conical Mounds Leading to Fire Point
images.caption: Follow a line of conical mounds that will lead you out to Fire Point which overlooks the Mississippi River.

directionsInfo: Take exit 254 off Interstate 80 to West Branch, Iowa. The Visitor Center is 0.3 mile north of Interstate 80.
weatherInfo: Spring and fall are mild with moderate temperatures. Average high temperatures in the spring and fall are between 50° and 60° F, with lows from 40° F to 50° F. Summer is hot and humid with average highs around 85° F. Winter can be cold, windy, and snowy with highs averaging 30° F or lower. Rain and thunderstorms are most frequent in the spring and summer.
name: Herbert Hoover
description: Orphaned at age nine, Herbert Hoover left West Branch never to live here again. In later years, he returned to his humble birthplace to celebrate his long career of public service. A memorial landscape remains to tell his story: how community, hard work, honesty, and usefulness to others opened a world of opportunity— and the presidency of the United States— to a child of simple beginnings.

images.altText: A one story wood frame house has board-and-batten exterior siding and a picket fence painted white.
images.title: Herbert Hoover Birthplace Cottage
images.caption: Herbert Hoover called his humble birthplace "physical proof of the unbounded opportunity of American life."

images.altText: A low brown barn-like building with three large doorways has a large horseshoe on its facade.
images.title: Blacksmith Shop
images.caption: Herbert Hoover's father Jesse owned a blacksmith shop similar to the one at Herbert Hoover NHS.

images.altText: Two marble ledger stones each mark a grave in a semicircular landscaped plot with a flagpole.
images.title: Gravesite of President & Mrs. Hoover
images.caption: Two simple marble slabs mark the graves of Herbert and Lou Henry Hoover.

images.altText: A one-story wooden building painted off-white has two windows and a central doorway.
images.title: Schoolhouse
images.caption: Many rural Midwestern towns like West Branch placed a high value on education.

images.altText: A cast bronze figure of a veiled goddess sits on a throne mounted on a concrete pedestal.
images.title: Statue of Isis
images.caption: The people of Belgium gave Herbert Hoover the statue "Isis, Goddess of Life" in gratitude for his famine relief efforts on their behalf during the First World War.

images.altText: A sprawling one story public building of rough-faced yellowish stone has a white portico entrance.
images.title: Herbert Hoover Presidential Library & Museum
images.caption: Exhibit galleries and archival collections tell of the triumphs and tragedies of Hoover’s long career in public service.

images.altText: Two doorways, one on either side, of a broad white wood frame building divides the sexes.
images.title: Friends Meetinghouse
images.caption: The plainly appointed Friends Meetinghouse and the practices within express Quaker values of peace, simplicity, integrity, and service to others.

directionsInfo: The site is located in downtown Topeka, Kansas at 1515 SE Monroe Street.
weatherInfo: Kansas has a temperate but continental climate, with great extremes between summer and winter temperatures but few long periods of extreme hot or cold.
name: Brown v. Board of Education
description: The story of Brown v. Board of Education, which ended legal segregation in public schools, is one of hope and courage. When the people agreed to be plaintiffs in the case, they never knew they would change history. The people who make up this story were ordinary people. They were teachers, secretaries, welders, ministers and students who simply wanted to be treated equally.

images.altText: Monroe School and park visitor center
images.title: Monroe Elementary School
images.caption: Monroe Elementary School, was one of the four segregated elementary schools for African American children in Topeka

images.altText: Historic classroom image, 1949
images.title: Monroe Classroom
images.caption: Monroe School Class Photo 1949

images.altText: Front entrance to Monroe school
images.title: Exterior of Monroe School
images.caption: Front entrance to historic Monroe school.

images.altText: Brown v Board National Hsitoric Site
images.title: Brown v Board NHS Exterior
images.caption: The Monroe Elementary School Building.

images.altText: Visitors join a national park program around the Monroe school building and grounds
images.title: National park programs
images.caption: Visitors join a national park program around the Monroe school building and grounds

fullName: Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site

directionsInfo: Fort Larned National Historic Site is located on KS Hwy 156, six miles west of Larned, Kansas.
weatherInfo: Central Kansas has a four-season climate. Winter tends to be cold and dry, with average daytime highs below 40F (4C). Foehn winds blowing across the Great Plains from the Southwest periodically raise temperatures above 80F (27C). Unsettled warmer air, higher winds, and severe weather arrive in the spring and often last through early July. Late summer days hover above 90F (32C) and readings over 100F (38C) are not uncommon. Fall is variable but generally milder with showers changing to snow and ice later.
name: Fort Larned
description: Discover a complete and authentic army post from the 1860s -1870s! This well-preserved fort on the Santa Fe Trail shares a tumultuous history of the Indian Wars era. The sandstone constructed buildings sheltered troops who were known as the Guardians of the Santa Fe Trail.

images.altText: Sandstone army buildings arranged in a square around parade ground.
images.title: Aerial Photo of Fort Larned
images.caption: The historic sandstone buildings at Fort Larned date to 1868

images.altText: Man in leather apron hammering hot steel in blacksmith shop.
images.title: Blacksmith Demonstrations at Fort Larned
images.caption: The blacksmith demonstration is one of the most popular living history demonstrations.

images.altText: Men in 19th century U.S. Army uniforms fire a reproduction period cannon.
images.title: Artillery Demonstration
images.caption: Volunteers demonstrating the use of a mountain howitzer during one of Fort Larned's living history weekends.

images.altText: Men in 19th century U.S. Army uniforms lower an American flag.
images.title: Flag Retreat
images.caption: Volunteers help recreate the U.S. Army flag lowering ceremony known as Retreat.

images.altText: Man in 19th century U.S. Army uniform interacts with visitors in period barracks.
images.title: Visitors in the Barracks
images.caption: A volunteer shows visitors how soldiers lived during the 1860s at Fort Larned.

images.altText: Three young children having their picture taken with Santa Claus in a period room.
images.title: Visiting Santa
images.caption: Young visitors get their picture taken with Santa during the fort's Christmas Past event.

images.altText: African American men in 19th century cavalry uniforms on horseback.
images.title: Buffalo Soldiers
images.caption: Buffalo Soldier re-enactors help bring Fort Larned's history to life.

directionsInfo:
Fort Scott National Historic Site is located in downtown Fort Scott, Kansas. U.S. Highways 69 and 54 intersect here. Fort Scott is about 90 miles south of Kansas City and 60 miles northwest of Joplin, Missouri. It is 4 miles from the Kansas-Missouri border.

Signs directing visitors to Fort Scott are posted on highway 69 for visitors coming from the north and the south and on highway 54 for visitors coming from the east and the west. Highway 69 between Fort Scott and Kansas City is a four lane highway,
weatherInfo: Spring and autumn are pleasant with mild temperatures. Summers are generally hot and humid, while winters are mild with periods of cold weather, snowfall, and ice storms. Thunderstorms, some severe, are common throughout the spring and summer. During periods of severe weather, visitors should seek shelter, as the area is prone to lightning strikes Visitors are advised to check the weather prior to traveling.
name: Fort Scott
description: Promises made and broken! A town attacked at dawn! Thousands made homeless by war! Soldiers fighting settlers! Each of these stories is a link in the chain of events that encircled Fort Scott from 1842-1873. All of the site's structures, its parade ground, and its tallgrass prairie bear witness to this era when the country was forged from a young republic into a united transcontinental nation.

images.altText: A field of sunflowers next to a stone building.  Wood frame structures in background.
images.title: Sunflowers at Fort Scott
images.caption: A field of sunflowers adds a splash of color to a view of the parade ground at Fort Scott.

images.altText: Wood frame structures with stairs next to a stone walkway. Structures reflect afternoon sunlight.
images.title: Officers Quarters at Sunset
images.caption: Officers quarters at Fort Scott bathed in the light of the afternoon sun.

images.caption: Soldiers on horseback patrolling the prairie

images.caption: High school students dressed as laundresses demonstrate laundry methods of the 1840s

directionsInfo: Nicodemus National Historic Site is located in northwestern Kansas on Highway 24 between Hill City and Stockton.
weatherInfo:
Northwest Kansas has a four season climate typified by long, hot summers, cold winters, short spring and fall seasons, and nearly constant breeze. Humidity is relatively low compared to the eastern portion of the state.

Afternoon thunderstorms with lightning, hail, and gusty winds frequently occur during the spring and summer. Tornados are possible but are less common in Kansas than they are in several other states. In the event of a tornado seek shelter immediately. Winter snow accumulation is usually l
name: Nicodemus
description: Formerly enslaved African Americans left Kentucky in organized colonies at the end of the of post-Civil War Reconstruction period to experience freedom in the "promised land" of Kansas. Nicodemus represents the involvement of African Americans in the westward expansion and settlement of the Great Plains. It is the oldest and only remaining Black settlement west of the Mississippi River.

images.altText: District #1 Schoolhouse
images.title: District #1 Schoolhouse
images.caption: Nicodemus was the first school district in Graham County, Kansas. They first met in dugouts, and then in a frame building. The current building was built in the early 1900's after a fire destroyed the previous one.

images.title: The First Baptist Church
images.caption: Church seen through a field of prairie grass.

images.title: Township Hall
images.caption: The Township Hall on a beautiful Spring day.

weatherInfo: Typical weather for the preserve ranges from lows of zero in the winter and highs of 90 + degrees in the summer. Please check current weather conditions at NOAA before hiking into the preserve. Lightning poses a danger when hiking into the prairie.
name: Tallgrass Prairie
description: Where's the tall grass? Tallgrass prairie once covered 170 million acres of North America. Within a generation the vast majority was developed and plowed under. Today less than 4% remains, mostly here in the Kansas Flint Hills. The preserve protects a nationally significant remnant of the once vast tallgrass prairie and its cultural resources. Here the tallgrass prairie makes its last stand.

images.altText: fall wildflowers at the preserve
images.title: Fall wildflowers at the preserve
images.caption: Fall is the season for another assortment of color on the prairie

images.caption: Historic 1881 Spring Hill Ranch house

directionsInfo: The Birthplace Unit of the park is located approximately 2 miles south of the town of Hodgenville on U.S. Highway 31E South. The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek is located approximately 10 miles northeast of the Birthplace Unit of the park.
weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in Central Kentucky. However, temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer is usually hot and humid. Winter is moderately cold with mixed precipitation.
name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace
description: For over a century people from around the world have come to rural Central Kentucky to honor the humble beginnings of our 16th president, Abraham Lincoln.  His early life on Kentucky's frontier shaped his character and prepared him to lead the nation through Civil War.  The country's first memorial to Lincoln, built with donations from young and old, enshrines the symbolic birthplace cabin.

images.altText: The Memorial Building surrounded by fall colors
images.title: The Memorial Building with fall colors
images.caption: Over 200,000 people a year come to walk up the steps of the Memorial Building to visit the site where Abraham Lincoln was born

images.altText: The first memorial erected to honor Abraham Lincoln
images.title: The Memorial Building
images.caption: The Memorial Building constructed on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

images.altText: The symbolic birth cabin on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
images.title: The Symbolic Birth Cabin of Abraham Lincoln
images.caption: The symbolic birth cabin of Abraham Lincoln.

images.altText: Statue of the Lincoln family in the park's Visitor Center
images.title: Statue of the Lincoln Family in the Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors to the park can view the statue of the Lincoln family.

fullName: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park

directionsInfo: Please use the following link to learn more about how to get here from various locations.
weatherInfo: The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
name: Big South Fork
description: Encompassing 125,000 acres of the Cumberland Plateau, Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area protects the free-flowing Big South Fork of the Cumberland River and its tributaries. The area boasts miles of scenic gorges and sandstone bluffs, is rich with natural and historic features and has been developed to provide visitors with a wide range of outdoor recreational activities.

images.altText: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.title: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.caption: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall

fullName: Big South Fork National River & Recreation Area

directionsInfo: Camp Nelson National Monument is located along US 27 about 20 miles south of Lexington, Kentucky, 6 miles south of Nicholasville on US 27, and 7.5 miles southeast of Wilmore along US 1268. The Park entrance is on the original Danville Pike, adjacent to US 27, one mile north of the Camp Nelson National Cemetery.
weatherInfo: Kentucky has a moderate climate, characterized by warm, yet moist conditions. Summers are usually warm, and winters cool. Kentucky's weather patterns are influenced by the Gulf of Mexico, especially during summer. Spring and summer are the rainiest seasons, though storms occur year-round. Most storms occur between March and September.
name: Camp Nelson
description: Established as a Union supply depot and hospital during the Civil War, Camp Nelson became a recruitment and training center for African American soldiers, and a refugee camp for their wives and children. Thousands of slaves risked their lives escaping to this site with the hope of securing their freedom and, ultimately, controlling their futures by aiding in the destruction of slavery.

images.altText: The visitor center building
images.title: Camp Nelson Civil War Heritage Park Visitor Center
images.caption: The Camp Nelson Civil War Heritage Park Visitor Center

images.altText: A row of rough, wooden bunk beds in the soldiers' barrack house.
images.title: Interior of Soldiers' Barrack Building
images.caption: Visit the barracks to imagine life at Camp Nelson during the Civil War.

images.altText: A white, 2 story farm house with a Civil War cannon sitting in front of it
images.title: Perry House
images.caption: The Perry House at Camp Nelson

images.altText: African American Civil War soldiers stand at attention outside their barracks.
images.title: United States Colored Troops at Camp Nelson, KY during the Civil War
images.caption: African American Civil War soldiers fighting for the Union stand at attention outside their barracks at Camp Nelson, KY.

images.altText: Open fields and earth works at Camp Nelson
images.title: Open fields and earth works at Camp Nelson National Monument in Kentucky.
images.caption: Open fields and earth works at Camp Nelson National Monument in Kentucky.

directionsInfo:
By Plane
The closest major airport is located in Knoxville, Tennessee approximately 85 miles away.  Flights can also be made into Lexington, Kentucky approximately 130 miles away.

By Car
The park entrance is located on Highway 25E just south of Middlesboro Kentucky.
weatherInfo:
Summers at Cumberland Gap are hot and humid, with temperatures commonly in the mid to upper 90s.

Winters are generally mild with rain and some periods of snow January through March. Temperatures usually range in the 30s and 40s. Weather can sometimes be unpredictable, especially at higher elevations.
name: Cumberland Gap
description: At Cumberland Gap, the first great gateway to the west, follow the buffalo, the Native American, the longhunter, the pioneer... all traveled this route through the mountains into the wilderness of Kentucky. Modern day explorers and travelers stand in awe at this great gateway and the many miles of trails and scenic features found in the park.

images.altText: Cleopatra's Pool in the Gap Cave
images.title: Gap Cave
images.caption: Cleopatra's Pool is located deep in the Gap Cave

images.altText: View from the Pinnacle Overlook
images.title: Mountain View
images.caption: View from the Pinnacle Overlook

images.altText: Hensley Settlement
images.title: Hensley Settlement
images.caption: Weathered log cabins greet visitors to Hensley Settlement

images.altText: Pioneers
images.title: Pioneers Crossing Creek
images.caption: History comes alive

directionsInfo:
Fort Donelson's main entrance is located along Highway 79, in Dover Tennessee. It is advised to start a visitor experience here.

(From December 7, 2015 until announced, Fort Donelson's temporary visitor center will be at the Stewart County Visitor Center, 117 Visitor Center Lane, Dover, TN, 37058).

Physical address for the park's Fort Heiman unit, in Calloway County, Kentucky (unstaffed and in development): 682 Fort Heiman Road, New Concord, Kentucky.
weatherInfo: Fort Donelson National Battlefield traditionally experiences mild to moderate winters and hot summers with an average high of 90 degrees in the summer and 40 in winter; average lows in the winter are 30 degrees but single digits are not unusual. Rainfall in the area averages 53 inches a year with an additional 6 inches of ice/snow and violent thunderstorms can take place at any time of year.
name: Fort Donelson
description: Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant was becoming quite famous as he wrote these words following the surrender of Confederate Fort Donelson on Sunday, February 16, 1862. The Union victory at Fort Donelson elated the North, and stunned the South. Within days of the surrender, Clarksville and Nashville would fall into Union hands. Grant and his troops had created a pathway to victory for the Union.

images.altText: Sunset on the Cumberland River
images.title: The Dover Hotel
images.caption: The Dover Hotel, the headquarters of General Simon B. Buckner (CSA), and location of the Confederate surrender.

images.altText: The View from the Upper River Battery
images.title: Upper River Battery
images.caption: During the battle, the Confederate forces had a commanding view of the Cumberland River.

images.altText: Cannon drills during the 154th anniversary of the Battle of Fort Donelson
images.title: Cannon Drills
images.caption: Members of the 9th Kentucky re-enactment group demonstrate cannon drills for the public.

images.altText: Confederate earthworks.
images.title: Confederate Trenches
images.caption: A view of the Confederate trenches, where Confederate Soldiers once stood watch.

images.altText: Hallowed ground.
images.title: Fort Donelson National Cemetery
images.caption: The Fort Donelson National Cemetery, final resting place for Soldiers who fell in battle during the Civil War, the Spanish-American War, World War I, and World War II.

directionsInfo:
DO NOT FOLLOW YOUR GPS!

From the North: Take Interstate 65 to Exit 53 (Cave City Exit). Turn right onto KY-70. Follow 70/255 as it becomes the Mammoth Cave Parkway in the park. Follow the Mammoth Cave Parkway to the Visitor Center.

From the South: Take Interstate 65 to Exit 48 (Park City Exit). Turn left onto KY-255 and follow 255 as it becomes the Park City Road into the park. Follow Park City Road until it joins the Mammoth Cave Parkway; turn left. Follow the Mammoth Cave Parkway to the Visitor Center.
weatherInfo: Kentucky has a moderate climate with warm, yet moist conditions. Summers average in the high 80s; winters average in the low 40s. Southern Kentucky, where Mammoth Cave is located, receives the highest average precipitation for the state, about 50 inches per year, mostly in spring. Winter can bring mild to moderate snow and ice. Storms happen year-round, and can include tornadoes and flooding in low-lying areas, but severe weather is infrequent. The temperature deep in the cave is a constant 54°F (12°C).
name: Mammoth Cave
description: Mammoth Cave National Park preserves the cave system and a part of the Green River valley and hilly country of south central Kentucky. This is the world's longest known cave system, with more than 400 miles (643 km) explored. Early guide Stephen Bishop called the cave a "grand, gloomy and peculiar place," but its vast chambers and complex labyrinths have earned its name - Mammoth.

images.altText: A ranger explains the cave to visitors in the vast expanse of the passage called Broadway.
images.title: Broadway in Mammoth Cave
images.caption: A ranger explains Mammoth Cave in the vast passage known as Broadway. Rotunda, one of the cave's largest rooms, is just ahead.

images.altText: Dripstone formations create a panoply of textures in the Frozen Niagara section of Mammoth Cave
images.title: Mammoth Cave - Dripstone Wall
images.caption: Dripstone formations create a panoply of textures in the Frozen Niagara section of Mammoth Cave as slowly dripping water redeposits dissolved limestone over the course of centuries. Image is a panoramic composite.

images.altText: A girl peers wonderingly into the shadows of Mammoth Cave.
images.title: Wonder in Mammoth Cave
images.caption: Mammoth Cave's shadows have beckoned the explorer deep within its visitors for geneerations, asking the question "Where does that lead? What lies in the dark places?" The questions remain as compelling today as they did for the first explorers.

images.altText: A kayaker paddles up the languid waters of the Green River in Mammoth Cave National Park.
images.title: Green River in Mammoth Cave National Park
images.caption: More than 30 miles of the Green and Nolin Rivers course through Mammoth Cave NP, representing one of the most biologically diverse river systems in the Eastern United States. Their languid waters are a magnet for canoeist, kayakers and anglers.

images.altText: A layer of fog hangs over a small group gathered to enter Mammoth Cave on a summer day.
images.title: Fog at Mammoth Cave Entrance
images.caption: A layer of mist hangs over a small tour group gathered at the Historic Entrance of Mammoth Cave on a summer day - it both delights the skin and fogs spectacles, and gives a sense that one is on the threshold of another world.

images.altText: Frances Benjamin Johnston and her photographic expedition enter Mammoth Cave in 1892.
images.title: Frances Benjamin Johnston Enters Mammoth Cave in 1892
images.caption: Frances Benjamin Johnston and her photographic expedition enter the Historic Entrance of Mammoth Cave, 1892.

directionsInfo: There are several visitor locations in the Atchafalaya NHA, please visit www.atchafalaya.org for exact locations and directions.
weatherInfo: The weather varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov for forecast information.
name: Atchafalaya
description: Our country’s landscape is rich and mysterious.  It is filled with twisting bayous, rivers and America’s largest river swamp.  We have fields of sugar cane and cotton, ancient live oaks and towering cypress.  Alligators, raccoons, and even bears roam our lands while 270 species of birds take to our skies.  From our waters come catfish, shrimp, oysters and the crawfish that make us so well known.

images.altText: Atchafalaya Basin
images.title: Atchafalaya Basin
images.caption: Atchafalaya Basin

directionsInfo:
To reach Oakland Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 127, Flora/Cypress. Head east on LA Highway 120 toward Cypress. Cross over LA Highway 1 onto LA Highway 494. The parking lot and entrance pavilion for Oakland is 4.5 miles east of Highway 1 on the left.

To reach the grounds of Magnolia Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 119, Derry. Head east on LA Highway 119. Cross over LA Highway 1 and proceed for 1.1 miles. The parking area of Magnolia Plantation is on the right just before the road closure..
weatherInfo: Weather in central Louisiana can be unpredictable. Summers are hot and humid. Winter is relatively mild with measurable snowfall every 5-10 years. Average rainfall is approximately 55-60 inches per year. The area is also subject to severe thunderstorms, hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes. Visitors might want to bring hats, umbrellas, and drink plenty of water. Please check the local weather forecast before planning your visit to the park.
name: Cane River Creole
description: The Cane River region is home to a unique culture; the Creoles. Generations of the same families of owners and workers, enslaved and tenant, lived on these lands for over 200 years. The park tells their stories and preserves the cultural landscape of Oakland and Magnolia Plantations, two of the most intact Creole cotton plantations in the United States.

images.altText: Magnolia quarters
images.title: Fall perennials in front of Magnolia Quarters
images.caption: Magnolia plantation quarters were once occupied by the enslaved; they were used in the 20th century by sharecroppers.

images.altText: Yellow canna lilies
images.title: Yellow canna lilies
images.caption: Yellow canna lilies grow in the bottle garden in front of the Oakland main house.

images.altText: Japanese Magnolia
images.title: Japanese Magnolia
images.caption: Every January, our Japanese Magnolia blooms its splendor pink.

images.altText: Sunrise over Oakland
images.title: Sunrise
images.caption: The golden sunrise casts a shadow over the buildings

images.altText: Slave/Tenant quarters
images.title: Slave/Tenant quarters
images.caption: One of two existing Slave /Tenant quarters at Oakland Plantation.

images.altText: Bike Rides
images.title: Bike Rides
images.caption: Cane River is a great place to take a ride and learn some history; the park offers rides year-round.

images.altText: Vintage chairs on the cabin porch at Magnolia Plantation
images.title: Magnolia Quarters
images.caption: Magnolia Plantation provides a quiet spot for contemplation.

fullName: Cane River Creole National Historical Park

directionsInfo: Cane River National Heritage Area in northwestern Louisiana is a largely rural, agricultural landscape known for its historic plantations, its distinctive Creole architecture, and its multi-cultural legacy. The central corridor of the heritage area begins just south of Natchitoches, and extends along both sides of Cane River Lake for approximately 35 miles.  The heritage area includes Cane River Creole National Historical Park, seven National Historic Landmarks, three State Historic Sites, and other places.
weatherInfo: Weather in central Louisiana can be unpredictable. Summers are typically hot and humid, and winters are relatively mild. The area is also subject to severe thunderstorms, hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes. Visitors should be prepared for changing weather conditions.
name: Cane River
description: More than 300-years of history are etched into the rural landscape of colonial forts, plantations, churches, cemeteries, and homes that comprise Cane River National Heritage Area. Historically, this region lay at the intersection of the French and Spanish Realms in the New World, with the town of Natchitoches originating as an important 18th century trade center.

images.altText: Historic house with steep pitched roof, brick walkways leading up to open front porch
images.title: Roque House
images.caption: The Roque House, originally built in 1803, has since been restored and is a great example of French Creole architecture.

images.altText: Large white plantation house with large two story porch
images.title: Melrose Plantation
images.caption: The Melrose Plantation was built in 1833 and offers regular tours.

images.altText: Cotton field with colorful sunset
images.title: Cotton Field
images.caption: Beauty is all around in Natchitoches Parish.

images.altText: Waterway with deck stretching out over water in foreground and homes on other side of water; sunset
images.title: Cane River
images.caption: The Cane River which defines the region is actually an oxbow lake that once was the primary channel of the Red River.

directionsInfo: El Camino Real includes a wide variety of sites and organizations across five states.
weatherInfo:
Due to the length of El Camino de los Tejas National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Here's a link to the South Central US:

www.accuweather.com/en/us/south-central/weather-radar
name: El Camino Real de los Tejas
description: Come on a journey that will carry you through 300 years of Louisiana and Texas frontier settlement and development on a Spanish colonial "royal road" that originally extended to Mexico City, Mexico.

images.altText: Mexican mission stands in the dirt
images.title: Mission San Bernardo ruins, Guerrero, Coahuila, Mexico
images.caption: Construction of the mission church began in 1760 but was never completed. The outstanding ruins are virtually the only visible remains of the complex of missions established in the area. The purpose was to convert Coahuiltecan Indians to Catholicism.

images.altText: lots of greenery along a river; sunflowers in the foreground
images.title: El Paso de Jacinto/Paso de los Indios, Webb County, Texas
images.caption: Around 1746, explorer Jacinto de León discovered a ford that allowed safe passage across the Río Grande in this vicinity; it had probably been used for centuries by American Indians.

images.altText: stone house ruins; briliant green grasses and trees on the right
images.title: Rancho los Ojuelos, Webb County, Texas
images.caption: This national historic district consists of 13 stone houses (several in ruins) constructed from hewn sandstone blocks, chinked and plastered, ranging from rectangular flat roofed Colonial style buildings to hip roofed two room structures. Post-1750s.

images.altText: rock indentations in a dry creek with five people walking under clouds
images.title: McKinney Falls State Park, Travis County, Texas
images.caption: Recent research reveals that in 1716 the expedition of Domingo Ramón followed the left bank of Onion Creek along the western edge of McKinney Falls State Park to its junction with Williamson Creek. You can walk in rock indentations in the creek bed.

images.altText: trail segment indentation with leaves in it, trees along the side
images.title: Mission Tejas State Park, Houston County, Texas
images.caption: This 1.5-mile-long trail segment crosses an area that has remarkable visual integrity. The trail segment courses parallel to State Road 21 and at times crosses the highway.

fullName: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

directionsInfo: Jean Lafitte's headquarters and the park's French Quarter Visitor Center is located at 419 Decatur St. in New Orleans. There are five other park sites scattered throughout south Louisiana. For information on all of the park sites and visitor centers, see the Directions URL.
weatherInfo:
All temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit. Note that relative humidity, especially in summer months, can reach 90%, so temperatures can feel 10-20 degrees hotter than actual temperature.
Spring (March, April, May) average high 77, low 61
Summer (June, July, August) average high 89, low 75
Fall (September, October, November) average high 78, low 64
Winter (December, January, February) average high 64, low 48
name: Jean Lafitte
description: In Jean Lafitte's day, silver and gold filled a pirate's treasure chest, but today's treasures are people, places, and memories. Discover New Orleans’ rich cultural mix. Learn Cajun traditions from people who live them. Watch an alligator bask on a bayou’s bank. Walk in the footsteps of the men who fought at 1815’s Battle of New Orleans. Follow the link to discover the treasure of Jean Lafitte.

images.altText: Spanish moss hangs from live oak tree
images.title: Barataria Preserve of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Spanish moss and lush vegetation provide glimpses of Louisiana's wild wetlands at Jean Lafitte's Barataria Preserve.

images.altText: An oak tree arches over a cannon-guarded rampart with historic house and American flag in background
images.title: Chalmete Battlefield at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Chalmette Battlefield's American rampart and cannons still guard the site of the Battle of New Orleans in 1815.

images.altText: Setting sun lights up cemetery headstones
images.title: Chalmette National Cemetery at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Established during the Civil War, Chalmette National Cemetery's 14,000+ headstones pay tribute to those buried there.

images.altText: Visitor center exhibit titled "Crossroads of Cultures"
images.title: French Quarter Visitor Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Hundreds of years of history and thousands of people from all over the world have created New Orleans' distinctive cultural mix.

images.altText: Model of an early Acadian home sits in a glass case
images.title: Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Bringing skills and traditions from Nova Scotia, the Acadian exiles in Louisiana found a new home and a new name---Cajuns.

images.altText: Center exhibit with glass display cases and photos
images.title: Prairie Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: The Acadians (Cajuns) who settled Louisiana's Cajun prairies were cowboys, farmers, and ranchers.

images.altText: Exhibit case full of musical instruments
images.title: Wetlands Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.caption: Acadian (Cajun) music began in cabins and dancehalls and has become famous worldwide.

fullName: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve

directionsInfo: The park's main visitor center is in New Orleans' French Quarter, near the Mississippi River levee on North Peters Street between Dumaine Street and St. Phillip Street. The park also produces educational concerts at the New Orleans Jazz Museum at 400 Esplanade Avenue.
weatherInfo:
All temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit. Note that relative humidity, especially in summer months, can reach 90%, so temperatures can feel 10-20 degrees hotter than actual temperature.
Spring (March, April, May) average high 77, low 61
Summer (June, July, August) average high 89, low 75
Fall (September, October, November) average high 78, low 64
Winter (December, January, February) average high 64, low 48
name: New Orleans Jazz
description: Only in New Orleans could there be a National Park for jazz! Drop by our visitor center at 916 North Peters St. to inquire about musical events around town. In the mood for a world class musical experience? Attend a jazz concert or ranger performance at the new state of the art performance venue on the 3rd floor of the New Orleans Jazz Museum.

images.altText: Exhibit titled "What Is New Orleans Jazz?"
images.title: Visitor Center Exhibit at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: "What is New Orleans Jazz?" A visit to the park's main visitor center at 916 North Peters Street will answer the question.

images.altText: Kids and adults playing instruments on a stage
images.title: Visitor Center Concert at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: Passing jazz traditions from one generation to the next is an important part of the park's mission---and great listening too!

images.altText: Singer with jazz band, including park rangers
images.title: US Mint Concert by New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: The park's state-of-the-art concert space at the Old US Mint is the perfect place to enjoy some jazz.

images.altText: Rangers and others sing and play on a stage
images.title: US Mint Voting Rights Act Program at New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: Programs like this celebration of the Voting Rights Act bring together history, culture, and music.

images.altText: A young brass band musician plays a trumpet
images.title: Community Events by New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
images.caption: The park works with local partners to share jazz at community events, festivals, and other venues.

fullName: New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park

directionsInfo: By car, from Interstate 20, take the Delhi exit and travel north on LA 17, east on LA 134 and north on LA 577.
weatherInfo:
Summers are sunny, hot, and humid. Winters tend to be mild; however, humid rainy periods occur throughout the year. Sudden and severe thunderstorms are common, so stay alert to weather forecasts. Check with rangers at the Visitor Center and/or USS Cairo Museum for updates on weather patterns.

Wear comfortable sportswear appropriate for the season, with walking or hiking shoes recommended.
name: Poverty Point
description: Now a nearly forgotten culture, Poverty Point at its peak 3,000 years ago was part of an enormous trading network that stretched for hundreds of miles across the continent. It was - and is - also an engineering marvel, the product of five million hours of labor. Explore the culture of a highly sophisticated people who left behind one of North America’s most important archeological sites.

images.altText: A grassy green mound.
images.title: Bird Mound
images.caption: A grassy green mound.

images.altText: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.
images.title: Bird Mound
images.caption: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.

images.altText: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.
images.title: Bird Mound
images.caption: Bird Mound - a grassy green mound.

directionsInfo:
Plane —
Closest commercial airport:
Jackson, MS, 50 miles to the east. 

Car —
Directions to Vicksburg:
From the east — Take Interstate 20 west to Vicksburg, MS. Use exit ramp 4B. Follow Clay Street (US-80) west 0.25 miles to park entrance.

From the north — Take Interstate 55 south to Jackson, MS. To save time, use Interstate 220 bypass on west side of Jackson. Take Interstate 20 west to Vicksburg approximately 40 miles. Use exit ramp 4B. Follow Clay Street (US-80) west 0.25 miles to park entrance.
weatherInfo: Spring and fall in Vicksburg are always very pleasant with cool nights and warm, sunny days with temperatures ranging from lows of 40-50 degrees to highs of 70 degrees. Winter weather in Mississippi is usually mild except for occasional cold air invasions, which normally last only a couple of days. Temperatures range from lows of 30 degrees to highs of 50 degrees. In the summer, weather is consistently hot, beginning in the low 70's and climbing to highs ranging from 80-90 degrees in the afternoon.
name: Vicksburg
description:
To Confederate President Jefferson Davis, Vicksburg was the "nailhead that holds the South's two halves together."  President Abraham Lincoln remarked "Vicksburg is the key" to victory, and could be the north's lifeline into the south.  

As the federals closed in on the Fortress City, they were met by a ring of forts with over 170 cannon. The resulting battle would determine the war's outcome.

images.altText: Union cannon aimed at Confederate lines
images.title: Union Cannon
images.caption: The Union artillery played a major role in the outcome of the Vicksburg Campaign.

images.altText: a headstone is seen in a tree
images.title: Headstone in Tree
images.caption: A headstone in the Vicksburg National Cemetery rest beside a tree.

images.altText: Stars behind the Illinois State Memorial
images.title: Illinois State Memorial
images.caption: Stars gleam behind the Illinois State Memorial.

images.altText: Roses in bloom in front of the Shirley House
images.title: The Shirley House
images.caption: Roses in bloom in front of the Shirley House, the only remaining Civil War structure in the park.

directionsInfo: From Boston take I-95 north to Augusta, Maine, then Route 3 east to Ellsworth, and on to Mount Desert Island. For an alternate route, continue on I-95 north to Bangor, Maine, then take Route 1A east to Ellsworth. In Ellsworth, take Route 3 to Mount Desert Island.
weatherInfo: Located on Mount Desert Island in Maine, Acadia experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 45-90F (7-30C). Fall temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C). Typically the first frost is in mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 73 inches (185 cm). Winter temperatures range from 14-35F (-10 - 2C). Spring temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C).
name: Acadia
description: Acadia National Park protects the natural beauty of the highest rocky headlands along the Atlantic coastline of the United States, an abundance of habitats with high biodiversity, clean air and water, and a rich cultural heritage. Each year, more than 3.3 million people explore seven peaks above 1,000 feet, 158 miles of hiking trails, and 45 miles of carriage roads with 16 stone bridges.

images.altText: Large puffy clouds dot a brilliant blue sky as wave crash against the rocky coastline of Acadia.
images.title: Acadia's rocky coastline
images.caption: Millions of people come to Acadia for our distinctive rocky coastline.

images.altText: A brilliant sunset filled with hues of blue, red, orange, magenta, and purple highlight the sky.
images.title: Sunset atop Cadillac Mountain
images.caption: As the tallest point on the eastern seaboard Cadillac Mountain provides fantastic viewpoints.

images.altText: Two hikers ascend a sheer cliff trail by way of historic iron rung ladders.
images.title: Climbing The Precipice
images.caption: Whether it's a stroll along Ocean Path or a difficult ascent up The Precipice, there are hiking trails for everyone!

images.altText: A man peers into a telescope as the Milky Way lights up the night sky.
images.title: Starviewing
images.caption: With dark skies, Acadia is a fantastic place to come see the stars.

images.altText: Hiking tracks carved through three feet of snow wind through a heavy snow-laden forest.
images.title: Heavy snow-laden trees
images.caption: During the colder months snows transform our landscape into a winter wonderland.

directionsInfo: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument is located in north central Maine approximately a 2-hour drive west of Acadia National Park in Bar Harbor and 1-hour drive north of Bangor, Maine, both of which are served by regional airports.
weatherInfo: Northern Maine experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 45-90F (7-30C). Fall temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C). Typically the first frost is in mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 73 inches (185 cm). Winter temperatures range from 14-35F (-10 - 2C). Spring temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C).
name: Katahdin Woods and Waters
description: Spread across a wild landscape offering spectacular views of Mount Katahdin, Katahdin Woods and Waters invites discovery of its rivers, streams, woods, flora, fauna, geology, and the night skies that have attracted humans for millennia.
fullName: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument

directionsInfo: The Saint John Valley is located in northern Aroostook County, Maine, 200 miles north of Bangor at the northern terminus of ME 1. It is best reached by private vehicle. From Interstate 95, use exits at Sherman or Smyrna Mills for Route 11 to Fort Kent, or the exit at Houlton for U.S. Route 1 North.
weatherInfo: Located in remote northern Maine, Aroostook County experiences all four seasons. Summers temperatures average highs near 75° F (23° C) while winter temperatures average lows often below 0° F (-17° C). Snow falls typically from November through April and averages well over 100 inches of snow per winter.
name: Maine Acadian Culture
description: Maine Acadians share beliefs and experiences tying them to a common religion, languages, and history. The St. John River, land, and family are essential to their culture. The National Park Service supports the Maine Acadian Heritage Council, an association of historical societies, cultural clubs, towns, and museums that work together to support Maine Acadian culture in the St. John Valley.

directionsInfo: The park is located on Campobello Island in New Brunswick, Canada. The customs station is located at the southern end of the island. Car is the best way to travel to the park; there is no public transportation available. From Boston take I-95 north to Bangor, Maine. Take Route 1A east to Ellsworth, then follow Route 1 east to Whiting Village. Take Route 189 to Lubec and cross the FDR Memorial Bridge to Campobello Island. The visitor center is located approximately two miles from the bridge.
weatherInfo: Roosevelt Campobello experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 50-80F (10-27C). Fall temperatures range from 25-70F (-4-21C). Typically the first is in frost mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 67 inches (170 cm). Winter temperatures range from 5-30F (-15 - -1C). Spring temperatures range from 20-60F (-6-16C).
name: Roosevelt Campobello
description: For many years, Franklin D. Roosevelt summered on Campobello Island. As an adult, he shared with his family the same active pursuits he enjoyed on the island as child. Although he visited less frequently after contracting polio, Campobello remained important to FDR. Today Roosevelt Campobello International Park serves as a memorial to FDR and a symbol of cooperation between the U.S. and Canada.

directionsInfo: Saint Croix Island International Historic Site is best reached by private vehicle. The site is located 8 miles (13 km) south of Calais, Maine, on US Route 1, and can be reached either by Route 9 from Bangor or US Route 1, the coastal route from Portland and points south. From US Route 1, turn onto St. Croix Drive. The entrance gate is on the right. The visitor center is inside the ranger station.
weatherInfo: Located in Maine, Saint Croix Island experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 50-80F (10-27C). Fall temperatures range from 25-70F (-4-21C). Typically the first is in frost mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 67 inches (170 cm). Winter temperatures range from 5-30F (-15 - -1C). Spring temperatures range from 20-60F (-6-16C).
name: Saint Croix Island
description: The winter of 1604-1605 on Saint Croix Island was a cruel one for Pierre Dugua's French expedition. Iced in by freezing temperatures and cut off from fresh water and game, 35 of 79 men died. As spring arrived and native people traded game for bread, the health of those remaining improved. Although the expedition moved on by summer, the beginning of French presence in North America had begun.

images.altText: View of the drive into Saint Croix Island International Historic Site.
images.title: Saint Croix Island Entrance
images.caption: View of the drive into Saint Croix Island International Historic Site.

images.altText: A wayside discussing the history of the island along the interpretive trail.
images.title: Interpretive Trail
images.caption: An interpretive trail guides visitors through the history of the island and the people who called it home.

images.altText: A bronze sculpture of a Passamaquoddy person reaching out to assist the French settlers.
images.title: Bronze Sculpture
images.caption: The Passamaquoddy's assistance kept the French explorers alive.

images.altText: A bronze sculpture of Pierre Dugua with a reenactor standing nearby.
images.title: Pierre Dugua, Sieur de Mons
images.caption: Pierre Dugua and his men spent a dealthy winter on Saint Croix Island.

images.altText: Three visitors read an interpretive wayside along the trail.
images.title: Visitors reading a wayside along the trail
images.caption: As you walk along the trail waysides provide more information about surviving that deadly winter of 1604-05.

fullName: Saint Croix Island International Historic Site

directionsInfo: Ten miles south of I-70 on Maryland Route 65
weatherInfo: The weather is fairly mild.  Summers can be very warm and humid and winters cold and snowy.  We have four distinct seasons with the fall and spring being the best times to visit the battlefield.
name: Antietam
description: 23,000 soldiers were killed, wounded or missing after twelve hours of savage combat on September 17, 1862. The Battle of Antietam ended the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia's first invasion into the North and led Abraham Lincoln to issue the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation.

images.altText: a monument of a soldier in the background with graves in front of the monument

images.caption: Private Soldier Monument at the cemetery

images.caption: 130th Pennsylvania Monument at Bloody Lane

images.altText: artillery piece sitting on a rock break
images.title: Cannon the Field
images.caption: Artillery played a key role at Antietam.  Over 500 cannon were involved in the fighting.

images.altText: three arch stone bridge over Antietam Creek
images.title: Burnside Bridge
images.caption: Burnside Bridge in the snow from the Union side of Antietam Creek.

directionsInfo: There are two entrances to Assateague Island National Seashore. Assateague's north entrance is at the end of Route 611, eight miles south of Ocean City, MD. The south entrance is at the end of Route 175, two miles east of Chincoteague, VA. There is no vehicle access between the two entrances on Assateague Island. Vehicles must return to the mainland to access either the north or south entrance.
weatherInfo:
Spring: Often windy and cool with lows in the 40's and highs in the 60's.
Summer: Hot and humid with lows in the 60's and highs in the 80's.
Fall: Warm with lows in the 50's and highs in the 70's.
Winter: Damp cold and often windy. Lows in the 20's, highs in the 40's.
name: Assateague Island
description: Want to live on the edge? Visit a place recreated each day by ocean wind and waves. Life on Assateague Island has adapted to an existence on the move. Explore sandy beaches, salt marshes, maritime forests and coastal bays. Rest, relax, recreate and enjoy some time on the edge of the continent.

images.altText: Wild horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.title: Wild Horses on the dunes at Assateague
images.caption: There are few places in the United States where you can view wild horses.Take advantage of the opportunity to view these horses in a natural habitat.

images.altText: Horses grazing in the marsh at the water's edge.
images.title: Wild horses grazing in the salt marshes on Assateague Island
images.caption: Assateague's wild horses can often be found grazing in salt marshes.

images.altText: Tree Swallows migrating along the beach at Assateague
images.title: Tree Swallows Migrating along Assateague
images.caption: Enormous flocks of migrating tree swallows stop and rest on Assateague beaches in the fall.

images.altText: tents and vehicle in the oceanside campground dunes
images.title: Camping at Assateague
images.caption: Tent camping in the Oceanside campground at Assateague is a great way to relax and recreate at the beach.

images.altText: waves on Assateague beach with people fishing in the background
images.title: Waves on Assateague beach
images.caption: Visit the shifting sands at the water's edge where thousands of waves change the beach every day.

directionsInfo: The 18.2 square miles of the Baltimore National Heritage Area encompass the city's oldest neighborhoods as well as the downtown and waterfront areas.
weatherInfo: Weather can be extremely hot in the summer and extremely cold in the winter. Fall and spring very pleasant.
name: Baltimore
description: For nearly three centuries, Baltimore has stood as a center of commerce and culture for the Chesapeake Bay. The city has seen the incredible transformation of American identity, shaped by war, prosperity, and struggles for freedom and civil rights. Visit the Baltimore National Heritage Area to experience the places and people that shaped the nation and forged the American identity.

images.altText: Washington Monument, Baltimore
images.title: Baltimore National Heritage Area
images.caption: Washington Monument, Baltimore

directionsInfo: This 29-mile highway connects Baltimore, MD and Washington, D.C
weatherInfo:
The Washington, D.C. area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy.
Spring: During these months of transition, the weather can alternate from warm, humid air coming from the south to cold, dry air coming from the northwest. Be prepared for changing conditions.
Summer: The warmest months are June, July, and August, with average highs in the 80s (~31 ?) combined with high humidity. Temperatures often climb into the 90s (~34?).
name: Baltimore-Washington
description: This 29-mile highway connects Baltimore, MD and Washington, D.C. The parkway has carried visitors to and from the capital city since 1954.

directionsInfo: To reach the visitor center from the east, follow US Route 15 to MD Route 77 and go west about 3 miles.  The visitor center is on the right side of the road.  From the west, take I 70 to MD 66 at exit 35.  Turn left onto MD 66 north and travel about 5 miles, passing through the roundabout.  Turn right onto MD 64 and drive 1 mile.  Turn right onto MD 77.  Drive on MD 77 about 7.5 miles.  The visitor center is on the left.
weatherInfo:
Summer (June-Aug) average temperature is between 61 and 81 degrees Fahrenheit.

Fall (Sep-Nov) average temperature is between 45 and 64 degrees Fahrenheit.  Fall foliage is at its peak in mid-October

Winter (Dec-Feb) average temperature is between 24 and 41 degrees Fahrenheit.  Winter snowfall is between 5-12" per month.

Spring (March-May) average temperature is between 41 and 63 degrees Fahrenheit.

Average precipitation is approximately 4 inches per month.  

(Source: usclimatedata.com)
name: Catoctin Mountain
description: President Franklin D. Roosevelt created programs to give people a chance to rebuild their lives from the Great Depression. The Works Progress Administration and the Civilian Conservation Corps gave this land a second opportunity and through re-growth, a new role as a recreation area.

images.altText: Rock formation with mountains in the background

images.altText: A woman and girl hike along a tree-lined trail.

images.altText: A log cabin in the woods

images.altText: A stone and wood building with plants and flowers in front

images.caption: First time visitors should begin their park experience at the visitor center.

directionsInfo:
By Car: Capital Beltway (I-495), Maryland outer loop exit 40 Cabin John Parkway to Clara Barton Parkway; Virginia inner loop exit 41 Clara Barton Parkway East; follow Clara Barton Parkway to MacArthur Boulevard and Glen Echo exit, left onto MacArthur Boulevard, straight across traffic circle at Goldsboro Road, next left onto Oxford Road, end of street, parking lots on the left.

By Metro: Red Line to Bethesda or Friendship Heights Station, transfer to Montgomery County Ride-On Bus # 29, Glen Echo stop.
weatherInfo: Weather for the Washington, D.C. area.
name: Clara Barton
description: Clara Barton dedicated her life and energies to help others in times of need - both home and abroad, in peacetime as well as during military emergencies. Glen Echo was her home the last 15 years of her life and the structure illustrates her dedication and concern for those less fortunate than herself.

directionsInfo:
From the Beltway (I495/I95), take Exit 3, Indian Head Highway south (MD210/Indian Head Highway) and drive for approximately 3.5 miles to Old Fort Road. Turn right for 1 mile to Fort Foote Road S, turn left. Follow the winding road through the residential area to entrance sight on the left for the fort.

If driving north on MD210/Indian Head Highway turn left onto the 2nd Old Fort Road you come to (Old Fort Rd cross 210 twice).  There will be a McDonald's on your left at the correct traffic light.
weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning.
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
name: Fort Foote
description: Fort Foote was constructed in 1863  atop Rozier's Bluff to strengthen the ring of fortifications that encircled Washington, D.C. Two of the Guns that protected Washington are still there along with the remains of the fort's earthworks.

directionsInfo:
The park is three miles southeast of the Baltimore Inner Harbor and just off I-95. Follow the brown Fort McHenry directional signs along all major routes to the park. 

From I-95 northbound, take Exit 55 Key Highway and follow Fort McHenry signs.
weatherInfo:
Temperatures and weather in the spring and fall months tend to be mild. Ice, snow, and freezing temperatures can occur during winter. Extreme heat can occur during the summer months.

Inclement weather may impact park hours of operation year round. Refer to the park alerts or call ahead to confirm operating hours.
name: Fort McHenry
description: by the dawn's early light, a large red, white and blue banner? Whose broad stripes and bright stars . . . were so gallantly streaming! over the star-shaped Fort McHenry during the Battle of Baltimore, September 13-14, 1814. The valiant defense of the fort inspired Francis Scott Key to write "The Star-Spangled Banner."

directionsInfo:
From I-95/495 take exit 3, Indian Head Highway South/MD 210. Travel about 4 miles to Fort Washington Road, turn right. The park is located at the end of the road.

From Waldorf, MD: MD228 to Indian Head Highway/MD210 North. Turn left onto Old Fort Road. Continue to end of road, at the stop sign turn left onto Fort Washington Road, continue to park entrance.
weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning.
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
name: Fort Washington
description: Built to defend the river approach to  Washington, DC, Fort Washington has stood as silent sentry for over 200 years. As technologies advanced so did Fort Washington, from the brick and stone of the 19th century to the concrete and steel of the 20th century.  Joining the National Park Service in 1946, the park continues to protect the Potomac River.

directionsInfo:

By Metro: Red Line to Bethesda or Friendship Heights Station, transfer to Montgomery County Ride-On Bus # 29, Glen Echo stop.
weatherInfo: Weather for Washington, D.C. and Bethesda, Maryland areas.
name: Glen Echo
description: Glen Echo Park began in 1891 as a National Chautauqua Assembly "to promote liberal and practical education." By 1911, it transformed into DC's premier amusement park until it closed in 1968. Since 1971, the National Park Service has owned and operated the site and today, with the help of the Glen Echo Park Partnership for Arts and Culture, offers year-round cultural and recreational activities.

Take a left on Greenbelt Road .

weatherInfo:
The Washington, D.C. area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. 
Spring: During these months of transition, the weather can alternate from warm, humid air coming from the south to cold, dry air coming from the northwest. Be prepared for changing conditions.
Summer: The warmest months are June, July, and August, with average highs in the 80s (~31 ?) combined with high humidity. 
Fall: Expect a drop in temperature and humidity in September
name: Greenbelt
description:
The park and campground are open year round.
Greenbelt Park is located in suburban Greenbelt, Maryland. 
Specific site Reservations are required at the Greenbelt Park campground year round. 
The park features a 174 site campground with specific site reservations, nine miles of trails, and three picnic areas. 
Enjoy the affordability, peaceful surroundings and National Park Service hospitality.

directionsInfo:
Hampton is easy to get to because it's close to three interstate highways--routes 695, 70, and 95. From the Baltimore Beltway (I 695) eastbound or westbound: Take Exit 27B, Dulaney Valley Road northbound. Take the first right turn onto Hampton Lane. The park will be on your right, about one mile from the intersection.

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION: Bus #11 stops at Goucher College, less than one mile from Hampton. The Light Rail stop at Lutherville is approximately three miles from Hampton NHS.
weatherInfo: Weather during the spring and fall months tend to be mild. Visitors can expect mild to severe seasonal weather during the winter and summer months.  Inclement weather may impact park hours of operation year round. Refer to the park alerts or call ahead to confirm operating hours.
name: Hampton
description: Once possibly the largest private home in America by 1790, the Hampton mansion serves as a grand example of late-Georgian architecture in America. Hampton is also the story of its people, as the estate evolved through the actions of the Ridgely family, enslaved African Americans, European indentured servants, and paid laborers within a nation struggling to define its own concept of freedom.

images.altText: Hampton Mansion in the fall
images.title: Hampton Mansion Historic Site
images.caption: Hampton Mansion in the Fall

directionsInfo: From the Capital Beltway (I495/95) take Exit 3 to MD 210 South/Indian Head Highway, travel approximately 4 miles to Fort Washington Road, turn right.  At the traffic light, Livingston Road, turn right.  The Harmony Hall Regional Center will be on your left.  That is where you will need to park.  After parking, when facing Livingston Road, go to your left and the park entrance is the next driveway.
weatherInfo:
Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. 
Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. 
Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly..
name: Harmony Hall
description: The 18th century Harmony Hall mansion is located on a 62.5-acre open pasture land estate along the Potomac River.  This estate was purchased by the National Park Service in 1966, to preserve southern Maryland cultural heritage. Surrounded by a rich landscape, it offers visitors many chances to connect with Colonial History. The park also home to the remains of the Want Water House and canal.

images.altText: Photo Harmony Hall Mansion
images.title: Harmony Hall Mansion
images.caption: East elevation of Harmony Hall Mansion

images.altText: Photo of Harmony Hall taken in 1938
images.title: Historic Harmony Hall
images.caption: Historic image of Harmony Hall, circa 1938.

directionsInfo: Harpers Ferry NHP's Visitor Center is located along US Route 340 in West Virginia. The park entrance is 8 miles east of Charles Town, WV and 20 miles southwest of Frederick, MD.
weatherInfo:
Harpers Ferry experiences all four seasons - the cold and snow of winter, the rain and flowers of spring, the humidity and sunshine of summer, and the chill and leave change of fall. We will strive to keep you up-to-date as Harpers Ferry's landscape changes with the seasons.

To see the current weather or the forecasted weather for Harpers Ferry, please visit the National Weather Service site and set the zip code to 25425.
name: Harpers Ferry
description: A visit to this quaint, historic community, at the confluence of the Potomac and Shenandoah rivers, is like stepping into the past.  Stroll the picturesque streets, visit exhibits and museums, or hike our trails and battlefields. Spend a day or a weekend.  We have something for everyone, so come and discover Harpers Ferry!
