directionsInfo: Capulin Volcano National Monument is located in northeast New Mexico. The monument is located 34 miles east of Raton, NM, and 60 miles west of Clayton, NM. No public transportation systems serve the park.
weatherInfo:
Elevations in the park range from approximately 7,000 feet to 8,182 feet on the crater rim. Windy conditions may exist at the top of the volcano.

Summers are mild (highs in the mid-80sF/approximately 30C). Thunderstorms are common in July and August. Light jackets may be needed during the summer.

Winters are cold, and blizzards may result in temporary park closures. Warm and layered clothing should be worn the rest of the year.
name: Capulin Volcano
description: Come view a dramatic landscape—a unique place of mountains, plains, and sky. Born of fire and forces continually reshaping the earth’s surface, Capulin Volcano provides access to nature’s most awe-inspiring work.

images.altText: A cloud shrouded volcano rises behind a field of yellow flowers.
images.title: Capulin Volcano
images.caption: Capulin Volcano in summer.

images.altText: View of cinder cone volcano and the road leading to the top of the volcano as seen from the air.
images.title: Aerial View of Capulin Volcano
images.caption: Capulin Volcano is a classic example of a cinder cone. The crater is approximately 130 m (420 ft) deep and 440 m (1,450 ft) across. The base of the mountain is 6 km (4 mi) in circumference. Volcano Road spirals up the volcano, providing panoramic views.

images.altText: A shaded bench on the side of a paved nature trail wending through juniper trees and grasses.
images.title: Nature Trail at Capulin Volcano
images.caption: A paved nature trail at Capulin Volcano NM.

images.altText: Layers of rock are visible in the steep hillside along a road.
images.title: Volcano Road
images.caption: Layers of volcanic material can be seen in the Volcano Road that takes visitors to the top of Capulin Volcano.

images.altText: View of a cinder cone volcano covered with grasses, small trees, and other plants.
images.title: Capulin Volcano-Best Example of a Cinder Cone in North America
images.caption: Although Capulin Mountain is considered no longer active, because its excellent condition, the cinder cone is considered one of the best and most accessible examples of a cinder cone in North America.

directionsInfo: To access the park's only entrance road, New Mexico Highway 7, turn north from US Hwy 62/180 at White's City, NM, which is 20 miles (32 km) southwest of Carlsbad, NM and 145 miles (233 km) northeast of El Paso, TX. The entrance road stretches a scenic seven miles (11.3 km) from the park gate at White's City to the visitor center and cavern entrance. The address for the park's visitor center is 727 Carlsbad Caverns Hwy, Carlsbad, NM, 88220, located 27 miles (43 km) from the town of Carlsbad.
weatherInfo: Carlsbad Caverns National Park is located in the Chihuahuan Desert in southeast New Mexico. Summers are hot with temperatures between 90°F (32°C) and low 100s °F (38°C). Windy conditions and mild temperatures are common in early spring (March-May) with frequent rain in early fall (August-September). This part of the country also sees cold temperatures in the winter with occasional snow and icy conditions. Most days, the park is enveloped by a gorgeous blue sky with very few clouds, 278 sunny days a year!
name: Carlsbad Caverns
description: High ancient sea ledges, deep rocky canyons, flowering cactus, and desert wildlife—treasures above the ground in the Chihuahuan Desert. Hidden beneath the surface are more than 119 caves—formed when sulfuric acid dissolved limestone leaving behind caverns of all sizes.

images.altText: Looking up through the mouth of the cave on the Natural Entrance path.
images.title: The Natural Entrance
images.caption: Beautiful view looking back out the Natural Entrance as you descend into the cave.

images.altText: Visitors rest at the formation "Rock of Ages."
images.title: Rock of Ages
images.caption: Part of the Big Room tour, the "Rock of Ages" is a spectacular formation.

images.altText: Visitors gathered in the outdoor amphitheater to experience bat flight.
images.title: A ranger presents a Bat Flight Program to hundreds of visitors.
images.caption: Every summer evening visitors gather in the outdoor amphitheater to watch hundreds of thousands of bats leave on their nightly food forage.

images.altText: Visitors watch as droplets ripple through a cave pool.
images.title: Longfellow's Bathtub
images.caption: A spectacular view from Longfellow's Bathtub, a long cave pool, inside the Big Room.

images.altText: "The Chandelier" is spotlighted in this photo taken inside the Big Room.
images.title: The Big Room inside the cavern.
images.caption: A scenic view of the Big Room, highlighting "the Chandelier" formation clinging to the 250 foot high ceiling.

images.altText: Gorgeous formations inside the Big Room of the cavern.
images.title: Scenic Big Room
images.caption: A grand view of the Big Room, fully decorated with stalagmites and stalactites.

images.altText: A hedgehog cactus in bloom in a rocky garden.
images.title: Life Among Rocks
images.caption: Amid the arid rocky environment, a hedgehog cactus blooms in the spring.

images.altText: Two Jr. Rangers earn their badges.
images.title: New Jr. Rangers
images.caption: Ranger Chris Bramblett kneeling with two new Jr. Rangers, after the children were awarded their badges.

directionsInfo: Road conditions can be rough or impassable. Please call in advance for updates.
weatherInfo:
Summer highs are typically in the 80's to mid-90's. Thunderstorms can produce heavy localized downpours and sudden dramatic drops in temperatures.

Winter temperatures will drop to well below freezing most nights. If you plan to camp in the winter, prepare for nighttime temperatures in the teens or lower.

Spring and Fall are great times to visit with more moderate temperatures, but unexpected storms can change things dramatically. Monitor local weather forecasts.
name: Chaco Culture
description: Today the massive buildings of the ancestral Pueblo peoples still testify to the organizational and engineering abilities not seen anywhere else in the American Southwest. For a deeper contact with the canyon that was central to thousands of people between 850 and 1250 A.D., come and explore Chaco through guided tours, hiking & biking trails, evening campfire talks, and night sky programs.

images.altText: Black on White Bowls
images.title: Red Mesa Black on White Bowls
images.caption: Many of the things discovered at Chaco came from other places. These bowls came from the Red Mesa area. Red Mesa Black on White was produced from about A.D. 875 to 1040. Due to the lack of adequate resources, very few pots were produced in Chaco Canyon.

images.altText: Pueblo Bonito with Cliff Face
images.title: Pueblo Bonito with Cliff Face
images.caption: Pueblo Bonito is the most famous Chacoan great house. Constructed between 850 and 1150, Pueblo Bonito had almost 700 rooms, 32 kivas, and 3 great kivas.

images.altText: Gallup Black on White Pitchers
images.title: Gallup Black on White Pitchers
images.caption: These pitchers are another form of pottery that was created elsewhere and then brought to Chaco canyon. This particular style was manufactured from A.D. 1030 to 1150.

images.altText: Night Sky Above Fajada Butte
images.title: Night Sky Above Fajada Butte
images.caption: In 2013 Chaco Culture NHP was designated an International Dark Sky Park. The park has night sky and sunrise programs throughout the year.

images.altText: Black and White Photo of Una Vida Great House
images.title: Una Vida
images.caption: Una Vida is one of Chaco's largely un-excavated great houses. It's location provides great views of the canyon floor while being a short walk from a striking rock art panel.

directionsInfo: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro includes a wide variety of sites and organizations across two states.
weatherInfo:
Due to the length of El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Here is a link for the Southwest US.

www.accuweather.com/en/us/southwest-region/weather-radar
name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro
description: Take a journey on El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail to savor 300 years of heritage and culture in the Southwest. This Spanish colonial "royal road" in New Mexico and Texas originally extended to Mexico City, Mexico.

images.altText: tan-colored pueblo Indian ruins with blue sky and three people
images.title: Kuaua Ruin in Coronado Historic Site, Bernalillo, New Mexico
images.caption: The Tiwa pueblo of Kuaua lies in ruin at Coronado Historic Site. The site includes a rebuilt kiva that displays reproductions of original murals adorning its walls. Be sure to go to the visitor center where some of the original murals are displayed.

images.altText: adobe buildings including two beehive-looking ovens with people in a courtyard
images.title: El Rancho de las Golondrinas, La Cienega, New Mexico
images.caption: El Rancho de las Golondrinas was a historic paraje (stopping place) along El Camino Real. “The ranch of the swallows” dates from the early 1700s, and is now being used as a living history museum.

images.altText: shrubby desert scene with people walking under a cloud-filled sky
images.title: Jornada del Muerto, County Roads A013 & E070, Sierra & Doña Ana Counties, New Mexico
images.caption: Walk in the footsteps of settlers from the 1600s who had to walk along this dreaded yet unavoidable section of El Camino Real: Jornada del Muerto or Dead Man’s Journey.

images.altText: fort ruins in the sunlight with cottonwood trees on the left
images.title: Fort Selden Historic Site, Radium Springs, New Mexico
images.caption: Fort Selden was built near the town of Las Cruces in 1865 and housed troops for 25 years. The visitor center offers exhibits on frontier military life during the fort’s heyday and the grounds are self-guided.

images.altText: large white chapel under blue sky
images.title: Presidio Chapel of San Elizario, Mission Trail, El Paso, Texas
images.caption: Spanish troops built a presidio (fort) and chapel at this site during the 1780s to protect settlements in the lower Río Grande Valley downstream from El Paso, Texas.

fullName: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail

directionsInfo: Take exit 85 of I-40 in Grants, New Mexico. After you exit, head south on Santa Fe Ave, and continue straight over the freeway overpass. Take a left at the entrance sign for El Malpais Visitor Center. Continue 300 yards until you reach the parking lot.
weatherInfo: As a general rule, daily temperatures swing roughly 30 degrees (F) from night lows to afternoon highs. Summer is sunny and hot with monsoon rain storms with average high of 80 (F), while Winter is cool, sunny, with potential snow storms and an average high of 45 (F). Spring and Fall are generally dry, with the occasional storm rain and/or snow storm.
name: El Malpais
description: The richly diverse volcanic landscape of El Malpais offers solitude, recreation, and discovery. Explore cinder cones, lava tube caves, sandstone bluffs, and hiking trails. Wildlife abounds in the open grasslands and forests. While some may see a desolate environment, people have been adapting to and living in this extraordinary terrain for generations. Come discover the land of fire and ice!

images.altText: Summer at Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.title: Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.caption: A vast expanse of lava fields as seen from Sandstone Bluffs Overlook

images.altText: Snow on the El Calderon Trail
images.title: Snowy Landscape
images.caption: Winter exploration allows one to discover the quiet beauty of El Malpais

images.altText: Summer view from El Calderon cinder cone
images.title: View from El Calderon
images.caption: A hike to the top of El Calderon cinder cone offers one a view of the entire monument.

images.altText: Hiking in Summer
images.title: Wildflowers on the El Calderon Trail
images.caption: Enjoy a stroll along the El Calderon Trail to view beautiful wildflowers in summer.

images.altText: Lava Tube caving at El Malpais
images.title: Lava Tube Cave
images.caption: Explore lava tube caving at El Malpais National Monument

directionsInfo: From Albuquerque, NM, or from the east: take Interstate 40 west to Grants. At exit 81, go south on Highway 53 for 42 miles to El Morro National Monument. From Flagstaff, AZ, or from the west: take Interstate 40 east to Gallup. At exit 20, go south on Highway 602 for about 31 miles. Turn east (left) onto Highway 53. El Morro is 25 more miles.
weatherInfo:
At an elevation of 7,219 feet (2200 meters) winters can be cold and snowy. Summers are warm with afternoon thunder showers from mid-July through mid-September. Trails can close unexpectedly due to severe weather.
Average snowfall: 40 inches per year.
Average precipitation (snowmelt and rain): 16 inches per year.
Warmest month: July, with average highs of 84 degrees and lows of 52 degrees.
Coldest months: December and January, with average lows of 14-15 degrees, and average highs of 44-45 degrees.
name: El Morro
description: Imagine the refreshment of finding water after days of dusty travel. A reliable waterhole hidden at the base of a sandstone bluff made El Morro (the headland) a popular campsite for hundreds of years. Here, Ancestral Puebloans, Spanish and American travelers carved over 2,000 signatures, dates, messages, and petroglyphs.  Make El Morro National Monument a stopping point on your travels.

images.altText: Headland in Snow
images.title: El Morro in snow
images.caption: El Morro blanketed with snow

images.altText: El Morro with Sunflowers
images.title: El Morro with Sunflowers
images.caption: El Morro with Sunflowers

images.altText: Pool at El Morro
images.title: Pool at El Morro
images.caption: A drinking hole for visitors for hundreds of years, the pool at El Morro has significant cultural and historical value.

images.altText: Trail at El Morro
images.title: Trail at El Morro
images.caption: Constructed by the CCC, the historic headland trail at El Morro offers visitors great views and the archaeological site of Atsinna.

images.altText: Atsinna Pueblo
images.title: Atsinna Pueblo
images.caption: Atsinna Pueblo sits atop the headland at El Morro

images.altText: Ranger recreates a historic photo
images.title: Then and Now at the Pool
images.caption: A ranger recreates a historic photograph at El Morro near The Pool.

images.altText: A ranger recreates a historic El Morro Photograph
images.title: Ranger Recreates Historic Photograph
images.caption: Ranger Andrew recreates a historic photograph with Petroglyphs at El Morro.

directionsInfo:
Fort Union National Monument is located in the Northeastern portion of the state of New Mexico. 8 miles off of Interstate I-25 on State Highway NM 161.
New Mexico: From Albuquerque (156 miles), Santa Fe (94 miles) or Las Vegas, NM (28 miles) take I-25 North, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161.
Colorado: From Denver (313 miles), Colorado Springs (243 miles) or Raton (95 miles) take I-25 South, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161.
weatherInfo:
Fort Union is situated at 6,760 feet above sea level. Daytime temperatures between June and September may exceed 90 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter temperatures often drop below 32 degrees Fahrenheit. Temperatures may vary within 50 degrees in a 24-hour period.
During the winter, it is not uncommon for the temperatures to drop below 0°F (-18°C.) 
During the summer, expect high temperatures, intense sunlight and extreme low humidity.
name: Fort Union
description: Exposed to the wind, within a sweeping valley of short grass prairie, amid the swales of the Santa Fe Trail, lie the territorial-style adobe remnants of the largest 19th century military fort in the region. For forty years, 1851-1891, Fort Union functioned as an agent of political and cultural change, whether desired or not, in New Mexico and throughout the Southwest.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Wagons encrusted in frost
images.title: Freezing Fog in Mechanics Corral
images.caption: One of the most photographed areas of the monument, the Mechanics Corral onced serviced wagons that travelled along the Santa Fe Trail.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Panorama of Officers Row
images.title: Big Skies Over Officers Row
images.caption: Blue skies and billowing clouds frequently add to the incredible viewshed that surrounds the monument grounds.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.title: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.caption: Located deep within the Mora Valley, Fort Union National Monument contains a vast array of plant and animal life.

images.altText: Moon in sky above adobe remnants
images.title: Remnants of the Past
images.caption: Located on the monument grounds is the world's largest collection of Territorial-Style adobe remanants.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.altText: Fort Union Visitor Center Sign
images.title: Fort Union NM Visitor Center
images.caption: Completed in 1960, the Visitor Center at Fort Union was one of the first built during the "MIssion 66" program for the National Park Service. It was designed by the internationally known architect Cecil Doty.

directionsInfo:
Passenger vehicles can drive north of Silver City, New Mexico to the monument on NM Hwy 15. The 46 mile trip can take up to two hours due to the narrow and mountainous curving nature of the road.

Large RVs and vehicles pulling trailers should NOT use NM Hwy 15. From Silver City, take US Highway 180 to Santa Clara. Turn left onto NM Hwy 152 and drive to San Lorenzo. At San Lorenzo, turn left onto NM Hwy 35 and follow it to its termination at NM Hwy 15. Turn right on NM Hwy 15 and follow signs to the park.
weatherInfo: Weather is extremely variable. Summers are usually in the 80s but approach 100 °F. Winters have occasional snow or temperatures near 0 °F. Thunderstorms are common in the summer and early fall, usually in the afternoon. Thunderstorms and lightning may cause temporary closures of the monument.
name: Gila Cliff Dwellings
description: For thousands of years, groups of nomadic people used the caves of the Gila River as temporary shelter. In the late 1200's, people of the Mogollon Culture decided it would be a good place to call home. They built rooms, crafted pottery and raised children in the cliff dwellings for about twenty years. Then the Mogollon moved on, leaving the walls for us as a glimpse into the past.

images.altText: Exterior view of Mogollon Cliff Dwelling
images.title: Mogollon Cliff Dwelling with T Door
images.caption: The T-shaped door suggests trade between Mogollon and Ancestral Puebloan.

images.altText: Cliff Dwellings walls and rooms with narrow catwalk
images.title: A Place to Call Home
images.caption: Most of the dwellings walls are original. Some even preserve a builder's fingerprints that are over 700 years old.

images.altText: Sunrise view of Gila Cliff Dwellings with brilliant sky.
images.title: Winter Solstice Sunrise at Gila Cliff Dwellings
images.caption: Visitors enjoy panoramic views of the canyon and dwellings at Gila Cliff Dwellings.

images.altText: View of Mogollon dwelling rooms within a cave.
images.title: Looking Back in Time
images.caption: Tularosa Phase Mogollon people made these caves their home in the late 1200's.

images.altText: Distant view of Gila river valley and mountains beyond.
images.title: View of the Gila River Valley near Gila Cliff Dwellings NM
images.caption: The Oldest Wilderness Area in the United States Awaits.

images.altText: Light snowfall on red rock cliffs along river.
images.title: Gila National Forest Approach to Gila National Monument in Winter
images.caption: Winter wonderland along the Gila River

images.altText: Eroded cliffs reflecting off a river
images.title: Eroded Cliffs Along the Gila River
images.caption: As the first designated Wilderness Area, the Gila offers endless opportunites peaceful reflection.

directionsInfo: The office of the Manhattan Project NHP superintendent is located in Denver, Colorado. Locations of NPS visitor centers and any other park facilities are currently being determined and will be evaluated as part of the park planning process. For directions to the Manhattan Project NHP site in Hanford, WA; Los Alamos, NM; and Oak Ridge, TN, please visit http://www.nps.gov/mapr/planyourvisit/directions.htm.
name: Manhattan Project
description: This site tells the story about the people, events, science, and engineering that led to the creation of the atomic bomb, which helped end World War II.

directionsInfo:
Pecos National Historical Park is 25 miles east of Santa Fe, New Mexico off of Interstate 25. Visitors travelling north on I-25: take exit 299 on to HWY 50 to Pecos village and south two miles on State Road 63.

Those travelling south on I-25: take exit 307 and proceed four miles north to the Park on State Road 63.
weatherInfo:
Pecos National Historical Park is located at nearly 7,000 feet in altitude in the high desert region of Northern New Mexico. Please know your limits at this high desert altitude. We recommend that you wear clothing appropriate to the season, bring plenty of water, stop for a snack or lunch at one of the picnic tables, wear comfortable shoes, and put on plenty of sunscreen.

Specific daily Pecos weather information may be accessed at this link: http://www.nps.gov/peco/planyourvisit/weather.htm.
name: Pecos
description: In the midst of piñon, juniper, and ponderosa pine woodlands of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains not far from Santa Fe, the remains of Indian pueblos stand as meaningful reminders of people who once prevailed. Pecos National Historical Park helps visitors explore the cultural exchange and geographic features that played such crucial roles in the rich history of the Pecos Valley.

images.altText: fishing access on the Pecos River
images.title: Pecos River
images.caption: There are three fishing seasons at Pecos National Historical Park--always popular with anglers.

images.altText: park superintendent
images.title: Every Kid in a Park
images.caption: Pecos NHP Superintendent with future park stewards in 2015.

images.altText: glorieta pass waysides
images.title: Looking toward the Glorieta Pass
images.caption: Located near Kozlowski's trading post and the entry to the Forked Lightning Ranch, these waysides point the visitor toward the Glorieta Pass.

images.altText: View of pottery in museum case
images.title: Pottery Image with Feathered Serpent
images.caption: This image was found on many pieces of pottery in the Pecos valley.

images.altText: Church and preservation workers in distance, kiva in foreground.jpg (943 kb)
images.title: Mission Church and Kiva
images.caption: Clouds gather on a summer day at the mission church

images.altText: Looking from trail toward round uncovered kiva and low wall
images.title: Partially Excavated Kiva
images.caption: View from Ruins Trail

images.altText: Buffalo gourd in foreground, mesa in background
images.title: Buffalo Gourd
images.caption: Buffalo Gourd prevalent throughout the summer

images.altText: Mission church with clouds behind
images.title: Pecos Mission Church
images.caption: Distant View of Mission Church

directionsInfo: GPS: Lat: 35.139 Long: -106.711 From Interstate 40, take the Unser Blvd. exit (#154) proceed north 3 miles to Western Trail. Turn left or west onto Western Trail and follow road to the Visitor Information Center parking lot. From Interstate 25, take the Paseo del Norte exit (#232) and proceed west to Coors Road exit south (must be in center lane to veer left at the Y). Proceed south on Coors Road to Western Trail. Turn right or west onto Western Trail and follow road to the Visitor Info Center parking lot.
weatherInfo: Altitude approx. 5000 ft. Usually sunny and dry, with low relative humidity. Winter temperatures range from 45 to 50 degrees F. Summer temperatures range from 88-99 degrees F. 278 days of sunshine per year. Spring can be windy with 20 to 30 mph sustained winds which can produce periods of blowing sand and dust. For current weather forecast, Google Albuquerque weather.
name: Petroglyph
description: Petroglyph National Monument protects one of the largest petroglyph sites in North America, featuring designs and symbols carved onto volcanic rocks by Native Americans and Spanish settlers 400 to 700 years ago. These images are a valuable record of cultural expression and hold profound spiritual significance for contemporary Native Americans and for the descendants of the early Spanish settlers.

images.altText: Mammal petroglyph along the Mesa Point Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.
images.title: Desert Mammal petroglyph
images.caption: Mammal petroglyph along the Mesa Point Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.

images.altText: Petroglyph of a macaw parrot along the Macaw Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.
images.title: Macaw petroglyph
images.caption: Petroglyph of a macaw parrot along the Macaw Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.

images.altText: Petroglyph imagery of a coyote and rattlesnake in Rinconada Canyon.
images.title: Coyote and Rattlesnake watching over Rinconada Canyon
images.caption: Petroglyph imagery of a coyote and rattlesnake in Rinconada Canyon.

images.altText: Petroglyph panel of sheep grazing in Rinconada Canyon.
images.title: Grazing Sheep in Rinconada Canyon
images.caption: Petroglyph panel of sheep grazing in Rinconada Canyon.

images.altText: Winter scene of snow covered cinder cones at the Volcanoes Day Use Area.
images.title: Snow Dusted Cinder Cones
images.caption: Winter scene of snow covered cinder cones at the Volcanoes Day Use Area.

directionsInfo: Reach the Mountainair Headquarters by taking I-25 south from Albuquerque to Belen, then NM 47 diagonally to US 60, then east 21 miles to Mountainair. To travel the historic highway route (Turquoise Highway) from the north, take I-40 east from Albuquerque to NM 337, drive south 47 miles (76K) to junction with NM State Highway 55. Proceed right (west) on Hwy 55 about 16 miles (26 K). Turn right on Highway 60 and proceed one block to HQ.  Information on the ruins & surrounding area is available here.
weatherInfo:
Salinas Pueblo Missions is at 6100-6500 ft (1860-1980 m) in an arid climate. Average annual rainfall is about 15 inches. 

Winters can be cold & snowy. Summer highs are above 90F/32C with cool evenings. 

June-September often has thunderstorms. Flash flooding may occur in the area. Abo Ruins is especially prone to road closures as a result. 

Spring highs average 75F/24C & Fall a little cooler. 

High winds often occur. Trails may be closed during these times. Check local weather prior to visiting.
name: Salinas Pueblo Missions
description: Tucked away in the middle of New Mexico you’ll find Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument. The three sites offer a glimpse into a unique time in history. A time entrenched with cultural borrowing, conflict, and struggles. The now abandoned sites stand as reminders of the Spanish and Pueblo People’s early encounters.

images.altText: A path through stone walls of an old church.
images.title: Inside the Abo Church
images.caption: A view inside the Abo Church looking north. A nice carpet of grass is usually present during summer months.

images.altText: Stone foundations of an old mission structure.
images.title: An overview of the Abo Mission
images.caption: An overview of the Abo Mission with the Convento in the foreground.

images.altText: An solar eclipse outlines an old stone structure at Salinas Pueblo NM.
images.title: Annular Eclipse seen from Gran Quivira
images.caption: An annular eclipse was visible from Gran Quivira in 2012. A special program allowed visitors to experience this amazing celestrial event.

images.altText: A paved path winds through the stone foundations of several old kivas.
images.title: Kivas at Gran Quivira
images.caption: An overview of kivas at Gran Quivira

images.altText: Stone walls of a roofless building rise into a bright blue sky.
images.title: Quarai Mission
images.caption: An overview of the Quarai Mission, seen from the west.

images.altText: Pink flowers and green foliage frame the roofless remains of a stone mission.
images.title: Quarai Mission in Spring
images.caption: Quarai Mission in Spring

directionsInfo:
From Jemez Springs, NM: Follow Highway 4 north. Preserve is about 22 miles from Jemez Springs. Look for the Main Gate at Mile Marker 39.2.

From Los Alamos, NM: Take Trinity Drive to Diamond. Take a left on Diamond, then a right on West Jemez Road to the intersection with State Highway 4. Take a right [away from Bandelier National Monument], following the highway up and into the Jemez Mountains.) The Preserve is 18 miles up Highway 4 from Los Alamos. Look for the Main Gate at Mile Marker 39.2.
weatherInfo: Each season offers a different experience: lush springs, moderate summers, golden falls, and snowy winters. Average temperatures are 22°F (-6 C) in January and 60°F (16 C) in July.  Temperature extremes range from a high of 84°F (29 C) in summer to -30°F (-34C) in winter. Precipitation is heavier during summer monsoon rains (thunderstorms) in July and August and winter snowstorms in December through March. Higher elevation lends to much cooler temperatures than nearby Albuquerque.
name: Valles Caldera
description: About 1.25 million years ago, a spectacular volcanic eruption created the 13-mile wide circular depression now known as the Valles Caldera.  The preserve is known for its huge mountain meadows, abundant wildlife, and meandering streams. The area also preserves the homeland of ancestral native peoples and embraces a rich ranching history.

images.altText: View of Valle Grande, Redondo Peak, and goldens aspens.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: Along the south rim of the caldera, Rabbit Ridge offers some amazing views of Valle Grande and Redondo Peak.

images.altText: Elk on a foggy morning
images.title: Elk in Fog
images.caption: Early morning or late evening is the best time to see elk within the Valles Caldera National Preserve.

images.altText: View of Missing cabin with Redondito peak in the background.
images.title: Missing Cabin
images.caption: The Missing Cabin greets visitors as they enter the Valles Caldera National Preserve.

images.altText: San Antonio cabin under a mostly cloudy sky
images.title: San Antonio Cabin
images.caption: San Antonio Cabin often housed cowboys when the preserve was privately-owned and operating as a ranch.

images.altText: View from La Garita looking south across Valle San Antonio toward Redondo Peak.
images.title: View from la Garita
images.caption: Along the north rim of the caldera, La Garita offers breathtaking views of Valle San Antonio and Redondo Peak.

images.altText: Two bull elk fighting.
images.title: Elk Bulls Fighting
images.caption: The fall elk rut is a big attraction for visitors to see bull elk sparing and to hear the bulls bugle.

directionsInfo: White Sands National Monument is located off of US Highway 70 between the cities of Las Cruces and Alamogordo. The monument is about 15 miles west of Alamogordo and 52 miles east of Las Cruces.
weatherInfo: Temperatures at White Sands vary greatly throughout the year. Summer time temperatures can be very hot. Winters are mild with cool evenings. Spring time is the windy season. Fall is very enjoyable with mild daytime and night time temperatures.
name: White Sands
description: Rising from the heart of the Tularosa Basin is one of the world's great natural wonders - the glistening white sands of New Mexico. Great wave-like dunes of gypsum sand have engulfed 275 square miles of desert, creating the world's largest gypsum dunefield. White Sands National Monument preserves a major portion of this unique dunefield, along with the plants and animals that live here.

images.altText: Aerial of white sand dunes.
images.title: Aerial of Dunefield
images.caption: The dunes at White Sands cover 275 square miles of the Tularosa Basin.

images.altText: Close up view of ripples on a dune.
images.title: Ripples
images.caption: The wind shapes and moves the dunes as a whole but gives each individual dune the texture of ripples.

images.altText: Dunes colored orange by sunset.
images.title: Sunset Colored Dunes
images.caption: Sunsets are one of the most popular times to visit White Sands. Visitors can experience sunset every day of the year.

images.altText: Cottonwood trees with orange leaves.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: Fall is a wonderful time to visit as most of our plants with leaves change beautiful colors.

images.altText: Grey shadows on dunes.
images.title: Shaded Dunes
images.caption: As the sun changes its angle through the sky it allows shadow to roll across the dunes.

directionsInfo: The African Burial Ground National Monument is located on the first floor of the Ted Weiss Federal Building located at 290 Broadway in Lower Manhattan; close to Foley Square and just north of City Hall. Our visitor center is located mid-block on Broadway between the cross streets of Duane Street and Reade Streets.
weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
name: African Burial Ground
description: African Burial Ground is the oldest and largest known excavated burial ground in North America for both free and enslaved Africans. It protects the historic role slavery played in building New York City.  The site honors both the spirit of those buried here and those who fought for the respectful protection of this site for this and future generations.

images.altText: African Burial Ground Memorial
images.title: African Burial Ground Memorial
images.caption: African Burial Ground Memorial

images.altText: Entrance to visitor center with four banners above doorway.
images.title: Visitor Center Entrance
images.caption: Entrance to the African Burial Ground National Monument visitor center.

images.altText: Outdoor memorial entrance with closed gate.
images.title: Outdoor Memorial Entrance
images.caption: Outdoor memorial entrance with closed gate.

images.altText: Memorial's circle of diaspora.
images.title: Memorial's circle of diaspora.
images.caption: Memorial's circle of diaspora.

images.altText: Exhibits within visitor center.
images.title: Exhibits within visitor center.
images.caption: Exhibits within visitor center.

directionsInfo: Castle Clinton is located in historic Battery Park. It is only directly accessible by foot, bicycle, or wheelchair. You cannot drive directly to the site. Local parking is nearly impossible to find and expensive. All public transportation options are located outside of Battery Park.
weatherInfo:
Castle Clinton National Monument has a variety of weather. New York City has hot summers and cold winters. Spring can have heavy rains and Autumn can be cool. 
http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
name: Castle Clinton
description: Located at the southern tip of Manhattan Island, Castle Clinton stands where New York City began, and represents not only the city’s growth, but the growth of a nation. Initially intended to prevent a British invasion in 1812, the fortification has transformed over the years to welcome theatergoers, immigrants, sightseers, and now, millions of visitors to New York Harbor.

images.altText: Castle Clinton NM Entrance
images.title: Castle Clinton National Monument
images.caption: Castle Clinton stands where New York City began.

name: Champlain Valley
description: Nestled between the Adirondacks of New York and the Green Mountains of Vermont, the Champlain Valley has been the setting for innovations in business and technology, invasions and armed insurrections, new directions in religion and politics, long periods of peace and prosperity, and the beginnings of the conservation movement.

directionsInfo: Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site is located on Route 9G in the Town of Hyde Park, NY.
weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40°F to 70°F.  Rain is not uncommon.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70° F to 100° F.  Humidity can be high throughout the summer months with periods of rain.

Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40° F to 70° F.  Peak leaf season is mid-October.  Rain is not uncommon.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30° F to 50°F.   Ice, Freezing Rain and Snow are not uncommon.
name: Eleanor Roosevelt
description:
"The greatest thing I have learned is how good it is to come home again." Eleanor Roosevelt 

This simple statement expresses her love for the modest house she called Val-Kill. The only National Historic Site dedicated to a first lady, Val-Kill welcomes visitors in the style of Mrs. Roosevelt. Come and be part of the entire Roosevelt Experience at Val-Kill.

images.altText: A view of the buildings at Val-Kill
images.title: Eleanor Roosevelt's Val-Kill
images.caption: Looking across the water at the Stone Cottage and Val-Kill Cottage

images.altText: Stone Cottage at Val-Kill
images.title: Stone Cottage at Val-Kill
images.caption: Val-Kill is a special place that serves as a window into Eleanor Roosevelt's private and public life.

images.altText: Val-Kill Cottage
images.title: Val-Kill Cottage
images.caption: Val-Kill became the nucleus of Franklin and Eleanor's overlapping network of friends and political associates. After FDR's death in 1945, Val-Kill became Mrs. Roosevelt's permanent home.

images.altText: View of Val-Kill cottage from the garden
images.title: View of Val-Kill Cottage from the garden
images.caption: Mrs. Roosevelt's favorite room was the sleeping porch on the second floor overlooking the garden.

images.altText: Bridge at Val-Kill
images.title: Bridge at Val-Kill
images.caption: Mrs. Roosevelt would hear her guests approach as they drove over the bridge.

directionsInfo:
Begin your journey in the east, west, or right in the middle of New York State, you can't go wrong-- the canal's treasures are strong together along the waterway like gems on a necklace.

The canal is accessible by CAR, RAIL, BIKE, and BOAT and from major airports: Albany International (ALB), Syracuse Hancock International (SYR), Greater Rochester International (ROC), and Buffalo-Niagara International (BUF).
weatherInfo: Weather along the Erie Canalway National Heritage Corridor can vary greatly from one end of the Corridor to the other. Lake effect snows in winter from Buffalo to Syracuse may only be flurries by Utica, and merely cloudy skies in Albany. Clearing skies in Rochester may be the wake of a heavy thunderstorm that has moved on to Saratoga Springs.
name: Erie Canalway
description:
Explore the Erie Canal and discover America's most famous and influential man-made waterway. Nowhere else will you find the distinctive locks and low bridges of the New York State Canal System or discover towns and cities whose watery front doors still give way to lively Main Streets. 

More than 500 miles of historic waterways and trails are here to explore.

images.altText: Dozens of kayakers paddle along the Erie Canal.
images.title: Oswego Paddlefest
images.caption: Kayakers at the Oswego Paddlefest

directionsInfo: The main entrance of Federal Hall is located at 26 Wall Street, near the corner of Wall Street and Nassau Street in Manhattan's Financial District. The rear entrance, which is wheelchair accessible, is located at 15 Pine Street, near the intersection of Pine Street and Nassau Street. It is highly recommended that all visitors use mass transit when traveling to Federal Hall.
weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
name: Federal Hall
description: Here on Wall Street, George Washington took the oath of office as our first President, and this site was home to the first Congress, Supreme Court, and Executive Branch offices. The current structure, a Customs House, later served as part of the US Sub-Treasury. Now, the building serves as a museum and memorial to our first President and the beginnings of the United States of America.

images.altText: Federal Hall Interior
images.title: Federal Hall Interior
images.caption: Federal Hall Interior

directionsInfo:
Fire Island National Seashore Headquarters:
Via Long Island Expressway/I-495: Take Exit 61 (Patchogue-Holbrook Road) to Waverly Ave. Head south on Waverly Ave to West Ave. Turn right onto Laurel Street.

Via NY-27: Take Exit 52 onto Waverly Ave. Head south on Waverly Ave to West Ave. Turn right onto Laurel Street.
weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures may range from high 30s to low 50s (F). Rain and sun are equally common.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 65 F to 90 F.

Fall: Temperatures from 70 F in early autumn to 40 F later in the season may be expected.

Winter: Temperatures in the 30s (F) are common, with below freezing temperatures possible.
name: Fire Island
description: Immerse yourself in an enchanting collage of coastal life and history. Rhythmic waves, high dunes, ancient maritime forests, historic landmarks and glimpses of wildlife, Fire Island has been a special place for diverse plants, animals and people for centuries. Far from the pressure of nearby big-city life, dynamic barrier island beaches offer both solitude and camaraderie, and spiritual renewal.

images.altText: Ripple marks in the sand near the shoreline
images.title: Fire Island's shoreline is constantly changing
images.caption: Fire Island beaches are constantly changing, offering first-time and repeat visitors something new each time they come.

images.altText: A view from a meadow of the historic Old Mastic House
images.title: Old Mastic House at William Floyd Estate
images.caption: A view of the Old Mastic House from the grounds of the William Floyd Estate

images.altText: Grasses and shrubs cover the undulating backdune habitat of Fire Island's wilderness.
images.title: Fire Island Wilderness
images.caption: Unparalleled opportunities for solitude and recreation can be found in New York State's only federally designated wilderness, the Otis Pike Fire Island High Dune Wilderness.

images.altText: The Fire Island Lighthouse against a vibrant sunset.
images.title: View of Fire Island Lighthouse from Great South Bay
images.caption: People from around the world come to visit the Fire Island Lighthouse.

images.altText: View of ocean and primary dune with boardwalk winding up to the Sunken Forest overlook.
images.title: View of primary dune from Sunken Forest overlook
images.caption: Get one of the best boardwalk views on a walk through the Sunken Forest - a more than 350 year-old, globally rare ecosystem.

directionsInfo: Take I-90 (NY Thruway) to Exit 33 (Verona-Rome). Turn Right onto Rt. 365 E. Follow Rt. 365, veering left as Rt. 365 merges with Rt 69 at the fork in the road. This will take you over an arterial bridge into the City of Rome. Fort Stanwix NM will be across Erie Blvd. on the right side of James Street.
weatherInfo: The Park lies within a temperate zone and experiences four full seasons. Summer can become very hot and humid. Snow is common as late as May and as early as October. The fort area can become muddy in all seasons. With most activities outdoors, good closed-toe walking shoes and low heels are advised. Air conditioning and heating is limited to park visitor center most times in the year. Water and extra layers of clothing in all seasons are always recommended!
name: Fort Stanwix
description: For centuries, the Oneida Carrying Place, a six mile portage connecting the Mohawk River and Wood Creek, served as a vital link for those traveling by water from the ocean to the Great Lakes. When Europeans arrived, nations fought for control of the carry, the homelands of the Six Nations Confederacy, and the rich resources of North America. In this struggle, Fort Stanwix would play a vital role.

images.altText: A park ranger directs a group of children thorugh the fort.
images.title: Which Adventure Will You Choose?
images.caption: From ranger tours, to walking trails, to exploring history, there's plenty to do at Fort Stanwix!

images.altText: Children dance, jump, and skip on the parade ground of reconstructed Fort Stanwix.
images.title: Celebrate the Park! Fort Stanwix at 40 & the NPS Centennial!
images.caption: The park is gearing up for the National Park Service Centennial. Find out what's going on and what's already been done!

images.altText: Small boxes in rows contain small artifacts, including broken pipes and glass bottles.
images.title: Objects From the Past: Museum Collection
images.caption: Learn more about the objects in the park's museum collection.

images.altText: A woman digs in a carefully excavated hole.
images.title: Uncovering the Past at Fort Stanwix
images.caption: What evidence of the past has been found at Fort Stanwix? Stop through to find out!

images.altText: Soldiers stand in a neat row holding their muskets.
images.title: Fort Stanwix: History Happened Here!
images.caption: Discover the vital role that Fort Stanwix/Schuyler, the fort that "never surrendered" played in the American Revolution.

directionsInfo:
General Grant National Memorial is located in Riverside Park, on the upper west-side of Manhattan. 

The entrance to the mausoleum is between north-bound and south-bound Riverside Drive, near the intersection of West 122nd Street. The visitor center is located to the west, across south-bound Riverside Drive.

Street parking is available, but can be very hard to find. The area is well-served with both Bus and Subway, by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York (http://www.mta.info/).
weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
name: General Grant
description: The final resting place of President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia, is the largest mausoleum in North America. It testifies to a people’s gratitude for the man who ended the bloodiest conflict in American history as Commanding General of the Union Army and then, as President of the United States, strove to heal a nation after a civil war and make rights for all citizens a reality.

images.altText: General Grant Mausoleum
images.title: General Grant Mausoleum
images.caption: General Grant Mausoleum

images.altText: Two red stone sarcophagi are in a crypt. A bust of General Sherman can be seen in the distance.
images.title: The Sarcophagi of Ulysses and Julia Grant
images.caption: Two sarcophagi, made of granite from Wisconsin, house the remains of Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia. Bronze busts of key union generals (like William T. Sherman seen here) occupy the  niches in the lower crypt.

images.altText: A circular dome is held up by carvings of allegorical figures.
images.title: The Upper Dome of the Mausoleum
images.caption: The dome of the memorial stretches 150 feet into the sky. On its four corners are four allegorical sculptures, executed by J. Massey Rhind.

images.altText: A neoclassic pavilion sits on the hillside, surrounded by trees with the Hudson River below.
images.title: The Overlook Pavillion, above the Visitor Center
images.caption: The Overlook Pavilion is great place to check out the scenery. Beneath the overlook is the park's visitor center.

images.altText: A black wrought-iron fence surrounds two trees. The enclosure is located directly behind the tomb.
images.title: Site of the Temporary Tomb
images.caption: This enclosure marks the location of the temporary vault where Grant was initially interred. His remains were in the temporary vault for 12 years, from 1885-1897.

directionsInfo: Governors Island is located in New York Harbor, 1/2 mile from the southern tip of Lower Manhattan and 400 yards west of the end of Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue and Red Hook waterfront. It is accessible only via ferry. Ferry service from Manhattan is the main way to access the island. During the summer public access season, the ferry departs from Battery Maritime Building at 10 South Street, at South and Whitehall Streets (next to the Staten Island ferry terminal). Check www.govisland.com for ferry schedules.
weatherInfo: During the summer public access season from May to September, the weather is typical of the mid-Atlantic region. Thunderstorms can come quickly with short downpours. There may be extended periods of heat or humidity that might last a week or more. The island is generally a few degrees cooler than the city due to the fairly constant breeze.
name: Governors Island
description: From 1794 to 1966, the U.S. Army on Governors Island was part of the social, political, and economic tapestry of New York City. Today, the island is a vibrant summer seasonal venue of art, culture, and performance against the backdrop of two centuries of military heritage and the skyline of one of the great cities of the world. The island is open to the public,  May 1st thru Oct 31st

images.altText: Bridge over dry moat leading into a gated fort.
images.title: Fort Jay gate house and moat.
images.caption: An early spring morning view of Fort Jay. The gate house is the oldest structure on Governors Island dating back to 1794.

images.altText: Front of sandstone brick fort with arched entrance way.
images.title: Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument
images.caption: Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument was constructed in 1811 and was a pioneering design in American fortifications.

images.altText: A park ranger talking to a group of visitors inside a large stone room in a fort.
images.title: Ranger guided tour of Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument
images.caption: Ranger-led tours of Castle Williams show the pioneering features of fortification architecture that would be used in other masonry forts constructed in the 1800s.

images.altText: Manhattan Skyline stands behind the barracks of Fort Jay
images.title: Manhattan from Fort Jay
images.caption: History frames our understanding of the present

images.altText: Canon and Manhattan Skyline from top of castle
images.title: Manhattan from Castle Williams
images.caption: A civil war era canon sitting upon the top of Castle Williams juxtaposes the new and old, with the glimering shine of Manhattan in the background

directionsInfo: Hamilton Grange National Memorial is in Saint Nicholas Park in Manhattan. It is located at 414 West 141st Street, between Convent Avenue and St. Nicholas Avenue.
weatherInfo: New York City has a temperate climate, and temperatures in northern Manhattan are frequently several degrees cooler than those in the southern part of the city.
name: Hamilton Grange
description: Alexander Hamilton created the tools for the success of the United States. From his humble beginnings as an orphan on the Caribbean island of Nevis, he became George Washington's right-hand man. Come visit Hamilton Grange and find out more about this controversial founder and the country home that he built on his Harlem estate.

images.altText: Hamilton Grange National Memorial
images.title: Hamilton Grange National Memorial
images.caption: Hamilton Grange National Memorial

images.altText: Hamilton Grange National Memorial, Entrance
images.title: Hamilton Grange National Memorial, Entrance
images.caption: Hamilton Grange National Memorial, Entrance

images.altText: Hamilton Grange On The Move
images.title: Hamilton Grange On The Move
images.caption: The Grange on its way to a new home in St. Nicholas Park.

directionsInfo:
The Harriet Tubman National Historical Park includes the Thompson Memorial African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, the Harriet Tubman Visitor Center, the Tubman Home for the Aged, and the Harriet Tubman Residence. A related Tubman site that lies outside of the national historical park is the Fort Hill Cemetery where Tubman is buried. 

View directions to each of these five sites on our directions page.
weatherInfo: Auburn, New York has four distinct seasons. Fall and spring are usually mild and summers tend to be sunny, warm, and humid. Winter weather is variable and conditions can change quickly. Snow in November is not uncommon. The heaviest snowfall tends to be in January with an average of 33”.
name: Harriet Tubman
description: Harriet Tubman was guided by a deep faith and devotion to family, freedom, and community. After emancipating herself and members of her family, she moved them from Ontario, Canada to Fleming and Auburn, New York in 1859. Central New York was a center for progressive thought, abolition, and women’s suffrage where Tubman continued to fight for human rights and dignity until she died in 1913.

images.altText: White single family home with front porch.
images.title: Harriet Tubman Home for the Aged
images.caption: Part of Tubman's Auburn farm, this building helped shelter the needy.

images.altText: Wooden church with tall steeple
images.title: Thompson Memorial AME Zion Church
images.caption: Located near Tubman's home, the church continues to honor Tubman's legacy of freedom.

images.altText: Headstone of Harriet Tubman
images.title: Tubman Grave
images.caption: Tubman grave at Fort Hill Cemetery

images.altText: Brick building surrounded by autumn trees
images.title: Harriet Tubman Residence
images.caption: Tubman's Auburn residence.

directionsInfo: The Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site is located on Route 9 in Hyde Park, NY about 90 miles north of New York City and 70 miles south of Albany.
weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40°F to 70°F.  Rain is not uncommon.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70° F to 100° F.  Humidity can be high throughout the summer months with periods of rain.

Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40° F to 70° F.  Peak leaf season is mid-October.  Rain is not uncommon.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30° F to 50°F.   Ice, Freezing Rain and Snow are not uncommon.
name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt
description:
"All that is within me cries out to go back to my home on the Hudson River" FDR

This quote captures FDR's connection to Springwood, the estate that he loved & the place he considered home. The first US Presidential Library was started by FDR here. Visit the Home of FDR and Presidential Library & Museum to learn about the only President elected to four terms.

images.altText: Springwood, the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt
images.title: Springwood - Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt
images.caption: Spingwood, the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt

images.altText: The Rose Garden at the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt

images.caption: The Rose Garden at the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt

images.title: Springwood
images.caption: Springwood

images.altText: Christmas at Springwood

images.caption: Christmas at Springwood

directionsInfo: For directions to particular sites within the Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area, visit http://www.hudsonrivervalley.com
weatherInfo: For details and information, please visit www.hudsonrivervalley.com.
name: Hudson River Valley
description: Maurice D. Hinchey Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area stretches from New York City to Albany. The area's resources exhibit the roles of freedom and dignity in the valley's history, and the historical and contemporary role of commerce. Revolutionary War stories, famous residences, scenic parks and gardens, and landscapes all contribute to the Hudson Valley's beauty and significance.

images.altText: Lookout over the Hudson River
images.title: Hudson River Valley From Constitution Island
images.caption: The Hudson River Valley is full of natural wonders, historic riches, and cultural treasures

fullName: Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area

directionsInfo: Located on the corner of Delancey Street, the Visitor Center and Museum Shop is where tours start and end, and where tickets are sold.
weatherInfo: For details and information, visit, https://www.tenement.org/.
name: Lower East Side Tenement Museum
description: The heart of the museum is a historic tenement, home to an estimated 7,000 people from over 20 nations between 1863 and 1935. The tenement’s cramped living spaces, the lives of past residents and the history of the Lower East Side, contribute to its representation of the immigrant experience. Throughout the year, programs such as walking tours and readings are offered.

images.altText: Brick building in downtown NYC
images.title: Lower East Side Tenement Museum
images.caption: Lower East Side Tenement Museum

fullName: Lower East Side Tenement Museum National Historic Site

directionsInfo:
The park entrance road is located off of route 9H  two miles south of Kinderhook Village.  

GPS Coordinates:  42° 22' 52'' N   -73° 42' 13'' W
weatherInfo: The weather at Martin Van Buren National Historic Site is typical of the northeast United States; it varies considerably throughout the year. Always check the forecast prior to your visit and dress accordingly. Be sure to wear comfortable walking shoes.
name: Martin Van Buren
description: Politics before the Civil War was a whirlwind of opposing interest groups. Martin Van Buren was able to unite those groups becoming president in 1837. As frustration and violence over the extension of slavery grew in the 1840's, Van Buren ran for the presidency twice more from this house. He hoped to unite sectional interests but failed; ultimately so did the union.

images.altText: Sunset over the farm fields of Lindewald
images.title: Sunset over the farm fields of Lindewald
images.caption: A stunning sunset over the the fields of Lindenwald with the Catskill Mountains rising in the distance.

images.altText: President Van Buren's Home
images.title: President Van Buren's Home
images.caption: Van Buren called his home and farm Lindenwald.  He lived here after his term as president from 1841 to 1862.  He ran two presidential campaign from Lindenwald in 1844 and 1848.He ran presidential vam

images.credit: National Park Service by Michael Fredericks
images.altText: Paycheck from Martin Van Buren to Irish Servant Catherine Kelly
images.title: Paycheck from Martin Van Buren to Irish Servant Catherine Kelly
images.caption: Many of the domestic workers at Lindenwald were Irsh.  They are emblamatic of the great waves of immigrants which beagn arriving in the United states during the ante bellum period.

images.credit: national Park Service by Michael Fredericks
images.altText: Martin Van Buren by Hiram Powers
images.title: Martin Van Buren by Hiram Powers
images.caption: This bust of van Buren which is in the library of Lindenwald was sculpted by Hiram Powers.  Another version of the bust may be found in the Red Room of the White House.

images.altText: Lindenwald's Main Hall
images.title: Lindenwald's Main Hall
images.caption: The main hall and dining table at Lindenwald were used by President Van Buren to not only entertain, but to use his skills to bend political issues his way through the ante bellum period.

fullName: Martin Van Buren National Historic Site

directionsInfo: See the websites for each of the ten national parks in New York Harbor for directions. To get to our offices at Federal Hall National Memorial: the main entrance of Federal Hall is located at 26 Wall Street, near the corner of Wall Street and Nassau Street. The rear entrance, which is wheelchair accessible, is located at 15 Pine Street, near the intersection of Pine Street and Nassau Street. It is highly recommended that all visitors use mass transit when traveling to Federal Hall.
weatherInfo:
Look up weather for New York City for most of the national parks in New York Harbor:
http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=40.7142&lon=-74.0059#.VqfYL_krKUk. Gateway National Recreation Area's Sandy Hook Unit in central New Jersey  can be found here: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=40.7142&lon=-74.0059#.VqfYL_krKUk.
name: National Parks of New York Harbor
description:
National Parks in New York City? Yes! There are 11 parks with a total of 23 different sites you can visit in all five boroughs and parts of New Jersey.

Check them out below.

images.altText: Manhattan skyline as seen from Governors Island National Monument
images.title: Manhattan skyline as seen from Governors Island National Monument
images.caption: National Parks of New York Harbor includes ten national parks, including six within Manhattan alone.

images.altText: General Grant National Memorial at dusk in midwinter
images.title: General Grant National Memorial at dusk in midwinter
images.caption: The largest mausoleum in North America pays tribute to Civil War general and U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant, who is entombed here with his wife Julia.

images.altText: Battery Weed, Fort Wadsworth, Staten Island
images.title: Battery Weed, Fort Wadsworth, Staten Island
images.caption: Gateway National Recreation Area covers two states and three New York City boroughs. Several of its sites are former military bases, such as Fort Wadsworth.

images.altText: Statue of Liberty looking ahead
images.title: Statue of Liberty looking ahead
images.caption: Statue of Liberty National Monument also includes Ellis Island Immigration Museum.

images.altText: African Burial Ground National Monument
images.title: African Burial Ground National Monument
images.caption: A vast cemetery for enslaved and free Africans, forgotten since the 1790s, was rediscovered in 1991.

fullName: National Parks of New York Harbor

directionsInfo:
From the South: Take I-90 to I-290 north to I-190. Follow the signs to Niagara Falls.

From Canada: Cross the Niagara River on either Ontario Provincial Highway 420 in Niagara Falls, Ontario, or Provincial Highway 405 north of Niagara Falls, Ontario.
weatherInfo: For details and information, visit, http://www.discoverniagara.org/.
name: Niagara Falls
description: Designated by Congress in 2008, the Niagara Falls National Heritage Area stretches from the western boundary of Wheatfield, New York to the mouth of the Niagara River on Lake Ontario, including the communities of Niagara Falls, Youngstown, and Lewiston. The region is home to natural wonders, rich cultural traditions, and nationally significant historical sites.

images.altText: Arial view of Niagara Falls State Park
images.title: Niagara Falls State Park
images.caption: Niagara Falls State Park

directionsInfo: Take either the Northern State Parkway to Exit 35N or the Long Island Expressway (I-495) to Exit 41N. At those exits, take Route 106 North for approximately 6 miles to downtown Oyster Bay. Turn right onto East Main Street (at Nobman's Hardware Store) and travel 2 miles on East Main Street/Cove Road. Turn left onto Cove Neck Road and drive 1.5 miles to Sagamore Hill National Historic Site.
weatherInfo:
The Atlantic Ocean and Long Island Sound moderates the climate of Long Island and Sagamore Hill.

Spring: Highs average between 50 F and 70 F. Snow in early March becomes rain by April.
Summer: Average highs range between 70 F and the upper 80s F. Summers are drier but thunderstorms are possible.
Fall: Highs are from the mid-50s F to the mid-70s F. Fall is the driest season, but showers are possible.
Winter: Highs are around 40 F. Snow showers are common; the largest accumulations come in February.
name: Sagamore Hill
description: Sagamore Hill was the home of Theodore Roosevelt, 26th President of the United States, from 1885 until his death in 1919. During Roosevelt's time in office, his "Summer White House" was the focus of international attention. Explore the natural surroundings and become inspired by the legacy of one of America's most popular presidents.

images.altText: Theodore Roosevelt House with state historical society signage
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt House
images.caption: Theodore Roosevelt House at Sagamore Hill

images.altText: A nature trail to Cold Spring Harbor passes through woods.
images.title: Nature Trail
images.caption: Walk the grounds and explore the place the Roosevelt family called home.

images.altText: Papers, pens, and an inkwell arranged on a wooden desk.
images.title: Roosevelt's Library
images.caption: World War I-era papers on Theodore Roosevelt's library desk

directionsInfo: Take the 5 Lexington Avenue (green) line to the Dyre Avenue station in the Bronx, the last stop. Proceed north to E. 233rd Street and make a right, going east. Walk several blocks. Make a left onto Provost, heading north. Provost becomes S. Third Ave. Continue north on S. Third Avenue to the stop sign on the right at the Salvation Army. Make a right at stop sign onto S. Columbus. Saint Paul's will be on your right. Walk from the subway to the site should be about 15 minutes, approximately 2/3 of a mile.
weatherInfo: The weather in New York City is basically the same as for this northern suburb. Please visit http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=40.91259830500047&lon=-73.83707741599966#.Vqjtf_krKUk.
name: Saint Paul's Church
description: Since 1665, Saint Paul's Church played a vital role in the colonial life of Eastchester, 20 miles north of New York City. Townspeople voted at the nearby Village Green; local militia drilled outside its doors. But the American Revolution changed everything. American, British and Hessian troops tore down the old wooden meetinghouse for firewood and used the unfinished stone chapel as a hospital.

images.altText: Rebecca Turner gravesite
images.title: Rebecca Turner gravesite
images.caption: A former enslaved person, Rebecca Turner attended the church and is buried in the cemetery. A local elementary school is named after her.

images.altText: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site
images.title: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site
images.caption: The church was originally a wooden meetinghouse. This stone structure was still unfinished when US, British and Hessian troops used it for a hospital during the Revolution.

images.altText: Encampment volley
images.title: Encampment volley
images.caption: History is a blast, especially when costumed Revolutionary War interpreters visit the site during a special event.

images.altText: Local students gather inside Saint Paul's Church
images.title: Local students gather inside Saint Paul's Church
images.caption: In 2015, local students visited the site to honor Rebecca and Benjamin Turner, two former members of Saint Paul's Church. Local schools have been named after the couple.

images.altText: The restored church pews
images.title: The restored church pews
images.caption: The pews have been rebuilt to resemble what was here when the stone church was first opened.

fullName: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site

directionsInfo: Saratoga National Historical Park is located between U.S. Route 4 and N.Y. Route 32, about 4 miles north of the Village of Stillwater, N.Y. The park is roughly 40 miles north of Albany, N.Y. and 14 miles southeast of Saratoga Springs, N.Y.  More detailed directions, and downloadable maps, are available on our website.
weatherInfo: The park experiences all four seasons.  Temperatures can be as low as -20 degrees Fahrenheit in winter and as high as 100 degrees Fahrenheit in summer.  Check local weather reports for more detailed information.
name: Saratoga
description: Here, in 1777, during the American War for Independence, American troops battled and beat a British invasion force, marking the first time in world history that a British Army ever surrendered. This crucial victory secured essential foreign recognition and support, instigated world-wide wars, affirmed United States independence, and changed the face of the world.

images.altText: A building shaped slightly like two low, adjoining mushrooms sits on a lush green lawn.
images.title: Battlefield Visitor Center
images.caption: Our Visitor Center boasts a scenic view overlooking part of the Battlefield.

images.altText: A small, red farmhouse sits beside a red cannon and a few green trees.
images.title: John Neilson House
images.caption: Neilson House was a mid-level American headquarters in the Battles of Saratoga.

images.altText: A narrow, winding path leads through some trees to a 2-story yellow house.
images.title: Philip Schuyler House
images.caption: Schuyler House was the country estate of American General Philip Schuyler.

images.altText: A narrow, stone obelisk on top of a green hill reaches into a partly cloudy sky.
images.title: Saratoga Monument
images.caption: This 19th-century obelisk commemorates America's victory in the Battles of Saratoga.

images.altText: An informational sign sits beside a wooden walkway winding amid early autumn trees.
images.title: Victory Woods
images.caption: A half-mile path through Victory Woods tells of this last British camp following the Battles of Saratoga.

directionsInfo: Liberty Island is located in New York Harbor, and can only be reached by boat. Ferries operated by Statue Cruises depart from Battery Park in Lower Manhattan in New York City, New York and Liberty State Park in Jersey City, New Jersey.
weatherInfo: It is typically colder and more windy in New York Harbor than in elsewhere in the New York City metropolitan area. Winters are cold and damp. Spring and Fall can range from chilly to warm. Summers are warm to hot and humid.
name: Statue Of Liberty
description: "The Statue of Liberty Enlightening the World" was a gift of friendship from the people of France to the United States and is recognized as a universal symbol of freedom and democracy. The Statue of Liberty was dedicated on October 28, 1886.  It was designated as a National Monument in 1924.  Employees of the National Park Service have been caring for the colossal copper statue since 1933.

images.altText: Patina green statue atop her pedestal on Liberty Island; grey cloudy sky in the distance
images.title: The Statue of Liberty on Liberty Island from Statue Cruises Ferry
images.caption: The Statue of Liberty's patina green stands out brilliantly on a cloudy day.

images.altText: The Statue of Liberty in front of the New York City skyline.
images.title: The Statue of Liberty with New York City Skyline
images.caption: Statue of Liberty stands tall on Liberty Island with the skyline of bustling New York City in view.

images.altText: Close-up of the Statue of Liberty's head, crown, and the folds of her robe
images.title: Close-up of the Statue of Liberty's Head
images.caption: This close-up reveals fine details of the Statue of Liberty's face, hair, crown, and robe, which can be difficult to see even in person.

images.altText: Entire patina green Statue of Liberty and very top of granite pedestal
images.title: The Statue of Liberty taken on Liberty Island
images.caption: The Statue of Liberty stands tall on her pedestal: from the ground to the tip of the torch, she measures 305 feet 1 inch (93 meters)!

images.altText: Shoulders, head, and raised right arm of the Statue of Liberty from behind the statue.
images.title: Statue of Liberty from Flagpole Plaza on Liberty Island
images.caption: Millions visit the Statue of Liberty each year, but only a select few, like this peregrine falcon perched on the left-most ray, enjoy the view from above the crown.

directionsInfo: Christopher Park is bounded by Christopher, Grove, and West Fourth Streets. By subway, take the Broadway 1 Line - 7th Avenue local to Christopher Street-Sheridan Square Station; or via the 7th Avenue bus line on the M8 or M20. From Jersey City, take the Holland Tunnel to Ericsson Pl, via exit 3, then take the Avenue of the Americas north to Christopher Street. From Brooklyn take the Manhattan Bridge to Canal Street, then take the Avenue of the Americas north to Christopher Street.
weatherInfo: New York City experiences all four seasons. It is typically hot in the summer and cold in the winter with cool springs and autumns.
name: Stonewall
description: Before the 1960s almost everything about living openly as a lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, or queer (LGBTQ) person was illegal. New York City laws against homosexual activities were particularly harsh. The Stonewall Uprising on June 28, 1969 is a milestone in the quest for LGBTQ civil rights and provided momentum for a movement.

directionsInfo: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site is conveniently located in New York City at 28 East 20th Street, between Park Avenue South and Broadway.
weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
name: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace
description: This is the boyhood home of the first U.S. president to be born in New York City. Raised in a townhouse at 28 E. 20th St., Theodore Roosevelt would grow up to be our 26th President and become immortalized on Mount Rushmore. However, he started life as a sickly yet bright boy who exercised to improve his health and began a lifelong passion for the "strenuous life."

images.altText: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace Exterior
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace Exterior
images.caption: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace Exterior

fullName: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site

directionsInfo:
The TR Inaugural Site is located on the north edge of downtown Buffalo on Delaware Avenue, between Allen and North Streets.  Free parking is available to the rear.

For details, see http://www.nps.gov/thri/planyourvisit/directions.htm
weatherInfo:
Summer tends to be mild but humid.
Fall moderate temperatures.
Winters can have prolonged cold spells and be snowy, with occasional periods of intense snow.
Spring mild and rainy.
name: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural
description: As president, Theodore Roosevelt created protections for ordinary citizens, began regulation of big business, and made the US a major force in international affairs. Yet one of the most important presidencies in America's history nearly didn't happen. See the place where a brief, emotional, and improvised ceremony in Buffalo, NY brought TR into office, and forever altered the nation.

images.altText: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural Site
images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural Site
images.caption: This home in Buffalo, NY, is where Theodore Roosevelt took the oath of office as President on September 14, 1901.

fullName: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural National Historic Site

directionsInfo: The Thomas Cole National Historic Site is located at 218 Spring Street, near the western entrance to the Rip Van Winkle Bridge, in the village of Catskill, New York, at the foot of the Catskill Mountains in the Hudson Valley.
weatherInfo: For details and information, visit, http://www.thomascole.org/.
name: Thomas Cole
description:
In 1825, America was still a new nation, just forming its own unique identity and traditions. Thomas Cole invented a new style of art, one that Americans could call their own. His landscape paintings launched the art movement known as the Hudson River School.

His groundbreaking achievements took place here in Catskill, New York -- in the "peaceful shades" of his beloved home, Cedar Grove.

images.altText: Yellow home with a large porch sits underneath large trees
images.title: Thomas Cole National Historic Site
images.caption: Thomas Cole National Historic Site

directionsInfo: See complete directions on Upper Delaware S&RR's webpage.
weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from lows of 26 F to highs of 80 F with average rainfall of 5 inches.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from lows of 55 F to highs of 85 F with average rainfall of 4 inches. 

Fall: Temperatures usually range from lows of 30 F to highs of 83F. Fall foliage is at its peak sometime in October as daily mountain temperatures vary frequently and influence the change.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from lows of 15 F to highs of 49 F.
name: Upper Delaware
description: Canoe through rapids and quiet pools as the Delaware River winds its way through a valley of swiftly changing scenery or fish amid rolling hills and riverfront villages in one of the finest fishing rivers in the northeastern United States. The clean water of the Delaware, the last major undammed river in the eastern United States, supports a healthy ecosystem and offers tranquility and excitement.

images.title: Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River
images.caption: A view of Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River

images.altText: a Park Ranger shows children the wonders of nature
