weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40°F to 70°F.  Rain is not uncommon.

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70° F to 100° F.  Humidity can be high throughout the summer months with periods of rain.

Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40° F to 70° F.  Peak leaf season is mid-October.  Rain is not uncommon.

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30° F to 50°F.   Ice, Freezing Rain and Snow are not uncommon.
name: Vanderbilt Mansion
description: Vanderbilt Mansion NHS, in terms of architecture, interiors, mechanical systems, road systems and landscape, is a remarkably complete example of a gilded-age country place, illustrating the political, economic, social, cultural, and demographic changes that occurred as America industrialized in the years after the Civil War.

images.altText: Misty April Morning
images.title: Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site
images.caption: A misty Spring morning at the Vanderbilt Mansion

images.altText: Fall Colors in the Hudson Valley
images.title: Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site
images.caption: Thousands of visitors flock to the Hudson Valley in the Fall to see the leaves change colors.

images.altText: The Formal Gardens
images.title: The F. W. Vanderbilt Formal Gardens
images.caption: The formal gardens of the Vanderbilt Estate consist of multiple tiers defined over a hillside, surrounded by a graceful landscape.

images.altText: View of the Hudson River looking North from the Overlook
images.title: Overlook
images.caption: The inspiring historic view of the Hudson River from the Overlook at Vanderbilt Mansion.

images.altText: West Point Band performs at the Vanderbilt Mansion
images.title: Summer Concert Series
images.caption: West Point Band performs at Vanderbilt Mansion, part of the Summer Concert Series.

directionsInfo: From the New York State Thruway (I-90) take exit 41 (Route 414). Turn right onto Route 414 South after exiting the tollbooth. Follow Route 414 South for approximately four miles. At the intersections of Route 414 and Routes 5 & 20, turn left onto Route 5 & 20 East. Follow for approximately one and a half miles into the Village of Seneca Falls. The Visitor Center is on the left at 136 Fall Street, Seneca Falls, NY 13148.
weatherInfo: In the winter, temperatures range from 0-40 degrees with an average of 10 inches of snow per month. Summer temperatures range from 60-85 degrees with high humidity.
name: Women's Rights
description: Women’s Rights National Historical Park tells the story of the first Women’s Rights Convention held in Seneca Falls, NY on July 19-20,1848.  It is a story of struggles for civil rights, human rights, and equality, global struggles that continue today.  The efforts of women’s rights leaders, abolitionists, and other 19th century reformers remind us that all people must be accepted as equals.

images.altText: The Wesleyan Chapel in summer
images.title: Wesleyan Chapel
images.caption: The Wesleyan Chapel, site of the first Women's Rights Convention

images.altText: Front of Women's Rights National Historical Park Visitor Center
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors can come to learn about the largest social movement in history, the women's rights movement.

images.altText: The Elizabeth Cady Stanton House with a tree and National Park Service sign in the front yard
images.title: Elizabeth Cady Stanton House
images.caption: Take a ranger led tour in the home where Elizabeth Cady Stanton led the women's rights movement and raised 7 children

directionsInfo: The Blue Ridge Parkway Visitor Center is located at Parkway milepost 384, which is about a mile south of the US 70 intersection (or one mile north of the US 74-A intersection) and about 8 miles east of downtown Asheville. The Folk Art Center is located nearby, two miles to the north along the Parkway.
weatherInfo: https://www.wunderground.com/q/zmw:28801.1.99999
name: Blue Ridge
description: The Blue Ridge National Heritage Area is a place unlike any other on Earth, where ancient landscapes enchant the eye and age-old traditions warm the heart.  The distinctive landscape of the North Carolina mountains and foothills combined with the region’s living traditions of craft, music, agriculture and Cherokee heritage create a wealth of natural and cultural treasures unmatched in our country.

images.altText: Southeast Region NHA
images.title: Southeast Region NHA
images.caption: Southeast Region NHA

directionsInfo: The Parkway is a 469 mile long scenic road connecting Shenandoah National Park in Virginia to Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina. There are numerous places to get on and off near interstate crossings and other federal and state highways. There are markers every mile along the Parkway, counting from 0-469 through Virginia and North Carolina. We suggest using a map and identifying the area you want to go, as GPS directions often do not understand our milepost system.
weatherInfo: The weather on the Parkway can vary wildly due to different elevations and locations along the 469 mile stretch. Precipitation is possible any time of the year. Winter can be cold and snowy, especially at the higher elevations. Spring and fall can have large temperature swings, from near freezing to over 70 degrees Fahrenheit. Summers can be hot in the lower elevations, but the highest elevations will remain cool. The mountains can also create summertime thunderstorms, so be prepared for weather changes.
name: Blue Ridge
description: A Blue Ridge Parkway experience is unlike any other: a slow-paced and relaxing drive revealing stunning long-range vistas and close-up views of the rugged mountains and pastoral landscapes of the Appalachian Highlands. The Parkway meanders for 469 miles, protecting a diversity of plants and animals, and providing opportunities for enjoying all that makes this region of the country so special.

images.altText: Black Bear Cub
images.title: Black Bear Club
images.caption: Black bears are among the many mammals found across the Blue Ridge Parkway.

images.altText: Fall at Linn Cove Viaduct
images.title: Linn Cove Viaduct
images.caption: Linn Cove Viaduct, located in the North Carolina Highlands district, is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.altText: Summer colors at Mabry Mill
images.title: Mabry Mill
images.caption: Located in Virginia's Plateau district, picturesque Mabry Mill is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.altText: Mountain vista and clouds on the Blue Ridge Parkway
images.title: Mountain vista
images.caption: Beautiful mountain in North Carolina draw visitors from around the world to the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.altText: water cascading into Linville Falls plunge basin
images.title: Linville Falls
images.caption: The Linville Gorge offers visitors the opportunity to learn about fascinating geology and view magnificent waterfalls.

directionsInfo:
Cape Hatteras National Seashore is located along NC-12 in the Outer Banks of North Carolina. You can reach the seashore from the north by following US 158 to Nag Heads, NC and the turn-off to NC-12 and Cape Hatteras National Seashore. From the south, you can take NCDOT ferries from Swanquarter, NC and Cedar Island, NC to the village of Ocracoke on Ocracoke Island.

The provided physical address is the location of the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse, roughly in the middle of the park.
weatherInfo: The weather along the Outer Banks varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for forecast information.
name: Cape Hatteras
description: The sound of ocean waves, the starry night sky, or the calm of the salt marshes, you can experience it all. Shaped by the forces of water, wind, and storms these islands are ever changing. The plants, wildlife, and people who live here adapt continually. Whether you are enjoying the beach, kayaking the sound, or climbing the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse there is something for everyone to explore!

images.altText: A young girl performs a cartwheel as she enjoys the beach.
images.title: Cartwheel on the Beach
images.caption: Girl enjoys Cape Hatteras by performing a cartwheel.

images.altText: Black and white painting of the brick Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.
images.title: Cape Hatteras Lighthouse
images.caption: Black and white spirals decorate the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.

images.altText: Two kids play in the sand.
images.title: Playing in the Sand
images.caption: Two kids enjoy the sands of Cape Hatteras.

images.altText: A young girl paddles across the water with the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse visible in the distance.
images.title: Paddling Pamlico Sound
images.caption: Lots of recreation opportunities await visits on the sound side of the barrier islands.

images.altText: The first-order Fresnel lens is visible in the lantern room of the Bodie Island Lighthouse.
images.title: Fresnel Lens
images.caption: Bodie Island Lighthouse still has its first-order Fresnel lens.

directionsInfo: Only two areas of Cape Lookout National Seashore can be reached without taking a ferry: the Visitor Center  on Harkers Island and the Visitor Information Center in Beaufort, NC.  Please note: the park mailing address does not bring you to the Harkers Island Visitor Center parking lot. If you are using a GPS device - use the parking lot coordinates (34.68494, -74.52725) or the following "address" which approximates the location of the parking lot entrance: 1800 Island Rd, Harkers Island, NC 28531
weatherInfo:
Spring: Temperatures generally range from 50 F to 70+ F. Rain & wind are common

Summer: Temperatures usually range from 80 F to 100 F with high humidity (80-90%).  Average wind speed is 10-15 mph. Be prepared with plenty of water.  With little shade on the islands, an umbrella to provide shade from the sun is a good idea.
 
Fall: Temperatures usually range from the high 70 F to the upper 40 F.  

Winter: Temperatures usually range from 50 F - 32 F. Winds can be strong. Dress in layers.
name: Cape Lookout
description: A boat ride three miles off-shore brings you to the barrier islands of Cape Lookout National Seashore.  Horse watching, shelling, fishing, birding, camping, lighthouse climbing, and touring historic villages--there’s something for everyone at Cape Lookout.  Be sure to bring all the food, water, and supplies you need (and carry your trash out of the park) when visiting these remote beaches.

images.altText: Mature sea oat plant seed heads gracefully drooping in the sun
images.title: Sea Oats
images.caption: In late summer, Sea Oats are the most conspicuous plant growing on the sand dunes with their graceful, drooping seed heads.

images.altText: small sandpipers poke their bills in the sand while waves break in the background
images.title: Sanderlings
images.caption: Small sandpipers, called Sanderlings, are common sights on the ocean beach as they search for food in the sand between waves

images.altText: : Black & white patterned tower of the Cape Lookout Lighthouse stands against a blue & white cloud f
images.title: Cape Lookout Lighthouse
images.caption: The Cape Lookout Lighthouse is still an active aid-to-navigation, warning ships of the nearby shoals.  Climbing to up to see the view from the gallery level, 14 stories above the ground, is also a popular activity by visitors during the summer.

images.altText: 2 ladies sit in beach chairs on the sand with their feet in the water
images.title: Relaxing by the Ocean
images.caption: Watching the waves, feeling the cool sea breeze and the warmth of the sun make for a relaxing day.

images.altText: A surf fisherman stands in the water holding his surf rod and watching the waves
images.title: Surf fishing
images.caption: Surf fishing is a popular pastime at the beach

directionsInfo: The park is located three miles south of Hendersonville, NC on Little River Road off of the Greenville Highway/Rt. 225 in Flat Rock, NC. Visitors using GPS or mapping software should use 1800 Little River Road and look for the signs directing you to the visitor parking lot on Little River Road.

name: Carl Sandburg Home
description:
Carl Sandburg provided a popular voice for the American people of the twentieth century and still speaks to us through his words, activism, music and the beauty and serenity of Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site.

Explore Sandburg's legacy and Experience Your America!

images.altText: A view of the Sandburg Home as visitors enter the park
images.title: Carl Sandburg Home NHS
images.caption: The Sandburg family enjoyed living in the Carolina mountains along with a collection of 12,000 books and a herd of dairy goats.

images.altText: Dairy goats graze peacefully near the Sandburg barn

images.caption: Connemara Farms dairy goats graze peacefully near the Sandburg barn

images.altText: Spring-born kid goats greet visitors to the barn

images.caption: A view of the front lake and Sandburg Home as visitors enter the park

images.title: Hiking Trails in the Park
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy more than five miles of hiking trails through the park.

directionsInfo: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site is located on the northern end of Roanoke Island, north of the town of Manteo, NC.
weatherInfo: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Please check the National Weather Service at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for up-to-date weather forecast information.
name: Fort Raleigh
description:
Fort Raleigh National Historic Site protects and preserves known portions of England's first New World settlements from 1584 to 1590.

This site also preserves the cultural heritage of the Native Americans, European Americans and African Americans who have lived on Roanoke Island.

images.altText: View of the ditch and wall of the reconstructed earthwork

images.altText: Tree standing next to the maritime forest path of the Thomas Hariot Trail

images.caption: Venture through a maritime forest

images.altText: Pieces of a crucible left behind by the 1585 English expedition

images.caption: Home of The Lost Colony drama performed every summer

directionsInfo: Great Smoky Mountains National Park straddles the borders of the states of Tennessee and North Carolina. The three main entrances to the park are in the Gatlinburg, TN; Townsend, TN; and Cherokee, NC.
weatherInfo: Elevations in the park range from approximately 875 feet to 6,643 feet and the topography can drastically affect local weather. Temperatures can vary 10-20 degrees Fahrenheit from mountain base to top, and clear skies lower down do not guarantee equally pleasant weather at higher elevations. Visit http://www.nps.gov/grsm/planyourvisit/weather.htm for seasonal weather information and links to local forecasts.
name: Great Smoky Mountains
description: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park.

images.altText: A thick layer of frost covers the fields, trees, and mountains in Cades Cove.
images.title: Frosty Morning in Cades Cove
images.caption: Wintertime brings a quiet beauty to the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.altText: Wisps of fog hang over the forests in the mountains.
images.title: "Smoke" Rising From the Mountains
images.caption: The park gets its name from mists that often rise like smoke from the mountains.

images.altText: Tombstones stand in front of a white, wooden church on a foggy morning.
images.title: A Foggy Morning at Cades Cove Methodist Church
images.caption: Historic buildings such as churches, gristmills, barns, and homes allow visitors to get a feel for life in the mountains before the national park was created.

images.altText: Rhododendron bushes line the banks of a stream filled with large boulders.
images.title: The Waters of Roaring Fork Below Grotto Falls
images.caption: Abundant rainfall means lush forests and beautiful stream scenes in the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.altText: A hillside in the forest covered with white trillium flowers
images.title: The "Wildflower National Park"
images.caption: Wildflowers, such as these white trillium, can be found blooming from February through November in the park.

images.altText: Bright gold and red leaves shine through the fog in a forest.
images.title: Fall Colors Near Newfound Gap
images.caption: Fall leaf season is one of the busiest times of year in the park.

images.altText: Gold and red fall colors fill the valleys while snow coats the mountain tops.
images.title: Fall Meets Winter
images.caption: In spring and fall, weather in the foothills can be pleasant, while snow and cold rule on the mountain tops.

weatherInfo:
Summers are warm to hot and humid with the occasional thunderstorm.

Spring and Fall are cool with rainy periods.

Winter is mild and cold with snow and ice possible in January and February.

Wear comfortable clothing for the season and good walking shoes year round!
name: Guilford Courthouse
description:
"I never saw such fighting since God made me. The Americans fought like demons."

-Lt. General Charles, Earl Cornwallis

The largest battle of the Revolutionary War's Southern Campaign was fought at the small North Carolina backcountry hamlet of Guilford Courthouse. The battle proved to be a turning point for British military operations in the Revolutionary War.

directionsInfo:
Moores Creek National Battlefield is located 20 miles NW of Wilmington, North Carolina.
·  From Highway 17, follow US 421 to NC 210, then West on NC 210
·  From Interstate 40, take exit 408 (NC 210) West at Rocky Point.
·  From Interstate 95 North, take exit 13-A for NC 74 East towards Wilmington. 
·  From Interstate 95 South: take exit 81-B for I-40 East towards Wilmington. 
·  From Fayetteville, North Carolina, take Interstate 95 South to Exit 13-A

Questions please call us as 910-283-5591 x2234
weatherInfo: Currie, North Carolina has mild Winters and moderate to hot Summers with varying humidity.
name: Moores Creek
description: In the early morning hours of February 27, 1776 Loyalist forces charged across a partially dismantled Moores Creek Bridge. Beyond the bridge, nearly 1,000 North Carolina Patriots waited quietly with cannons and muskets poised to fire. This battle marked the last broadsword charge by Scottish Highlanders and the first significant victory for the Patriots in the American Revolution.

images.title: Artillery Demonstration at Moore's Creek
images.caption: Artillery Demonstration at Moore's Creek.

directionsInfo: The trail travels over 330 miles through four states.
weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
name: Overmountain Victory
description: Stretching 330 miles through four states (Virginia, Tennessee, North and South Carolina) the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail traces the route used by patriot militia during the pivotal Kings Mountain campaign of 1780. Follow the campaign by utilizing a Commemorative Motor Route which uses existing state highways marked with the distinctive trail logo, or 87 miles of walkable pathways.

images.altText: The OVVI NHT marker is on a fence with the Green River in the background.
images.title: AlexandersFordAtTheGreenRiver
images.caption: A trail marker is on a fence with the Green River in the background.

images.title: Alexander's Ford Trail
images.caption: Reenactors march along the historic trail at Alexander's Ford in North Carolina.

images.altText: A sign on the Overmountain Victory Trail at Elkin reminds visitors not to stray off the trail.

images.caption: A marker stands beside the winding trail in Abingdon, Virginia.

directionsInfo: Wright Brothers National Memorial is located along US 158 in the town of Kill Devil Hills on the Outer Banks of North Carolina.
weatherInfo: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Please check the National Weather Service at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for up-to-date weather forecast information.
name: Wright Brothers
description:
Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903.

With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever.

images.credit: Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright, and John Daniels
images.altText: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time as Wilbur assists.
images.title: First Flight
images.caption: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time on December 17, 1903.

images.altText: Copper busts of the two brothers with the moon visible in the blue sky.
images.title: Busts and Moon
images.caption: Copper busts of Wilbur and Orville Wright stand atop Big Kill Devil Hill.

images.altText: The large boulder and plaque sit where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.
images.title: First Flight Boulder
images.caption: This boulder marks the spot where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.

images.altText: Visitors walk along the flight line where Wilbur and Orville Wright flew and landed.
images.title: Walking Along History
images.caption: Visitors explore the landing spots of the Wright brothers' first flights.

images.altText: View straight up at the monument with the Sun directly behind the stonework.
images.title: Wright Brothers Monument
images.caption: Black-and-white image of the Wright Brothers Monument

images.altText: Two young girls look across the grounds of Wright Brothers National Memorial.
images.title: National Aviation Day
images.caption: Visitors enjoy celebrating aviation where modern aviation was born.

images.altText: Visitors moving along a sidewalk to the top of the hill where the monument stands.
images.title: Journey to the Top
images.caption: Visitors climb Big Kill Devil Hill to visit the Wright Brothers Monument.

directionsInfo:
Plane
Fly into Bismarck or Minot, ND. Hazen, ND (15 miles from site) has an airport for small planes.

Car
One-half mile north of Stanton, ND on County Road 37. One hour northwest of Bismarck, ND and one and a half hours southwest of Minot, ND.

Public Transportation
Charter and tour bus parking available at Visitor Center parking lot.
weatherInfo: Summers are warm and sunny with temperatures occasionally reaching 100 degrees F and frequent afternoon thunderstorms.  Winters are invigorating, with extremely cold temperatures as low as -35 degrees F.  High winds and sunny skies are common in winter.  Snow is sporadic in the relatively dry climate, but blizzards are common.
name: Knife River Indian Villages
description: Earthlodge people hunted bison and other game, but were in essence farmers living in villages along the Missouri and its tributaries. The site was a major Native American trade center for hundreds of years prior to becoming an important market place for fur traders after 1750.

images.caption: Garden

fullName: Knife River Indian Villages National Historic Site

directionsInfo:
Theodore Roosevelt National Park is located in the Badlands of western North Dakota. 
There are three units to the park. The South Unit entrance is in the town of Medora, ND off of Interstate 94 exits 24 and 27. The North Unit entrance is on Highway 85 approximately 14 miles south of Watford City, ND. The remote Elkhorn Ranch Unit sits roughly in the middle of the North and South Units and is accessed via gravel roads. Consult park staff for directions to the Elkhorn Ranch Unit.
weatherInfo: In winter, some or all park roads may be closed due to snow.
name: Theodore Roosevelt
description: When Theodore Roosevelt came to Dakota Territory to hunt bison in 1883, he was a skinny, young, spectacled dude from New York. He could not have imagined how his adventure in this remote and unfamiliar place would forever alter the course of the nation. The rugged landscape and strenuous life that TR experienced here would help shape a conservation policy that we still benefit from today.

images.altText: the Little Missouri River under blue skies
images.title: A View from the Maah Daah Hey Trail
images.caption: The Maah Daah Hey Trail follows the Little Missouri River for several miles before it enters the Theodore Roosevelt Wilderness.

images.altText: A colorfully striped butte in the foreground overlooks a dark green badlands landscape
images.title: River Bend Overlook, North Unit
images.caption: The River Bend Overlook offers one of the most popular views in the park's North Unit.

images.altText: a green prairie hilltop overlooks the badlands, shrouded in shadows
images.title: Sunset on Buck Hill
images.caption: A short climb to the top of Buck Hill in the park's South Unit rewards hikers with a sweeping panorama and a fantastic place to watch the sun rise or set.

images.altText: A muddy river bank lined with cottonwood trees and steep buttes
images.title: Ekblom Trail
images.caption: The Ekblom Trail is the gateway to the Theodore Roosevelt Wilderness. All you have to do is make it across the river!

images.credit: NPS Photo / Roland and Lisa Honeyman
images.altText: a string of bison are silhouetted against the backdrop of hazy blue and yellow badlands
images.title: Bison Trail
images.caption: Bison roam the badlands from top to bottom, surprising visitors with their agility and ability to cross even the most rugged terrain.

images.altText: two bull bison collide heads in a dusty battle for dominance
images.title: Raise a Ruckus
images.caption: In the summer, bull bison wage furious battles over the right to breed.

images.credit: NPS Photo / Rolan and Lisa Honeyman
images.altText: A bugling bull elk and his harem of cows stand on the edge of a butte as the sunlight fades
images.title: Fall Bugle
images.caption: The ghostly bugles of bull elk can be heard wafting through the badlands in the fall.

images.altText: the swirling, dusty looking milky way runs vertically though a starry night sky
images.title: Milky Way
images.caption: Though light pollution in the area is increasing, the night sky over Theodore Roosevelt National Park remains beautiful and inspiring.

images.altText: a strange looking sand and rock formation stands in a prairie of brown grass
images.title: Hoodoos
images.caption: Theodore Roosevelt described the badlands as "so fantastically broken in form and so bizarre in color as to seem hardly properly to belong to this earth."

images.altText: The rising sun casts light on Roosevelt's snow-covered cabin.
images.title: Maltese Cross Cabin
images.caption: Imagine waking up on a crisp winter morning in Roosevelt's Maltese Cross Cabin. It is no wonder that his heart was captured by the romance of life in the West.

directionsInfo:
The park is centrally located along the western shoreline of Saipan, adjacent to downtown Garapan.
From airport, proceed north on Airport Road (Tun Herman Pan Highway) until the road ends at Monsignor Guerrero Road (Highway 16). Turn left and continue until the road ends at Beach Road. Turn right until the road ends at the American Memorial Park Mall. Turn left onto Micro Beach Road. The parking lot is on the right.
weatherInfo:
Saipan Island has a tropical rainforest climate with no dry season. 
The temperature varies from 75°F to 88°F and is rarely below 73°F or above 90°F.The climate is tropical, hot and humid throughout the year, with a relatively cool and dry season from December to June, and a warmer and rainy season from July to November.  The temperatures are stable throughout the year.
name: American Memorial
description: American Memorial Park honors the American and Marianas people who gave their lives during the Marianas Campaign of World War II. 5,204 names are inscribed on a memorial which was dedicated during the 50th Anniversary of the Invasion of Saipan. Within the 133-acre boundary are white beaches, sporting areas, picnic sites, playgrounds, walkways, and a 30-acre protected wetland and mangrove forest.

images.altText: Large lawn in front of the memorial.
images.title: Lawn at American Memorial Park
images.caption: A popular place for visitors.

images.altText: Rehearsing at the American Memorial Park ampitheater
images.title: Ampitheater at American Memorial Park
images.caption: The ampitheater is where many performances take place.

images.altText: The visitor center is open daily.
images.title: Visitor Center at American Memorial Park
images.caption: The visitor center  is a popular place to learn about Saipan's role in WWII history.

images.altText: People walking the paths at the American Memorial Park.
images.title: Walking the path at American Memorial Park.
images.caption: The paths at the American Memorial Park are always in use.

images.altText: Crystal clear blue swimming at the park.
images.title: The beach at American Memorial Park.
images.caption: The beach is an inviting place to swim and relax.

directionsInfo: "Youngsholm" is located in Wilberforce, Ohio near Wilberforce University. It is situated less than one mile west of the Wilberforce University and Central State University campuses on U.S. Route 42 at 1120 US Route 42 E.
weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 29 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 74 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just under 40". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of about 22".
name: Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers
description: Throughout his life, Charles Young overcame countless obstacles in his ascent to prominence.  In spite of overt racism and stifling inequality, Young rose through the military ranks to become one of the most respected leaders of his time.  A well-rounded man with a steadfast devotion to duty, Young led by example and inspired a generation of new leaders.

images.altText: A view of the main park building from U.S. 42 in front
images.title: Youngsholm
images.caption: Youngsholm on a day of a Commissioning Ceremony in 2015

images.altText: The main park building on a sunny day
images.title: Day of Dedication
images.caption: Youngsholm on the day of the park dedication, April 2, 2013

images.altText: Colorful stained glass glowing from the sun's rays
images.title: Stained Glass Transom
images.caption: The colorful stained glass transom above the main entrance door to Youngsholm

images.altText: A picture of a bronze plaque on a boulder

directionsInfo:
Plane
Cleveland Hopkins International Airport and Akron-Canton Regional Airport offer many daily flights to the area. Car rentals are available at both airports.

Bus & Train
Bus stations are located in downtown Cleveland and Akron. The Amtrak station is in downtown Cleveland.

Car
The park is easily accessible by car from all directions. A good place to start your visit is at Boston Store Visitor Center located at 1550 Boston Mills Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. (81° 33.512' W) (41° 15.803' N).
weatherInfo:
Spring's rain and warming temperatures bring new leaves on trees, blooming wildflowers, and visitors anxious get out on the trail. 

Summer temperatures range from 49 to 95 degrees F and can be humid. Dressing in layers is advisable. 

Fall temperatures can range from low 70s during the day to freezing during the night. Fall foliage often peaks in mid-October.

Winter weather conditions can rapidly change, due to the lake effect snow from Lake Erie. Temperatures vary from mid-30s to below zero.
name: Cuyahoga Valley
description: Though a short distance from the urban areas of Cleveland and Akron, Cuyahoga Valley National Park seems worlds away. The park is a refuge for native plants and wildlife, and provides routes of discovery for visitors. The winding Cuyahoga River gives way to deep forests, rolling hills, and open farmlands. Walk or ride the Towpath Trail to follow the historic route of the Ohio & Erie Canal.

images.altText: Scenic train as it pulls into Peninsula Depot.
images.title: Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad in Peninsula
images.caption: Many park visitors ride the scenic excursion trail through the valley or take advantage of the Bike Aboard option to ride one way with their bike.

images.altText: A ray of sunshine streaming through the rock formation along the Ledges Trail.
images.title: Along the Ledges Trail
images.caption: One of Cuyahoga Valley's most popular trails, the Ledges Trail proved glimpses of great color and rock formations throughout the year.

images.altText: A misty sunset over a lone goose at the Beaver Marsh
images.title: Sunset at the Beaver Marsh
images.caption: Anytime of day or night there is some wildlife at the Beaver Marsh to capture your attention.

images.altText: Brandywine Falls the parks 60 ft waterfall.
images.title: Brandywine Falls
images.caption: Brandywine Falls is Among the Most Popular Attractions in Cuyahoga Valley National Park

directionsInfo: The David Berger National Memorial is located on the grounds of the Mandel Jewish Community Center of Cleveland.
weatherInfo:
The weather at David Berger Memorial is typical of Northeastern Ohio: four distinct seasons. 

Spring's rain and warming temperatures bring new leaves on trees and blooming wildflowers.

Summer temperatures range from 49 to 95 degrees F and can be humid. 

Fall temperatures can range from low 70s during the day to freezing during the night. Fallcolor peaks mid-October.

Winter weather conditions can rapidly change. Temperatures vary from mid-30s to below zero.
name: David Berger
description: This site honors the memory of David Berger, an American citizen who was one of 11 Israeli athletes killed at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Germany. David had no expectations of winning a medal but joined the Israeli weightlifting team to realize his dream - a dream which ended tragically. The Memorial is dedicated to his memory and the memory of the ten other athletes.

images.credit: Courtesy of Mandel Jewish Community Center of Cleveland
images.altText: The David Berger Memorial Sculpture
images.title: Sculpture
images.caption: The memorial sculpture depict five broken Olympic rings.

directionsInfo: From I-75, take U.S. Route 35 West (Exit 52b).  Keep right and follow signs for State Route 4/Germantown. Turn slightly right onto S. Williams St. Continue to Fourth Street & turn right and proceed into parking lot on your left. Visitor Center will be directly next to parking lot.
weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 39 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 74 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just above 41". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of about 25".
name: Dayton Aviation Heritage
description: Three exceptional men from Dayton, Ohio, Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright and Paul Laurence Dunbar, found their creative outlet here through accomplishments and failures, and finally success. However, these men offered the world something far greater, they offered the world hope, and the ability to take a dream and make it a reality.

images.altText: The Wright-Dunbar Interpretive Center as viewed from Williams St.
images.title: Wright-Dunbar Interprevitive Center
images.caption: The Wright-Dunbar Interpretive Center as viewed from Williams St.

images.altText: The Wright Glider on display in the visitor center lobby
images.title: 1902 Wright Glider
images.caption: 1902 Wright Brothers glider inside of the Wright-Dunbar Interp. Center

images.altText: People mingling on the Huffman Prairie
images.title: 2015 Aero Carnival
images.caption: Visitors walk and enjoy exhibits during the 2015 Aero Carnival event

images.altText: Visitors and guests walking on sidewalk in front of park
images.title: Third St sidewalk in front of park
images.caption: The facade of the Wright Dunbar Interpretive Center on Third St.

images.altText: Entrance and windows to the Wright Cycle Company building
images.title: Facade of the Wright Cycle Company
images.caption: A view of the entrance to the Wright Cycle Company on Williams St.

images.altText: A Wright Flyer glides through the air in front of a tree line
images.title: 1905 Wright Flyer replica
images.caption: The 1905 Wright Flyer replica during a demonstration flight.

fullName: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park

directionsInfo: The Battlefield in Maumee Ohio at the intersection of US23/I-475 and US24 (Anthony Wayne Trail). A parking lot and visitors center are located on Jerome Road, where the 1.4 Northwest Territory Trail loops through the wooded area where the 1795 Battle of Fallen Timbers took place.
weatherInfo:
The weather at Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis is typical of Northern Ohio: four distinct seasons. 

Spring's rain and warming temperatures bring new leaves on trees and blooming wildflowers.

Summer temperatures range from 49 to 95 degrees F and can be humid. 

Fall temperatures can range from low 70s during the day to freezing during the night. Fallcolor peaks mid-October.

Winter weather conditions can rapidly change. Temperatures vary from mid-30s to below zero.
name: Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis
description: The Battle of Fallen Timbers was the culminating event that demonstrated the tenacity of the American people in their quest for western expansion and the struggle for dominance in the Old Northwest Territory. The events resulted in the dispossession of American Indian tribes and a loss of colonial territory for the British military and settlers.

images.altText: A panoramic image of the monument site.
images.title: Fallen Timbers Monument
images.caption: The Fallen Timbers Monument includes a 10-foot bronze statue of General Wayne.

images.altText: An image of the newly completed visitor center.
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: The Fallen Timbers Battlefield Visitor Center is not yet open to the public.

images.altText: The Fallen Timbers monument site
images.title: Fallen Timbers Monument
images.caption: The monument site contains several features including this granite and broze monument near the Maumee River.

fullName: Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis National Historic Site

directionsInfo: The First Ladies National Historic Site is located in downtown Canton, Ohio. Free parking is available behind the Saxton House or at our gated lot on the corner of Market Avenue South and 3rd Street SW (entrance from Market Avenue South).
weatherInfo:
The weather at First Ladies National Historic Site is typical of Northeastern Ohio: four distinct seasons. 

Spring's rain and warming temperatures bring new leaves on trees and blooming wildflowers.

Summer temperatures range from 49 to 95 degrees F and can be humid. 

Fall temperatures can range from low 70s during the day to freezing during the night. Fallcolor peaks mid-October.

Winter weather conditions can rapidly change. Temperatures vary from mid-30s to below zero.
name: First Ladies
description: First Ladies National Historic Site consists of two properties in downtown Canton, Ohio - the home of First Lady Ida Saxton McKinley and a small visitor center with an exhibit and film. Come learn about how the position of First Lady has evolved over time to include a public role.

images.altText: a front view of the Ida Saxton McKinley House
images.title: First Ladies National Historic Site
images.caption: This was the longtime residence of William and Ida McKinley.

images.altText: A piano in the Saxton McKinley Home
images.title: Saxton McKinley House Piano
images.caption: Ida Saxton's original piano is just one of many items belonging to President McKinley and First Lady Ida McKinley.

images.altText: A view of the City National Bank Building which was donated to the First Ladies Library.
images.title: National First Ladies' Library Education and Research Center
images.caption: There is a 91-seat Victorian Theatre on the lower level, where films and documentaries on the first ladies are shown and author lectures and live presentations are held.

images.altText: Close up view of home entrance.
images.title: Saxton McKinley Home
images.caption: The Saxton McKinley Home is significant as the only residence with direct historical ties to President William McKinley remaining in his hometown of Canton.

directionsInfo: Take U.S. 23.  Exit U.S. 23 at State Route 207 and turn right.  Continue on S.R. 207 for 2 miles until it merges with S.R. 104 (Make no turns, continue straight on road as it turns into S.R. 104).  Follow S.R. 104, turn left into park (approximately 1.8 miles past the S.R. 104 & S.R. 207 intersection), follow entrance road to visitor center.
weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 30 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 75 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just under 38". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of less than 24".
name: Hopewell Culture
description: Earthen mounds and embankments forming huge geometric enclosures grace the landscape of the Ohio River Valley. These monumental structures were built by Native American hands almost 2,000 years ago. Hopewellian people gathered at these earthworks for feasts, funerals and rites of passage.  Come learn about these sacred spaces and reflect upon the lives of these American Indians.

images.altText: Three visitors to the park reading an interpretive sign
images.title: Visitors at Mound 7
images.caption: Visitors read a sign in front of Mound #7

images.altText: The early morning sun shining on the mounds

images.caption: Dawn at the Mound City Group

images.title: Visitors at Seip
images.caption: Visitors gather at the front of the Seip Mound at Seip Earthworks

images.altText: A coyote in front of a mound
images.title: Coyote at Mound City Group
images.caption: A coyote stares down the photographer while roaming among the mounds

images.altText: An elevated view of the Mound City Group
images.title: Aerial View of Mound City Group
images.caption: An aerial view of the Mound City Group in fall

images.altText: A copper bird cutout
images.title: Copper Effigy Bird
images.caption: A 2,000 year old copper effigy bird cutout crafted by the Hopewell.

images.altText: A copper cutout of a breastplate
images.title: Copper Breastplate
images.caption: Copper breastplate cutout made by the Hopewell culture 2,000 years ago

directionsInfo:
From Interstate 90 - exit at Route 306 and head north to Route 20. East on Route 20 about 1.5 miles. Site is on north side of Mentor Avenue.

From Route 2 - exit at Route 306 and head south to Route 20. East on Route 20 about 1.5 miles. Site is on the north side of Mentor Avenue.
weatherInfo: Winter tends to be cold with snow and ice from January - early March. Summers are comfortable, but can be humid and reach into the 90's. There is a 300 yard walk between the Visitor Center and Garfield home; visitors are advised to check weather conditions prior to their visit.
name: James A Garfield
description: A front porch can serve many purposes. For some, a place to enjoy the breeze on a warm summer night. For others, a perch from which to keep eyes on what's happening in their neighborhood. In 1880, James Garfield used his front porch as a platform to greet thousands of well-wishers during his presidential campaign. Today, the porch serves as a gateway to the story of the Garfield family.

images.altText: Carriage House entrance from the south
images.title: Carriage House
images.caption: The Carriage House, built in 1894, was repurposed by the National Park Service to become a modern visitor center. It was part of a $12.5 million restoration in the 1990's.

images.altText: A view of the memorial library addition through the trees.
images.title: Library addition, north side
images.caption: Mrs. Garfield constructed a beautiful addition to the Garfield home following the President's assassination in 1881. These 9 rooms contain the first Presidential Memorial Library,  including the a fireproof vault which once contained Garfield's papers.

images.altText: Front porch of Garfield home showing red front door
images.title: The Front Porch, Garfield Home
images.caption: The front porch of James Garfield's home was the scene of the first front porch campaign. The presidential candidate gave patriotic speeches and met with thousands of people who came to which him well during the summer and fall of 1880.

images.altText: Visitor Center main entrance off the parking lot.
images.title: Visitor Center, Main Entrance
images.caption: A friendly greeting awaits visitors who enter the Visitor Center. This historic building, constructed in 1894, serves as bookstore, exhibit gallery and auditorium where the park film is shown. Tickets for tours of the Garfield home are also available her

images.altText: Hand-painted tile shows a bird next with blue eggs
images.title: Hand-painted Fireplace Tile, Garfield Dining Room
images.caption: Mrs. Garfield was known for her artistic talent, which softly blankets the interior of the Garfield home. In particular, the dining room boasts two tiles which were hand-painted by Mrs. Garfield, surround by others done by her children.

fullName: James A Garfield National Historic Site

directionsInfo: The National Aviation Heritage Area has multiple sites located throughout eight counties in the Dayton, Ohio and western Ohio area. Please be sure to visit a specific National Aviation Heritage Area website for directions and/or maps to each location.
weatherInfo: The National Aviation Heritage Area lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 39 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 74 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just above 41". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of about 25".
name: National Aviation
description: Aviation is chock-full of tradition & history and nowhere will you find a richer collection of aviation than here, the birthplace of aviation.  From the straightforward bicycle shops that fostered the Wright brothers' flying ambitions to the complex spacecraft that carried man to the moon, the National Aviation Heritage Area has everything you need to learn about this country’s aviation legacy.

images.altText: Visitor center building in background with plaza in foreground
images.title: Dayton's National Park
images.caption: The Wright-Dunbar Interpretive Center located just west of downtown Dayton

directionsInfo: Perry's Victory and International Peace Memorial is located within the Village of Put-in-Bay on South Bass Island. The most common way to reach the island is by the Jet Express or Miller Boat Line ferries.  When traveling east, use Ohio Turnpike to US 250 north to SR 2 west. When traveling west, use Ohio Turnpike to SR 53 north to SR 2 east. From SR 2 take the SR 163 exit OR the ST 250 exit for the Jet Express passenger ferry, OR take the SR 53 exit for Miller Boat Line vehicle and passenger ferry.
weatherInfo: Summer months can be extremely hot and humid, with occasional and sudden severe thunderstorms. Fall and spring are pleasant with cool temperatures and brisk winds. During the Winter the Memorial and Visitor Center are closed.
name: Perry's Victory & International Peace
description: Perry's Victory and International Peace Memorial was established to honor those who fought in the Battle of Lake Erie, during the War of 1812, and to celebrate the long-lasting peace among Great Britain, Canada and the U.S. The Memorial, a Doric column, rising 352 feet over Lake Erie is situated 5 miles from the longest undefended border in the world.

images.altText: Night sky with Memorial Column in the middle with sun just starting to come up in lower right corner
images.title: Night Sky and Memorial

images.altText: Sun setting over Put-in-Bay Harbor
images.title: Sun setting over the Bay

images.altText: The Memorial Column with the United Kingdom, Canadian, and US Flags flying from poles on the lawn.
images.title: Perry's Victory and International Peace Memorial

directionsInfo:
From I-71 north; Take Exit 2 (Reading Road and Eden Park Drive). Stay in right lane; turn left at first stoplight onto Dorchester Avenue, and go to the top of the hill. Turn right on Auburn Avenue and go 1 ½ blocks to the site. Park will be on the right.

From I-71S, take Exit 3 (Taft Road). Follow Taft Road westbound.  Go 0.75 mile to Auburn Avenue. Turn left and go 0.5 mile to the site. Park will be on the left.
weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 48 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 77 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just under 40". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of less than 12"
name: William Howard Taft
description: High atop one of Cincinnati's most prominent hilltops stands the two-story Greek Revival house where William Howard Taft was born and grew up. Hard work, a good education, and an interest in civic duty are attributes that made the Taft family outstanding leaders over the years. The environment that shaped Taft's character and philosophy  is highlighted  on a visit to the site.

images.altText: A cardboard cutout of Taft against the wall
images.title: William Howard Taft cutout
images.caption: A William Howard Taft cardboard cutout in the education center

images.altText: The Taft house and visitor center
images.title: Park Photo
images.caption: The Taft House and Education Center as seen from Auburn Ave.

images.altText: The Taft House
images.title: Park Wallpaper with Centennial logo
images.caption: The William Howard Taft NHS wallpaper

images.altText: Animatronic robot sitting near a car display by creek
images.title: Charlie Taft III Display
images.caption: Animatronic Charlie Taft III robot inside of the Taft Education Center

images.altText: Portrait of Taft on a wall near a fireplace
images.title: Inside of the Taft House
images.caption: A portrait of William Howard Taft hangs in the foreground of a portrait of his father

fullName: William Howard Taft National Historic Site

directionsInfo: From US I-35 drive through the towns of Davis and Sulphur to the intersection of State Highway 7 and 177. Drive south on Hwy. 177 and take the first left to the Travertine Nature Center. Park Headquarters is located at 901 W. 1st Street, Sulphur, Oklahoma.
weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid. Temperatures above 100ºF occur, and humidity often exceeds 50%. Winters are mild and prolonged freezes are rare. Thunderstorms are common April through July.
name: Chickasaw
description: Springs, streams, lakes - whatever its form, water is the attraction at Chickasaw National Recreation Area. Relax in the coolness of shaded streams or take a dip in a swimming hole. Little Niagara and Rock Creek beckon waders and swimmers. Veterans Lake calls anglers to test their skills. Lake of the Arbuckles provides excellent opportunities for motorboating, skiing, fishing, and swimming.

images.altText: Lincoln Bridge with Travertine Creek flowing below
images.title: Lincoln Bridge
images.caption: Lincoln Bridge stands out as one of the oldest park structures

images.altText: Two people hiking over a water feature
images.title: Hiking to Buffalo Springs
images.caption: Two people walk towards Buffalo Springs, one of the park's many fresh water springs

images.altText: Herd of bison
images.title: Park Bison
images.caption: The park has a herd of bison which are very popular

images.altText: Lake boating on a summer day
images.title: Lake of the Arbuckles
images.caption: Lake of the Arbuckles attracts many boaters each summer for various recreational activities

images.altText: Lake fishing with family
images.title: Family Fishing Fun
images.caption: Learning to Fish at Veterns Lake

directionsInfo: The Memorial & Museum are located at 6th St. and Harvey Ave in Oklahoma City, OK.
weatherInfo: Summers are very warm with temperatures averaging low- mid 90’s. Also, be mindful of the heat index. Spring weather brings mild temperatures, 60’s-70’s, but the ability to produce severe storms that could include heavy rains, strong winds, hail, and tornadoes. While winters are generally mild delivering temperatures in the 40’s and 50’s, the wind chill can be brutal. No matter the season you are planning to visit, be prepared for the winds to be gusting.
name: Oklahoma City
description: The outdoor symbolic memorial is a place of quiet reflection, honoring victims, survivors, rescuers, and all who were changed forever on April 19, 1995. It encompasses the now sacred soil where the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building once stood, capturing and preserving forever the place and events that changed the world.

images.altText: Tiles with hand prints and chalkboards set into the ground for children.
images.title: Children's Area
images.caption: This area provides letter shaped chalkboards to allow the continued emotional expressions from those young and old. A surrounding wall displays a collection of painted tiles sent by schools, showing their compassion for the bombing-affected community

images.altText: Fencing with pictures, stuffed animals and other tokens left on it.
images.title: Memorial Fence
images.caption: This 200 foot section of chain link fence was taken from the original barrier surrounding the bombing site. The fence served as the first spontaneous memorial and a location for people to leave tokens of collective grief. It retains this purpose still to

images.altText: Summer evening photo of the Memorial lit up at night
images.title: Summer Nights
images.caption: Beat the summer heat, on an evening stroll through the illuminated Field of Empty Chairs, the Gates of Time, and the Survivor Tree. All walkways are brightened to allow enjoyment of this peaceful time of day.

images.altText: Snow covered Field of Empty Chairs
images.title: Snow on Empty Chairs
images.caption: The Memorial becomes a silent place during the rare winter snow storms that blow through. The cold and quiet house a stillness made for reflection as one walks through the Field of Empty Chairs.

images.altText: Bright Red Chinese Pastiche tree in the Rescuers' Orchard.
images.title: Rescuers' Orchard in Fall
images.caption: This Chinese Pastiche is located in the small orchard that was planted in recognition of the over 12,000 rescue workers who responded to the bombing. Its vibrant hues draw attention to the tremendous work these heroes accomplished.

directionsInfo: Cheyenne is situated in western Oklahoma approximately 140 miles west of Oklahoma City and 128 miles east of Amarillo, Texas; just 22 miles north of I-40 on State Highway 283. The town of Cheyenne is the county seat of Roger Mills and inhabits 23.3% of the entire county population.Cheyenne is approximately 30 miles north of I-40 on Hwy 283 and approxima
weatherInfo: Weather in western Oklahoma can vary considerably. Winters can be mild to severe with ice storms being the biggest concern. Spring is usually short but pleasant although severe weather, including tornadoes, is still a possibility. Usually a strong breeze is associated with spring weather. Summers are brutally hot and visitors should be cautioned about spending any length of time in the heat. Falls are cool with a bitter wind.
name: Washita Battlefield
description: On November 27, 1868, Lt. Colonel George Armstrong Custer led the 7th U.S. Cavalry on a surprise dawn attack on a Cheyenne village led by Peace Chief Black Kettle. The event was an example of the tragic clash of cultures that occurred during the Great Plains Wars. It is also a place of remembrance and reflection for those who died here.

images.altText: The Washita River in winter covered in ice and snow
images.title: Washita River
images.caption: The Washita River looking much the same as it did during the attack on November 27, 1868

images.altText: Cheyenne tipis backlite by sunset
images.title: Tipis at Sunset
images.caption: Cheyenne tipis backlite by sunset

images.altText: A Cheyenne Dog Soldier tells stories inside his tipi
images.title: Cheyenne Dog Soldier Telling Stories
images.caption: A Cheyenne Dog Soldier tells stories inside his tipi

images.altText: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center on a summer day
images.title: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center
images.caption: The Washita Battlefield National Historic Site Visitor Center on a summer day

images.altText: A Park Ranger knells down among Junior Rangers so only his hat shows within the crowd of children.
images.title: Learning Something New at Washita
images.caption: A Park Ranger helps children with their Jr. Ranger books.

images.altText: A Cheyenne Warrior and U.S. Cavalry soldier hold a meeting next to a tipi
images.title: "Meeting the Enemy"
images.caption: A Cheyenne Warrior and U.S. Cavalry soldier hold a meeting next to a tipi

directionsInfo: Much of the year, the park's North Entrance is closed to cars. The North Entrance Road closes for the season on November 1 (or earlier if there is significant snowfall) and tends to open in early June.  The park’s South Entrance is open year round. Winter travelers from Roseburg will need to take Route 138 east to Route 230 south to Route 62 east to the park's west entrance. Winter travels from Bend will take Route 97 south to Route 62 north and west to the park's south entrance.
weatherInfo:
October through June Crater Lake is snow covered. Snowfall averages 533 inches (1,350 cm) annually, and by early spring, it is typical to have ten to fifteen feet (4 meters) of snow on the ground. 

July, August, and September are drier and warmer. A typical daytime high temperature during these three months is around 67°F (19°C), but can range from 40°F to 80°F or more (4°C to 27°C). Temperatures cool off rapidly in the evening, with a typical nighttime low around 40°F (4°C).
name: Crater Lake
description: Crater Lake inspires awe. Native Americans witnessed its formation 7,700 years ago, when a violent eruption triggered the collapse of a tall peak. Scientists marvel at its purity: fed by rain and snow, it’s the deepest lake in the USA and one of the most pristine on earth. Artists, photographers, and sightseers gaze in wonder at its blue water and stunning setting atop the Cascade Mountain Range.

images.altText: A view of Crater Lake and Wizard Island
images.title: Wizard Island
images.caption: Looking at Crater Lake and Wizard Island from Discovery Point

images.altText: a view of Phantom Ship and Chaski Bay

images.caption: A view across Crater Lake from the lakeshore

images.altText: Crater Lake as seen from the summit of Mt. Scott

images.caption: A view of the caldera from Mt. Scott, the highest point in Crater Lake National Park

images.altText: water flowing over Vidae Falls

directionsInfo:
From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. Turn south onto Fort Vancouver Way. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center.

From I-205, go west on Highway 14 about six miles, then take I-5 north. From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center.
weatherInfo: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site is located in a mild, temperate climate. However, in the case of severe weather, park alerts posted on the park's website will provide information about emergency closures.
name: Fort Vancouver
description: Located on the north bank of the Columbia River, in sight of snowy mountain peaks and a vibrant urban landscape, this park has a rich cultural past. From a frontier fur trading post, to a powerful military legacy, the magic of flight, and the origin of the American Pacific Northwest, history is shared at four unique sites. Discover stories of transition, settlement, conflict, and community.

images.altText: Fort Vancouver Garden
images.title: Fort Vancouver Garden
images.caption: The garden at the reconstructed Fort Vancouver showcases the many plants that were grown at the historic Fort Vancouver.

images.altText: Black Powder Demonstrations at Fort Vancouver NHS
images.title: Black Powder Demonstrations at Fort Vancouver NHS
images.caption: The military history at Vancouver Barracks is told through living history demonstrations, including historic weapons demonstrations.

images.altText: Fort Vancouver
images.title: Fort Vancouver
images.caption: A walk through the reconstructed Fort Vancouver is a highlight of any trip to Fort Vancouver National Historic Site.

images.altText: McLoughlin House
images.title: McLoughlin House
images.caption: The McLoughlin House in Oregon City is a unit of Fort Vancouver National Historic Site. Here, visitors learn about Dr. John McLoughlin and the early history of Oregon state.

images.altText: Pearson Air Museum
images.title: Pearson Air Museum
images.caption: At Pearson Air Museum, visitors learn about the history of Pearson Field and early aviation in the Pacific Northwest.

directionsInfo: John Day Fossil Beds encompasses 14,000 acres in three geographically separated units in Oregon: Sheep Rock, Painted Hills, and Clarno. The Sheep Rock Unit is located between the towns of Dayville and Kimberly. The Painted Hills Unit is located 9 miles northwest of of the town of Mitchell. The Clarno Unit is located on Highway 218 twenty miles west of the town of Fossil.
weatherInfo: Weather conditions at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument are highly variable in this semi-arid desert landscape. Summer highs can climb into the 110's. Winters tend to be fairly mild, with occassional snow and ice and lows occasionally dipping into the single digits.
name: John Day Fossil Beds
description: Colorful rock formations at John Day Fossil Beds preserve a world class record of plant and animal evolution, changing climate, and past ecosystems that span over 40 million years.  Exhibits and a working lab at the Thomas Condon Paleontology and Visitor Center as well as scenic drives and hikes at all three units allow visitors to explore the prehistoric past of Oregon and see science in action.

images.altText: Sheep Rock
images.title: Sheep Rock
images.caption: Sheep Rock, with the John Day River in the foreground

images.altText: Painted Hills
images.title: Painted Hills
images.caption: The Painted Hills on a stormy winter day.

images.altText: Clarno
images.title: Clarno
images.caption: The Clarno Palisades are remains of ancient volcanic mudslides.

images.altText: Miohippus
images.title: Miohippus
images.caption: Miohippus is just one of many amazing fossils found here.

images.altText: Paleontologist at work
images.title: Paleontologist at work
images.caption: The Thomas Condon Paleontology Center is both a visitor center and research center.

fullName: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument

directionsInfo: From Portland: Take Highway 26 West to Seaside. Go north on Highway 101 through Seaside. Turn right at the stop light on SE Ensign Lane. Continue to drive about one mile, turn right onto Fort Clatsop Road, the entrance will be on your left.
weatherInfo: During the 106 days the Lewis and Clark Expedition wintered at Fort Clatsop in 1806 it rained all but 12 days and they saw the sun 6 times. While we are usually not so dreary, but we do see an average of 70 inches of rain a year and we are the foggiest location in the Lower 48 states. Summer months are usually nice with days ranging from 55-70 degrees. Winters are wet and mild, usually 40-55 degrees.
name: Lewis and Clark
description: Explore the timeless rainforests and majestic coastal vistas. Discover the rich heritage of the native people. Unfold the dramatic stories of America's most famous explorers. The park encompasses sites along the Columbia River and the Pacific Coast. Follow in the footsteps of the explorers and have an adventure in history.

images.altText: Runners along a fern and tree-lined trail
images.title: Running on History
images.caption: Runners compete in a friendly race along a fern and tree-lined trail.

fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park

directionsInfo:
Take 199 to Cave Junction, Oregon.
Turn onto OR-46 (a Chevron gas station is on the corner).
Follow OR-46 for 20 miles to the Monument and Preserve.
weatherInfo: For current weather conditions visit http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=42.07376224008719&lon=-123.3984375&site=mfr&smap=1&unit=0&lg=en&FcstType=text#.Vqe3FfkrKUk
name: Oregon Caves
description:
Deep within the Siskiyou Mountains are dark, twisting passages that await your discovery.  Eons of acidic water seeping into marble rock created and decorated the wondrous “Marble Halls of Oregon.” Join a tour, get a taste of what caving is all about, and explore a mountain from the inside and out.

Reservations available up to one day ahead of visit.
Same Day tickets available at park.

images.altText: Miller's Chapel at Oregon Caves
images.title: Milller's Chapel
images.caption: Miller's Chapel at Oregon Caves National Monument and Preserve

images.altText: Mountain Meadows at Bigelow Lakes
images.title: Mountain Meadows at Bigelow Lakes
images.caption: Mountain Meadows at Bigelow Lakes at Oregon Caves National Preserve

images.altText: Cave speliothems
images.title: Banana Grove formations
images.caption: Speliothems in the Banana Grove room, Oregon Caves.

images.altText: Flowstone and drapery in a dome pit
images.title: Speleothems
images.caption: Paradise Lost

directionsInfo: The park is located just off U.S. Route 22 approximately 12 miles west of Altoona and 10 miles east of Ebensburg. Take the Gallitzin Exit and turn right, following the signs. Visitors prior to 1992 accessed the park in other ways, but the GALLITZIN EXIT of US Route 22 is now the way to access the visitor center and historic area.
weatherInfo: The park is located in Cambria County, PA, and is at the summit of the Allegheny Mountains. Therefore, the park often takes on winter extremes. If planning on traveling from a long distance, please contact the park beforehand to ensure that the facilities are open. Please consult weather forecasts to ensure conditions are safe to travel in. Spring, summer, and fall are generally uneventful, but severe thunderstorms can occur.
name: Allegheny Portage Railroad
description: The first railroad to circumvent the Allegheny Mountains, the Allegheny Portage Railroad was the finishing piece of the Pennsylvania Mainline Canal.  "The Portage," opened in 1834, marking the first time that there was one, direct route between Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.  All things to all people, it served merchants, passengers, slaves in pursuit of freedom, and soldiers from the Mexican War.

images.altText: Lemon House
images.title: Lemon House
images.caption: Lemon House, one of the historic structures in the park.

fullName: Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site

directionsInfo: For details and directions on places of interest in the Delaware and Leigh National Heritage Corridor, visit, http://delawareandlehigh.org/.
weatherInfo: We have four seasons and the temperature varies 10 degrees from one end of the Corridor to the other on any given day. The winters are harsher in the two mountainous northern counties (Luzerne and Carbon) than in the southern-most county (Bucks).
name: Delaware & Lehigh
description: Come journey through five Pennsylvania counties bursting with heritage and brimming with outdoor adventure. Follow the D&L Trail, a historic pathway marked with stories about hearty lumberjacks, coal miners, lock tenders, and railroaders. Explore the history of the Corridor at the National Canal Museum or along quiet canal paths, challenging bike trails and the rippling waters of the river.

images.altText: Sketch of canal boats loading and unloading at a lock
images.title: Lock 2 of the Lehigh Canal
images.caption: Lock 2, the weigh lock at the beginning of the Lehigh Canal.

directionsInfo: The Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site is located at 532 N. 7th Street, Philadelphia, PA 19123. It sits in an urban area served by Interstates 95 and 676. On- street parking is usually available near the site. The site is also easily accessible by public transportation. See the directions web page for more information.
weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
name: Edgar Allan Poe
description: Described as horrifying, mystifying, and brilliant, Poe’s writing has engaged readers all over the globe. The six years Edgar Allan Poe lived in Philadelphia were his happiest and most productive. Yet Poe also struggled with bad luck, personal demons and his wife’s illness. In Poe’s humble home, reflect on the human spirit surmounting crushing obstacles, and celebrate Poe’s astonishing creativity.

images.altText: Color photo of a rectangular three story brick home with rows of windows on each floor.
images.title: Poe House, exterior
images.caption: Edgar Allan Poe lived in Philadelphia for six years, but he resided at this home for about a year, 1843-1844.

images.altText: Color photo of the parlor in the Poe House showing illustrations of furniture on the walls.
images.title: Parlor
images.caption: Wall mounted illustrations show how the room may have been furnished when Edgar Allan Poe lived in the house.

images.altText: Color photo of the basement with brick floor, false chimney, and wooden staircase.
images.title: Basement
images.caption: Is this where Poe got his inspiration for The Black Cat?  Descend to the basement and decide for yourself.

images.altText: Color photo showing a large raven statue with wings outspread on a metal plinth.
images.title: Raven statue
images.caption: Stand in the shadow of the raven statue in the yard.

images.altText: A small red-carpeted room with faux marble table, red upholstered chairs and sofa, and red curtains.
images.title: The Reading Room
images.caption: The reading room at the Edgar Allan Poe National Historical Site is furnished according to Poe's essay "The Philosophy of Furniture."

fullName: Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site

directionsInfo: There is no parking available on site. Access to the site is only available via shuttle buses that leave from the Gettysburg National Military Park Visitor Center (at 1195 Baltimore Street, Gettysburg, PA 17325) throughout the day.
weatherInfo: http://www.wunderground.com/cgi-bin/findweather/hdfForecast?query=17325
name: Eisenhower
description: Eisenhower National Historic Site is the home and farm of General and President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Located adjacent to the Gettysburg Battlefield, the farm served the President as a weekend retreat and a meeting place for world leaders. With its peaceful setting and view of South Mountain, it was a much needed respite from Washington and a backdrop for efforts to reduce Cold War tensions.

images.altText: The Eisenhower home with Ike's putting green in the foreground
images.title: Eisenhower home
images.caption: President Eisenhower was an avid golfer and had a putting green added to the backyard.

images.altText: Visitors arrive at the site via the park shuttle bus
images.title: Eisenhower Shuttlebus
images.caption: Visitors arrive at the site via the park shuttle bus.

images.altText: The Eisenhower home in autumn
images.title: The Eisenhower home in autumn
images.caption: The Eisenhower home in autumn.

images.altText: The Eisenhower living room
images.title: The Eisenhower living room
images.caption: The Eisenhower living room.

images.altText: The Eisenhower dining room decorated for the holidays
images.title: The Eisenhower dining room decorated for the holidays
images.caption: The Eisenhower dining room decorated for the holidays.

directionsInfo:
The entrance to the memorial is located on US Route 30/Lincoln Highway.  Traveling east on the PA Turnpike take exit 110 - Somerset and follow the signs.  Traveling west on the PA Turnpike take exit 146 - Bedford.  

GPS Address:  6424 Lincoln Highway, Stoystown, PA 15563.  Please note mapping programs may note alternate entrances, but the only entrance to the memorial is located on US Route 30.

For more details follow the link to our website
weatherInfo:
Fall-Winter Cooler weather starts in September with warm days and cool nights. The first snowfall of the season occurs by mid-October and extends through late March to mid-April. Daytime temperatures range in the mid-20s to 30s, with periodic warming in the 40s and 50s. The average annual snowfall is approximately 80 inches for Somerset County.

Spring-Summer May is more predictable for warmer weather with daytime temperatures in the 60s and 70s. July and August are also mild with highs in the 80s-90s
name: Flight 93
description: On Tuesday morning, September 11, 2001, the U.S. came under attack when four commercial airliners were hijacked and used to strike targets on the ground. Nearly 3,000 people tragically lost their lives. Because of the actions of the 40 passengers and crew aboard one of the planes, Flight 93, the attack on the U.S. Capitol was thwarted.

images.altText: Tall gray walls with a gap and black pathway leading to the gap
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: Flight Path Walkway and Visitor Center

images.altText: Tall gray walls with a black metal overhang and glass walls
images.title: Entrance to the Visitor Center
images.caption: Entrance to the Visitor Center

images.altText: Long glass panel with view of a long black wall and set of white walls in a field below.
images.title: View of the Memorial Plaza from the Flight Path Overlook
images.caption: View of the Memorial Plaza from the Flight Path Overlook

images.title: Wildflower field at the Memorial Plaza at the crash site
images.caption: Wildflower field at the Memorial Plaza at the crash site

images.title: Wall of Names at the Memorial Plaza at the crash site
images.caption: Wall of Names at the Memorial Plaza at the crash site

images.altText: Wildflowers blooming in Spring at the entrance sign for Flight 93 National Memorial
images.title: Memorial entrance
images.caption: The designed landscape memorial encompasses approximate 1,500 acres of ground.

directionsInfo: The main unit of the park is located 11 miles east of Uniontown, Pennsylvania on U.S. Highway 40. The visitor center, reconstructed Fort Necessity, Mount Washington Tavern and picnic area are located in the main unit of the park.
weatherInfo:
Weather varies considerably within each season.  Be prepared with layered clothing. Precipitation is common throughout the year.
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 25°F to 70°F.  On average, May is the wettest month.
Summer: Temperatures usually range from 50°F to 80°F. July is the warmest month.
Fall: Temperatures usually range from 30°F to 70°F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid-October. 
Winter: Temperatures range from 15°F to 40°F.  January is the coldest month.
name: Fort Necessity
description: The battle at Fort Necessity in the summer of 1754 was the opening action of the French and Indian War. This war was a clash of British, French and American Indian cultures. It ended with the removal of French power from North America. The stage was set for the American Revolution.

images.altText: cabin and stockade casting shadows on the snow
images.title: Fort Necessity in Winter
images.caption: Fort Necessity National Battlefield is open year round.

images.altText: Fort Necessity and the Great Meadow with trail and tree in the foreground
images.title: Fort Necessity
images.caption: Fort Necessity was the site of George Washington's first military experience at the beginning of the French and Indian War

directionsInfo: Friendship Hill NHS is located on PA 166 three miles north of Point Marion, Pennsylvania.
weatherInfo:
Weather varies considerably within each season.  Be prepared with layered clothing. Precipitation is common throughout the year.
Spring: Temperatures usually range from 25°F to 70°F.  On average, May is the wettest month.
Summer: Temperatures usually range from 50°F to 80°F. July is the warmest month.
Fall: Temperatures usually range from 30°F to 70°F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid-October. 
Winter: Temperatures range from 15°F to 40°F.  January is the coldest month.
name: Friendship Hill
description: Albert Gallatin is best remembered for his thirteen year tenure as Secretary of the Treasury during the Jefferson and Madison administrations. In that time he reduced the national debt, purchased the Louisiana Territory and funded the Lewis & Clark exploration. Gallatin's accomplishments and contributions are highlighted at Friendship Hill, his restored country estate.

images.altText: Gallatin house
images.title: Gallatin House - Stone House and well
images.caption: Friendship Hill was the country home of Albert Gallatin

directionsInfo: Gettysburg National Military Park is located in Adams County, Pennsylvania. The museum and visitor center is located at 1195 Baltimore Pike (Route 97) with a back entrance from the Taneytown Road (State Rt. 134). From North or South, follow US 15 to Gettysburg and watch for signs to direct you to the National Park Service Museum and Visitor Center. From East or West, drive into Gettysburg on US Rt. 30, turn South on Baltimore Street (Rt. 97), and follow signs to the entrance of the visitor center.
weatherInfo: http://www.wunderground.com/cgi-bin/findweather/hdfForecast?query=17325
name: Gettysburg
description: The Battle of Gettysburg was a turning point in the Civil War, the Union victory that ended General Robert E. Lee's second and most ambitious invasion of the North. Often referred to as the "High Water Mark of the Rebellion", Gettysburg was the Civil War's bloodiest battle and was also the inspiration for President Abraham Lincoln's immortal "Gettysburg Address".

images.title: The view from Little Round Top
images.caption: The view from Little Round Top.

images.altText: The Mississippi Monument at sunrise
images.title: The Mississippi Monument at sunrise
images.caption: The Mississippi Monument at sunrise.

images.title: The Soldiers' National Cemetery during special illumination event
images.caption: The Soldiers' National Cemetery during special illumination event.

images.title: A rainbow over the Abraham Brian Farm on Cemetery Ridge
images.caption: A rainbow over the Abraham Brian Farm on Cemetery Ridge.
