directionsInfo: The Gloria Dei Church is accessed from Christian Street in South Philadelphia. As in any city, use your street smarts and do not leave any valuables visible in your car. Several SEPTA bus routes serve the vicinity of the site.  Visit the website for more information.
weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
name: Gloria Dei Church
description: Before Pennsylvania there was New Sweden. Discover this last historic link to a forgotten past. Visit the church's pastoral surroundings and its burial ground of patriots and ordinary citizens alike.

images.altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church steeple during a sunset in Philadelphia.
images.title: Steeple of the Gloira Dei Church
images.caption: The Church building at Gloria Dei 'Old Swedes' has been in use since 1700, making it the oldest church building in Pennsylvania and the second oldest in the United States.  The steeple was completed in 1703.

images.altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church yard showing tombstones with the church in the background.
images.title: Gloria Dei Chuch yard
images.caption: Gloria Dei Church was designated as a National Historical Site in 1942. The Gloria Dei congregation owns and maintains the church and the related buildings, its ministry and the grounds.

images.altText: A color photo of the interior of Gloria Dei Church showing the pulpit and a stained glass window.
images.title: Interior of the Gloria Dei Church
images.caption: Situated above the pulpit is the only stained glass window in the church building.  Created in the mid 1800's, the window is the earliest example of American stained glass among the 3600 windows in the Philadelphia region.

images.altText: A 19th century photograph of the Gloria Dei Church, with the cemetery in the foreground.
images.title: The Gloria Dei Church c.1850
images.caption: This 1850's photograph shows a bird's-eye view of the Gloria Dei Church, with the cemetery in the foreground, with the masts of ships visible in the background.

images.altText: A color photo of a model tall ship hanging inside Gloria Die Church.
images.title: Model of a ship hanging inside Gloria Dei Church
images.caption: Hanging from the ceiling of Gloria Dei are models of the two ships that brought the first Swedish colonists to North America in 1638, the "Kalmar Nyckel" and the "Fogel Gryp."

fullName: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site

directionsInfo: On PA Route 345, 5 miles South of Birdsboro, Pennsylvania.
weatherInfo:
Summers are generally humid with daily temps. averaging 83 degrees (F) for a high and 60 degrees (F) for a low.  Daily temps. in January average 38 degrees (F) for a high and 20 degrees (F) for a low.

Precipitation averages 3-5 inches of rain per month during spring, summer and autumn.  During winter conditions can be icy with snow accumulating up to several inches.
name: Hopewell Furnace
description: Hopewell Furnace showcases an early American industrial landscape from natural resource extraction to enlightened conservation. Operating from 1771-1883, Hopewell and other "iron plantations" laid the foundation for the transformation of the United States into an industrial giant. The park's 848 acres and historic structures illustrate the business, technology and lifestyle of our growing nation.

images.altText: Artists' Illustaration of Hopewell Furnace in operation circa 1840.
images.title: Historical Rendering of Hopewell Furnace in Operation, 1840
images.caption: Overview of the Hopewell Furnace "iron plantation" community in operation during its prime.

images.altText: Front of Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House
images.title: Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House
images.caption: Hopewell Furnace's Boarding House housed single men or those living away from their families, who came to work at the furnace.

images.altText: Side view of blacksmith shop with cast house behind it.
images.title: Blacksmith Shop & Cast House
images.caption: The Cast House was the industrial center of the ironworks.  It is were iron ore was smelted into iron metal and products.  The smaller blacksmith shop formed iron metal into all kinds of necessary tools and goods used in everyday life.

images.altText: Side view of Hopewell Stove in front of wagon running gear.
images.title: Hopewell Stove
images.caption: The most notable manufactured product Hopewell Furnace made was its stoves.  They were produced by the thousands at Hopewell and other like furnaces in the early 19th century and were transported for sale by horse and wagon.

images.altText: Demonstration charcoal pile smoldering.
images.title: Charcoal Pile
images.caption: Charcoal was the fuel used to fire Hopewell Furnace and other furnaces of its age.  Thousands of bushles of charcoal were made from hardwood trees on the furnace lands and entered into the furnace to keep it "in blast."

directionsInfo: Independence National Historical Park is located in an urban area served by Interstates 95 and 676. The park is also easily accessible by public transportation, including SEPTA and PATCO mass transit routes. Whether you choose driving, the bus or the train, we recommend that you start your visit at the Independence Visitor Center at 6th and Market Streets.  See the park's website for specific directions.
weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
name: Independence
description: Goods, ideas, and people intermingled in early Philadelphia.  In this diverse city, a new republic was born.  The Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both debated and signed inside Independence Hall.  Nearby sits the Liberty Bell, an international symbol of liberty.

images.altText: Color photo of the Liberty Bell with Independence Hall in the background.
images.title: The Liberty Bell
images.caption: Recognizable for its crack, the Liberty Bell remains significant today for its message of liberty.

images.altText: Color photo of Independence Hall as seen from the north side of Chestnut Street.
images.title: Independence Hall
images.caption: Known as the birthplace of the United States, Independence Hall houses the room where the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both signed.

images.altText: A color photo of the Independence Visitor Center showing a brick building with tall windows.
images.title: Independence Visitor Center
images.caption: Pick up Independence Hall tickets, plan your visit, and watch films in the Independence Visitor Center.

images.altText: A color photo of the exterior of the Benjamin Franklin Museum in Franklin Court.
images.title: The Benjamin Franklin Museum
images.caption: Explore Franklin's life and character in the Benjamin Franklin Museum. The museum features artifacts, computer animations, and interactive displays that are geared toward visitors of all ages.

images.altText: A color photo of a printing press in the Franklin Court Printing Office.
images.title: The Franklin Court Printing Office
images.caption: Discover the pivotal role the printed word played in the American Revolution and the founding of the nation.  Franklin's printing office no longer survives, but it would have had equipment similar to what you'll see in the Franklin Court Printing Office.

images.altText: The exterior of the Second Bank of the United States showing a marble building with eight columns.
images.title: Portrait Gallery in the Second Bank of the United States
images.caption: The Second bank of the United States houses a fine collection of over 100 portraits, many of them by 18th century artist Charles Willson Peale.

images.altText: A color photo of the Assembly Room showing 18th century chairs and green, cloth covered tables
images.title: The Assembly Room in Independence Hall
images.caption: The Assembly Room in Independence Hall is where the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution were both signed.

directionsInfo: Take US Route 219 to the St Michael/Sidman exit. At the end of the exit ramp head East on PA 869 (there is a park sign at the end of the exit ramp). Travel approximately 1.5 miles on PA 869 watching for a left turn onto Lake Road at the sign for Johnstown Flood National Memorial. Follow Lake Road 1.5 miles until the visitor center appears on your right. Please park safely in the designated parking lot and not block any emergency access roads.
weatherInfo: Winters can be cold and severe. Spring can be seasonable and wet. Summer can be hot with potentials for thunderstorms. Fall can be seasonal, with cold temperatures into October and November.
name: Johnstown Flood
description: The South Fork dam failed on Friday, May 31, 1889 and unleashed 20,000,000 tons of water that devastated Johnstown, PA.  The flood killed 2,209 people but it brought the nation and the world together to aid the "Johnstown sufferers."  The story of the Johnstown Flood reminds us all, "...that we must leave nothing undone for the preservation and protection of our brother men."

images.altText: Remnants of the South Fork Dam
images.title: Remnants of the South Fork Dam
images.caption: Remains of the South Fork Dam, The Spillway Bridge, Visitor Center, and Lake View (Unger) House.

directionsInfo: Oil Region National Heritage Area is located in northwestern Pennsylvania. Commuter air service lands at the Venango Regional Airport in Franklin, Pennsylvania at the center of the Oil Region. Vehicle drivers who access Exits 29, 35, 42, and 45 of I-80 immediately enter the southern edge of the Oil Region National Heritage Area. Major communities are Emlenton, Barkeyville, Cranberry, Franklin, Oil City, and Titusville.
weatherInfo: For details and information, please visit, www.oilregion.org.
name: Oil Region
description: Oil Region National Heritage Area in northwestern Pennsylvania tells of the world’s first successful commercial oil well and a legacy of petroleum that continues to shape industry, society, and politics. The Oil Region includes oil artifacts, scenic communities, farmlands and woodlands, and industrial landscapes, and offers visitors heritage attractions and four seasons of outdoor recreation.

images.altText: Bicycler rides on the trail next to a freight engine
images.title: Rails and Trails
images.caption: Rails and Trails

directionsInfo: The Bost Building is located at 623 E. Eighth Avenue in Homestead, PA.
weatherInfo: For details and information, visit, https://www.riversofsteel.com/.
name: Rivers Of Steel
description: Situated in southwestern Pennsylvania, the Rivers of Steel National Heritage Area reveals how one region, in a sustained and thunderous blast of innovation, ambition and fire, forever changed America and its place in the world. It is the story of the industrialists and the workers who pushed an infant industry to it ultimate limits and in doing so pushed the world into the Age of Steel.

images.credit: Rivers of Steel National Heritage Area
images.altText: Tall steel stacks of a former mill sit alone
images.title: Rivers of Steel National Heritage Area
images.caption: Rivers of Steel National Heritage Area

fullName: Rivers Of Steel National Heritage Area

directionsInfo: From Highway 422 headed north out of Philadelphia, exit South Hanover Street and turn right at the intersection. After you cross the Schuylkill River turn left on to College Drive. The office will be on the left.
weatherInfo: Winters on the river are cold and damp with a cool spring and fall and a hot and humid summer. Sturdy hiking shoes are recommended for outdoor recreation during the snowy wintery season.
name: Schuylkill River Valley
description: The Schuylkill River Heritage Area is the birthplace of the movements that shaped the nation, fueled its growth, and reclaimed its future. It was along the banks of this river and its tributaries that the American, Industrial, and Environmental Revolutions were born. Explore the stories, visit the places, and experience the region’s vitality by visiting the Schuylkill River Heritage Area.

images.credit: Schuylkill River Valley National Heritage Area
images.altText: Sun beams through trees along the banks of the river
images.title: Schuylkill River Valley National Heritage Area
images.caption: The Schuylkill River watershed is one of America’s most significant historical, cultural, and industrial regions.

fullName: Schuylkill River Valley National Heritage Area

directionsInfo:
Our GPS coordinates are:
N 41.410730 (latitude), W 75.671329 (longitude) using our park entrance, Lackawanna Ave at Cliff St, 18503

Be careful NOT to use the park's MAILING address with a GPS unit as there is no entrance at that location. If the location info above fails, you can try 350 Cliff St with ZIP Code 18503 (the bookstore mail address).

General Driving Directions
Take I-81 to exit 185. At first traffic light turn left on Lackawanna Avenue. Continue on Lackawanna Ave to Cliff St and park entrance.
weatherInfo: Warm and sometimes humid summers; cold and rainy or snowy winters. Wear seasonable clothing and good walking shoes. For travel aboard the summer and fall seasonal excursion trains, please note that the commuter-type coaches are not air-conditioned, or may not be heated. Therefore, we recommend that you dress appropriately for the season that you plan to visit us!
name: Steamtown
description: You'd feel heat from the firebox, smell hot steam and oil; you'd hear the whistle, feel the ground vibrate, and watch as one-ton drive rods turned steel wheels. Remember the sound of "chuff-chuff" from the smokestack? Today, you can learn the history of steam railroad transportation, and the people who built, repaired and rode, as we work to preserve a special era in America's industrial history!

images.altText: An aerial overview of Steamtown National Historic Site
images.title: Steamtown NHS  - aerial overview
images.caption: This aerial overview of Steamtown NHS, which was created within the former railyards of the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western "Scranton Yards"

images.altText: Sparks fly as a park mechanic grinds metal in the Steamtown Locomotive Shops
images.title: Sparks fly
images.caption: Visitors can observe locomotive maintenance and repairs taking place in the Locomotive Shops on a guided tour

images.altText: A park ranger displays Roundhouse building details to a group of students
images.title: Education Programs
images.caption: Ranger-led educational programs are available at Steamtown NHS.  Here, a park ranger works with a group of students to explain Roundhouse architecture

images.altText: Park rangers assist children at a new temporary exhibit within the History Museum
images.title: Architectural Dig Exhibit
images.caption: The site features tempoary, changing exhibits in its History and Technology museums

images.title: Train rides
images.caption: Seasonal train rides, both inside the park boundaries and to further destinations, are part of the Steamtown experience, whether with vintage diesel or steam locomotives

directionsInfo: The Thaddeus Kosciuszko National Memorial is located at 3rd and Pine Streets in Philadelphia. It is within walking distance of Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell Center. Parking is quite limited near the site.  The site is easily accessible by public transportation.  See the park's web page for directions.
weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
name: Thaddeus Kosciuszko
description: Visit the house where wounded Polish freedom fighter Thaddeus Kosciuszko lived and hear how this brilliant military engineer designed successful fortifications during the American Revolution. See the room where he received notable visitors such as Chief Little Turtle and Thomas Jefferson.

images.altText: Color photo showing a three story brick rowhouse on a corner lot.
images.title: Kosciuszko House, exterior
images.caption: The Thaddeus Kosciuszko house is a national memorial to an international champion of human rights.

images.altText: Color photo of the bedroom with a orange upholstered sofa and a bed in the small room.
images.title: Bedroom
images.caption: Learn about Kosciuszko's role in the American Revolution as well as his defeat against the Russians in his native Poland.

images.altText: Black and white photo, circa 1960, showing a three story brick rowhouse situated on a corner lot.
images.title: Kosciuszko House, ca. 1960
images.caption: The home where Thaddeus Kosciuszko once lived fell into disrepair.  The site became a National Memorial in 1972.

directionsInfo:
The park is conveniently located off of U.S. Route 422. The main entrance to the park is at the intersection of State Route 23 and North Gulph Road.

From the Pennsylvania Turnpike, take Exit 326.
From Interstate I-76, take Route 422 West to Route 23 West/Valley Forge.
From State Route 252, take State Route 23 East.
weatherInfo: Winters at Valley Forge are cold and damp with a cool spring and fall and a hot and humid summer. Sturdy hiking shoes are recommended for outdoor recreation during the snowy winter season.
name: Valley Forge
description: Valley Forge was the site of the 1777-78 winter encampment of the Continental Army. The 3,500-acres of monuments, meadows, and woodlands commemorate the sacrifices and perseverance of the Revolutionary War generation. The park honors and celebrates the ability of citizens to pull together and overcome adversity during extraordinary times.

images.altText: Light fog across a grassy meadow with trees on either side
images.title: Fog in a meadow
images.caption: Fog in one of the many grassy meadow in Valley Forge National Historical park

images.altText: Three log cabin style huts in a deep snowy field.

images.caption: Three replica log huts in the deep snow at Valley Forge.

images.altText: A the-story stone house surrounded by grass and trees on a clear day.

images.caption: Washington's Headquarters in spring.

images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: The front entrance to the Valley Forge Visitor Center.

images.caption: The National Memorial Arch at Valley Forge.

directionsInfo:
From Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport

- Get on Expreso Román Baldorioty de Castro/PR-26 from Av. Aeropuerto
 
- Merge onto Expreso Román Baldorioty de Castro/PR-26
 
- Follow Avenida Luis Muñoz Rivera to Calle Norzagaray, Old San Juan
weatherInfo:
Puerto Rico enjoys year round tropical climate. Winters are breeze and summers are mostly hot and humid. It rains all year long with a "dry" season in April. Temperatures range from 80's in the winter to 90's in the summer.

The hurricane season starts in June and ends in November. On the longest day, June 22nd, the sun sets around 7pm. On the shortest day, December 22nd, the sun sets around 4:30pm.
name: San Juan
description: San Juan National Historic Site preserves stories of great ambition and aspirations. Countries fought for control of this tiny yet strategic island for centuries. Generations of soldiers have lived and worked within the forts. Visitors today are as inspired by these stories as they are by the beauty of the architecture and the ingenuity of design and engineering of this World Heritage Site.

directionsInfo:
From Interstate 95 North, take Exit 23 - State Offices. Take a left at the light to the bottom of Orms Street. At light, right onto Charles Street; continue straight through one light, then quick left into memorial parking lot.

From Interstate 95 South, take Exit 23 - Charles Street. Take first left onto Ashburton Street and continue straight through three lights. After the third light, take a quick left into the memorial parking lot.
weatherInfo: Summer temperatures range from 56-83F. Fall temperatures range from 30-70F. Winter temperatures range from 20-45F. Spring temperatures range from 30-70F.
name: Roger Williams
description: Roger Williams National Memorial commemorates the life of the founder of Rhode Island and a champion of the ideal of religious freedom. Williams, banished from Massachusetts for his beliefs, founded Providence in 1636. This colony served as a refuge where all could come to worship as their conscience dictated without interference from the state.

images.altText: Native garden in the foreground with the visitor center in the back.
images.title: Native American Garden and Visitor Center
images.caption: The visitor center also features a Native American Garden.

images.altText: A colonial kitchen garden with grenery growing.

images.caption: Come learn about history in our colonial kitchen garden.

images.caption: View of the park in early spring.

directionsInfo: For direction information please visit: http://www.tourosynagogue.org/visit/directions
weatherInfo: Summer temperatures range from 56-83F. Fall temperatures range from 30-70F. Winter temperatures range from 20-45F. Spring temperatures range from 30-70F.
name: Touro Synagogue
description: Touro Synagogue, a building of exquisite beauty and design, steeped in history and ideals, and one of the most historically significant Jewish buildings in America, was designated a National Historic Site in 1946.  Dedicated in 1763, it still serves an active congregation and each year greets over 30,000 visitors who come to see the magnificent interior and hear its remarkable story.

images.title: Touro Synagogue
images.caption: Sunny view of Touro Synagogue

directionsInfo: The park is located on the south side of Long Point Road .7 miles from US Highway 17, or 3 miles if coming from I-526.
weatherInfo: Winters are generally mild. Summers are hot and humid.
name: Charles Pinckney
description: Charles Pinckney was a principal author and signer of the United States Constitution. This remnant of his coastal plantation is preserved to tell the story of a "founding father," his life of public service, the lives of enslaved African Americans on South Carolina Lowcountry plantations and their influences on Charles Pinckney.

images.altText: 1828 Lowcountry cottage and grounds
images.title: Historic House and Grounds
images.caption: The historic house serves as the park's visitor center and features exhibits, film options, and a museum shop.

images.credit: New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation
images.altText: Charles Pinckney portrait
images.title: Charles Pinckney
images.caption: American founding father, Charles Pinckney, was a contributing author and signer of the U.S. Constitution.

images.altText: Live Oak
images.title: Live Oak
images.caption: Spanish Moss drape Live Oak in the early morning sun.

images.altText: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.title: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.caption: Flowering plants, like this Southern Magnolia, are remnant of historic ornamental gardens once enjoyed by former farm owners and still marveled over by modern visitors.

images.altText: Corn Crib
images.title: Corn Crib
images.caption: Snee Farm, once owned by Charles Pinckney, was a working farm for over 200 years. This corn crib, built in 1910, is one of the few remaining structures of a bygone era.

images.altText: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.title: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.caption: A .25 mile loop trail is a popular activity for visitors to enjoy the grounds and see points of cultural and natural interest along the way.

directionsInfo:
From Interstate 77, Exit 5
At Exit 5 turn onto SC Hwy 48 East/Bluff Road. Following the brown and white "Congaree National Park" directional signs, travel approximately 8 miles on and then take a slight right onto Old Bluff Road. Follow Old Bluff Road for 4.5 miles to the park entrance sign, which will be on the right. Proceed one mile to the Harry Hampton Visitor Center. Parking lots will be on the right.
weatherInfo: Check the forecast before getting on the road. Conditions can change rapidly within the park. Flooding can happen with little or no warning, so make sure to check water levels for Cedar Creek and the Congaree River.
name: Congaree
description: Astonishing biodiversity exists in Congaree National Park, the largest intact expanse of old growth bottomland hardwood forest remaining in the southeastern United States. Waters from the Congaree and Wateree Rivers sweep through the floodplain, carrying nutrients and sediments that nourish and rejuvenate this ecosystem and support the growth of national and state champion trees.

images.altText: View of the Congaree River during the Fall
images.title: Congaree River
images.caption: View of the Congaree River during the Fall

directionsInfo:

From I-85 S, take exit 92, turn right toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx.10 miles on the left.

From I-26 E, take exit 5, turn left toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx. 20 miles on the right.

From I-26 W, take I-85 North, take exit 83. Turn left on Hwy 110, approx. 8 miles. Turn right on Hwy 11. The park is about a half mile on the right.

Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.

name: Cowpens
description:
“…our success was complete…”
  -- Daniel Morgan to Nathanael Greene, January 19, 1781

A pasturing area at the time of the battle, this Revolutionary War site commemorates the place where Daniel Morgan and his army turned the flanks of Banastre Tarleton's British army. This classic military tactic, known as a double envelopment, was one of only a few in history.

images.altText: The sun is coming up on the battlefield in the direction that the Americans would have been facing.

directionsInfo:
Directions to the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center, 340 Concord Street, Charleston, SC

Take I-26 E to Charleston. Take exit 221B on the left for Meeting Street. Turn right onto Meeting Street. Turn left onto Calhoun Street. Proceed across East Bay Street and Washington Street. The Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center is straight ahead. Parking is on the left in the garage (7' clearance).
weatherInfo: Mild winters. Hot and humid during the summer.
name: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie
description:
Charleston, victorious over the Royal Navy in 1776 and scene of the largest patriot defeat in 1780, played a key role in the American Revolution. 

Charleston's appetite for revolution continued in the 1800s as the city blazed a path to secession to safeguard slavery. The Confederacy fired on the US garrison of Fort Sumter on April 12, 1861, opening the Civil War, which redefined American freedom.

images.altText: Fort Moultrie's main entrance with a United States Flag flying overhead
images.title: Fort Moultrie
images.caption: Fort Moultrie is a unit of Fort Sumter National Monument and is located on Sullivan's Island, SC. Visitors can learn about the entire history of static seacoast defenses in the United States, 1776-1947.

images.altText: Fort Sumter seen from the air, with a ferry boat at the dock.
images.title: Fort Sumter
images.caption: Fort Sumter is located on an island in Charleston Harbor and is only accessible by boat.

images.altText: A three-story brick structure on the Cooper River with the Town of Mount Pleasant in the background.
images.title: Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center
images.caption: The Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center is the primary departure point for the ferries to Fort Sumter.

images.altText: A tattered 33-star United States flag
images.title: Fort Sumter Garrison Flag
images.caption: Fort Sumter's 33-star garrison flag was flown over Fort Sumter during the Union's April 14, 1861 surrender ceremony, and again on April 14, 1865 to mark the end of the Civil War in Charleston. On display at the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center.

images.altText: Remnants of the 33-star Fort Sumter Storm Flag
images.title: Fort Sumter Storm Flag
images.caption: The 33-star "storm" flag was flown over Fort Sumter during the April 12-13, 1861 bombardment of Fort Sumter. The larger garrison flag had been lowered to repair a tear on April 11. On display at the Fort Sumter Museum.

fullName: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park

directionsInfo:
Kings Mountain National Military Park is located on South Carolina Highway 216.
From Greenville, SC travel on I-85 North to NC Exit #2. Turn right onto Hwy 216.
From Charlotte, NC travel on I- 85 South to NC Exit #2. Turn left onto Hwy 216.
weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
name: Kings Mountain
description: Thomas Jefferson called it "The turn of the tide of success." The battle of Kings Mountain, fought October 7th, 1780, was an important American victory during the Revolutionary War. The battle was the first major patriot victory to occur after the British invasion of Charleston, SC in May 1780. The park preserves the site of this important battle.

weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
name: Ninety Six
description: Settlers struggled against the harsh backcountry to survive. Cherokee Indians hunted and fought to keep their land. Two towns and a trading post were formed then abandoned to the elements. And two Revolutionary War battles claimed over 100 lives. Come discover the 18th century history of South Carolina.

name: Reconstruction Era
description: The Reconstruction era,1861-1898 the historic period in which the United States grappled with the question of how to integrate millions of newly freed African Americans into social, political,economic,  and labor systems, was a time of significant transformation. The people, places, and events in Beaufort County, South Carolina, reflect on the most important issues of this tumultuous time period.

directionsInfo: The heritage area is located throughout the state of South Carolina.
weatherInfo: The weather varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov for forecast information.
name: South Carolina
description: Designated in 1996, the South Carolina National Heritage Corridor is committed to promoting and preserving the cultural, natural and historic resources of the state. The corridor stretches across 17 counties from the Appalachian Mountains to the Atlantic Ocean.

images.altText: Ranger guided walks provide visitors an in-depth look at the largest remaining section of old-growth
images.title: A Walk in the Park
images.caption: Ranger guided walks provide visitors an in-depth look at the largest remaining section of old-growth bottomland forest in the United States

directionsInfo:
Badlands National Park is located 75 miles east of Rapid City, South Dakota.

Physical Addresses for GPS*

Park Headquarters: 25216 Ben Reifel Road, Interior, SD 57750.
Northeast Entrance (I-90, Exit 131): 21020 SD Hwy 240, Interior, SD 57750.
Pinnacles Entrance (I-90, Exit 110): 24240 Hwy 240, Wall, SD 57790.
Interior Entrance: 20640 SD Hwy 377, Interior, SD 57750.
weatherInfo: The Badlands weather is variable and unpredictable with temperature extremes ranging from 116° F to -40° F. Summers are hot and dry with occasional violent thunderstorms. Hailstorms and occasional tornadoes can descend on the Badlands with sudden fury. Winters are typically cold with 12 to 24 inches of total snowfall.
name: Badlands
description: The rugged beauty of the Badlands draws visitors from around the world. These striking geologic deposits contain one of the world’s richest fossil beds. Ancient mammals such as the rhino, horse, and saber-toothed cat once roamed here. The park’s 244,000 acres protect an expanse of mixed-grass prairie where bison, bighorn sheep, prairie dogs, and black-footed ferrets live today.

directionsInfo:
By car:  Jewel Cave National Monument is located 13 miles west of Custer, South Dakota and 24 miles east of Newcastle, Wyoming on U.S. Highway 16. The Monument is about 54 miles from Rapid City, South Dakota via U.S. Highway 16 / 385.

By plane:  The nearest major airport, Rapid City Regional Airport, is 63 miles away.
weatherInfo:
Spring:  Rain or snow is common.  Temperatures vary.

Summer:  Rain is common in June.  Sunny and dry in July and August.  Temperatures range from 70 to 95 degrees Fahrenheit.

Fall:  Mild temperatures and occasional rain or snow showers.

Winter:  Cold temperatures are common with occasional snow.
name: Jewel Cave
description: Immerse yourself within the third longest cave in the world. With over 202 miles of mapped and surveyed passages, this underground wilderness appeals to human curiosity. Its splendor is revealed through fragile formations and glimpses of brilliant color. Its maze of passages lure explorers, and its scientific wealth remains a mystery. This resource is truly a jewel in the National Park Service.

images.altText: A cave explorer rests by large stalagmites that are covered in cave popcorn.
images.title: Pinnacles Expressway
images.caption: The logomites or popcorn stalagmites this explorer sits near are hollow and sometimes grow taller than a person.

images.altText: A cave explorer looks at a clear blue lake in Jewel Cave
images.title: Hourglass Lake
images.caption: Hourglass Lake was discovered in October 2015 and is the first sizable body of water to be found in Jewel Cave.

images.altText: A park ranger walks on the Scenic Tour Route in Jewel Cave
images.title: Inner Sanctum
images.caption: The Inner Sanctum is a large passage on the Jewel Cave Scenic Tour near the Torture Room

images.altText: A tour participant squeezes through a very small passage on the Wild Caving Tour
images.title: The Brain Drain
images.caption: The Brain Drain is approximately 8 inches high by 24 inches wide and is the tightest passage on the Wild Caving Tour.

images.altText: A park ranger stands in a medium-sized room in Jewel Cave
images.title: The Heavenly Room
images.caption: The Heavenly Room lies at the end of the Jewel Cave Historic Lantern Tour.

images.altText: These calcite crystals, called Nailhead Spar, are the jewels of Jewel Cave
images.title: Nailhead Spar
images.caption: These calcite crystals, called Nailhead Spar, are the jewels of Jewel Cave

directionsInfo: Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is located at three sites along a fifteen mile stretch of Interstate 90 in western South Dakota. The Visitor Center is located immediately north of I-90, exit 131. The two historic sites which make up the park are four miles (Launch Control Facility Delta-01) and 15 miles (Launch Facility Delta-09) from the Visitor Center. No public transportation systems serve the park.
weatherInfo:
Rapid weather changes are common in the western South Dakota area where Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is located. Variations from season to season and from year to year are great. Characteristics of the climate are hot dry summers and bitterly cold winters.

Wind is a constant on the Great Plains, winds in excess of 50 mph not uncommon. During the winter season, winds typically blow from the north-northwest and have been known to cause wind chills in excess of -40 degrees.
name: Minuteman Missile
description: During the Cold War, a vast arsenal of nuclear missiles were placed in the Great Plains. Hidden in plain sight, for thirty years 1,000 missiles were kept on constant alert; hundreds remain today. The Minuteman Missile remains an iconic weapon in the American nuclear arsenal. It holds the power to destroy civilization, but is meant as a nuclear deterrent to maintain peace and prevent war.

images.altText: Glass structure over the silo allows visitors to look down at the missile
images.title: Delta-09 enclosure
images.caption: The glass enclosure allows visitors to view a Minuteman II missile in the silo.

images.altText: A cylindrical missile inside an underground silo.
images.title: Minuteman II Missile
images.caption: A Minuteman II nuclear missile remains on alert, representing the 1,000 missiles which kept a constant vigil during the Cold War.

images.altText: A brown building behind a tall fence with warning signs
images.title: Delta-01
images.caption: For thirty years, US Air Force staff monitored a flight of ten nuclear missiles at the Delta-01 Launch Control Facility.

images.altText: Two people are visible at the missile silo through a chain link fence
images.title: A winter visit to Delta-09
images.caption: A visit to the Delta-09 missile silo allows the opportunity to consider the role of these missile in America's defense during the Cold War.

images.altText: A large metal blast door with art of a Domino with a nuclear missile
images.title: "Thirty Minutes or Less"
images.caption: Behind this blast door is the control center where two missileers kept a constant watch over ten nuclear missiles.

images.altText: A painting of a nuclear missile bursting through a Soviet Flag
images.title: Morale Art of the Cold War
images.caption: Located next to the elevator, this painting served as a reminder to missileers who they were defending the United States against.

images.altText: View down a silo at a nuclear missile
images.title: Nose-to-Nose with Armegeddon
images.caption: Visitors can peer through the glass at a Minuteman II missile in the silo at Delta-09.

images.altText: Night view of the Delta-09 site
images.title: Night view of Delta-09
images.caption: Night view of the Delta-09 site

images.altText: A modern building with a prominent glass clerestory dominates a prairie landscape at sunset
images.title: Minuteman Missile Visitor Center
images.caption: The visitor center at sunset.

images.title: Cold War "Blast Door" art at Delta-01
images.caption: Morale art reminded missile officers who the enemy was during the Cold War

images.caption: A park ranger leads a tour in the underground control center

directionsInfo: Visitors traveling by car from the East use Exit 61 off I-90 follow signs. Coming from the West use exit 57 exit at Rapid City and follow U.S. Highway 16 southwest to Keystone and then Highway 244 to Mount Rushmore. Visitors coming from the south should follow Highway 385 north to Highway 244, which is the road leading to the memorial.
weatherInfo: Weather at Mount Rushmore can be highly variable in any season.  Summer high temperatures range from 70 100 degrees Fahrenheit.  Fall high temperatures range from 45 to 80 degrees Fahrenheit.  Winter high temperatures range from 20 to 40 degrees Fahrenheit.  Spring high temperatures range from 30 to 70 degrees Fahrenheit.  July and August are the warmest months, December and January the coldest.  March and April receive the most snow, while May and June receive the most rain.
name: Mount Rushmore
description: Majestic figures of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln, surrounded by the beauty of the Black Hills of South Dakota, tell the story of the birth, growth, development and preservation of this country. From the history of the first inhabitants to the diversity of America today, Mount Rushmore brings visitors face to face with the rich heritage we all share.

images.altText: Visitors walking along the Avenue of Flags with Mount Rushmore in the background.
images.title: Mount Rushmore and the Avenue of Flags
images.caption: Visitors walking along the Avenue of Flags with Mount Rushmore in the background.

images.caption: Mount Rushmore viewed from a distance through ponderosa pine trees.

images.caption: Closeup photo of Mount Rushmore under a bright blue sky.

images.caption: Mount Rushmore illuminated under a darkening evening sky.

directionsInfo: Wind Cave National Park is located in South Dakota about 11 miles north of Hot Springs, or about 22 miles south of Custer, on US Highway 385. The park Visitor Center, where all cave tours begin, is approximately 1/2 mile west of the highway.
weatherInfo:
Spring:  Highs range from 50 - 70 F with highly variable weather. Spring is the park's wettest season.

Summer:  Warm and generally dry with highs in the 80s F. Thunderstorms are common and can produce large hail and severe lightning. 

Fall:  Generally dry with warm days and cool nights. Highs in the 50s - 60s F. Lows below freezing are common.

Winter: Highs in the upper 30s F with lows in the 10s F. Snowfall averages 30 inches annually, periodically closing park roads.
name: Wind Cave
description: Bison, elk, and other wildlife roam the rolling prairie grasslands and forested hillsides of one of America's oldest national parks. Below the remnant island of intact prairie sits Wind Cave, one of the longest and most complex caves in the world. Named for barometric winds at its entrance, this maze of passages is home to boxwork, a unique formation rarely found elsewhere.

images.altText: a bison cow and calf on the prairie
images.title: Bison cow and calf
images.caption: Several hundred bison roam the rolling prairie of Wind Cave National Park.

images.altText: rolling hills of forest and prairie landscape
images.title: Rankin Ridge view
images.caption: Wind Cave National Park from Rankin Ridge, the park's highest point.

images.altText: criss-cross-patterned calcite fins of the cave feature boxwork
images.title: Boxwork
images.caption: Delicate fins of boxwork, a rare cave feature, in Elk's Room, Wind Cave.

images.altText: a caver with pads and helmet crawling in the cave
images.title: Wind Cave explorer
images.caption: Each summer, the Wild Cave Tour offers the chance to get up close and personal with Wind Cave.

images.altText: two prairie dogs watch from their burrow
images.title: Prairie Dogs
images.caption: Prairie dog sightings are common throughout the park's prairies.

directionsInfo:
GPS
The GPS setting for Andrew Johnson NHS may be listed as 121 Monument Ave, which is the park HQ in the National Cemetery. To arrive at the Visitor Center, use 101 North College Street, Greeneville, TN.

Plane
The closest airport is the Tri-Cities Regional Airport, 43 miles NE of Greeneville. From the airport, take I-81 South to exit 36 and follow the signs to Greeneville.

Car
From I-81S take exit 36 to Rt. 172 south to Greeneville. 
From I-81N take exit 23 to Rt. 11E north to Greeneville.
weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in East Tennessee, but temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer and Winter ranges can be extreme. The President's Homestead is not climate controlled and may be closed at times during excessive highs or lows in the summer and winter.
name: Andrew Johnson
description: The Andrew Johnson National Historic Site and National Cemetery interprets the life and legacy of the 17th President. Andrew Johnson's presidency, 1865-1869, illustrates the United States Constitution at work following President Lincoln's assassination and during attempts to reunify a nation torn by civil war. His presidency shaped the future of the United States and his influences continue today.

images.altText: Andrew Johnson Homestead
images.title: Andrew Johnson Homestead
images.caption: Home of the 17th President from 1851-1875

images.altText: Andrew Johnson's Early Home
images.title: Early Home
images.caption: The Johnson family home from the 1830s - 1851

images.altText: Andrew Johnson Monument
images.title: Andrew Johnson Monument
images.caption: Gravestone of President and Mrs. Andrew Johnson

directionsInfo:
The Obed Wild & Scenic River Visitor Center is located at 208 North Maiden Street in downtown Wartburg, Tennessee.

Please use the link for more information.
weatherInfo:
The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. 

Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
name: Obed
description: The Obed Wild and Scenic River looks much the same today as it did when the first white settlers strolled its banks in the late 1700s. While meagerly populated due to poor farming soil, the river was a hospitable fishing and hunting area for trappers and pioneers. Today, the Obed stretches along the Cumberland Plateau and offers visitors a variety of outdoor recreational opportunities.

images.altText: Obed in Fall
images.title: Obed WSR in Fall
images.caption: Obed in Fall

directionsInfo:
From Interstate 24 - Take Exit 76 and turn left (eastbound) or right (westbound) onto Medical Center Parkway. Turn left onto Thompson Lane. Turn left at the park entrance at 1563 N. Thompson Lane. Follow the tour road to the visitor center.

From Interstate 40 - Take Exit 235 onto TN 840. Take Exit 55 onto US 41/TN 70 and follow the signs for Murfreesboro. Turn right onto Thompson Lane at the first traffic light. Turn right at the park entrance at 1563 N. Thompson Lane.
weatherInfo: Summer is hot and humid with highs in the 90s. Spring and fall are pleasant. Winter temperatures are variable, but temperatures may drop below freezing with occasional snow.
name: Stones River
description: The Battle of Stones River began on the last day of 1862 and was one of the bloodiest conflicts of the Civil War. The battle produced important military and political gains for the Union, and it changed forever the people who lived and fought here.

images.altText: The sun rises behind a green field with a cannon in the foreground.
images.title: Sunrise at Mendenhall's Artillery Trail
images.caption: On January 2, 1863, fifty-seven Union cannons fired from this line ending the Battle of Stones River by killing or wounding more than 1,800 Confederates in less than an hour.

images.altText: A ray of sunlight shines on the ground at Stones River National Cemetery.
images.title: Stones River National Cemetery
images.caption: More than 6,100 Union soldiers lie in Stones River National Cemetery.

images.altText: Two cannons sit in an icy field.
images.title: The Chicago Board of Trade Battery
images.caption: The men of the Chicago Board of Trade Battery got their first taste of combat at the Battle of Stones River and helped stem the Confederate tide from this position during the afternoon of December 31, 1862.

images.altText: Union soldiers fire muskets.
images.title: Union Infantry Program
images.caption: Living history programs help visitors visualize the trials of soldiers during the Battle of Stones River.

images.altText: Bicyclists ride down a road bracketed by trees.
images.title: Bike Tour
images.caption: Thousands of visitors enjoy biking and hiking through the park.

directionsInfo: The heritage corridor is located throughout the state of Tennessee.
weatherInfo: The weather varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov for forecast information.
name: Tennessee Civil War
description: Experience the powerful stories of military conflict in a divided state, the demands of the homefront and occupation, the freedom of emancipation, and the enduring legacies of Reconstruction at sites across the entire state of Tennessee.

images.altText: Sunrise in the Shiloh National Cemetery
images.title: Cemetery
images.caption: Sunrise in the Shiloh National Cemetery

fullName: Tennessee Civil War National Heritage Area

directionsInfo: Alibates Flint Quarries is located approximately 35 miles north of Amarillo, Texas. From I-40 in Amarillo, take Lakeside exit north towards Lake Meredith National Recreation Area. Exit on TX 136 north towards Borger. After about 30 miles, turn west from TX 136 onto Cas Johnson Road. Park Service signs will be visible. Proceed approximately 3 miles to "Y" intersection and bear to right. Go northwest approximately 2 miles to the Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument Visitor Center.
weatherInfo: The Texas Panhandle experiences a wide variety of weather conditions throughout the year. Winters are cold and windy, and summers are hot and dry. It is usually a good idea to bring a jacket with you if you are planning on hiking to the quarries with a ranger because the mesa gets very windy, even in the summer.
name: Alibates Flint Quarries
description: 13,000 years ago this site was already well-known by mammoth hunters as a place to get the best stone for their tools. Centuries passed but the colorful flint found right here in the Texas panhandle never lost its value and usefulness. Visit and gain a sense of how integral this site was to the survival, commerce and culture of the High Plains.

images.altText: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site
images.title: Turtle Petroglyph
images.caption: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site

images.altText: Looking down from the nearby mesa onto the gardens and Alibates Visitor Center.
images.title: Alibates Visitor Center
images.caption: The gardens and Alibates Visitor Center host activities and ranger-led programs throughout the year.

images.altText: Colorful chunks of Alibates Flint.
images.title: Alibates Flint
images.caption: Used for at least 13,000 years, Alibates Flint was the choice of many tribes for their stone tools, spearpoints and arrowheads.

images.altText: Stair steps up the Alibates Flint Quarries Trail.
images.title: Alibates Flint Quarries Trail
images.caption: Take a hike up the Quarries Trail to learn about this important stone.

images.altText: A snowy mesa, as seen from the Alibates Visitor Center.
images.title: Snowy Alibates
images.caption: Every season hold special beauty at Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument.

directionsInfo: Six miles west of the HWY 90 and 277 North intersection.
weatherInfo:
Weather in Southwest Texas can change in a matter of minutes. It is best to check the local weather report. 
Amistad National Recreation Area usually has hot summers and mild winters.
name: Amistad
description: An oasis in the desert, Amistad National Recreation Area consists of the US portion of the International Amistad Reservoir. Amistad, whose name comes from the Spanish word meaning friendship, is best known for excellent water-based recreation, camping, hiking, rock art viewing, and its rich cultural history. Amistad is also home to a wide variety of plant and animal life above and below the water.

images.altText: Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: View of Amistad National Recreation Area from The Diablo East Nature Trail
images.caption: Blue skies and blue waters are common at Amistad National Recreation Area

images.altText: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.title: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.caption: A view of the Amistad Reservoir and the HWY 90 Bridge from Governors Landing.

images.altText: A view of the peaceful shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: The shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: A peaceful view of the shores along Amistad National Recreation Area

images.altText: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: The ever chainging and beautiful sunsets in Southwest Texas are one of the many things visitor enjoy while at Amistad National Recreation Area.

images.altText: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.title: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: Limestone is visible along the shoreline of Amistad National Recreation Area.

directionsInfo:
Several highways lead to Big Bend National Park: TX 118 from Alpine to Study Butte or FM 170 from Presidio to Study Butte (then 26 miles east to park headquarters) or US 90 or US 385 to Marathon (then 70 miles south to park headquarters). 

Distances between towns and services are considerable. Be sure you have plenty of gas, oil, food, and water for your trip.
weatherInfo:
Variable
-- February through April the park abounds with pleasant and comfortable temperatures.
-- May through August is hot and can also be stormy. Temperatures regularly reach well over 100 degrees in the lower elevations and along the Rio Grande.
-- September through January temperatures are cooler; the weather can quickly turn cold at any time during these months.
name: Big Bend
description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

images.altText: An ocotillo grows in the foreground and a pastel desert with bright green shrubs in the background
images.title: Desert Vista
images.caption: Desert Vista from Dorgan House

images.altText: Adult javelina, or collared peccary, and two young javelinas forage in a rocky area.
images.title: Javelina and Young
images.caption: A female javelina, or collared peccary, and her young, often called reds because of the color of their hair when very young.

images.altText: View of a river snaking through a desert landscape.
images.title: River Vista
images.caption: View of the Rio Grande River in Big Bend National Park.

images.altText: Two lane road disappears into the horizon in a desert landscape.
images.title: Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive
images.caption: Ross Maxwell Scenic Drive in Big Bend National Park

images.altText: Bright red claret cup cactus flowers bloom with a mountainous desert landscape in the background.
images.title: South Rim Vista
images.caption: South Rim Vista and Claret Cup Cactus

directionsInfo: Big Thicket National Preserve consists of 15 units spread across 7 counties. The visitor center is located approximately 30 miles north of Beaumont, and 8 miles north of Kountze, along US 69/287.
weatherInfo: Big Thicket National Preserve is generally very hot and humid during the spring and summer. Winters are mild. Snow and subfreezing temperatures are uncommon.
name: Big Thicket
description: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats converge in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meander through nine different ecosystems, from longleaf pine forests to cypress-lined bayous. It is a place of discovery, a place to wander and explore, a place to marvel at the richness of nature.

images.altText: Knobby cypress knees resembling cave stalagmites protrude up from a pool of water.
images.title: Cypress Knees
images.caption: Knobby knees, extensions of the root system, are a distinctive feature of the bald cypress trees.

images.altText: A dense stand of funnel-shaped carnivorous pitcher plants awaiting their next insect meal.
images.title: Pitcher Plants
images.caption: Look for carnivorous pitcher plants in bogs along the Sundew Trail and Pitcher Plant Trail.

images.altText: Three people paddling kayaks along a waterway densely lined with bald cypress trees.
images.title: Kayakers in Cooks Lake
images.caption: Kayaking is a popular way to explore the many waterways in the Big Thicket. Here, kayakers paddle along the Cooks Lake Paddling Trail near Beaumont.

images.altText: The yellow flowers of pitcher plants bloom beneath longleaf pine trees.
images.title: Pitcher Plants and Pines
images.caption: Early April is the best time to see wildflowers blooming in the Big Thicket..

images.altText: A woman and her dog on a metal bridge spanning a creek lined with bald cypress trees.
images.title: Hiker on bridge over Village Creek
images.caption: The view from the bridge over Village Creek is a highlight for hikers on the Kirby Nature Trail.

directionsInfo: From the west take exit 21 off of I-10 toward Piedras Street. Turn right onto Piedras and follow it to Paisano Drive. Turn left onto Paisano and then turn right onto San Marcial Street. From the north take exit 20A off of US-54 for US-62 toward Paisano Drive. Turn right onto Paisano and follow it until you reach San Marcial Street. From the east take exit 22B on I-10 toward US-54. Stay left until two lanes merge, move into the right lane toward Paisano Drive. Turn right at the light and merge onto Paisano.
weatherInfo: Chamizal National Memorial is open year-round, but periodic winter weather conditions may cause closure. Please check for alerts on the park website: www.nps.gov/cham. Thunderstorms typically occur during summer and early fall. There may be no shelter to avoid lightning, so please prepare by looking at weather forecasts and paying attention to developing weather conditions.
name: Chamizal
description: Chamizal is more than just an urban park to recreate or enjoy a quiet afternoon. These grounds are a reminder of the harmonious settlement of a 100-year border dispute between the United States and Mexico. We celebrate the cultures of the borderlands to promote the same mutual respect that helped to diplomatically resolve an international disagreement.

images.altText: a bench next to a tree with U.S. and Mexican flags flying against a mountain background
images.title: Mountain View
images.caption: Chamizal National Memorial stands as a reminder of the effectiveness of diplomacy and the power of friendship.

images.altText: a group of children with hand raised in front of park rangers and ground squirrel mascot
images.title: Junior Rangers
images.caption: Junior Rangers learn about Chamizal National Memorial.

images.altText: walking trails cross a field of green grass with mountain in the background
images.title: Trails
images.caption: Enjoy the green space of Chamizal in the heart of El Paso.

images.altText: Women in swirling skirts and men with sombreros and colorful ponchos dance onstage
images.title: Theater Performances
images.caption: Take in a theater performance such as this ballet folklorico.

images.altText: paintings hang from art gallery walls
images.title: Franklin G. Smith Gallery
images.caption: Browse art from the borderland in the Franklin G. Smith Gallery.

directionsInfo: We are approximately 2.5 hours south of Midland/Odessa starting on I-20 to HWY 17, 3.5 hours North West of Del Rio starting on HWY 90 to HWY 118, 4 hours east of El Paso starting on I-10 to HWY 118 and 7 hours west of San Antonio starting on I-10 to HWY 17.
weatherInfo: Summer Temperatures average a High of 95 and low of 65. Winter Temperatures average a High of 60 and a low of 20.  Wind is very common and heavy rainfall is very sporadic.
name: Fort Davis
description: Fort Davis is one of the best surviving examples of an Indian Wars' frontier military post in the Southwest. From 1854 to 1891, Fort Davis was strategically located to protect emigrants, mail coaches, and freight wagons on the Trans-Pecos portion of the San Antonio-El Paso Road and on the Chihuahua Trail.

images.altText: Two ladies working in the kitchen
images.title: Kitchen
images.caption: Special events bring back the smells of an 1800s Kitchen

images.altText: Garrison Flag flying over the post.
images.title: Parade Ground
images.caption: Garrison flag flying over the post within the box canyon Fort Davis is located.

images.altText: Artillery Crew stands at the ready
images.title: Artillery Crew
images.caption: The Artillery Crew stand ready for orders to post at their positions and fire the U.S. 3-inch Ordnance Rifle.

images.altText: Soldier mounted on his horse
images.title: Cavalry
images.caption: The U.S. Cavalry was utilized at Fort Davis for most of its existence. Here a soldier shows off the uniform and equipment of the 1800s.

images.altText: Building and trees at Fort Davis during the fall with yellow leaves.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: This sky island habitat is known for its dramatic season changes. Fall brings the end of our rainy season allowing the bright yellow Cottonwoods to shine. In spring /summer waving grasses and wildflowers show off their vivid colors once again.

directionsInfo:
Guadalupe Mountains National Park is located on the north side of US Hwy 62/180. 
If you are traveling east from El Paso, TX, we are 110 miles East of the city. Follow US Hwy 62/180 North to the Pine Springs Visitor Center. 
If you are traveling from Van Horn, TX, you will travel north on US 54 and make a left hand turn at the junction of US 62/180 to arrive at the park.
If you are traveling west from Carlsbad, NM, you will travel on US Hwy 62/180 South and cross into Texas. Follow signs to the park.
weatherInfo: Weather in the Guadalupe Mountains can change in an instant. In the Spring and Summer, average temperatures vary with highs between 70F-80F+ with evening lows in the 40F-60F range. The Fall and Winter bring milder temperatures with highs in between 50F-60F with evening lows in the 30F-50F range.
name: Guadalupe Mountains
description: Guadalupe Mountains National Park protects the world's most extensive Permian fossil reef, the four highest peaks in Texas, an environmentally diverse collection of flora and fauna, and the stories of lives shaped through conflict, cooperation and survival. Come experience mountains and canyons, desert and dunes, night skies and spectacular vistas within a place unlike any other within the NPS.

images.altText: El Capitan with blooming claret cup cacti
images.title: El Capitan
images.caption: Blossoming claret cup cacti add a splash of color to the Chihuahuan desert.

images.altText: Fall colors in Devil's Hall
images.title: Devil's Hall Fall Colors
images.caption: Changing maple trees line the Devil's Hall trail during the fall months.

images.altText: Pratt Cabin in McKittrick Canyon
images.title: Pratt Cabin
images.caption: Pratt Cabin is nestled in McKittrick Canyon with abundant trees and

images.altText: the slat flats become flooded during monsoon months after large rain events.
images.title: Flooded Salt Flats
images.caption: After the monsoon storms, the salt flats will often become flooded creating a seasonal lake.

images.altText: wildflowers blossom along The Bowl trail
images.title: The Bowl wildflowers
images.caption: During the spring months, wildflowers are a common sight along The Bowl trail.

directionsInfo:
There are several different ways to get to Lake Meredith. If you are coming from Amarillo, exit Loop 335 North, then exit Hwy 136 North to Fritch. Headquarters is located at 419 E. Broadway in Fritch. If coming from the North you can take 1913 from the Dumas Highway or 1913 from US 287.

The airport in Amarillo is approximately 35 miles south of Lake Meredith if traveling by air. Rental cars are available.
weatherInfo: The Texas Panhandle experiences a wide variety of weather conditions throughout the year. Winters are cold and windy, and summers are hot and dry. It is usually a good idea to bring a jacket with you because the region gets very windy, even in the summer.
name: Lake Meredith
description: Within the dry and windswept high plains of the Texas Panhandle lies a hidden oasis, a welcoming haven where wildlife and humans find respite from the dry grasslands above. Through this plain, the Canadian River has cut dramatic 200-foot canyons, or breaks, where humans have eked out a living for over 13,000 years. Lake Meredith now occupies these hidden coves where early humans once roamed.

images.altText: A boat speeds across Lake Meredith.
images.title: Lake Meredith
images.caption: A boat speeds across Lake Meredith.

images.altText: Wildflowers at Lake Meredith
images.title: Lake Meredith in Bloom
images.caption: Wildflowers bloom along the shores of Lake Meredith.

images.altText: A bench on the Harbor Bay Trail, overlooking Lake Meredith.
images.title: Harbar Bay Trail
images.caption: The Harbor Bay Trail has benches which offer hikers a respite with a view.

images.altText: Picnic shelter at a campsite overlooking Lake Meredith.
images.title: Camp with a View!
images.caption: Fritch Fortress and Sanford-Yake Camprgrounds offer campers beautiful views of the lake.

images.altText: Sanford Dam and Lake Meredith
images.title: Sanford Dam at Lake Meredith
images.caption: Lake Meredith was formed in the Canadian River Valley when the Sanford Dam was constructed.

directionsInfo:
By car to National Park Headquarters and the Visitor Center in Johnson City:

From Austin, take Highway 290 west.
From San Antonio, take Highway 281 north.
From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 east. 

By car to the LBJ Ranch and LBJ State Park and Historic Site:

From Johnson City, take Highway 290 fourteen miles west to the LBJ State Park.
From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 sixteen miles east to the LBJ State Park.

The nearest major airports are in Austin and San Antonio.
weatherInfo:
Overall, the park enjoys a sunny, mild climate during three seasons of the year.

Spring: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C). Rain is common in April and May.

Summer: Temperatures range from 70 F to 95 F (21 C/35 C). Temperatures can exceed 100 F (38 C) in July and August. Lightweight clothing and sunscreen are advisable. Be prepared with plenty of water.

Fall: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C).

Winter: Temperatures range from 35 F to 65 F (2 C/18 C) . Snow and ice are rare.
name: Lyndon B Johnson
description:
---Lyndon Baines Johnson

Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park tells the story of our 36th President beginning with his ancestors until his final resting place on his beloved LBJ Ranch. This entire "circle of life" gives the visitor a unique perspective into one of America's most noteworthy citizens by providing the most complete picture of any American president.

images.altText: View of Texas White House from front lawn.
images.title: Texas White House
images.caption: Because President Johnson spent one-fourth of his term a president in Texas, the press referred to this home as the "Texas White House"

images.altText: View of Boyhood Home from the front street.
images.title: Boyhood Home
images.caption: Lyndon Johnson was 5 years old when he moved to this home with his family. His childhood in a small rural town had great impact on his futur.

images.altText: A park visitor meets one of the ranch's Hereford cattle while driving the tour route.
images.title: Touring the LBJ Ranch
images.caption: A park visitor meets one of the ranch's Hereford cattle while driving the tour route.

images.altText: Luci Johnson (center in gray jersey) leads a bike tour
images.title: Cyclists in the LBJ 100
images.caption: Many special events, such as the LBJ 100 bike ride, take place during the year.

images.altText: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson
images.title: Gravestones for Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson
images.caption: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson

images.credit: LBJ Library Photo by Frank Wolfe
images.altText: President and Mrs. Johnson stand outside the Texas White House with dog Yuki.
images.title: Portrait of the Johnsons
images.caption: For their 1972 Christmas card, the Johnsons stand outside the Texas White House with their dog Yuki.

images.altText: View of the Pedernales River
images.title: Pedernales River
images.caption: The Pedernales River forms flows past the LBJ Ranch

images.altText: An exterior view of a Lockheed Jetstar used by President Johnson.
images.title: Lockheed Jetstar
images.caption: One of the five Lockheed Jetstars in service during the Johnson Presidency is now on display at the LBJ Ranch..

fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park

directionsInfo: The National Seashore is located on North Padre Island, southeast of the city of Corpus Christi, Texas. Visitors to the area should head east through Corpus Christi on Highway 358. After crossing the JFK Causeway onto Padre Island, Highway 358 changes to Park Road 22. Continue about 10 miles south on Park Road 22 to reach the park entrance.
weatherInfo: Padre Island has long, hot summers and short, mild winters. Summers are very humid. Winter can bring strong cold fronts and gale force winds. Most rain falls near the beginning and end of hurricane season (June-October). Average seasonal temperatures (Fahrenheit) are: Spring - high 70s-80s, low 50s-60s; Summer - high mid-90s, low 70s; Fall - high 70s-80s, low 50s-60s; Winter - high 50s-70s, low 30s-40s. Year-round, average wind speed ranges from 5-25 miles per hour. Relative humidity seldom drops below 70%.
name: Padre Island
description: Padre Island National Seashore separates the Gulf of Mexico from the Laguna Madre, one of a few hypersaline lagoons in the world.  The park protects 70 miles of coastline, dunes, prairies, and wind tidal flats teeming with life.  It is a safe nesting ground for the Kemp’s ridley sea turtle and a haven for over 380 bird species.  It also has a rich history, including the Spanish shipwrecks of 1554.

images.altText: A small boy plays at the water's edge on Padre Island
images.title: A boy at play on scenic Padre Island
images.caption: Over 60 miles of beach offers beautiful scenery and fun for the whole family.

images.altText: Tiny Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings crawl on the beach of Padre Island.
images.title: Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings
images.caption: Thousands of visitors come to the park each summer to watch newborn Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings get released into the Gulf of Mexico.

images.altText: A black skimmer flies by, slicing the surf with its lower bill to catch food.
images.title: Black Skimmer
images.caption: Over 380 bird species have been found at the park, making it a top destination for birders from around the world.

images.altText: A tent is set up close to the beach on Padre Island.
images.title: Camping on Padre Island
images.caption: Camping in a tent or RV is one of the most popular activities on Padre Island.

images.altText: A beautiful and colorful sunrise over the Gulf of Mexico on Padre Island.
images.title: Sunrise over the Gulf of Mexico on Padre Island
images.caption: Breathtaking sunrises, remote beaches, and dark night skies make Padre Island a top vacation destination.

images.altText: A woman drives a boat up to the ramp at Bird Island Basin.
images.title: Bird Island Basin Boat Ramp
images.caption: Bird Island Basin offers access to the Laguna Madre for boating, fishing, windsurfing, kayaking, and camping.

images.altText: A man in waders fishes in the surf along the Mansfield Channel jetties.
images.title: Fishing at Mansfield Channel
images.caption: Surf fishing is a great way to enjoy the outdoors at Padre Island National Seashore.

images.altText: Large seashells in front of the turquoise blue waters of the Gulf of mexico
images.title: Big Shell Beach at Padre Island National Seashore
images.caption: Padre Island National Seashore has over 70 miles of undeveloped coastline with ample beachcombing opportunities.

directionsInfo: The park is located on Brownsville's north side, near the city of Los Fresnos. It is just north of the intersection of FM 1847 (Paredes Line Rd.) and FM 511/FM 550.
weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid. Tropical weather systems generally affect the area from August to October. Winters are usually mild but cold fronts can drop temperatures by up to 30 degrees in about an hour.
name: Palo Alto Battlefield
description: On May 8, 1846, United States and Mexican troops clashed on the prairie of Palo Alto. The battle was the first in a two-year long war that changed the map of North America. Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park preserves the site of this notable battle and provides an understanding of the causes, events, and consequences of the U.S.-Mexican War.

images.altText: Shaded structure overlooking the battlefield
images.title: Battlefield overlook
images.caption: The overlook gives you a great view of the battlefield

images.altText: Coiled rattlesnake ready to strike.
images.title: Rattlesnake
images.caption: Rattlesnakes will let you know when you get too close.

images.altText: Sun rising over the battlefield
images.title: Sunrise
images.caption: Get here when the park opens and enjoy views like this.

images.altText: Sunset over the battlefield
images.title: Sunset over the battlefield

directionsInfo: Hwy 118 south from Alpine; Hwy 385 south from Marathon; FM 170 from Presidio through Study Butte.
weatherInfo:
Variable
-- February-April: High temperatures range from mid-70sF (23C) to low-90sF (32C) with lows from the mid-30sF (2C) to mid-50sF (12C). Cold fronts can bring freezing weather with rain or snow.
-- May-August: Temperatures are hot and the weather can be stormy. Temperatures over 100F (more than 38C) degrees.
-- September-January:Temperatures are cooler. The weather can turn cold any time during these months.
name: Rio Grande
description: It is an irresistible playground where unruly rapids check your skills as a canyon wren’s definitive call cascades down ancient limestone cliffs. Below the chasm, the canyon’s raw beauty dances across mirrored water. While the primal nature of the river stirs hunger for spirited adventure, the river is also an undulant ribbon of wetland corridor and, against all odds, the lifeblood of the desert.

images.altText: River in the foreground disappears into a high walled canyon in the background.
images.title: Santa Elena Canyon
images.caption: Santa Elena Canyon on the Rio Grande River.

images.altText: A desert river with a rugged landscape of cliff faces and hills in the background.
images.title: Rio Grande
images.caption: The Rio Grande seen from the Santa Elena River Access.

images.altText: A river disappears into a high-walled canyon.
images.title: Santa Elena Canyon
images.caption: The Rio Grande runs through the high-walled Santa Elena Canyon.

images.altText: A desert river with a tree lined bank in the background.

images.caption: Rio Grande Vista

images.caption: Rio Grande Vista and Crown Mountain

images.altText: People in two canoes paddle on a river threading through high canyon walls.
